HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Latin America Tackling Possible Computer Woes

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Approximately 37,000 clients of Banco Itau S.A., one of Brazil's largest banks, got a glimpse last month of the problems Latin Americans might encounter from the Year 2000 computer problem when they received a letter saying certain fees would be charged to their accounts as of Jan. 4, 1900.
The bank, which attributed the mix-up to human error and not to its technology, quickly remedied the problem with follow-up correspondence correcting the date to 2000. But doubts remained, since Itau was said to be among the region's best prepared companies for the Year 2000 problem, having invested more than $30 million to prepare its computers. 
 With a week to go, no one is quite sure what the fallout will be from Latin America's mixed approach to dealing with the Year 2000 problem. According to analysts dealing with the issue, some of the region's poorest countries, like Paraguay, are drastically ill-prepared, while other nations, like Chile and Mexico, planned ahead and budgeted funds to sufficiently adapt their government computers.
Still, there appears to be a consensus emerging among the people who have been rushing to prepare the region for the changeover to the year 2000: The parts of Latin America most at risk are also the most technologically advanced, while the most underdeveloped regions, while they will almost surely also be affected by the problem, are not likely to suffer as much as the region's pockets of relative wealth.
"It's like bank-robber logic," said Dale Vecchio, a research director at the Gartner Group, a consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn., that has examined preparations for the bug around the world. "Bank robbers search out the bank with the most money, just like Y2K will affect the societies with the most technology."
Perhaps nowhere in Latin America is this relation played out with greater tension than in Brazil, the region's largest country with 165 million people. While many parts of Brazil are relatively underdeveloped and not that dependent on technology, cities like Sao Paulo are highly wired. Ground zero for Brazil's race to prepare for the problem could be said to be along the banks of the Pinheiros, a murky river flowing through this city.
Flanking the Pinheiros are several dozen skyscrapers that developers built during the last decade as Brazil opened its economy in an embrace of foreign technology and investment. These structures, wired with state-of-the-art fiber optics, guarded by a legion of armed security personnel and topped with helicopter landing pads, have spent the last year being prepared to deal with the Year 2000 computer problem.
For Sylvio Roth, the technician in charge adapting computer systems for Jones Lang LaSalle, a London-based skyscraper-management firm that manages some of Sao Paulo's most exclusive commercial buildings, this means his schedule has been put into overdrive. Mr. Roth heads a team stocking up on electricity generators, diesel fuel and water supplies. Concerned with the possibility of a surge in crime after the new year, provisions are also being made for additional armed security forces.
"We've screened our buildings for possible problems, but now our priority is contingency," said Mr. Roth. "We're going to make sure our clients can do business for five to 10 business days after the first of the year, but this depends on things outside our control, like the capacity of electricity utilities and telephone companies."
For the most part, large companies in Brazil are generally prepared for the Year 2000 changeover, thanks in part to the fact that many state firms, including many utilities, were privatized in sales to foreign concerns during the last few years. And the federal government has said its computers will prove resistant to the problem.
Still, while it is generally acknowledged that most large companies could fare decently, many small firms which have not recognized the magnitude of the problem could suffer and thus put a drag on some parts of the economy, analysts said. This mixed approach has created worries in large countries like Brazil, but other nations, like nearby Paraguay, offer a striking contrast in their Year 2000 preparations.
The poorest and most politically and economically unstable member of Mercosur, the customs union also including Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay, Paraguay is considered one of the least-prepared countries for the Year 2000 problem. Things were made worse recently when Walter Schafer, the country's coordinator to deal with the issue, was dismissed after foreign news reports called attention to Paraguay's lack of preparation.
"The people in power got worried about Paraguay's image abroad," said Mr. Schafer in a telephone interview from Asuncion , Paraguay's capital. "We Paraguayans have so much else to worry about that it's no wonder our effort to deal with the bug was too little, too late, and now almost nonexistent."
Indeed, for the time being, the small country of 5 million seems to have more pressing problems to deal with. In late November, rumors swept Asuncion that some members of the armed forces were planning a coup. Authorities loyal to President Luis Gonzalez Macchi arrested 14 army members suspected of disloyalty.
According to Carlos Guedes, the official at the Inter-American Development Bank in Washington responsible for coordinating the institution's efforts to help Latin American countries deal with the computer problem, Paraguay's situation is similar to that of other small countries in the region, like Guatemala and Bolivia. In an attempt to help countries like these prepare for the problem, the bank this year opened a $200 million emergency credit line to finance computer upgrades.
"Some of these countries have been hurt by natural phenomena like hurricanes and a decline in the prices of their main commodity exports that make dealing with Y2K more difficult," Mr. Guedes said.
Ecuador is one country in the region that has suffered damage from natural disasters and, until recently, a weak market for oil, one of its main exports. Yet in a sign that the situation in places like Ecuador might actually be better off than some critics expect, the country, like most other Latin American nations, has organized a task force to deal with the Year 2000 problem.
Jacqueline Herrera, the official in charge of the task forces, said she is confident that crucial parts of the economy, such as electrical generation, telecommunications, water treatment and air travel, are prepared for the potential effects.
"We're better prepared than a lot of people might expect," said Ms. Herrera. "And we're in constant contact with other task forces in Latin America, so we know that our efforts are in line with others."
The saving grace of countries like Ecuador and Paraguay may lie in their relatively unsophisticated computer networks when compared with those in rich industrialized nations, or even those in more prosperous Latin American countries like Chile.
Even in those parts of Latin America where the Year 2000 problem might actually do damage, it is being shrugged off by many people. The relative nonchalance among Latin Americans to the issue might have something to do with their approach to the economic, political and social turbulence that have been common throughout the region's history.
"Latin Americans tend to be more passionate than their colleagues above the equator when it comes time to make a decision," said Max Gehringer, a Sao Paulo businessman who writes a column on corporate culture for Exame, Brazil's leading business magazine.
"In practical terms this means we either magnify a problem which really isn't that large or we underestimate something we don't understand entirely," said Mr. Gehringer. "Two things can happen on the first day of January: Either our companies will enter in reactive panic or an absence of problems will have us saying, 'See? It was all just hype.' "

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Opportunities in a Rusting Romania

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: PLOIESTI, Romania

 BODY:
There probably is not another Raytheon office campus on earth where mangy dogs and underdressed students of the manicure arts wander the grounds.
But it is here, in the dormitories of a run-down vocational high school, that Raytheon is joining America's experiment with Romania's distorted economy. 
 It is going so well that the company is erecting a new $8 million office building across town. Instead of being upstairs from the car-repair, dressmaking and barber classes, Raytheon will be next door to Ploiesti's lone citadel of higher education: The University of Oil and Gas.
"No liberal arts here," chuckled Peter Stephenson, general manager of Raytheon's 300-person operation, which he plans to expand to 500. "You've got to be an oil-or-gas man. And we'll do our recruiting next door."
In cities across Romania, American companies are taking advantage of one of the legacies of Romania's dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, who ruled for 25 years before he was overthrown and executed in 1989: Obsessed with industrialization, he nearly bankrupted his country building huge steel mills, oil refineries and factories. Many now lie rusting, but the engineering schools he added to Romania's already excellent school system still pump out graduates.
According to the Romanian-American Capital and Trade Development Group, Romania is top-heavy with engineers and has twice the number of computer-science graduates per capita that the United States does and seven times the rate in India.
And they work cheap. The economics can be compelling to companies like Raytheon, the military contractor based in Lexington, Mass. The average Romanian earns $1,000 a year; an engineer only twice that. For less than $5,000 a year, a foreign company can hire the best and brightest here to do work for which it would pay at least $60,000 a year in the United States.
Other American engineering companies here include Cambric Consulting of Draper, Utah, , which has 300 employees, and Harza Engineering of Chicago, which builds hydroelectric plants and has an agreement with the national Hydroelectric Institute to "borrow" 100 of its engineers for big projects. The institute's engineers earn paltry Romanian government salaries when there is no work, but several times that when Harza has work for them.
This may not be what some American workers want to hear, especially after the breakdown of World Trade Organization talks in Seattle early this month. But there is not even a loading dock they can picket. In place of a giant sucking sound made by these jobs going overseas is the quiet click of an Internet connection.
Indeed, it is unclear whether they are costing any American jobs at all. By providing an extra work force at a time when tens of thousands of engineering jobs advertised in the United States, they might enhance the prospects for American firms in the global marketplace.
Engineers here worked simultaneously with teams in Princeton, N.J., and Thailand on the design of a new Thai power plant; the model could reside on a computer in any country and the Romanians could work on it while the Americans were eating breakfast and the Thais were fighting the evening rush hour.
They helped design a polystyrene plant for Poland, a chemical plant for Equatorial Guinea, detergent and cigarette factories for Romania and a Pringle's potato chip factory for Belgium.
For their part, some Raytheon workers in Romania seem quite pleased with their new situation.
Doina Fortuna, 42, is a design technician who uses the computer model to extract blueprints for builders. Like approximately half her Raytheon co-workers here, she worked for decades at the Institute for Petrochemical Installation Design, a government institution privatized only three months ago. There, she worked on an easel with pens and T-squares; here she uses a $30,000 desktop computer, earns nearly triple her old pay, and has been sent to the Netherlands to learn new software.
She is not bothered by the campus, which despite its run-down surroundings, has roomy desks, sunlight and rugs on the floors. "I visited the institute a year ago, and I was afraid to go in the corridors because it was too dark, too small," she said. "You'll never see an office such as this there."
Ploiesti is not a pretty city -- aside from the clock museum and a few other buildings in an architectural style that might be called Addams Family Gothic, it is full of long rows of grim Stalinist apartment blocks. If the name sounds familiar, there was an earlier American connection: the legendary Ploiesti raids of World War II. Its refineries fueled Hitler's Panzer divisions, and the Allies were desperate to knock them out. Many bombers, hours from their bases in Italy, were shot down, and there is still a British military graveyard just south of town.
Ploiesti's oil boom began well before the internal-combustion engine. Peasants used to dig here for wagon wheel grease, said Marian Nicolescu, Raytheon's engineering manager, and its oil lit the streets of European cities back in the days when Pennsylvania, not Texas, was a wildcatter's dream. There are still five refineries in Ploiesti, which explains the concentration of engineering talent.
Cambric Consulting, probably the second-largest American employer of Romanian engineers and computer specialists, has 300 people in Brasov and Cluj. Brasov contains Romania's truck and tractor factories, and Cluj has industries and technical universities. Much of the Cambric work is converting two-dimensional drawings of engines and parts to three-dimensional computer models for clients like Deere & Company and Caterpillar.
Cambric's engineers are paid about $3,600 a year, with incentives for on-time work that can double their salaries. It also saves money on computers and software licensing fees by having its work stations in use 18 hours a day; employees work nine-hour shifts.
Similar work is done in India, but Cambric closed its 300-employee office in India three years ago and expanded its Romania operation from 12 engineers to 300. Asked about that, Viorel Scortaru Pasca, deputy manager of the Brasov plant, said he'd heard "the customers complained that the Indian engineers would say: 'Here's a problem. What do we do?,' while the Romanian engineers would say: 'Here's a problem. Here's how to solve it.' They were more creative."
Mr. Stephenson, a native of Australia, said he found Romanian engineers to be so highly educated "that we're probably overqualified -- even our human resources lady is a welding engineer. That's the beauty of what you find here." Fluency in English is about 50 percent, especially among the young. Older Romanians often speak French or Russian.
"The only problem with attitude," he said, "is a little too much respect for authority. They have trouble unfreezing. I like people to call me Peter, but there are still some who can't bring themselves to do that. But as far as the work ethic is concerned, there is no problem, no Communist hangover -- they do what has to be done."

HEADLINE: Growth in Holiday Season's Retail Sales May Set a 5-Year High

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
The season started at 4:30 a.m. the day after Thanksgiving with shoppers lining up outside of Toys "R" Us in Atlanta to buy Pokemon cards, and it built from there.
Yahoo, the leading Internet portal, recorded more purchases through its Web site in five days this month than during its entire 1998 holiday season. In Manhattan, a Gap store ran out of $175 leather pants so fast that the sight of shoppers breaking into tears of frustration became common. 
 The millennium may turn out to be a bust, but by any measure Christmas 1999 was swinging.
Retailers will not officially report their December sales until early January, and many of the biggest shopping days are still to come with post-Christmas sales. Already, though, analysts are saying the nation's largest stores are on track to see a year-over-year rise in purchasing well in excess of 6 percent, making this the strongest Christmas since 1994. Some merchants are even whispering about a blowout.
The International Council of Shopping Centers, which tracks purchases in small stores in a cross-section of malls, was showing a 6.6 percent rise in sales through last weekend. "We might possibly see it go up to 8 or 9 percent," John Konarski, the group's president, said.
Telecheck Services, which tracks check writing at a broad swath of the nation's retailers, seconded that assessment. "We are looking at close to an 8 percent gain for retail sales for the month of December," said William Ford, a Telecheck official. "It is an amazing season for the retailers."
A copious holiday season makes a fitting, if not unexpected, climax to a year in which Americans -- encouraged by a soaring stock market and rising wages -- have indulged in a sustained shopping spree. And in keeping with their fattened wallets, shoppers showed a lust for the finer things in life -- though not necessarily at any cost. If the season has had any theme, it is luxury at all price points.
Whether it was packaged as gauze-thin v-necks by the discounters or as a $375 hand-woven Pashmina muffler in wildberry -- think deep pink -- at Saks Fifth Avenue, customers could not get enough cashmere. "I am getting cashmere for my mother, my sister and my housekeeper," said Catherine Russell, an actress in Manhattan who started her holiday shopping just Tuesday.
Sales of jewelry, a category whose performance is tied to the state of the economy, were up 10 percent, according to the shopping center group's surveys. Zales Inc. reported a tremendous interest in relatively affordable solo diamond pendants; at Neiman Marcus, the upscale department store chain owned by Harcourt General, sales of much more expensive baubles, like ruby and emerald bracelets, were "outstanding," according to Karen Katz, executive vice president of stores.
While luxury was the watchword, discounters hardly ceded their role as the 800-pound reindeer of the shopping season. Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest retailer, said it was going to meet expectations of sales growth of 5 to 7 percent, as consumers thronged its stores to buy everything from Thunder Punch Buzz, an action figure from the Disney "Toy Story 2" movie, to flat-screen televisions.
Electronics retailers also fared very well as Americans clamored for the latest digital cameras, DVD players and personal digital assistants. According to the shopping centers council, the electronics category had the single biggest increase in sales, up 14.6 percent from last year.
In keeping with recent trends, department stores, as a group, were not faring as well as the rest of the retailing pack. The week before Christmas, many resorted to deep price-cutting to meet sales expectations. Dillard's, in the most drastic example of the phenomenon, was offering "after Christmas prices" of up to 50 percent off many items.
The result may be that while the department stores will post solid sales numbers, their margins could be thin -- a possibility that Wall Street is watching carefully.
"A lot of retailers are giving it away this season," said John D. Morris, an analyst at Gerard Klauer & Mattison.
There was another casualty in this unusually flush season: customer service. Data from the Labor Department indicates that retailers did not substantially increase their staffs for the season.
"The retail employment numbers are down a little on a seasonal adjusted basis, which is remarkable, really," said Carl Steidtman, chief retail economist with Pricewaterhouse Coopers. Mr. Steidtman speculated that the slip was at least partly attributable to a tight labor pool and automated check-out technologies.
Whatever the reason for their absence, human helpers were sorely missed. "This was by far the biggest Christmas for complaining about sales help," said Britt Beemer, chairman of America's Research Group, which conducts annual holiday surveys among shoppers. "Some 33.8 percent of shoppers felt stores were too short-handed, which was nine points higher than last year, which was already an all-time high."
Internet merchants benefited from the public perception that brick-and mortar stores were a hassle -- and from heavy spending on advertising. Visa International, which accounts for about half of the nation's credit card spending, estimated that online purchases roughly tripled from November and December of last year.
"It was a Christmas of different proportions than last year," said Kenneth Seiff, chief executive of Bluefly.com, an online store featuring cut-rate designer fashions. "Instead of being a novelty, people were here to shop."
Mr. Seiff estimated that his company did more business in its two peak days, Dec. 13 and 14, than it did in the entire fourth quarter of last year. Items popular offline were in demand online as well. "We re-ordered Pashmina four times," he said.
Yet for all its geometric and well-publicized growth, Internet sales still only accounted for about $3 billion, or less than 2 percent, of what the National Retail Federation estimates was $186 billion in total holiday retail sales of general merchandise, apparel and furnishings. That meant plenty of people were sticking loyally to their local mall, despite the inconvenience of crowded parking lots and absentee sales associates.
Barbara and Larry Hudgins of Athens, Ga., shopped for their five children and six grandchildren at Rich's, a regional department store chain owned by Federated Department Stores. Though Mrs. Hudgins said she had had trouble finding a sales clerk to help her in the children's department, her husband, who owns an electrical contracting company, said he would not consider switching to the Internet.
"Right at the present time, I don't trust it," he said. "I don't trust anybody who wants my credit card and who I can't see."
Then there were last-minute shoppers who just did not trust Web merchants to deliver on time. John Suh, a lawyer shopping Thursday in Herald Square in Manhattan, said he had heard mixed reviews about the Internet and just wanted to "have my gifts in hand."
Across Manhattan, the nation's shopping capital, a holiday-swelled tourist population helped keep stores churning. At a new Banana Republic store at Rockefeller Center, Monica Karalis, a concierge fluent in five languages, had her mouth full flipping back and forth from Spanish to Italian to French as she helped customers track down items like pony-skin belts.
While apparel with "Y2K" and "Year 2000" logos racked up disappointing sales nationwide, merchants in New York said that the market for themed plates and stuffed animals was brisk enough.
"We found that anything that had 'New York' on it and the year 2000 in combination was instantly gone," said Joe Denofrio, a spokesman for Macy's Herald Square. Other hot sellers at the store included Champagne flutes with 2000 embedded in their stems ($19.99 a pair) and musical snowglobes of Times Square playing "Auld Lang Syne" ($35).
"It is the non-New York customer buying," Mr. Denofrio said.

HEADLINE: Steel Imports Decline for Fourth Month

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Steel imports fell in November for the fourth consecutive month, the Commerce Department has reported.
On Thursday, the department said imports slid 9 percent, to 2.5 million metric tons -- a level 29 percent lower than a year ago. That followed drops of 5 percent in August, 10 percent in September and nine-tenths of 1 percent in October. 
 Several analysts called the trend cause for optimism. But some said the market had not yet recovered from an import surge last year, when the Asian economic crisis led to a high amount of foreign steel entering the United States. In response, the Clinton administration filed anti-dumping lawsuits against 30 nations, including Japan.
"The figures show a stable market," said Charles Butler, director of the Japan Steel Information Center. "There was never a crisis that many people talked about."
Greg Mastel, an economist at the New America Foundation, a research group in Washington, said the steel market "seems to be stabilizing a bit," although he added that "some sectors are having particular problems."
Imports of cold-rolled, semifinished and wire rod steel decreased from October levels. But imports of hot-rolled, cut-to-length plate and heavy structurals steel increased.
In the first 11 months of 1999, steel imports declined 16 percent from 1998 levels.

HEADLINE: Yen Falls Against Dollar; Global Markets Extend Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The yen posted its biggest decline against the dollar in more than a month yesterday after the Bank of Japan sold its currency for the 12th time since June.
At the same time, stock market records fell in Hong Kong, London and Paris, extending a pre-Christmas global rally. Financial markets in the United States were closed in observance of the Christmas holiday after staging a broad and powerful rally on Thursday. 
 The Bank of Japan sold an estimated $2 billion to $3 billion in yen in an effort to keep the country's economic recovery on track, analysts said, driving the currency to an exchange rate of 103.15 a dollar.
But the rate slid to 102.65 yen to the dollar at the close, though that was still up from the 101.78 yen late Thursday in London.
"It's year-end and the last thing the B.O.J. wanted was the yen to strengthen," said Divyang Shah, global strategist at IDEA Global.
The currency's move was exacerbated because many traders were absent on the day before Christmas. Japanese officials have sold more than $42 billion in yen since June to slow the currency's 10 percent gains against the dollar this year, which threatens to impede an economic rebound.
Japan's economy contracted for five consecutive quarters through last year, in the country's worst recession since World War II.
The stock market advance in Europe was paced by phone companies such as Sagem S.A., on optimism that rising demand will drive profits higher next year.
French retailers including Carrefour S.A. gained on expectations that consumers would spend more this holiday season than last.
"There's been continual upgrading of expectations for mobile phone growth all year," said Neville Reeves, who manages $100 million at Thames River Capital in London.
The Dow Jones Euro Stoxx 50, an index of 50 large European companies, advanced 14.81 points to a closing high of 4602.82, rising 3.3 percent for the week.
Markets in Germany, Italy, Switzerland, Spain and the Scandinavian countries were closed for Christmas. France's benchmark CAC 40 index rose to its 37th high close this year.
Sagem, a maker of mobile phones, climbed 54 euros, or 8.9 percent, to 658.5. About 4 million mobile phones will be given as Christmas gifts in Britain, double the number last year, The Financial Times reported. ARM Holdings P.L.C., Europe's top designer of chips for mobile phones, climbed 311 pence to 4.060.
The new high in Hong Kong is the first since August 1997, before the worst of the Asian financial crisis set in.
Lifted by Thursday's record session on Wall Street, Hong Kong stocks soared. The Hang Seng Index soared 537.20 points, or 3.3 percent, to close at 16,833.28, surpassing the previous record finish reached Aug. 7, 1997.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
An Emphasis on Gore's Experience

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:

This 30-second commercial is the seventh from Vice President Al Gore. It discusses his experience and is being broadcast in Iowa and New Hampshire beginning this weekend.
 
PRODUCER Century-Media.
 
ON THE SCREEN -- The question is posed on a black screen: "How much experience does America need?" Live color shots of Mr. Gore with regular people appear sequentially as he talks about Social Security (he hugs an elderly person), schools (a teacher appears with children in a classroom), the environment (a spray of cherry blossoms) and the economy (a roof-raising). Mr. Gore appears at the end in a blue suit reviewing a piece of paper. 

THE SCRIPT -- A male voice narrates: "How much experience does America need? To protect Social Security from those who want to raise the retirement age? To really take on the big drug companies and get affordable prescription drugs? To fight against vouchers that drain money from public schools? To preserve Medicaid and strengthen Medicare? To keep our environment clean and our economy strong? How much experience does America need? All it can get."
 
ACCURACY -- There are no factual claims in this commercial, but there are several dubious implications. One is that the Social Security retirement age is unchanging. In fact, the age at which one can retire and receive full benefits is already scheduled to climb gradually, to 67 from 65, over 24 years that begin in 2003.
 
But the underlying supposition is that former Senator Bill Bradley, Mr. Gore's lone rival for the Democratic nomination, lacks the experience to manage the big issues facing the country and that he would do things detrimental to the national interest, or at least the Democratic interest, like raise the retirement age. Mr. Bradley has equivocated on raising the age, saying that all options should be on the table. But Mr. Gore has not said specifically how he would shore up Social Security either, saying only, "I'm not for raising the retirement age."
 
The reference to taking on "the big drug companies" is a further dig at Mr. Bradley who, as a senator from New Jersey, received significant financial contributions from those companies, many of which are based in New Jersey. Other New Jersey Democrats, including Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who has endorsed Mr. Gore, are also mindful of the pharmaceutical industry's importance to their home state and have voted accordingly.
 
On school vouchers, Mr. Bradley has voted to allow experiments using them while Mr. Gore opposed doing so. Mr. Gore is also reminding viewers that Mr. Bradley has proposed eliminating Medicaid, although he would replace it with other health insurance.
 
SCORECARD -- Like previous Gore advertisements, this one inches closer and closer to a direct attack on Mr. Bradley's proposals, though it does not name the former senator. Mr. Gore is trying to reach the core Democratic constituency groups -- the elderly, teachers, blue-collar workers -- and hoping to spur them to the polls to save these fundamental Democratic programs by voting for him.
 
Mr. Gore has only recently begun to emphasize his experience as a qualification for the job of president. In this commercial, he suggests he has the experience to maintain the status quo, that is, the booming economy, without tinkering with core Democratic programs.
 
This spot will probably be followed by more that spell out in even tougher language the threat that Mr. Gore believes a Bradley presidency would pose. KATHARINE Q. SEELYE
 
Four advertisements for Mr. Gore are available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/politics

HEADLINE: Dreaming of a White Christmas? Just Buy It

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: DARIEN, Conn., Dec. 24

 BODY:
The meteorologists may say that there hasn't been any snow this winter in this quaint, affluent town. But don't tell that to Henry and Doris Herbert's 11 grandchildren.
Come Christmas morning, they will discover up to six feet of snow blanketing much of their grandparents' two-acre property here, giving them the perfect place to test out the sleds and toboggans they will receive as presents on Saturday. What's more, the six boys and five girls will discover that they will be the only ones in the neighborhood with a patch of winter in a landscape of green and brown -- offering irrevocable proof, no doubt, that this year, Santa decided that no one was more special. 
 In addition to expressing gratitude to Santa, they might want to give thanks to Snowman Services of Darien for the reminder that in the go-go 90's, you don't have to dream about a white Christmas, you can just order a man-made, made-to-order version if you're looking for the ultimate Christmas-morning indulgence.
For a minimum of $750, Snowman Services can manufacture snow to be dumped in backyards, front yards, parking lots or country estates, using a quieter version of the snow-making equipment used by ski resorts. And in a booming economy, the prospect of summoning winter with a simple phone call, take-out style, has been quite the fashionable gift or gesture this season.
"Some people have got into a bidding war," said Jonathan Sweeney, Snowman's owner, who controlled the Herbert family snowstorm this afternoon.
"One guy from Scarsdale said, 'I'll pay you $5,000 if you do us and blow the other people off tonight.' " (Mr. Sweeney declined the offer, saying that his policy was "first come first served.")
Creating snow, or faux snow, is not new, of course. Ski resorts do it, on a huge scale. Movie studios in California do it, for special effects. Even malls in Florida occasionally do it, for promotional purposes, by chopping up ice to get -- voila! -- something that feels like snow.
But the idea of creating snow for purely personal reasons -- so that one family can have it, while everyone else does not -- has caught on in only the last year or so. Mr. Sweeney, for one, takes orders for snow-filled birthday parties, corporate events and Christmas surprises throughout Fairfield County.
In Manchester, N.H., Kendall and Colette Veilleux began a snow-making business this year, after stumbling upon Mr. Sweeney's Web site.
And in Midland, Mich., SMI Snowmakers, one of the country's leading manufacturers of snow-making equipment for ski resorts, occasionally accepts orders for private parties, sometimes from the famous (an example: Celine Dion), at a cost of $3,000 to $10,000, said Joe VanderKelen, the company's president.
Making snow can be a finicky business. The temperature, for one thing, cannot exceed 30 degrees Fahrenheit. The process requires a lot of water, too, about 20,000 to 100,000 gallons per night. And the customer is usually expected to supply the water.
So to get, say, an acre of man-made snow, one-foot deep, requires about 27,000 gallons of water, or a little less than a swimming pool, which can be accomplished in six to eight hours, Mr. Sweeney said.
To do it right, Mr. Sweeney said, you also need to spend about $75,000 in start-up capital to procure a snow-making machine, which resembles a wayward jet engine; a generator; a trailer; cables; hoses; and a pressure booster.
And for the prospective client, of course, there is the cost, which is just a euphemism for sticker shock: $750 per night, per machine, in Mr. Sweeney's case. But here in Fairfield County, one of the wealthiest places in the country, cost is usually an afterthought.
Mr. Sweeney first got the idea in 1995, when one of the clients (a well-known Wall Street financier) of his full-time landscaping business, Darien Tree and Lawn Care, asked if man-made snow would be possible for a holiday party.
Though that project never came about, Mr. Sweeney eventually bought some equipment and tested it at his own house, overcoming problems like excessive noise. Then, in 1997, he tackled his first job: a children's party for a prominent doctor in Westport.
"It looked like a huge sperm whale that landed in their driveway," said Mr. Sweeney about that project, which was 8 feet tall, 25 feet wide and 100 feet long.
Soon, people started noticing Mr. Sweeney's creations popping up all over Fairfield County. And this year, Mr. Sweeney, 36, began advertising on WKHL, an oldies station in Norwalk, and at sites on the Internet -- www.snowmanusa.com and www.darien-lawn-tree.com.
It has grown so frenzied, he said, that he has hired extra workers and has turned down numerous requests because of scheduling conflicts.
Nicholas H. Fingelly Real Estate was one of the groups that made the cut. On Thursday afternoon, the company celebrated a very good year with a blanket of man-made snow surrounding its new office in Westport, topped by Christmas caroling and the occasional snowball.
"Some people dream of a white Christmas," said an ebullient Victoria Fingelly, a co-owner who was bedecked in a mink coat dotted with fake snow. "We make it happen."
Not everyone has had the same reaction, naturally, to the sight of uneven snowfall. A few bah-humbugs say that the practice could engender neighborhood envy; others say that it's just another convenience for the well-to-do.
But here, in Darien, Henry and Doris Herbert's five children decided that they could think of no better gift -- or surprise -- for the 11 grandchildren, whose ages range from 2 months to 16 years, than to pull a fast one on Mother Nature.
After all, it has been a few years since there was any snow on Christmas Day, said Lauren Banerjee, one of the Herberts' four daughters. And by splitting the $750 cost, the gift would actually be cheaper than a trip to, say, Radio City -- plus, the snow will last for perhaps a month.
But the surprise was momentarily in doubt today. When Mrs. Banerjee's 4-year-old nephew, Jack Fisher, talked about the weather, he calmly told his mom, Bebe Fisher, "There will be snow tomorrow."
Nervous, Mrs. Fisher asked Jack how he knew. Had someone slipped?
But the boy, who has never experienced a white Christmas, simply smiled and said, "Because it's Christmas."

HEADLINE: Effects of Economic 'Sunspots'

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Dec. 24

 BODY:
What do sunspots and economic forecasts have in common? Both affect the economy only if the public believes they do, according to a commentary by the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.
Economists have shown that public economic expectations can result in self-fulfilling prophesies, or behavior that causes the belief to come true. The Fed's use of forecasts to establish monetary policy can thus set the tone for public behavior. 
 But economic crystal balls are about as accurate as "soothsayers and weather forecasts," or watching sunspots to predict the economy, the commentary said.
For example, if the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's rate-setting panel, raises interest rates to pre-empt future inflation, the public and financial markets begin to act as if inflation is a reality which can cause inflation.
"Monetary policy decisions depend on what the public is expected to do, and the public bases its behavior on current monetary policy actions," said Charles Carlstrom, a Cleveland Fed economist, and bank consultant Timothy Fuerst, the commentary's authors.
The result is a hard-to-control cycle based only on mutual expectations. "Using forecasts to determine monetary policy actions introduces the possibility that inflation will increase just because the public expects it," they wrote.
For economists, the term sunspots symbolizes an event that affects some economic variable only because the public believes it does. It was coined after an 1884 theory that sunspots affect the earth's climate and thus agricultural productivity.
"A sunspot is therefore purely extraneous information that leads to a circle of self-fulfilling expectations," the commentary said.

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Russia, a Power on Ice, Frets About the Future

BYLINE: By SAL A. ZANCA 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The Soviet system is gone but not forgotten. It formed the basis for Russia becoming the most powerful nation in the history of figure skating.
Last March Russia became the first country to take all four titles at the world championships after winning all four at the European meet for the third year in a row. 
 So at the Russian national championships, which began Thursday, the spots for the world team are precious. A singles spot on the team virtually guarantees an international medal and prize money now allowed by the International Skating Union.
"The overall level here will be much higher than at the world championship," said Valentin Piseyev, president of the Russian Skating Federation.
In this week's Russian women's singles competition, for example, there are a half-dozen skaters with international medals, yet only three can make the national team.
Russian skaters are succeeding in spite of dwindling resources at home, where rinks are being shut down to devote the space to more lucrative schemes, coaches are leaving for higher-paying jobs in other countries and the Russian federation is struggling for money to support younger talent.
"The system is still the same," Piseyev said. "You may call it Soviet. You may call it Russian. What was invented in the Soviet system remains here, in Ukraine, in Uzbekistan and all the republics. What is now was done in the Soviet times."
Viktor Kudriavtsev, a coach of more than 40 years in the former Soviet Union and in Russia, agreed.
"The athletes you see now started in the Soviet times and the basis was in the Soviet times," he said. "The athletes now are on the ice now from 8 to 10 years."
Piseyev said: "Our success was based on preserving the preparation of the athletes from the very young to the highest level. All this is because of the high quality of the coaches."
But despite the current excellence of Russian skaters, there are some dark clouds ahead.
"All the negative tendencies in Russian sports now have also affected figure skating," Piseyev said. "This problem will affect the Russian figure skating in a few years."
Piseyev and Kudriavtsev detailed the problems. "More than 150 top figure-skating specialist coaches are working not in Russia but the United States," Piseyev said. "A month salary in Russia is equal to a one-day salary in the United States."
Kudriavtsev, who coached the 1998 Olympic champion Ilya Kulik before Kulik moved to the United States to work with another former Soviet coach, Tatyana Tarasova, added, "It is more difficult to find young talent now."
"The big work of the development of the figure skating was greatly reduced," Kudriavtsev said. "The family's economic situation here is low. And that is why many kids do not have opportunities to go into figure skating now."
In international competition, however, at least for now, the Russians keep winning. The incentive is pride, fueled by money.
"For the Russian athletes, in the old times the state will take back the money," Piseyev said. "Now they take it for themselves."
Yelena Sokolova knows. In 1998 she placed seventh at the Olympics and won two Grand Prix meets worth $30,000 each. Not bad for a 17-year-old in a country where the average annual salary is less than 15,000 rubles (about $533), according to Russian economic figures.
But last year Sokolova was only fifth at the nationals and then watched her teammates go one-two-three at the European championships and one-three at the worlds.
"It is more difficult for a Russian woman here than in European or worlds because anyone who skates here can win," she said. "Anyone."
Mariya Butyrskaya, who beat Michelle Kwan in March for the world title, faces the pressure not only of defending her title but also of just making the Russian team.
On Thursday night, minutes before she planned to drive to the rink for the championships, a car belonging to Butyrskaya blew up on a Moscow street. The newspaper Sport Ekspress said witnesses saw two young people running from the car shortly before it exploded. There were no reports of injuries or details of a police investigation. Butyrskaya declined to comment when asked about the report.
It's not as if making the world team and reaping the rewards means living happily ever after.
Although Aleksei Yagudin, a two-time world and European men's champion, has earned about a half-million dollars in prize money over the past two years, he was kicked off the exhibition tour for inappropriate behavior related to drinking. Yagudin was suspended by the Russian federation in May and went under a doctor's care.
"I hope his problems are behind him," Piseyev said. Yagudin is reluctant to talk about his problems.
Despite his credentials, he has never won a national title. In today's free skating here, Yevgeny Plushchenko, 17, landed a quadruple and seven triples to defeat Yagudin.
Other elite Russian skaters have had their troubles as well. Yelena Berezhnaya and Anton Sikharulidze, the world champions in pairs, have stumbled this season. Since a recent move to New Jersey with their coach, Tamara Moskvina, Berezhnaya has been homesick and Sikharulidze had an automobile accident and lost a lot of time from training. Despite their struggles this season, today they took advantage of opponents' mistakes to capture their second consecutive national title.
And the world ice dance champions, Angelika Krylova and Oleg Ovsiannikov, could not compete at the nationals and were uncertain of their ability to compete at all this season after she went to a hospital Wednesday to treat an old back injury.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Feted Abroad, and No Longer Banned in Beijing

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
THESE are exhilarating, and perhaps a bit frightening, times for 36-year-old Zhang Yuan, who is increasingly described in international film circles as perhaps the most gifted and original filmmaker of his generation, even though his movies have not been widely seen at home or abroad.
His past films, including "Beijing Bastards" (1992) and "East Palace, West Palace" (1996), were banned in China because they dealt with hidden subjects like alienated youths and furtive homosexual encounters. That they were stylistically off-beat as well -- "Beijing Bastards" was a deliberately raw, improvised slice of life in the rock underground -- compounded his sins in the eyes of Communist censors. 
 The commercial market abroad for serious Chinese movies is quite limited. But Mr. Zhang's seven feature films, including fiction and documentaries, have become favorites on the international art-house and film-festival circuit. Known for years as an intriguing underground filmmaker, he is now swamped with invitations to appear at festivals and seminars.
Just in the last several weeks, Mr. Zhang -- a stocky man with a baby face, the eyes of Edward G. Robinson and an explosion of curly hair that could shame Gene Wilder -- attended a screening of his films at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, spoke at a three-day Zhang Yuan retrospective held by the Harvard Film Archive, discussed his films at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, traveled to London for a museum screening and then went on to Argentina, where he helped judge a film festival.
"We recognize in his work a mastery of the medium," said Bruce Jenkins, curator of the Harvard Film Archive, explaining why it sponsored such a big program for a young, still-evolving director. "You can already tell he'll have an impressive body of work, that he'll be as important to his generation of filmmakers as Chen Kaige and Zhang Yimou have been to theirs." Mr. Jenkins was referring to the "fifth generation" masters who are in their late 40's and came out of the Beijing Film Academy years before Zhang Yuan.
More compelling to Mr. Zhang than the global acclaim, but also potentially more perilous to his art, is the shaky bridge he is crossing at home. Only two years ago, angry Chinese authorities confiscated his passport when he tried to go to the Cannes International Film Festival, where "East Palace, West Palace" had been entered, and threatened him with prosecution if he tried to make another film on the sly.
Now, Mr. Zhang has just made two features in cooperation with the government's film bureau, one fictional and one a documentary.
"I've been making films for almost 10 years now and virtually nothing has been seen by Chinese audiences," Mr. Zhang said in a recent interview in Beijing, between trips to Boston and London. "That's something that has really frustrated and pained me."
SO to reach his home audience -- and avoid possible arrest -- he allowed the censors to review the scripts and edited versions of his new features. In the case of both the fictional feature, "Seventeen Years," and the full-length documentary, "Crazy English," some last-minute cuts were required, Mr. Zhang said. And now, "Seventeen Years" is scheduled to open commercially in Beijing next month and prospects are good for the documentary to be released here, too.
"All artists have to make choices, and these become limitations," Mr. Zhang said, obviously troubled by the subject and aware that some younger artists here are wondering whether he has lost his edge. "Limitations are not necessarily all bad," he continued, "but as an artist you still have to make sure that what you are doing remains real."
Whatever the background, Mr. Zhang is proud of his two new films and at this stage would welcome more commercial success. While "East Palace, West Palace" has played art houses in many countries and brought in some money, Mr. Zhang has had to spend a large share of his time over the last decade shooting commercials and rock videos for a living, and trawling Europe and Asia for financial backers. He and his wife, Ning Dai, a screenwriter, live well by Beijing standards, but he still answers his own phone and makes all his own arrangements.
In September, "Seventeen Years" won him the best-director award at the Venice Film Festival. It does not yet have an American distributor, but deals have been signed in Italy, Japan, Brazil and several other countries.
The film tells the story of a girl who murders her taunting sister, then after 17 years in prison gets a leave to visit home to see her aged, bitter parents. It will not be mistaken for a Hollywood thriller: it proceeds quietly, the drama propelled by silences and glances as much as by dialogue.
But with its clean direction, Vermeeresque lighting and memorable characters, and a simple, wrenching story with a happy ending, the film may appeal to a broader audience here than Mr. Zhang's more ponderous early films would have.
The new documentary, "Crazy English," is about Li Yang, a wildly successful promoter who leads auditoriums full of Chinese in shouting out English phrases -- the path, he says, to overcoming inhibitions, learning English and making China strong. The feature has no narration; rather, it just lets Li keep talking, and he is so nimble and funny that the technique works.
Some Western critics have suggested that the film is a subtle expose of mob psychology, with allusions to Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution. Hearing that, Mr. Zhang laughs and says, "That's going too far."
"Even if Li Yang does have that tendency, it's a funny and cool one," he says. He hopes for a public television showing in the United States.
It's remarkable that Mr. Zhang ever got to make films at all, let alone develop an original sensibility. He was born in 1963 in the southern city of Nanjing. He had poor health, he says, and cultivated a love of painting. Only at about age 20 did he become interested in writing and film and learn that the Beijing Film Academy, China's elite training ground, had reopened in 1978, after the end of the Cultural Revolution.
In 1985, the academy advertised for a new batch of students. Tens of thousands applied, including Mr. Zhang, who had little knowledge of film but apparently did so spectacularly well in essays and interviews that he was one of 16 students accepted.
UP to that point the only foreign films that Mr. Zhang, like most Chinese, had seen were from the Soviet Union, North Korea and Yugoslavia. But the academy had copies of the best movies appearing in the United States and Europe.
"I was like someone who'd been starved for a long time," he recalled. While specializing in cinematography, he devoured the films of Martin Scorsese, watching "Taxi Driver," "Mean Streets" and others dozens of times. He also studied the work of Italian directors like Antonioni and Fellini.
But his biggest revelation, Mr. Zhang said, was seeing Chinese films of the 1930's. "That was a time when Chinese arts were at their liveliest," he said.
From the opening scene of his first film, "Mama," about a mother and her retarded child, which was completed in 1990, Mr. Zhang established himself as a fresh cinematic voice.
"Nearly every one of Zhang Yuan's films has broken thematic and stylistic ground," said Yaohua Shi, an expert on Chinese film at the University of Massachusetts who served as host for Mr. Zhang and his works recently. "He has opted for a gritty, deliberately unglamorous cinematic technique or the documentary style, often avoiding visual pyrotechnics."
Although Mr. Zhang had made "Mama" through official channels, it was not viewed favorably by officials and received almost no distribution, he said.
"At that point I realized that if I really wanted to express my own views about society, then I needed total independence," Mr. Zhang said.
The film he wanted to make next, "Beijing Bastards," which portrayed the amoral, apolitical lives of an underground youth culture, could not remotely have passed official muster. "They couldn't have reviewed a script because we didn't have one!" he said of the 1992 film, which featured the alienated rock songs of Cui Jian.
Sometimes called China's first independent feature, "Beijing Bastards" was filmed with an intentionally rough quality reminiscent of Andy Warhol, and it captured the attention of cognoscenti.
After a documentary about Tiananmen Square, Mr. Zhang made "Sons," a realistic fiction about a father's alcoholism and insanity.
"East Palace, West Palace," in 1996, showed a new sophistication and secured Mr. Zhang's reputation abroad. Showing the gay underworld of city parks and a police officer's homoerotic pull toward a masochistic cruiser, it examined themes that are simply not discussed in public here.
It may be no coincidence that in May 1996, China's cabinet passed new "Rules for Administration of Films" that, among other vague provisions, proscribed the making of movies that "threaten the security, reputation and interests of the state."
"There's no question that the new film law specifically banned independent filmmaking, outside the official studio system," said Chris Berry, an expert on the Asian cinema at La Trobe University in Melbourne, Australia. "Before that it was a gray area."
MR. ZHANG says that after the 1997 clash over the showing of "East Palace, West Palace" at Cannes, and the loss of his passport, he knew he was at an impasse. "If I had continued to work the same way, I'd probably have lost my freedom," he said.
After eight months of limbo, Mr. Zhang was given his passport back, and he began intensive discussions with the film authorities, leading to agreement in 1998 that he could resume making movies.
Now, even as he eagerly anticipates his first Chinese commercial release, he can't stop thinking about the strictures. "An artist has to express his point of view fully and without any constraint," he said. "If an artist can't do that, then there's no hope."
Will he always be able to find topics that excite him and are acceptable to the censors? "I have no idea," he replied.
"Deng Xiaoping used a parable to describe how we should run our economy," Mr. Zhang said, " 'Crossing the river by feeling the stones, one at a time.' "
He added, "I think China's artists also have to think this way."

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
A 'Pianist'? Less, Perhaps, and More

BYLINE: By JOSEPH HOROWITZ; Joseph Horowitz's book about the pianist Claudio Arrau has recently been reissued as a Dover paperback.

 BODY:
IN his 1869 pamphlet "On Conducting," a classic text on the art of musical interpretation, Richard Wagner complained that performances of the keyboard works of Bach were diluted by a misguided "smoothness" and "mildness," that "there was no trace of somber German Gothicism." In frustration, Wagner reports, he begged his friend Liszt "to cleanse my musical soul of these painful impressions." Liszt complied by playing the Prelude and Fugue in C sharp minor from the first book of "The Well-Tempered Clavier." With this single performance, Wagner concludes, "Liszt revealed Bach to me."
How did Liszt play the C sharp minor Prelude and Fugue? Very likely the way Edwin Fischer plays it in a recording reissued in Philips's series Great Pianists of the 20th Century. 
 The special grandeur of this reading is partly an act of "orchestration": the different fugal voices are differently colored. In contrast to the muted strings and winds with which he begins, Fischer trumpets the striding third subject. His applications of pedal evoke a vast and resonant cathedral space. He shapes the fugue's gathering mass with tidal swells and recessions. Attaining the climax, he attends less to Baroque polyphony than to Romantic harmony: the final move to the tonic key, prepared by a long dominant pedal, is of Brucknerian amplitude and weight.
The all-Bach Fischer reissue (Philips 456 766-2; two CD's) includes more than a dozen preludes and fugues, three concertos and the best-known and most haunting of all of Fischer's Bach recordings: the Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue. Here he shapes the arpeggios to suggest light refracted through stained glass. Adding octaves, pedaling through bar lines, he captures the Gothic thunder of a mighty organ. The entire work, imbued by Bach with the spirit of improvisation, actually sounds composed on the spot in a Faustian creative fever.
When these recordings were made, in the early 1930's, Fischer was among the most celebrated pianists in Europe, and his Bach was famous. But, for reasons both political and aesthetic, he was never well known in the United States.
Born in Switzerland in 1886, he settled in Germany, then -- pressed to adopt German citizenship -- returned to Switzerland midway through World War II. He died in Zurich in 1960. Fischer's wartime residence in Berlin and close association with the conductor Wilhelm Furtwangler tainted his reputation abroad. But, like Furtwangler, he was no Nazi. (He sheltered his Jewish pupil and future assistant, Katja Andy, one of several young Jewish musicians he helped to escape.)
Fischer feared flying and never visited North America. Even if he had, it would not have made much difference. Such American musical icons as Toscanini and Heifetz were everything Fischer was not: brilliant, precise, virtuosic. Fischer was nervous and erratic. Even compared with such New World arbiters of Germanic taste as Artur Schnabel and Rudolf Serkin (who intensely disliked him), he stood apart as a cloudy and beclouded artistic personality, old-fashioned and obscure.
His recordings, too, are singularly inconsistent. A second Fischer release in the Great Pianists series, with music by Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert (456 769-2; two CD's), is disappointingly earthbound, as if the compilers of this admirable series were restricting their Fischer selections to recordings with the fewest wrong notes.
For Fischer's Mozart, the CD to buy documents a 1954 Turin concert with Fischer playing and conducting the Concertos in E flat (K. 482) and C minor (K. 491) with the Royal Danish Orchestra (on Music and Arts). The movement to listen to is the Andante of the E flat Concerto, which Fischer performs as an Adagio. Singing the long melodies, with their chromatic decorations, he explores realms of exquisite pain unvisited by Mozart sopranos. In the healing finale of the same work, he improvises left-hand countermelodies, fashioning a cumulative density of ornamentation that proves magically cathartic. These performances are not about Mozart's perfection. Rather, they fearlessly explore a wondrous wealth and variety of expression.
Fischer's great concerto recording is of the Brahms B flat, a 1942 collaboration with Furtwangler and the Berlin Philharmonic (also on Music and Arts). This live performance is at the same time regal and ruthlessly spontaneous. The heights and depths of the piece, its fire and ruminative serenity, are completely served. Pianist and conductor challenge and rechallenge each other toward maximum expenditure.
Claudio Arrau, whose Berlin teacher Martin Krause also taught Fischer, once recalled: "Fischer didn't have very much technique, you know. But you didn't care. I remember there was always this argument between Krause and Fischer. Krause said: 'Why don't you practice? Do some exercises.' But he wanted to make music."
Arrau also said of Fischer: "One never had the feeling in performance of hearing a pianist." This statement, almost innocuous in its simplicity, says it all. Fischer's art was not about the act of performance. He was the antithesis of Vladimir Horowitz, for whom playing the piano was about playing the piano.

HEADLINE: South Carolina Confronts Urban Sprawl

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C.

 BODY:
Just outside this city of 60,000 lie huge stretches of subdivisions where a few years ago cattle grazed or loblolly pines grew wild, reflecting a pattern of sprawl around mid-sized cities that has led state leaders to call for more control on development and greater attempts to preserve open space.
Jim Hodges, the Governor of South Carolina, has agreed to take part in a conference here schduled for March 26 to 28 for talks on how sprawl affects the state. The organizers hope to bring together a disparate group, some of whom usually find themselves on opposing sides -- such as homebuilders and environmentalists. 
 It is a discussion that many call long overdue, but one that is touchy in a state that has swept forcefully out of economic doldrums with some $28 billion in industrial construction since 1995.
"The first thing we have to do is identify sprawl as a problem," said Kit Smith, a Richland County Councilwoman who has pushed for land use planning in her county, which includes Columbia, the state capital. "There is such a dichotomy in this state of rural and growth areas."
The pressures of development versus preservation are being felt elsewhere in the country as well. A study released earlier this month by the federal Department of Agriculture showed that 16 million acres of the nation's farmland, forests and open space had been developed from 1992 to 1997. And six of the 10 states that gobbled up most of the open space were in the South.
South Carolina ranked ninth with 539,700 acres, more than double the annual conversion rate of the previous 10 years. Texas was No. 1; Pennsylvania, No. 2; Georgia, No. 3, Florida, No. 4, and California, No. 6.
"We are one of the most wasteful states in the nation in terms of land," said Dana Beach, director of the nonprofit South Carolina Coastal Conservation League, based in Charleston, which researches and promotes coastal preservation.
But, said John Cone, director of the Homebuilders Association of South Carolina, "the fact is we still have huge, huge, huge amounts of open space in the state." For example, he said, the Agriculture Department found that the amount of farmland had remained the same over the five-year period its report covered.
Nearly 13 percent of this state, generally considered to be a rural and agricultural, has been developed, the agriculture agency's study showed. But that pales in comparison to highly developed industrial states such as New Jersey, with 41 percent of the land mass developed, or Massachusetts, with 32 percent.
The state's primary growth areas surround its biggest cities -- Charleston near the coast, Columbia in the central section and Greenville in the northwest, near the Blue Ridge Mountains. Myrtle Beach, a vacation resort area along the state's northern Atlantic coast, has seen tremendous growth as well, primarily in hotels and second-home resorts.
Another prominent growth spot has been York County, just south of fast-growing Charlotte, N.C. But York County, planners say, has jumped ahead of other areas in recognizing they are losing their cultural heritage.
Its County Council created York County Forever, a commission designed to protect one acre of land for every acre developed. The goal is 10,000 acres in five years. The county set aside $357,000 for this year, the commission's first, to buy land and to pay for conservation easements in key areas -- riverfronts, farmland and open space.
Jeanne Ferguson, the chairman of the commission, said the group soon will have executed deals on 3,500 acres.
"It's important for our county to retain its character," Mrs. Ferguson said. "Southerners have a real affinity for the land."
Here in Greenville, 1,018 subdivisions with 28,543 homes have been approved for construction in the last nine years, according to the Greenville County Planning Commission. The growth pattern here mimics the pattern that changed the nation's urban centers decades earlier, with the first subdivisions ringing the central city and then, as the houses aged and more people moved in, developers moved farther out.
Nearly 60,000 people moved into this county in the last decade, pushing the population to about 380,000, while the population of the city of Greenville remained virtually the same, planning commission records show.
"Numberwise, we are the fastest growing county in South Carolina," said David Montgomery, the economic demographics planner for the planning commission.
F. James Forbes, director of the Greenville County Planning Commission, said the county was trying to steer developers toward urban centers, rather than outlying areas, without much success so far.
Homebuilders, especially national companies, have gravitated toward the southern part of the county, which has no zoning. The only approval needed there is by the planning commission, which must make sure the infrastructure can handle development.
Only about half of Greenville County is zoned, while some high-growth counties such as Cherokee, along Interstate 85, the busy link between Charlotte and Atlanta, have no zoning at all. But, said Mr. Cone of the homebuilders' group, as public officials develop regulations they must remember that the market is what drives the developers' business. "People have decided they want to have a little piece of land with grass and trees and a couple of cars," he said. "That's the way the South is."
Sprawl has brought South Carolina's governments big-city problems, Ms. Smith said, such as traffic, water pollution and budgets spread thin to provide police, school, sewer and water service to outlying areas.
"We raise taxes every year in Richland County," she said. "When you build way out, it's the most expensive place to deliver services. There is always a social cost, an environmental cost and a financial cost to development."
Her county has begun to require developers to consider not only what they are going to put on their own land, but how development relates to the community as a whole. Often, she said, subdivisions are built beside a newly built and academically successful school without direct and easy access to it.
She would like to see communities where residents can walk to school and stores, even to their work. In addition, she said, agencies must coordinate planning of land use, road building, school construction and sewer and water line extensions.
"There is still this myth that large lots protect the rural landscape," she said. "They don't. They churn it up."
Moreover, Ms. Smith said, small changes add up. Old-fashioned grid designs for roads, rather than the disconnected subdivision thoroughfares, she said, give drivers more choices and thus cut down traffic on individual roads.
She said that she had talked with Inez Tenenbaum, the state's Superintendent of Education, about rewriting regulations that now require 25 acres for each school and prohibit two-story buildings. Such regulations bar putting schools on a smaller piece of property when necessary, said Ms. Smith.
"More and more sprawl has taken place because there hasn't been redevelopment of urban areas," said Dan Glickman, the federal Secretary of Agriculture, shortly after his agency's study was issued. People are moving farther and farther out because they are looking for green spaces, he added.
"It's primarily a local and state issue," he said. But, he added, he wants to reorient the nation's farm policy away from a commodity-driven approach and toward conservation.
Saying he considered his agency's report a "wake-up call," he noted that 70 percent of the nation's land was in private hands. The value of open space and farmland, he added, is "not for some anachronistic purpose."
"This is about how you want to grow," said Ms. Smith. "What will attract industry is good neighborhoods and good quality of life. We still have a chance to do it right in South Carolina."

HEADLINE: A Sharper Eye for the State's History

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN 

 BODY:
THE road signs that guide visitors in the new permanent exhibition at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford -- called "Tours and Detours Through Early Connecticut -- symbolize one of the show's major goals: to make connections between past and present. Designed in the familiar style of current road signs, they carry images of long ago, such as a wigwam or a Colonial house, as well as logos that still apply today, like a boat launching or a deer-crossing symbol.
The multi-layered exhibition, which received financial support from the state's Department of Economic and Community Development and the Connecticut Humanities Council as well as corporate and private sources, is designed to appeal to families and school groups. It offers lively visual displays and hands-on activities like crafts and puzzles alongside treasures from the society's collection -- portraits, manuscripts, original documents and antique furniture that will engage the adults in the group. 
 "The word tours in the show's title refers to the actual road that is marked into the floor of the exhibition galleries, leading the visitor on a chronological journey that begins in the early 1600's and ends in the late 1700's," said Kate Steinway, the society's director of exhibitions. "Detours implies that history is not clear or linear, and we take detours down various paths to learn, for example, what home life was like in a Colonial household or what role slavery and indentured servitude played in early Connecticut."
At the start of the show, visitors can choose the path of American Indians, to discover how the earliest inhabitants lived and learn the origins of the names they gave places, or the path that explores what life was like for the newly arrived Europeans as they struggled to establish a foothold in what was for them a hostile and dangerous land.
The two paths came together shortly after the start of European settlement, as Colonists brought new materials, products and ideas that forever altered the native Americans' way of life.
A table-top puzzle map of Connecticut about 1640 enables visitors to understand how both ative people and new settlers adapted the land to suit their needs. By lifting up the puzzle pieces that show fruit trees planted by English colonists, for example, or the pieces that depict animals such as deer and beaver, visitors can learn more about which foods and materials were indigenous and which imported.
The exhibition explains the differences in value systems and how misunderstandings soon led to open conflict, with episodes of attacks, enslavement and captive taking, culminating in the Pequot War in 1637 and King Philip's War, in 1675 and 1676.
Among the period weapons on display is an English sword used in the Pequot War and a American Indian war club. And an engraving printed in London in 1638 depicts an Indian fort in New England under siege.
In a recording of contemporary people reading from primary sources, as well as in quotations from letters and books, settlers and natives talk about each other: "Please remember that all the words of the Natives were written down by the English and not by the Natives themselves," cautions the label, careful, as is all the exhibition's text, to avoid stereotypes.
The tour describes the unfolding of the state's early history as outposts gave way to small communities.
A mural showing a typical Connecticut landscape has been made into a large magnet board, and visitors are encouraged to select from a variety of magnetized emblems of structures -- houses, barns, churches, mills, stone walls and cemeteries -- to create a Connecticut community of the 1700's.
The home as residence, as place of work and as hospital is the focus of the section entitled Colonial Lives. The role of women in running the home and farm is emphasized as well as the presence of slaves.
Objects made in 18th-century Connecticut are on display: a high chest of drawers from Colchester, a spinning wheel, a cattle yoke, a candle stand crafted in Hartford and a child's potty chair made of red maple (the last item a favorite among younger viewers).
Visitors, surrounded by reproductions of samplers, are urged to try their hand at embroidery, using plastic colored thread on a white plastic grid, and also at making moccasins, a traditional Indian craft.
Perhaps the most popular exhibit is a replica of a Colonial farmhouse, where children can try on reproductions of period clothing -- petticoats, corsets and aprons as well as breeches and waistcoats -- and can pretend to cook and eat a Colonial-style dinner.
The section on the Revolutionary War highlights the conflict many Colonists felt in choosing sides. After pondering some of the issues that divided those remaining loyal to England ("Loyalists") and those in favor of self government ("Patriots"), visitors are asked to vote for or against English rule.
"Press a Button to Start the Revolution" reads a signpost. Well, not quite, but visitors can hear recorded voices reading first-person accounts of Revolutionary War experiences, including the tale of 22-year-old Deborah Champion of Colchester, who rode on horseback through enemy lines to Boston to take papers to Gen. George Washington and was praised by him for her courage.
A handsome red wool cloak said to have been worn by Champion on her historic mission is on display, along with other Revolutionary era objects such as a powder horn belonging to a soldier from Wethersfield, a dress sword owned by Gen. Israel Putnam of Pomfret and a small swivel cannon made at the Salisbury iron works about 1777.
The iron furnaces of northwestern Connecticut churned out cannons, cannonballs, bullets, bayonets and guns for the Continental army, while shipyards along the Connecticut River built and outfitted vessels that plundered British ships. Their output, combined with a large-scale home effort to produce food and clothing for the soldiers, made a vast contribution to the Revolutionary cause and earned Connecticut the designation of Provision State.
No exhibition devoted to Colonial Connecticut could ignore the topic of the Charter Oak -- the true story of the charter granted by England to the colony in 1662 and the myth that grew around its disappearance 25 years later, when a new king attempted to repeal it because it granted Connecticut an unusual measure of self-government.
Legend has it that an early Revolutionary War sympathizer hid the charter in the hollow of a large oak tree that stood in Hartford. For almost two centuries, the old tree was venerated as an icon, and when a storm felled it in 1856, its wood was made into innumerable souvenirs, large and small, some of which found their way into the collections of the historical society. On view are chess pieces, a pitcher, beads, a goblet, jewelry made by Tiffany and Company, as well as a tall clock made in Hartford in the 1870's.
A reproduction of the charter is on hand to recall this episode, and young visitors are urged to celebrate the independent spirit of Connecticut Olonists by hiding it in a hole of a make-believe tree.
The Connecticut Historical Society (1 Elizabeth Street, Hartford; 860-236-5621) is open Tuesday through Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Admission is $6, $3 for people 60 and over and students, free for children under 6.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
New Sports Promoter

 BODY:
County Executive Andrew J. Spano has appointed a Mount Kisco lawyer and sports agent, David J. Meiselman, as chairman of a commission for sports and entertainment.
In his new role, Mr. Meiselman will focus on promoting Westchester for sporting events and franchises. In addition to being a lawyer, Mr. Meiselman is chairman and chief executive officer of the Star Management Group, which represents professional athletes and entertainers in contract negotiations, endorsements and appearances, money management and charitable and foundation work. The National Football League Players Association has recognized Mr. Meiselman as a certified player representative. 
 Mr. Spano, who will not be paying Mr. Meiselman for his services, praised the commission "as an economic development idea" that could mean new income sources for the county.
Mr. Meiselman, a senior partner in the law firm of Meiselman, Farber, Packman & Eberz, said he would begin his duties by forming an advisory board of athletes and entertainers who live in Westchester.
In the last 25 years, his firm has represented clients like Mobil Oil, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, International Paper, the Hartford Insurance Company, Fisher-Price, Union Carbide and the New York State Medical Society.
