HEADLINE: Correcting the Record On Westchester History

 BODY:
Regarding the article "A Village Here, a Village There. But Why?" Special Issue: The Best of Westchester, Nov. 21 it would be nice to think that in today's quaint-looking villages, civic pride and the desire to stay out of New York City had inspired the formation of Westchester's many villages. But the historical record simply does not bear this out. In fact, Westchester lost the entire southern portion to New York City without protest. We ended up today with 17 towns, 22 villages, 6 cities, 90 hamlets, 59 fire districts, 40 school districts and a tangle of other districts for other reasons entirely.
After the Revolution, the Westchester countryside was wrecked. Main roads were largely impassable much of the year. The state carved the county into 21 towns (county government was weak) and gave them some powers, but not all. Then as now, towns cannot provide fire protection (only indirectly through fire districts). Poor police and fire protection and terrible roads were the primary reasons for the large number of incorporations for much of the 19th century. The first to incorporate (Ossining in 1813, Peekskill in 1816) were far from New York City. When the railroads brought people -- and more fires -- incorporations increased. When annexation was an issue it was local, not New York City (Tarrytown's incorporation swiped the most valuable land in Irvington). 
 Consider the difference between incorporation in the towns of Yonkers and Greenburgh. Part of the town of Yonkers became a village in 1855. By 1872, village services were so much better there that town residents voted to become a city. The town ceased to exist. In contrast, services were so poor throughout the town of Greenburgh that almost all the communities incorporated into separate villages. (The hamlet of Hartsdale was the exception.)
The writer of your article, Marilyn Wood Hill, attributes the spate of incorporations circa 1874 to a strong desire to avoid being annexed to New York City. This is simply not the case. In 1874, the whole of Westchester voted on a plan to annex what is now the northern half of the Bronx. Residents of the areas under consideration voted 4,230 for being annexed, 109 against. In the rest of Westchester, 9,023 voted for the plan and 2,643 against. By 1894 when an advisory vote was held for further annexation, word got out that the people annexed in 1874 were pleased with the city's far superior provision of services. This time, the vote in areas under consideration was split, with annexation having a slight edge in most places.
I found no evidence that villages incorporated in 1874 in order to prevent being annexed. In fact, they were finally able to incorporate because of a significant change in state law in 1874: people no longer had to petition the State Legislature for the right to incorporate. Instead, 300 citizens living within a certain number of square miles could petition and hold an election. And the state's Village Law empowered them to raise money to pay for services.
Walter Law, developer of Briarcliff Manor, enlarged his original plan in order to have the critical mass needed to become a village.
The article focused on Bronxville, which is surely the most singular exception in Westchester, being a village which successfully excluded people of certain economic and ethnic origins.
In the rest of the county, I believe that civic pride grew slowly and in the early days centered on the successful provision of services like free libraries, fire departments and schools. Indeed, much of the squabbling over boundaries in this century has been over who pays for what, and how well it is provided. Home rule is Westchester's most sacred cow and evidence of the expense to which citizens will go to have an identity that is distinct from one's neighbors.
Unfortunately, it has led to such massive lack of enforceable regional planning that our worst problems today are, once again, roads and schools.
 
KAROLYN WRIGHTSON
Hastings-on-Hudson
 
The writer is a former executive director of the Westchester County Historical Society and for seven years contributed a weekly column on local history to the Gannett Suburban Newspapers. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Not Enough Substitutes? Productive Teachers Needed

 BODY:
I read with interest, but no surprise, the Nov. 28 article "Not Enough Substitute Teachers to Go Around," about the grave shortage of substitute teachers. It's no surprise. It has been that way for years.
One thing your article did not mention is the number of personal days off teachers are contractually entitled to in the districts. In the Katohah-Lewisboro district it has been 24 per year. This is in addition to leave for other reasons. It seems that teachers are absent more than people who work for private industry, where this level of absenteeism would never be tolerated. In fact, most Americans are now working longer hours and more days per year than their counterparts in any other industrialized country, a major contributing factor to American high productivity and booming economy. 
 With the focus on improving education, getting teachers to stay in the classroom might be a good place to start. Considering the various and many causes for disruption to educational time like staff development, which usually results in early dismissals, parent conferences (also early dismissal) and the excess of other noneducational activities that occupy schools, it is no surprise that we're faced with the disaster that is public education. To get our educational engines fired up, again, we might have to take a lesson from business and increase teacher productivity, to the benefit of students.
 
ROSE M. RAIMONDO
South Salem

HEADLINE: A Firm Foundation, Starting at the Roof

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
WHAT does a house of worship need every bit as much as pulpit and pews or altar and tabernacle, ark and bima, minaret and mihrab? What architectural element rivals such liturgical features in importance?
A roof in good repair. 
 Without a solid roof, bells are silenced, stained glass buckles, murals peel away and ornamental plaster domes collapse.
By the very nature of the structure -- an enormous volume spanned by a complex roof -- a religious sanctuary is terribly vulnerable to damage from above. The loss of its roof in a fire 16 months ago forced Central Synagogue in mid-Manhattan out of its landmark home until 2001. It has used the occasion to undertake a thorough $38 million renovation and restoration.
Its new roof is now in place. Henry Fernbach, who designed the synagogue in 1872, would feel right at home in the rafters because the structure is framed entirely in timber. The columns and beams of Douglas fir are massive, up to 20 feet long and 12 inches across.
Why build a roof of wood when the last one burned down? "It actually performs better than steel," said Jonathan Schloss of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, architects of the renovation. Steel would have buckled under the heat, he said, but only one of the original timber roof trusses failed during the blaze.
Fire is one potent enemy. Water is the other.
The Brooklyn Tabernacle had to worry first about fixing the leaking roof of the former Loew's Metropolitan Theater downtown, which it plans to renovate as a 3,600-seat sanctuary and church complex. A 13-year project to restore the Eldridge Street Synagogue on the Lower East Side can only now begin in earnest, following the completion in May of a new roof and skylights.
"An incredible amount of what we pay for is water protection -- roofs, drain pipes, internal leaders," said Peg Breen, president of the private New York Landmarks Conservancy, which has made grants and loans of more than $4 million to religious properties through its Sacred Sites program.
Many houses of worship have recently undertaken or are planning roof projects, including the Church of the Virgin Mary, the Russian Orthodox Cathedral of the Transfiguration of Our Lord and St. John's Lutheran Church in Brooklyn; the Fordham University Chapel and Riverdale Presbyterian Church in the Bronx; Congregation Orach Chaim and the Little Church Around the Corner in Manhattan and the Woodrow United Methodist Church on Staten Island.
I T'S the toughest thing for a congregation to raise money for," Ms. Breen said. "A family might want its name on a stained-glass window. But no one wants their name on a drainpipe."
And because they are wary of financing sectarian missions or breaching the church-and-state wall, few government agencies or private philanthropies support the preservation of religious landmarks.
Ms. Breen said raising money for the sacred sites program "is the hardest sell we have, and the need increases every year."
So she welcomed as a "fabulous new vehicle" the $4 million preservation fund set up by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation to make grants and loans for historic buildings in Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood. The conservancy administers the fund.
Earlier this month, contracts were signed for the first grants. St. Martin's Episcopal Church at Lenox Avenue and 122nd Street and the Ebenezer Gospel Tabernacle, Christian Mission, at Lenox Avenue and 121st Street are each to receive $100,000.
News of the grants was greeted warmly by Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the city Landmarks Preservation Commission. "One of my biggest frustrations is that we're precluded, as a government agency, from offering financial support," she said. "It was a very big mission of mine to get money for Harlem churches."
St. Martin's has also applied for a grant from New York State, which makes money available for historic preservation projects from the Environmental Protection Fund and Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act.
"I have a personal passion for the sacred sites issue," said Bernadette Castro, commissioner of the state Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. "I think they are very important -- if they qualify -- as significant pieces of architecture that in many cases are the focal point of a community, be it a Main Street or be it Manhattan."
Eligible properties are those listed on both the state and federal registers of historic places. They must be owned by nonprofit organizations -- an easy hurdle for most congregations to clear. The work that the state will fund is limited to exteriors.
For St. Martin's, the money could not come soon enough. It has already had to cover some of the copper sheathing on its magnificent bell tower with temporary plywood siding. In the voluminous sanctuary, ragged courses of spalling plaster and flaking paint testify to water damage.
"We've always operated on the principle of being a self-supporting church," said the Rev. David Johnson, the rector emeritus. "But the reality of expenses today -- it will probably cost $75,000 to $100,000 just for scaffolding." The first phase of repair and stabilization might reach $500,000; a daunting sum for a congregation that is still vital but smaller and grayer than it once was.
It may seem a stretch for the empowerment zone corporation to play angel, especially when its purpose is to spur business and create jobs, using $300 million in Federal, state and city money. But the agency sees historic buildings as catalysts in economic development, as they bring visitors -- and visitors' dollars -- uptown.
"Many, many people come up to visit, to hear gospel services and to enjoy the architecture of these splendid, unrivaled jewels," said Alex Saavedra, director of planning and historic preservation for the empowerment zone. "St. Martin's has one of only two carillons in New York City. That's something visitors would love to come see." (The other carillon is in Riverside Church.)
St. Martin's, originally known as Holy Trinity, was completed in 1888 to designs by William A. Potter. As an example of the robust Romanesque Revival style associated with Henry Hobson Richardson, it has few rivals, if any, in New York City.
In 1928, the Rev. John Howard Johnson founded the St. Martin's congregation, which eventually took over the Holy Trinity buildings and was made an independent parish. One of his sons, David, was the rector from 1961 until this year. Another, the Rev. Johan Johnson, is the current rector.
Although Father David Johnson is nominally retired, he can still climb nimbly up the open staircase to the tower and swing the bells, one of which weighs 3,100 pounds and is 53 inches across, sending the sound booming out across Harlem.
Cast by the Van Bergen foundry in the Netherlands, the carillon was dedicated exactly 50 years ago this month. And it will be rung at midnight on Friday to mark the millennium. The 42 bells are in good order, Father Johnson said, but the clavier -- a keyboard the size of an upright piano with five-inch wooden levers -- must be replaced. There is no point, however, in fixing the carillon until the tower structure and the roof overhead are secure.
Father Johnson refers to the carillon as the "poor people's bells," since its $45,000 cost (roughly $350,000 today) was met by the congregation. It is one of his tenets that "beauty should not be the exclusive preserve of the wealthy."
Roberta Brandes Gratz makes the same point as she sits in the women's gallery of the Eldridge Street Synagogue and conjures images of a congregation that lived in tenements and labored in sweatshops.
"There was no place in their lives that there was a real refuge until they came into this building," she said. "This is one place where you could feel valued."
Ms. Gratz is the founder of the nonprofit Eldridge Street Project, incorporated in 1986 to restore the synagogue used by Congregation Khal Adath Jeshurun with Anshe Lubtz, which had trouble for many years raising a minyan -- much less millions of dollars to rebuild its landmark home, between Canal and Division Streets.
Completed in 1887, the synagogue offered incomparable visual riches to worshippers: rose windows and horseshoe arches, cusps and finials, brass and walnut and stained glass, a velvet-lined ark with room for 24 Torah scrolls. But the main sanctuary exceeded the needs of the congregation long ago, and services are now held in a modest basement sanctuary.
One great challenge faced by the restoration architects, Beyer Blinder Belle, will be to avoid making the place look as good as new. "It's the current frontier of restoration artistry," Ms. Gratz said. "How do you restore without losing the patina of time?"
For now, there is patina to spare. The sanctuary appears at first glance to be more ragged today than when restoration began. "There was so much water penetration that it took a couple of years for all of the plaster to fall off," Ms. Gratz explained.
And ornaments like the grand chandelier have been removed. "I used to say it was held up by a string to God," Ms. Gratz said, since it was hard to see how else it was supported by the fragile structure.
Meanwhile, work that is largely invisible to an untrained eye has prepared the building for more aesthetic improvements.
MOST important was repointing the brick facade and installing a new slate roof, with skylights, this year. "They didn't tell me until after it was done that bricks were crumbling in their hands," Ms. Gratz said. "Even I didn't appreciate how tenuous this building was."
"Now with the roof and exterior walls, this building can stand another 100 years, even without a heating system," she said.
The project has raised and spent $3 million to date for restoration and stabilization work, and an almost equal amount for educational and cultural programs, said Amy E. Waterman, the executive director. It hopes to raise $8 million more, to complete the restoration and establish an endowment.
At Central Synagogue, paradoxically, it was an earlier renovation project that cost its roof. The fire was apparently started by a worker's blowtorch during the installation of an air-conditioning system in the rooftop.
For "about a minute" after the fire, there was thought of razing the gutted building at Lexington Avenue and 55th Street and starting anew, said the senior rabbi, Peter J. Rubinstein. That was quickly replaced by a resolve not just to rebuild but to alter the building to meet contemporary needs.
"We had already been wrestling with issues of space, sound, lighting and configuration," Rabbi Rubinstein said. "Although we would not have chosen the means by which this was done, there are very few times in American religious history that a congregation has the opportunity to retrofit a cathedral-type building. As awful as it was, the fire gave us this opportunity."
Central was completed in 1872 and is the oldest building in continuous use as a synagogue in New York. Its almost fragrantly complex blend of Moorish and Victorian styles went in and out of favor over the years, and was gradually toned down.
"It doesn't have its full panoply of powers," said Hugh Hardy, architect of the renovation. "We want to see that restored."
That means reviving the dazzling, lacy stencilwork, adding chandeliers in the cusps of the horseshoe arches along the balcony and sconces under the balcony. "When you have multiple sources of light, the whole place will shimmer," Mr. Hardy said.
In place of the metal sheets that covered the old roof, black and red slate will be laid in geometric patterns. Decorative cresting will be restored to the parapets and the copper globes atop the twin towers will be highlighted in gold leaf.
"Putting architectural accouterments back is putting people back in touch with their history," Rabbi Rubinstein said.
Some of the historic fabric will be changed, however. The existing front steps are each about two inches higher than would be customary today. That steep cascade spilling down to Lexington Avenue could be quite intimidating when a crush of people spilled from the sanctuary after services.
So shallower steps are to be installed. As a result, the entire front lobby will have to be lowered 13 1/2 inches and the doorways will have to be enlarged to meet the new staircase. Two steps will also be removed within the lobby. The distance will be made up with a new four-step rise within the sanctuary.
SOME preservationists worry that the renovation may be going too far. "Each alteration initiates a sequence of related changes that in total will seriously compromise the design of this 127-year-old landmark," said Joy Kestenbaum, an architectural historian who has studied the work of Mr. Fernbach.
But the landmarks commission approved the plans. "You could see it as a change that was necessary and appropriate to the architecture," Ms. Raab said, "coupled with incredible resources that are being poured into restoration."
Rabbi Rubinstein said the synagogue was more than halfway toward its fundraising goal. "I believe we're bringing back an architectural anchor," he said. "I believe it will be a light in what has become a cavernous enclosure. As people go to work, just a visual connection with this building will provide a spiritual balance in life."
The Brooklyn Tabernacle sounds a similar theme in its plan for a $37 million "campus" designed by Kapell & Kostow and centered on the 81-year-old Metropolitan Theater, one block from Macy's on the Fulton Street mall. The facade of the theater and two adjoining buildings will be reclad in brick and limestone and a bell tower will be added at the corner of Livingston and Gallatin Streets, rising 115 feet.
"Just as the Lord is our lighthouse," the Tabernacle declares on its Web site, "we pray that this new campus will act as a lighthouse to the lost and needy."
Loew's Metropolitan was built in 1918 in the shell of an old dry-goods store. It was designed by Thomas W. Lamb, arguably the foremost theatrical architect of his day, and is lush with ornamentation, including medallions and cameo-like reliefs with crouching sphinxes and gamboling sprites.
With the removal of interior walls that had divided the theater into a quad, the astonishing enormity of the auditorium is once again apparent. Its deep balcony seems to sweep halfway across downtown.
And the tabernacle can use the space. Its nationally renowned choir has more people -- 250 -- than many congregations. All told, it counts 10,000 members and has long since outgrown the 1,400-seat former Carlton Theater at Flatbush and Seventh Avenues, which was remodeled as a sanctuary 20 years ago by Maurice Wasserman, now a principal at Kapell & Kostow.
At the Metropolitan, the stage must be expanded, with risers for the choir and a sunken orchestra pit. New lighting and sound systems will be installed, as well as audio and video recording equipment.
But as much of Mr. Lamb's architectural detail will be preserved as possible, said Michael Kostow, using original drawings from the Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library at Columbia University.
"The tabernacle, from day one, was 100 percent behind restoring the interior," Mr. Kostow said. "It was important for them to give something back to Brooklyn."

HEADLINE: One Person's Frivolities Are Another's Enrichment

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In response to Francis Filardo's letter last Sunday, which included band and chorus in a list of "frivolities" that take time and energy away from "serious" studies in school, I couldn't disagree more vehemently. Music is a serious discipline, and all students should have the opportunity to explore their talents and interests in that area. This is especially so if they come from educationally and economically deprived families that wouldn't otherwise expose them to the arts. In fact, I'd say that any experience that gives students a view of the wider world will enrich them and provide them with the resources helpful in choosing a fulfilling path in life. 
 I did learn how to read and write in school, and struggled through accelerated math for no good reason that I can tell. Today, I earn a living as a graphic designer. I'm also a performing musician, and have earned a few paychecks from writing as well.
One of my biggest regrets from my high school years is that I was unable to take chorus as well as art; there weren't enough elective slots.
 
LIZ PAGAN
Bloomfield

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Governor Leads the Charge Against Taxing the Internet

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TO listen to Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, a conservative, tax-cutting Republican, the escalating debate over whether to make the Internet a permanently tax-free shopping zone is no contest.
He brushed aside concerns that state and local sales tax revenue would dry up as shoppers fled the malls for the Web. He suggested that traditional retailers should stop whining about unfair competition from the Internet and start viewing the technology as an opportunity to build new markets. And he said the best economic strategy is to nurture the potential of the Web to preserve the competitive advantage that is the basis of the America's current prosperity. 
 "I don't have the slightest interest in destroying the tax base of cities, states and counties," Mr. Gilmore said in an interview. "But there is an interesting philosophical debate going on here. Some politicians are basically saying that you have to have fairness and a level playing field. Since we're going to have a sales tax, we have to apply it to the Internet."
That, Mr. Gilmore said, is precisely the wrong approach.
"Government is entitled to the revenue it needs to provide services, but it is not entitled to reach into new areas to get revenues it doesn't need," he said. "Government is not entitled to a taxation windfall just because a new industry has emerged."
If there were any doubts that the Internet is reshaping the economy in fundamental and far-reaching ways, they were dispelled this year, as dot-com stocks drove Wall Street, as the stodgiest of corporations embraced the power of the Web and as technology-driven enhancements in business efficiency startled Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve.
But economic policy makers are only beginning to respond, and the political parties are just starting to recognize the potency of technology-related issues.
No issue has had a higher profile in recent months than tax-free cybershopping, a perk (or quirk) of electronic commerce that millions of consumers enjoyed for the first time this holiday shopping season. Online shoppers usually must pay for shipping, but rarely pay any sales tax on goods bought from companies that do not have physical presence, like a store or a warehouse, in the state where they live.
The issue has come up regularly in the presidential campaign. Both Al Gore and George W. Bush have said they favor extending the current moratorium on Internet taxation while the matter is studied, but are concerned about the fallout for state finances and traditional retailers. Most of Mr. Bush's Republican rivals want to make the moratorium permanent.
It is a tough issue, raising questions of fairness and ideology without providing much middle ground on which a compromise can be built, and there are passionate voices on both sides.
But no one argues the case against Internet taxation more vociferously or with greater certitude than Mr. Gilmore. He has built his political identity on tax cutting, and the state he governs is home to one of the most successful technology corridors outside California, with America Online among his many Internet-dependent constituents.
Mr. Gilmore was chosen by Republican leaders in Congress to be chairman of a national commission studying the issue. Its latest meeting, this month in San Francisco, reached a deadlock between members who think applying sales tax to electronic transactions is both proper and technically feasible and those, like Mr. Gilmore, who think it would be a mistake and would anyway be too complicated to enforce.
FOR starters, Mr. Gilmore said, there is no sign that online sales are coming at the expense of traditional retailers or are eating into state and local tax revenues.
"The statistical data will have to come later," he said. "But at this point you only have to look into the stores and the malls and ask, 'How's business?' Business is booming. There is no evidence I can see that sales tax revenue is down or that commerce in traditional bricks-and-mortar retailing is down."
The governor's message to traditional retailers, especially local stores, is to stop fighting the Internet and embrace it: "It's wonderful for small business. It's a dynamic development that gives small-business people the ability to broaden their bases and compete with big business."
Mr. Gilmore acknowledged the importance of ensuring Internet access for the poor, so online commerce and its benefits will not flow only to those who can afford computers and monthly service fees.
His bottom line is that because no one can foresee precisely how electronic commerce will develop or what its economic effects will be, the best policy is to bar the door to Internet sales taxes. But that same uncertainty might equally argue for a more flexible approach, one that does not prejudge where technology will drive an economy now changing in ways no one yet fully grasps. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Company Worth More Than Spain?

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Crazy markets call for wacky stock valuation methods. Forget price-to-sales ratios; why not rank stocks based on the gross domestic products of the world's nations?
G.D.P., to be sure, is the yearly output of goods and services of a country, while market value, a company's total worth, changes daily. Moreover, G.D.P. cannot capture all that is generated in the information age. 
 But with stocks so high, it is a telling exercise. "These stocks have become like major land masses," Theodore Aronson, principal of Aronson & Partners in Philadelphia. "There's nothing to compare them to anymore. It's price to fantasy."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE/EAST VILLAGE;
A Room of Their Own: Girls Club Seeks a City-Owned Site

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
Ten-year-old Amanda Wright mingled on the steps of City Hall last week with a dozen of her friends.
The group, members of the Lower Eastside Girls Club, had just presented more than 3,500 postcards signed by parents and neighbors to a representative of the mayor's office, asking Mayor Giuliani to let the group buy a vacant city-owned lot on Avenue D between Seventh and Eighth Streets, to build a place for their club. 
 The club was founded in 1995 as a place where "girls can develop confidence in themselves." It offers an after-school tutoring program, a baking company that serves as an entrepreneurial training program, and a book club, among other activities.
Why does the club, which serves 150 girls between 8 and 18 each week, need its own building? Amanda and her friends answered promptly.
"There are a lot of girls who want to be in the Girls Club, but they can't, because there is no room," said Amanda, who joined the group in September.
Tania Hernandez, 14, who has been a club member for more than three years, said they needed more space for basketball and swimming.
Antoinette Valentin, 10, agreed. "We need more space for more girls and more room for our activities," she said.
Those activities are now held "in schools and community centers and churches, in other people's space," said Lyn Pentecost, the executive director and a club founder.
In remarks outside City Hall, Ms. Pentecost said Community Board 3 recommended a year ago that the lot be given to the club. "Why is it taking so long?" she asked.
Ms. Pentecost said she had spent two years talking with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development about other vacant lots in the neighborhood. When the girls' club found the Avenue D site, Ms. Pentecost said, the housing agency referred her to the city's Economic Development Corporation.
"We've been working with the girls club since October," said Janel Patterson, a spokeswoman for the agency. "We received an incomplete proposal two weeks ago and have requested additional information."
Ms. Pentecost said she submitted a detailed explanation, and feared that the corporation, which must decide whether to sell the land, would keep seeking more information "for the next 10 years."
The club raises money through public and private grants and community fund-raising activities. It has financing for two connected buildings: a three-story structure on East Eighth Street and a seven-story one on Avenue D. That building would also include retail shops on the first floor as well as office space and rooms for other organizations.
With a new building, the club will be able to serve more than 1,000 girls, Ms. Pentecost said.
 ERIC V. COPAGE

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Among New York Centenarians, a Few Factories

BYLINE: By REBECCA COONEY 

 BODY:
FOR the last two centuries, New York has been a home to industry. From sugar refining to candy making, from printing to the manufacture of musical instruments, clothing, pharmaceuticals, paints, barrels and tanks, industry has helped shape the city. Perhaps that was no surprise, given the city's wealth of immigrant labor, its port and the number of buyers.
For much of the 20th century, manufacturing has been on the decline in New York, as in other urban centers. Now, the city focuses on service and information. But reminders of the industrial past remain, businesses that have been making the same products for 100 years, even if the technology has changed. 
 Domino Sugar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is the last sugar refinery left. In the 1880's, there were seven operating on the Brooklyn waterfront. During the last half of the 19th century, New York was the national center of the printing industry; before World War I, there were hundreds of mom-and-pop engraving shops, specializing in stationery, business cards and stock certificates, said Jeffrey R. Van Zandt, the third-generation owner of Continental-Anchor Ltd., an engraving business in Long Island City, Queens.
But the advent of larger, more expensive presses that could handle greater volume, and diminished demand for fancy cards and stationery put many such firms out of business by the 1960's. Today there are just a handful. And while manufacturers of musical instruments were the city's fifth-biggest employer in the mid-19th century, according to The Encyclopedia of New York City, only one piano maker is left, Steinway & Sons.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: ROSENWACH TANK -- The barrel on the city's seal is a testament to the importance of cask making in New York's development. In 1896, the Rosenwach family bought a barrel-making company for $55. Rosenwach Tank, with factories in Williamsburg and Long Island City, still makes the wooden water tanks seen on the city's skyline. Computers and machine tools are used, but tanks are erected in virtually the same way as early in the century.; CONTINENTAL-ANCHOR --Founded in 1890 in Lower Manhattan, Continental specializes in engraved stationery and cards. In the 60's, it began buying up other engraving firms; it moved to Long Island City in 1994. Though Continental uses computers for its designs, it employs pressmen like Eugene Joseph, above, for the careful placing of paper in the presses.; FIBRE CASE AND NOVELTY -- Since 1894, Fibre Case and Novelty in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has been making cases for clothing for the garment industry, which has been a major force in the city's economy, thanks to its many immigrant workers. This third-generation business manufactures cases much the same way it has for more than a century, although now the material is plastic, not fiber. Above, Julio Aquilar rivets a case.; STEINWAY & SONS -- From 1860 to 1910, Steinway & Sons had a factory on Park Avenue between 52nd and 53rd Streets. Its factory on 19th Avenue and Steinway Place in Astoria, Queens, above, has been making pianos since 1871. In its special tuning room, Alexander Hernandez tunes a piano. (Photographs by Rebecca Cooney)

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volvo S40;
Will Young Americans Adopt a Baby Volvo?

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR 

 BODY:
THESE days, an automaker doesn't want to be caught offering a dull, me-too product in the heart of the market. The $25,000 price range is a predatory jungle inhabited by best sellers like the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord, American favorites like the Ford Taurus and Buick LeSabre and sporty imports like the BMW 323i and Audi A4 -- not to mention a battalion of minivans, well-regarded sedans like the Volkswagen Passat and Olds Intrigue and sporty coupes like the Toyota Celica.
Now there is also the Volvo S40, a compact sport sedan priced just below $25,000 that is aimed at the young buyers who have long eluded, or even ignored, Volvo. This will be a very tough market for the Swedish company to crack. If things aren't crowded enough now, Lexus and Jaguar have new small cars in the works. 
 Volvo, known for its extensive safety features, has generally catered to older buyers (average age, 45) who didn't mind trading a little flair in the styling department and a little sizzle under the hood for big, boxy, even boring designs. Big, boxy and boring aren't my words -- they rolled off the tongues of 20-to-35-year olds when Volvo asked them to describe its cars.
With the S40 sedan -- and a wagon version called the V40 -- Volvo is trying to attract younger buyers with a few coins jangling in their pockets. The auto marketers call this the "entry-level luxury market." In fact, it is a big-growth, high-profit business where every luxury brand worthy of its burled wood inserts and heated seats is trying to make a splash.
Volvo wants buyers who are under 35 and don't mind the limits of a smaller car, who want some European panache but might not have the cash for an Audi, BMW or a Saab, all of which can easily barrel through the $30,000 level.
The S40 and the V40 are the latest in a string of new models that Volvo has brought to the United States. By next fall, the auto maker -- which was bought by Ford this year -- will have completed a three-year overhaul of its entire American lineup. Last year, its most significant change was the S80, a new flagship sedan with front-wheel drive and nary a square corner on its skin.
The S40 echoes that look. With a nicely raked front end and a swooping rear roofline, this curvy little Volvo is attractive. It feels small inside, but the space is cleverly used. The rear seat is surprisingly roomy, for instance, thanks to a design trick: The rear seats are angled back more than usual to put extra space between the front and rear passengers and increase the headroom.
The S40 comes well-equipped, especially in comparison with the hot-selling BMW 323i, a car with a starting price $4,000 higher. On its base model, BMW skimps on touches that buyers have come to expect: front and rear armrests cost extra, the visors do not have lighted mirrors and the rear seat does not fold to add cargo space.
The S40, which is built in the Netherlands in a joint venture with Mitsubishi, comes with all those trimmings and more. While BMW offers a powerful 2.5-liter six-cylinder engine, Volvo uses a 1.9-liter in-line four that is turbocharged and intercooled to perk up acceleration. The engine certainly delivers reasonable pickup and handling for a sport sedan, but it does not have the power surge of BMW's six. Volvo has tried to reduce the lag time before the turbo kicks in, but I still noticed a slight hesitation before the car raced ahead.
With its balanced suspension, precise steering and firm ride, the BMW 3-Series has long served as the ride-and-handling benchmark for sport sedans. Volvo cannot match BMW in that respect, but it does not fall far off the mark. I did not feel as confident in the S40 on parkway cloverleafs and twisting country roads as I did in the BMW or, for that matter, in the Audi A4. The Swedes can still learn something from the Germans about suspensions and handling.
And Volvo might even consult its countrymen at Saab, whose 9-3 and 9-5 cars have the most impresive turbocharged four-cylinder engines I have yet encountered.
Volvo does excel in safety features; If you want to feel safer, you might consider an armored personnel carrier. There are two huge air bags in the dashboard and two in the sides of each front seat that provide extensive protection to heads and torsos. The passenger compartment has been substantially reinforced, in case of a rollover, and the side pillars and door beams were engineered to absorb the brunt of the impact if the car is struck from the side.
The headrests, though they don't offer much comfort in highway cruising, are supposed to provide elaborate whiplash protection if the car is struck from the rear.
For all the focus on safety, however, the S40 does not have a headrest in the center of the rear seat, something one finds on less expensive European cars like the Volkswagen Jetta. The S40 does have a three-point belt for the middle rear passenger.
There are also pockets in the backs of the front seats and small side pockets in the rear doors. The rear seat is split in a 70-30 configuration, and both parts flip down to swallow cargo that the trunk cannot contain. There was but one cup holder for the rear passengers (and just one more up front), and the rear windows did not fully retract.
But the biggest annoyance was the placement of the power window buttons on the center console, next to the mirror controls. With the armrest down, those buttons are difficult to reach. Time and again as I approached a toll booth, I groped for the window buttons and ended up moving the mirrors out of place or accidentally lowering the passenger window. Volvo says it has heard similar complaints and plans to redesign the center console on 2001 models.
Otherwise, the Volvo was cozy but comfortable. The seats delivered pleasant support and included adjustable lower-back support. Wind noise was minimal. The four-speed automatic transmission has three shift modes: sport, economy and winter. A five-speed manual transmission is not available, but Volvo says it is thinking of adding one. Sporting drivers can shift for themselves with the A4, 323i and Infiniti G20.
In a crowded field, the S40 certainly stood out for its safety and for its value. Compared with the three cars I drove for comparison's sake, the S40 was less expensive than the BMW and the Audi and not much more than the G20. As for the curse of being big, boxy and boring, Volvo has definitely overcome the first two. It is making progress on the third.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A starter Volvo for would-be Bimmer buyers.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
In Search of Frequent Gamblers

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
GARY W. LOVEMAN, chief operating officer of Harrah's Entertainment, thinks gamblers are promiscuous. "We have customers who play around with everybody," he says.
He is referring not to bedroom habits, but rather to gamblers' lack of loyalty to any particular casino company. Mr. Loveman, a former Harvard Business School professor, is trying to change that. If he succeeds, he will have created a new model for growth in the casino business. 
 Harrah's has invested more than $100 million in computers and software to develop what is widely regarded as the industry's most sophisticated "frequent bettor" program. Like airline frequent-flier plans, Harrah's "Total Rewards" program awards participants with perks -- in this case, rooms, meals and other benefits -- and bombards them with promotional mail.
The idea is to grow by getting more business from Harrah's existing casinos and customer base. That is in contrast to the strategy of other companies: building splashy new casinos.
"There is a huge margin for profitable growth without having to build ever more elaborate and sophisticated facilities," said Mr. Loveman, wearing a pullover shirt at Harrah's headquarters here, where everyone else seemed to be in suits. It is, he said, "the triumph of software over hardware in gaming."
So far, analysts say, the strategy is working. Harrah's and its chief executive, Philip G. Satre, have received praise from trade magazines.
Joseph V. Coccimiglio, an analyst with Prudential Securities, says Harrah's has had greater revenue growth in most markets than the industry as a whole, despite having casinos that are far from the fanciest. In the third quarter, he said, Harrah's grew nearly three times as fast as the overall market in Laughlin, Nev., and twice as fast in Atlantic City.
Even rivals have praise for the initiative. "Harrah's has done far better than anyone at that, and they've developed a brand in an industry that's brandless," said James J. Murren, chief financial officer of MGM Grand.
But Harry Curtis, an analyst at Robertson Stephens, cautioned that it was too early to tell how much of the success stemmed from Harrah's strategy and how much from the overall strength of the gambling business.
Mr. Loveman, 39, received his doctorate in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and became an assistant professor at the Harvard Business School, writing papers or books on topics from technology to Eastern European economic reform.
He also taught a popular course in the management of service companies. "That was his real obsession," said Thomas DeLong, a professor of management at Harvard. He said that it was not unusual for professors there to go into consulting or investment banking, but that gambling was a bit of a surprise.
Several years ago, Mr. Loveman taught a training course at the Promus Companies, predecessor to Harrah's. He was smitten by gambling -- as a business and as an academic challenge, though not as a pastime. "It's a data-rich industry," he said, "and analytically it's quite sophisticated," making it an ideal place to test his theories.
Mr. Loveman wrote an unsolicited letter to Mr. Satre offering ideas on how the company could grow. He was hired as a consultant. Later, in May 1998, though he had never held a full-time corporate job, Mr. Loveman was hired as chief operating officer.
Mr. Satre said an outsider was needed to carry out Harrah's marketing effort."If there's an analogy, it's Lou Gerstner going into I.B.M.," he said, referring to Mr. Gerstner's move from RJR Nabisco..
In 1997, Harrah's started its rewards program, in which customers are issued a card that they insert into slot machines and that keeps track of how much they gamble. Other casinos have similar programs, but Harrah's offers it on a national basis, with the points valid at any of its 19 casinos.
"This works because we have the broadest distribution of properties," Mr. Satre said. To expand its empire, Harrah's in the last two years has bought the Rio Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and the Showboat chain and has agreed to acquire Players International Inc.
In an industry that generally develops its talent internally, Mr. Loveman has hired data-mining and marketing experts from companies like American Express. New software has been developed that not only keeps track of how much customers gamble but predicts who might be induced to gamble more. Sixty-five percent of the gambling in the company's casinos is now done by its nine million card holders.
Officially on a two-year leave from Harvard that ends in June, Mr. Loveman spends weekends with his wife and three children at his home in Wellesley, Mass. But Mr. Loveman said that when his leave expires, he will resign from the ivory tower to stay at Harrah's. "It's been certainly the most exciting period of time I've had in my professional life," he said.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
A Blip, But With A Legacy

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN barely 50 years, we baby boomers have certainly made our mark on the current millennium. We have risen to political power and created a high-technology world that will shape the future. On the calendar, we have been but a blip in this millennium, but one that has made much noise. Who can dispute that boomers are on top now?
But as we celebrate on Friday, we should be aware that what dawns on Saturday will be the beginning of the end of baby-boomer dominance. It won't be our millennium; it won't even be our century. I suspect that when our great-grandchildren celebrate the arrival of 2100, the phrase baby boomer will have long gone out of the vocabulary. What exactly was a flapper, anyway? 
 So what will happen to boomers in the next century? We will soon know whether boomers were able to accomplish the basics, like saving enough for retirement and enough to send the baby boomlet through college, and some of us may learn whether it was wise to spend $1 million in the New York suburbs for a five-bedroom home on a quarter-acre lot. Will we really be retiring early, as many of us dream, or will we be hanging on until someone puts us out to pasture?
To get an idea of what is in store for us, I asked two experts, both of them baby boomers themselves: Edward N. Wolff, a professor of economics at New York University, who has long studied wealth and its effects, and Bambi Holzer, a senior vice president for investments at PaineWebber, who wrote "Retire Rich: The Baby Boomer's Guide to a Secure Future" (John Wiley & Sons, 1998).
Optimistic about their generation, both said boomers were likely to meet all their financial goals. Mr. Wolff said it would be a remarkable achievement, considering that boomers entered the work force when the economy was stagnant and that the sheer volume of workers kept wages low. And the money they did have, he said, they spent.
"This was the spendthrift generation 20 years ago, the generation that didn't save at all," he said. "Now they've accumulated a large amount of wealth. It will turn out that they did better than their parents because their parents were more conservative. Baby boomers have been much more adventurous."
Mr. Wolff said his research showed that in 1998, the average wealth of baby boomers 44 to 49 years old was about $245,000, more than 60 percent more than what their parents had at the same age, adjusted for inflation.
He and Ms. Holzer said one reason was that with the decline of traditional pensions, boomers had to take over saving for their retirement. That taught them how to invest.
"The baby boomer generation was the first do-it-yourself generation in investing," she said. "As a result of that education, our generation is aware of the investment process. It has been forecast that the 401(k) assets amassed by individuals will be greater than the value of their homes."
IF we're so smart, will we be smart enough to get out in time, before a market crash?
Mr. Wolff says yes, and he even thinks that we probably won't get stuck with overpriced houses. But it may not have anything to do with savvy. We will just become more conservative with money.
"I think what's going to happen is those close to retirement are going to buy retirement homes," he said. "Boomers will also begin to diversify more into bonds and liquid assets, such as CD's and Treasury bills. And they will pay off outstanding mortgages."
On retirement, Mr. Wolff and Ms. Holzer both predicted that boomers wouldn't keep it simple. "Boomers won't want a rocking-chair retirement," Ms. Holzer said.
Mr. Wolff said boomers did not identify with careers as their parents did and would gladly let go of the reins. They would then direct energies elsewhere.
"Baby boomers are more interested in personal fulfillment," he said. "They will be much more in tune with bettering themselves. I think they will still be a force politically and culturally and will contribute to the intellectual life of the country."
That's quite an assessment for a generation that had such a countercultural start. Boomers, Mr. Wolff said, will accomplish their goals "despite their gloomy beginning and the initial perception of the generation, much to our parents' surprise."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Rail Stocks: What's Beyond The Tunnel?

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A LITTLE over a century ago, railroads were the equivalent of today's Internet stocks.
These days, the $40 billion North American railroad industry remains a core component of the economic and transportation infrastructure. But no one will confuse Burlington Northern Santa Fe or Canadian National Railway -- which last week announced a $6 billion deal to form the biggest railroad on the continent -- with Yahoo. 
 The merger is the latest of many over the last few years. But consolidation and good economic times have yet to do much to raise the bottom line. And investors are really turned off: for the last three years, the group has badly underperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Gary Yablon, a managing director and transportation analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, took some time last week to talk about the merger, the railroads and their competitors. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Wall Street was not immediately impressed with the Burlington-Canadian deal. Do you think this is a good marriage?
 
A. It makes sense longer term. Both companies will achieve more together than they would separately.
A big part of the reason it makes sense is that these two roads are leveraging themselves to north-south trade, be it Canada-U.S. trade or Mexico-U.S. trade. The volume of this Nafta trade, if you like, is growing two to three times faster than the volume of domestic trade flowing from east to west, or vice versa.
But when investors see the results they have seen over the last couple of years, they tend to be skeptical.
 
Q. There is also some doubt about whether it will be approved by regulators. Will it?
 
A. I suspect it will get approved. There is not much overlap between the two roads. The things I understand the Surface Transportation Board looks at are public harms and public benefits, and how much one offsets the other. And I don't think the other railroads feel this is such an intrusive merger that they will need to fight it.
 
Q. The strong economy and the cost-cutting that comes as an industry consolidates are conditions that Wall Street usually loves. But the railroads haven't yet seen much benefit. Why not?
 
A. To begin with, we are in an economy that has been driven more by service improvements than by rising production of things like chemicals, coal, grain and lumber. And hauling those sorts of things is what the railroads do.
Also, the strong economy masks some things. Because the dollar has been strong, coal traffic, which is a lucrative market for railroads, has been declining due to more attractively priced coal from other countries. Similarly, grain traffic bound for Asia has been anemic because of the crisis in that region. That has hurt and put a cloud over revenues.
And there have been integration issues stemming from these mergers, particularly in the East, where Norfolk Southern and CSX split up Conrail. Whatever revenue stream you have seen from these mergers has been masked by integration costs.
Railroads realize they must get service up to satisfy their shippers before they can turn to looking out for their shareholders. That is one of the reasons the stocks have not done so well.
 
 
Q. Can you make an investment case for owning railroads right now?
 
A. I am not making the investment case for railroads right now.
Historically, we have been quite bullish on the group. But over the last couple of years, that has not been the case. I think the industry needs to improve service levels and show that congestion-related issues are falling by the wayside. Improvement in those areas will raise investor confidence and the valuation of these stocks. Broadly speaking, that is not happening on a steady-enough basis at the moment.
Still, at the moment, we are recommending Union Pacific and Burlington Northern.
 
Q. Of the freight transportation groups you follow -- air transport, railroads and trucks -- which one has the best investment potential over the next year?
 
A. Over the course of the next year, truckers have the best potential, followed by rails and then air freight, with the exception of United Parcel Service.
Trucking share prices are trading at almost recession-like levels and shippers are using fewer and fewer truckers.
Right now, the only stock that is working and has worked is USFreightways.
Two others are Swift Transportation and Covenant Transport. Both companies are 20 percent growers whose stocks are trading at historically low valuations. Both are non-union organizations with enormous, enormous potential. They do have the risk of rising gasoline prices, but they can pass that through to customers in the form of higher prices.

HEADLINE: Down and Out on Wall Street

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
AH, the roaring stock market. With averages and indexes setting one record after another, investment profits seem like an American birthright.
Yet at a time when tales of investment coups are as likely to be heard over family dinners as among high-fiving traders at Wall Street watering holes, it is easy to overlook the truism that there is a seller for every buyer -- and that some of those skeptics are deserting the market, not moving on to the next can't-lose stock. 
 In fin-de-siecle America, you don't hear so much from this dour segment of investors and seers, this sloth of bears. They considered the market expensive when the Dow Jones industrial average was half its current level. They thought buying the dips was a trap. As 1999 began, they took comfort in the fact that the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had never risen more than 20 percent for four consecutive years, as it had from 1995 through 1998, and then climbed further.
So miss much of the greatest bull market in history they did. So far, in 1999 alone, the Dow has jumped an additional 24 percent, the Wilshire 5000 has risen 20.6 percent and the S.& P. has gained 18.6 percent. Most spectacularly, the Nasdaq composite, fueled by technology issues, has rocketed 81 percent, the most for any major index since 1915.
It is not easy being a bear. As the days have passed, some have suffered from tarnished reputations and the loss of clients -- even jobs. And they've had to endure the withering scorn of market evangelists.
"Who could have ever dreamed that this thing would go as far as it did?" asked Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter Investment Management and the firm's chief global strategist, who turned wary in mid-1998.
Certainly not David W. Tice, whose Prudent Bear mutual fund, which sells stocks short in anticipation that they will fall, has been one of the worst-performing of more than 3,000 mutual funds the last three years.
Nor Charles I. Clough, 57, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, who in August announced his retirement. In recent years, he has advised investors to allocate more money to bonds and cash -- to the annoyance of many Merrill brokers.
Then there is Gail Dudack of Warburg Dillon Read, a market technician, who was abruptly bounced this autumn as a member of the so-called Elves Index panel on the "Wall Street Week" television program. Louis Rukeyser, the host, explained that Ms. Dudack had simply been bearish too long and was undermining the Elf consensus of rising prices in the short term.
All along, the technology-driven stock market has soared with an irrepressible American economy as its accomplice; economic growth has persistently exceeded its supposed speed limits, while inflation has remained at bay.
In February, the uninterrupted expansion that began in March 1991 will set a longevity record, 107 months. Productivity has also surged. And the unemployment rate has sunk so low, scarcely above 4 percent, that many economists are rethinking its longstanding inverse relationship with inflation.
Indeed, an economy that once looked like a bubble of excessive exuberance, not unlike Japan's a decade ago, now seems highly resistant to forces like higher interest rates. And a sage like Lawrence B. Lindsey, a former Federal Reserve governor who is the top economic adviser to George W. Bush, can only regret that he sold his stocks 18 months and 2,800 Dow points ago, believing them overvalued.
Despite their errant predictions, members of the bear contingent of the 1990's remain convinced -- even adamant -- that they will be proved right. And they have their reasons. Their rationales go far beyond the structural bias on Wall Street that minimizes expression of the downbeat, that makes sell recommendations as rare as dinosaurs (as the chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission observed recently), and that can mean a loss of underwriting business or, for an analyst, being cut off from contact with a company's management.
In fact, some bears say their ranks are bigger than is evident -- and growing with each new breathtaking Nasdaq milestone. "Some of our biggest clients," said James S. Chanos, president of Kynikos Associates, which bets on price declines, "are some of Wall Street's leading executives." Many other market professionals, secretly worried, acknowledge privately that they remain fully invested against their better judgment.
"The problem is that a lot of people increasingly believe that it's a bubble -- but they're long," said Marc Faber, a onetime Wall Streeter who works in Hong Kong. "When it changes direction, I think you will get big selling pressure."
At the latest reading, the Consensus Index of Bullish Market Opinion for stocks, compiled weekly by Consensus Inc. of Kansas City, stood at 52. In other words, close to half of the large brokers and investment advisers the firm monitors are bearish on the overall market. That compares with a fourth-quarter peak of 60 just before Thanksgiving.
Still, the bears remain outnumbered by the bulls, who see the new economy as justifying the ebullience. They think the bears are transfixed by historical analysis. "They're really children of the 70's," said Gail D. Fosler, chief economist for the Conference Board, a research group. "There is just an incredible diffusion of technology" that has raised productivity and thus economic prospects.
But it is not just the market's relentless climb that makes the bears bears. They worry about stocks' grounding in economic reality, pointing to threats like the record American trade deficit and what they see as unsustainable consumer spending.
 
Leon Levy
Leon Levy, a founder of Oppenheimer & Company, whose Midas touch is the stuff of Wall Street legend, says it has been a "humbling experience" to have been so wrong on two counts: first, badly underestimating investors' love affair with technology in recent years and, of even greater consequence, doubting that the economy would get through the decade without a recession.
But he is not about to change. Mr. Levy, relaxing in his capacious Midtown Manhattan apartment, which is filled with his renowned collection of Greek and Roman antiquities, sees storm clouds thickening in all directions.
"I would be surprised if it lasted for more than six to nine months," he said of the roaring bull market. When stocks fall, he added, today's avid investors are likely to turn into tomorrow's cautious consumers.
For Mr. Levy, who is 74, the talk of a new economic paradigm that dismisses the idea of recession -- and underpins the bull market -- arouses thoughts of the 1920's. That is when cars became affordable for the average worker and a flood of inventions promised other previously unimaginable things.
"Were the cheap automobile, which led to the suburbs, the shopping center and everything else, and the telephone and the radio less revolutionary than the Internet?" he asked. "It seems to me they were not."
The Levy analysis -- propounded full time by Mr. Levy's nephew, David A. Levy, from the family's Levy Institute Forecasting Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. -- is based on an observation by Leon Levy's father, Jerome Levy. Before World War I, he expressed the belief, then surprising but now conventional wisdom, that profits are what make employers hire, generating other blessings.
Nowadays, the Levys worry that the reverse will happen: that a market break will cause consumers with a falling net worth to spend less, shrinking corporate profits and leaving the economy with a surfeit of office buildings, plants and machinery from what they contend has been far too much capital investment.
Leon Levy frets particularly about the rapidly expanding trade deficit, which reached another record in October, $25.9 billion, signaling a shift to production abroad. "This is something that shows no sign of reversing, and it has to come to a bad end," he said. Eventually, he added, it means fewer American jobs.
For now, though, David Levy said, the United States is short of workers, not jobs, and wage pressure is likely to push up inflation. "If the economy doesn't slow down enough to give us disappointing profits, then interest rates are going to keep rising," he said. "That greatly darkens the outlook for the stock market continuing this great mania that we've seen."
Plausible as that may be, David Levy stated in December 1995 that there was a 50 percent probability of a recession in 1996. It has yet to be sighted, of course. And the Dow industrials have jumped more than 4,000 points since then.
Despite his pessimism, Leon Levy remains heavily invested in stocks, which he pays other, generally much younger people to manage. His only hedge is taking short positions in some of the indexes. "I certainly don't tell them what to do," he said. "But I won't give money to a manager unless, when I ask him what he does when the market goes south, he has a well-thought-out answer."
 
Marc Faber
Marc Faber has been a close witness to bucketsful of economic and financial distress since moving to Hong Kong from Wall Street in 1973. Among them were Japan's 1989 stock market crash and the decadelong recession that ensued and may or may not have ended this year.
But nothing has impressed him as much -- or cost him so dearly -- as the wave of speculative ardor that has characterized the American stock market since at least 1996. It has taught this colorful, ponytailed, motorcycle-riding investor and adviser some painful lessons.
"This is the biggest bubble I've seen," thundered Mr. Faber, 53, a Swiss-born skeptic who writes The Gloom, Boom & Doom Report, a monthly commentary for subscribers. In a telephone interview from his office, where, as he commonly does, he was working well past midnight, he sounded like a true, if chastened, believer.
When assessing this market, he said, just look at the past. "Everything is depressed compared to Yahoo," he said, "but it's not necessarily depressed based on historical standards and compared to interest rates and compared to the earnings outlook."
The "good news," he contended, is that the bubble inevitably will burst -- perhaps as soon as January, a month with more than its share of historic reversals, including that of the Nikkei 225, Japan's benchmark stock index, a decade ago.
This implosion of stocks will drag the American economy, which has become dangerously subservient, along with it, he predicted. "Should U.S. stocks decline by as much as I believe they will, a U.S. recession will follow," he said.
While Mr. Faber has made many accurate calls (he was one of the few who predicted the Asian meltdown) being bearish about the United States has proved expensive. His short positions are losers, and he has made little or no gain putting money into gold and gold stocks, a strategy he has followed for years.
"The funny thing," Mr. Faber added, "is that you could have actually made money on the short side in the last two years because a lot of stocks went down. But if you concentrated on shorting what you perceived to be the most overvalued, it's that sector that has gone through the roof." That sector, of course, is high technology.
"I've been wrong about the U.S.," he acknowledged, citing two chief mistakes. He said he misjudged the willingness of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, to allow speculative excesses to build after cautioning in December 1996 that there were signs of "irrational exuberance."
He is unnerved by what he considers to be an overly expansionary monetary policy here. "How come the monetary base has been expanding at an annual rate of over 22 percent for the last three months?" he asked.
His second misstep, Mr. Faber said, was failing to predict the frenzied scramble for Internet and other technology stocks. Many sell at unheard-of multiples of revenues and have no immediate prospect of earning a profit. "I have underestimated the enthusiasm, the speculative fever and the greed in the United States and around the world," he said. "I underestimated the stupidity of the public."
 
Barton M. Biggs
Though not the purest of the breed, Barton M. Biggs, who has been a relative bear on the American stock market for only 18 months, is as gloomy as the chief strategist of a major Wall Street house can afford to be.
"The technology, Internet and telecommunications craze has gone parabolic in what is one of the great, if not the greatest, manias of all time," he told Morgan Stanley clients in a recent essay on strategy. Expanding on that theme in an interview, Mr. Biggs, 67 and a former marine, called stocks overpriced by some 45 to 50 percent, according to the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter valuation model. The message: the place to put money is elsewhere.
"I'm convinced that over the next three to four years, the U.S. market is going to be the worst of the big markets in the world," Mr. Biggs said from his 22nd-floor Midtown Manhattan office. "I think it's going to underperform next year by, let's say, 10 to 12 percentage points and over the next five years by 3 to 5 points a year."
The problem, he said, is that the old economy is "getting crushed" by the so-called new one, resulting in a bifurcated stock market. The old category includes consumer icons that have lost pricing power because of deflation as well as traditional smokestack manufacturers. "Increasingly, the profitability of the old economy, ranging from Coke to Caterpillar, is under tremendous pressure," Mr. Biggs said. Indeed, many old-economy stocks have dropped to near-depression levels.
"I miscalculated how fast the Internet was going to impact the world," he added. "This is a wild thing that's happening here, this destruction of profitability." Between the third quarters of 1998 and 1999, aggregate corporate profits of manufacturers slid more than 5 percent, to $163.1 billion.
He, too, said the technology bubble would pop one day. "I'm no longer convinced that the Internet part of the new economy is going to anywhere near live up to the expectations embedded in stock prices," he said, stopping just shy of predicting that the shakeout will bring down the rest of the market.
But Mr. Biggs is sticking to a global allocation of about 65 percent stocks and 35 percent bonds. "I'm scared to death, but it's too painful to underweight stocks and hold a lot of cash and bonds," he said. "You're risking your business. They don't like it when you're in cash when the market goes up."
 
James S. Chanos
Running what he believes to be the biggest short-selling operation in the world, Kynikos Associates, James S. Chanos is a professional bear. Kynikos is derived from the Greek word for cynic, and Mr. Chanos makes his living finding stocks that are overvalued, then selling them in hopes of profiting from their eventual return to earth.
In this market, with the S.& P. 500 selling at 31.5 times earnings, nearly twice the historical norm, and with highfliers like eBay going for more than 1,000 times earnings, Mr. Chanos should be in his glory as he goes about deflating the overblown.
Instead, he has changed his ways.
In 1996, Mr. Chanos bowed to the times and created a second hedge fund, called Beta Hedge, to supplement his older, short-only fund, Ursus Partners. The new fund really hedges -- that is, it matches short positions with an equal value of long ones, a market-neutral strategy that translates into betting only on his picks of individual stocks.
"This came from the realization," said Mr. Chanos, whose office in the Citicorp Center in Midtown Manhattan has a seemingly unending view, "that the market headwinds had been, and were, so strong that it was masking the high positive returns of short-selling." In other words, the stock market's rise was fueled by such a powerful force that it was preventing many overpriced stocks from going down.
The new fund proved a salvation for Kynikos. It does not disclose results, but it is believed that Beta Hedge has returned about 17 percent a year since it was formed; its short-only cousin, Ursus Partners, has been flat.
Mr. Chanos, 42, takes no view about the likely direction of the market, but has not had much trouble these days finding unjustifiably inflated stocks. He defines inflated stocks as those whose prices reflect discrepancies between investor perceptions and economic reality.
Corporate earnings provide evidence. Most Internet companies have none at all, and at many profitable companies this decade, there has been a substantial decline in the quality of earnings. Increasingly, Mr. Chanos said, they are overstated because of the proliferation of stock options, the phenomenon of repeated "nonrecurring" charges and the passage of legislation protecting executives from lawsuits. This so-called safe-harbor law gives dishonest managements a chance to mislead investors with impunity, he said.
For all the opportunities to sell short, he must buck more than an unfavorable bullish trend. Tax treatment of short-sellers is unfavorable, it is often hard to borrow stocks to sell short and there is a rule against selling short on downticks. And there is the opprobrium of most of the investment world and the constant stream of upbeat Wall Street appraisal and company news.
His advice for ordinary investors is to avoid short-selling. A much better way to reduce risk, he said, would be to "sell down their longs."
 
James Grant
The spare, paneled conference room seems to tell a lot: the rolltop desk, the old Underwood typewriter, the portrait of the losing 1888 Democratic ticket of Grover Cleveland and Allan G. Thurman. And, yes, a large picture of William Holbrook Beard's painting, "The Bear Dance."
But James Grant, 53, the editor-entrepreneur whose office sits cater-cornered to the New York Stock Exchange, is neither a man of the 19th century nor a born pessimist. He has been wrong about the stock market for a decade, he said, because he is a contrarian. And being contrary in the 1990's meant playing Chicken Little while other people became rich.
"I am a skeptical person," said the 6-foot-5 Mr. Grant, a former columnist for Barron's, sometime TV commentator and proprietor of Grant's Financial Publishing. "I am forever doubting received wisdom. It's sometimes a profitable state of mind -- but often it's not." Mr. Grant, who once ordered up neckties depicting a bear wearing only a barrel, wryly calls himself "the world's leading authority on where the stock market is not going."
In the 1980's, Mr. Grant was a prominent worrier about the boom in corporate debt, the thinly financed run-up in real estate, the fragile balance sheets of banks and the bubble in Japan. He proved largely on target. But he went wrong in early 1991 as the allied countries were pushing Iraq out of Kuwait.
"That was my Waterloo," he said. The stock market took off, creating enough wealth to negate the debt problems. Unfortunately, Grant's kept on reading footnotes in corporate reports, he said, missing the forest for the trees.
With a certain regret -- though he says he is not sure he would have done much better as "another voice in the choir" -- Mr. Grant acknowledged that "we have monumentally missed it on the all-important matter of common stocks."
Grant's Interest Rate Observer, his main publication, has had some latter-day on-the-money calls, positive and negative. It was down, for example, on Coca-Cola, focusing on its accounting practices. Coke, which has had many setbacks, has indeed seen its stock languish. He was also on target in 1997, when he saw CMGI, a sort of supertechnology holding company then selling at about $12, as worth more than the sum of its parts. It now fetches more than $270.
According to a successful old Wall Streeter, he said, bears always sound smarter but their thinking can prove a trap. "The truly perceptive person, knowing that, knows when's the time not to doubt," Mr. Grant said.
Now, while a majority of American stocks have fallen from their highs -- and declining stocks have persistently outnumbered advancing ones -- Mr. Grant is not ready to return to Wall Street. He finds one of the best opportunities in Japan, the mirror image of the 1980's and "the beginnings of something terrific."
This time, he is backing his opinion with cash. He founded a hedge fund concentrating on the small-capitalization Japanese stocks that he thinks had sunk to bargain prices (and have risen lately).
"I happen to have been profoundly wrong, negative on this greatest of all bull markets," he said, referring to his misjudgment in the United States. "But I've resolved I'm not going to miss the next once-in-a-lifetime opportunity."
