HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
Revitalized, For Work And Play

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
IN 1986, when Brady Wood came here as a teenager from New Orleans, he thought something was missing in the city -- like a soul. "This place was a great cultural void," he said. "Too clean, too much glass and steel."
No longer. Mr. Wood, now 32, says Dallas finally has "a place that's cool": the Deep Ellum neighborhood, just across the Central Expressway from downtown. And he had a hand in transforming it. 
 Once a jumble of half-abandoned industrial buildings and the site of the city's largest homeless encampment, Deep Ellum is now a magnet for young professionals, stylish stores and the city's growing Internet industry. It has a proliferation of retail businesses selling most everything from trendy furniture to tattoos, and dozens of places to eat, drink, dance and socialize. "This neighborhood," said Mr. Wood, who owns two nightspots and two restaurants in the district, "could be the next Melrose or SoHo."
There is more to the comparison than a developer's enthusiasm. The evolution of Deep Ellum into a thriving entertainment and creative business center reflects a broader national trend. Growing populations of single people, young couples without children and, more recently, empty nesters are recolonizing near-downtown districts in New York, San Francisco, Seattle, Chicago and other cities, and creative businesses like design studios, ad agencies and Internet start-ups are following them in.
Against this backdrop, Deep Ellum provides noteworthy evidence that the same dynamic is at work in a new category of cities, like Dallas, that did most of their growing after World War II and never before possessed neighborhoods that many people would call hip.
Characteristically, the emergence of Deep Ellum started with two ingredients: cheap rents and old buildings. In its first heyday in the 1930's, Deep Ellum was a center for African-American entertainment, but by the 1980's it had withered to a handful of restaurants and bars and little else. One of the rare parts of this thoroughly modern city untouched by large-scale redevelopment, Deep Ellum had blocks of old warehouses and factories ideal for conversion into artists' lofts.
When a few art galleries and nightclubs moved in, attracted by the cheap rents, real estate investors like Mr. Wood and Don G. Blanton saw possibilities. "I did a lot of traveling in the country, and Dallas didn't have anything like that for people," said Mr. Blanton, who now owns 35 buildings in Deep Ellum. "We had no Greenwich Village or anything like that."
It took nearly two decades for the vision to become reality, but the rewards have been great for the pioneer investors. Buildings that changed hands in the 1980's at $5 a square foot now attract offers in the range of $100 a square foot. Yet Mr. Blanton, a West Texas native who lives and works in Deep Ellum -- his spacious loft is a short walk from his office on Commerce Street -- thinks it is not yet time to sell. In fact, he is looking for more properties in the district.
He is not alone: corporate real estate interests are appearing on the scene. A major developer, Joseph G. Beard of Westdale Asset Management, plans to refurbish an old building at the western edge of Deep Ellum as part of a $90 million hotel-retail complex.
Mr. Beard, whose firm specializes in condominiums and apartment complexes, is impressed by the return of a residential population to the district. According to Barry Annino, 42, a longtime local real estate agent, the number of apartment and loft dwellers in Deep Ellum has risen to more than 2,000, from 200 a decade ago. And based on projects already announced, Mr. Beard estimated that the number would more than triple again in the next few years.
With the new residents has come a surge in interest from Internet businesses. In the past, Dallas's technology companies tended to cluster in suburbs like Richardson and Plano, but Deep Ellum is rapidly becoming a preferred home for dot-com concerns like Broadcast.com (now part of Yahoo), which announced a move into an 80,000-square-foot warehouse, with 700 new jobs.
Mr. Annino, a former tennis pro from Queens who came to Dallas in 1985, leased Broadcast.com its first 3,000-square-foot building here five years ago. Regarded as the unofficial mayor of the neighborhood, Mr. Annino sees Yahoo's decision to keep the company in Deep Ellum as validation of the district's emergence as a prime location for Internet businesses. Many smaller companies that have leased space there, he said, have told him that they were attracted by the new ambience of the district, in much the same way as their analogues have been drawn to TriBeCa in Manhattan.
"This location is perfect for a business like mine," said Brett Strauss, 33, the president of Third Stone, an eight-person Web design studio on Canton Street that counts Broadcast.com among its customers. "You have to be near the heart of things, near the talent pool. This is young industry and this is a young part of town."
In many eyes, one cloud hangs over Deep Ellum's future. Experience elsewhere teaches that a neighborhood that is newly fashionable is also newly vulnerable: Longtime residents like Brady Wood worry that the boom times that are following Deep Ellum's so-called discovery will wind up obliterating the character of the place that has made it so attractive.
In New York, SoHo first gained cachet as an artists' haven, but rising rents have driven many of the artists away even as galleries and restaurants have thrived. If not monitored carefully, Mr. Wood said, the same dynamic could play out in Deep Ellum, snuffing out the neighborhood's spontaneity as its one-of-a-kind shops are overwhelmed by national chains and as local bohemians are supplanted by well-turned-out young lawyers and stockbrokers.
"I love this neighborhood," he said over coffee at Cafe Brazil, a local late-night hangout. "It's a great place to work, and it keeps me in Dallas. But if it lost its character and became like everywhere else here, I'd have to go back to New Orleans."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Still Bullish, But Pulling In The Horns

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
AS Abby Joseph Cohen puts it, she has been "jumping up and down" since early in the decade, telling clients across the country that the stock market had plenty of room to grow, even when other strategists said the opposite was true.
Using conservative and well-researched earnings estimates and factoring in the economy's low-inflation environment, Ms. Cohen, the diva of this bull market, has argued in her measured way that the stock market's undervaluation was a reason to expect good returns from equities. 
 Well, she's not jumping up and down any more. In her 2000 forecast, Ms. Cohen, market strategist at Goldman Sachs, said the stock market is fairly valued. In an interview last week, she said the market has been fairly valued since March.
She is emphasizing this point now, she said, because "this is the first time we have spent any length of time at fair value in this bull run." Then she added: "We no longer think the market is cheap."
That is a big change. It means, she said, that price appreciation will move back to its historical trend, that is, high single-digit annual increases in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
That pace would be a lot slower than investors are used to. In 1999, for the fifth consecutive year, the S. & P. 500, as well as the market's two other marquee indexes -- the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite -- are heading for double-digit returns.
So why haven't alarm bells been ringing since she issued her report on Dec. 16? It is possible that many investors have ignored this warning because her market forecasts have always been understated. While she has been correct about the market -- and has not buckled during sharp downturns during 1997 and 1998 -- her forecasts for the gains in the S.& P. 500 and the Dow have been short of actual performance.
Ms. Cohen says she does that on purpose. "I am trying to come up with a forecast that is not on the extreme end of the bell curve," she said. "I want a forecast that we are comfortable with achieving."
Because of the understated nature of her forecasts, the themes she lays out each year assume added importance. And, until now, they have remained pretty constant.
She often reminds investors, for example, that market advances follow a staircase pattern -- spurts followed by trading ranges. That theme should be even more relevant in a market with slower growth. Her "Supertanker America" theme, which argues that global crises will not derail the United States economy, still holds true. The same goes for the "Silly Putty" theme, which has claimed for years that the profit and economic expansion will stretch much longer than anyone expects. The need for nimble stock-picking, another theme, is even more important in a market where 67 percent of the stocks on the New York Stock Exchange are 20 percent or more below their 52-week highs.
Now comes the first change in one of her major themes since she became a bull in early 1991. Ms. Cohen argued for years that the stock market could live with higher price-to-earnings ratios when inflation was low. Lower inflation, she has said, increases investor confidence in the growth of profits and makes them willing to pay more for a given level of earnings.
But now, she noted, inflation is beginning to rise modestly. That means "inflation is no longer going down and it is no longer something that gives us a significant margin for improvement in valuations," she said. That, she explained, is a reason for believing that the market will stay fairly valued.
None of this means that Ms. Cohen is pessimistic. The market, she says, will hit new highs in 2000, with operating earnings for the S.& P. 500 rising 8 percent. And the earnings will be more solid than the percentage increase implies because the second half of 2000 will have to be compared with a very strong second half of 1999.
As for Ms. Cohen's market forecast, which she says provides direction, not precision, she puts the S. & P. 500 at 1,525 and the Dow at 12,300 at the end of next year. Those are jumps of 4.6 percent and 7.8 percent, respectively, from the levels on Thursday.
Ms. Cohen is favoring financial stocks, including banks and insurance companies, in part because they fell so sharply this year that she thinks they are good values. "You are buying a financial services growth stock at a 40 percent discount to the market," she said. And technology stocks are still on her list, although she thinks the "valuations are not as appealing as they were."
THE biggest threat Ms. Cohen sees is the politics of a presidential election year, a factor that many strategists have not even mentioned in their musings about 2000. "Directional changes could be problematic," she wrote in her outlook analysis. "For example, federal budget policy has been moving toward restraint since 1992; proposals for excessive tax cuts or spending programs could be worrisome."
She dismisses the risk of a surge in inflation and says Year 2000 computer problems will be few. She does not think that economic recovery and stock-market rallies abroad will siphon off investors from the United States market. Indeed, Ms. Cohen said global growth would help the profits of American multinationals.
And she says the stock market will weather the rate increases that she and most other analysts expect the Federal Reserve to make early next year if the economic growth refuses to slow from the torrid 5 percent annual pace of the last six months. "This is something that will not come as a surprise," she said. "It is already a built-in presumption."
So the shock for investors, if Ms. Cohen is right about market valuations, is that normal returns next year will look puny compared with the last five, robust years.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Even in the Best of Times, The Ultimate Consumer Fix

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
AMERICANS are clearly of two minds when it comes to shopping at the fin de millennium. Their appetite for luxury goods has never been greater. The big sellers this holiday season -- cashmere, diamond pendants and DVD players -- also speak to pampered sensibilities.
But even as Americans rush to snap up these fancy goods, they have not forgotten the joys of penny-pinching. 
 The steadiest, most substantial growth in the retail industry has come at the top discount chains. Wal-Mart, Target, Costco Warehouse and other stores now account for roughly a third of annual domestic retail sales, not including autos and restaurants, and that percentage is growing.
It may seem odd that Americans are searching for cut-rate prices at the height of the postwar era's longest economic boom. But as the discounters have moved from selling clearance polyesters and paper towels in bulk to offering brand names for less, they have positioned themselves to provide the ultimate psychic fix of a consumer culture: the bargain.
Getting blue jeans, stemware or hiking boots at, say, Target instead of Bloomingdale's is a "badge of honor," said Wendy Lieberman, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a retail consulting firm based in New York City. "It says, 'I am one smart shopper.' "
Discount stores have not always had such a lofty place in the expert shopper's universe. Loehmann's and Filene's Basement have long drawn bargain-hunters relentlessly stalking the deeply marked down designer clothing, hoping to pass it off as straight out of Saks or Bergdorf Goodman's. And just a decade ago Kmart was for many only for garden supplies, small appliances, work clothes and the like.
But during the recession of the early 1990's, trends shifted. Customers noticed that the discounters had remodeled their stores, stressed customer service and, most important, stocked less expensive versions of the apparel and housewares found in department and specialty stores. Kmart early on signed up Martha Stewart and her color-coordinated road show of paints, sheets and suburban panache. For its part, Target has trendy wool twin sets and toasters designed by the architect Michael Graves, Disney's favorite architect.
Now, according to the Shop 2000 study by WSR Retail, some 84 percent of Americans with incomes over $70,000 shop at mass merchandisers -- an increase of almost 50 percent from 10 years ago.
"The hallmark of shopping in the 21st century is that the woman who shops at Neiman Marcus in the morning will be browsing the halls of Target in the late afternoon," said Paco Underhill, author of "Why We Buy" (Simon & Schuster, 1999). "The social stratification is over."
Mr. Underhill, a self-styled psychologist of shopping, said discount shopping is viewed by many Americans as a kind of virtue. "It says, 'I am secure enough in who I am that I do not find it threatening to walk into Wal-Mart,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Forget the Millennium. Try to Predict One Week.

BYLINE: By JENNY LYN BADER 

 BODY:
SIX shopping days left until the century cusp, and the average shopper has stopped ordering bulk shipments of mineral water and started making lunch dates for January. Pundits who spent the fall debating portents of doom have begun making predictions about the next hundred years and the next thousand.
Awaiting the apocalypse couldn't have remained a national sport for long. After all, the whole fun of a national sport is rooting for some guy, no matter how messed up he is, and wondering whether he'll prevail against incredible odds. If the messiah showed up he would just prevail. What fun is that? 
 The final weeks of most centuries have been more nerve-wracking than the denouement of this one. The first time a century ended, members of a desert religious sect got themselves buried in Qumran with their graves facing north so they could greet the messiah when he resurrected them. He didn't show. In the 990's, Christian priests took the Vikings to be the biblical destroyers from Gog and Magog bringing the end of the world. Turned out they were just Vikings.
Today the world is still intact, despite gloomy predictions from the heavy hitters of prophecy. The mystic Edgar Cayce, who accurately predicted the stock market crash of 1929, predicted that the American coasts would flood in 1998. Jeane Dixon, the astrologer who foresaw John F. Kennedy's assassination, thought a world war would be fought in 1999.
Most notably the world was supposed to explode this past July, according to Nostradamus, who wrote cryptic prophetic verses in 1555 and usually hated to give a verifiable date. But he liked it when numbers came in threes, so in one of his rare specific moods he foretold the Great Fire of 1666: "The blood of the just will be required in London/burned by fire in thrice twenty and six." (CII, Q51). In another precise moment, he pinpointed this past July as a time of war and heaven-sent destruction: "In the year 1999 seven months,/From the sky will come a great King of Terror. . . Before and afterwards Mars rules happily." (CX, Q72) Interpreters of the verse have seen the King of Terror as a fusion weapon, a nuclear warhead, or a spaceship due to land around Independence Day. (Could he have been anticipating the movie?)
After July came and went, fans of eschatological prophecy calmed down a bit. But the big breakthrough came in September, the start of the academic year, with the arrival of next year's day planners, Filofaxes and art calendars in stationery stores. Ancient mystics did not have stationery stores and could remain riled up for longer. Contemporary mystics had to face facts. How could time both be ending and also be mapped out on so many glossy sheets of cardboard? Anticipating the end suddenly seemed not a sign of faith and imagination but just a good excuse to put off one's car payments.
But now that the mood has changed from predicting the end to predicting the future, the time frame seems too long-term. How can we think about the next century or the next millennium, when it's hard enough to tell what's going to happen this week?
Not to worry. A round-up of predictions for the coming week appears below. Unlike predictions for the year 3000, these can be verified. Just keep this newspaper around until next Sunday.
Faith Popcorn Founder, BrainReserve. Author of "Clicking" and "The Popcorn Report." Known for predicting the rise of home businesses, home shopping and organic foods, the rise of four-wheel drive, and the fall of New Coke.
"Y2K and New Year's Eve both will be a big bust. . . . Resort towns will be full.
"Major cities will not."
Dr. Edward Yardeni Chief global economist and investment strategist, Deutsche Bank Securities. Predicted the 90's bull market .
"My short-term forecast is that the Nasdaq will hit a new record high on December 30. That's it. It's the only short-term forecast that I think has any chance of being right."
Harry S. Dent, Jr. Author of "The Roaring 2000s Investor"(1999). Also predicted the bull market of the 90's, in his book "The Great Boom Ahead"(1992).
"We don't think Y2K is going to be a big problem. To be out of this market is suicide. I would not be surprised to see in the last week of December a short, minor pullback. If it did that, I'll buy."
Laurie Twilight Astrologer. Six months before, predicted an earthquake on the day one occurred in Turkey.
"I think there'll be some kind of good news on the 28th or the 29th because Mercury and Jupiter are going to be flowing beautifully, and that's an aspect of forgiveness. Either there could be some peace accord, or a great push on the individual level to have peace within people's lives, in their community and family."
Paul Rudnick Playwright and author. Has no major forecasting credential, but possesses an uncanny ability to anticipate moods.

John Deutsch Former director of the C.I.A. Predicted many major events, most of them classified.

People are so self-absorbed in this money society that they don't know anything about anybody else."

"I have developed a mathematical model (which I have called the law of accelerating returns) which describes the processes underlying the double exponential growth of certain technological capabilities, such as computer speed and price-performance; computer memory capacities; the speed, resolution, and bandwidth of brain scanning . . . The predictions I made during the 1980's, for the 1990's, turned out to be very accurate . . . But the methods I've developed don't apply to predicting short-term incidents.
"To make the kinds of predictions you're asking, either one would have (1) to be a soothsayer (which I don't claim to be), or (2) to be willing to make predictions that are likely to be wrong. There seem to be a lot of people in the second category, but I prefer to make predictions where I have a reasonable basis . . . I'm just not in the guessing game.

Jessica Avery Manager, Business Development, IBM. Correctly predicted the decline of CD-ROMs but says "everyone did." Has no weather forecasting credentials.

HEADLINE: The World;
America Moves Apart From the U.N. on Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
A YEAR ago, the world was mesmerized by the spectacle of exploding rockets lighting the skies over Baghdad as American and British warplanes taught Saddam Hussein a lesson about defying United Nations arms inspections. A year later, it is clear that the fireworks were obscuring another reality: the final retreat of the Clinton administration from a policy of making the United Nations the focal point of policy on Iraq -- and, indeed, from making Iraq a focal point of policy.
Now fixed on the glittering prize of a broader Middle East peace among Israel and its neighbors, the administration has let Iraq slip into the middle distance, where it is likely to remain for the last year of the Clinton era unless President Saddam Hussein does something very foolish and provocative. 
 American policy, which once put so much focus on United Nations arms inspections to restrain Saddam Hussein's military ambitions, seems to now rely on more quietly keeping him hemmed in with sanctions, period. If his weapons programs get to a really dangerous point, new large-scale bombing is always an option anyway.
For many diplomats here, the most telling sign of Iraq's eclipse was the decision of Richard C. Holbrooke, the powerful new American representative at the United Nations, to give no priority to the issue here when he arrived in the fall, just as final negotiations on creating a new arms inspection system to monitor the Iraqis were reaching a crucial point. That system was adopted by the Security Council a week ago but is likely to take months to put into place -- if it can be put in place at all, given Iraq's immediate outrage at the very idea.
From the vantage point of the United Nations, the American policy on Iraq now seems to be on autopilot. A senior American official recently told a group of foreign policy experts that only a handful of people in the United States either knew or cared about the issue, an indication that the policy was hardly under active review.
For at least two years, the administration has been focused almost exclusively on two projects: first, continuing sanctions to try to weaken the Iraqi government and slow its quest for new weapons of mass destruction, and second, supporting the Iraqi opposition in exile, even though it is fragmented and few people take it seriously as an immediate threat to Mr. Hussein. Many experts say the only possibility of overthrow that Mr. Hussein really fears is a palace coup.
Thus the continuing standoff with Mr. Hussein. No arms inspections are likely soon, and therefore there is no end in sight for sanctions, which Mr. Hussein sees as a gross insult to Iraq's sovereignty, as is American enforcement of no-flight zones in the north and south, where Iraq fires on American planes and the planes keep bombing Iraq's air defenses.
Nine years after the gulf war, many nations have come to disagree with the United States that sanctions by themselves should be the bedrock of an Iraq policy. The Arabs, for example, have said the Americans long ago became cynical about inspections -- that they stopped wanting the inspections to work, because if Iraq ever passed the test it would lead to the liberation of Mr. Hussein from the box into which sanctions help keep him. The inspections also tied American policy to an activity carried out not by Americans, but by the United Nations.
"The fact that the sanctions regime has lost virtually all the support it once enjoyed around the world -- and that Saddam Hussein is still firmly in place -- seems to matter very little in Washington's thinking," said David Malone, a Canadian diplomat who is president of the International Peace Academy, a research organization with close ties to the diplomats at the United Nations.
Moreover, he said, "once it became clear that partners in the Security Council, particularly among the permanent five, were no longer willing to support sanctions, Washington had a choice to make between Security Council solidarity and sanctions" to support its goal of containing Iraq, said Mr. Malone.
WITH the decision in favor of sanctions, rather than any inspection regime the council could readily agree on, it became inevitable that the chief United Nations arms inspection official, Richard Butler, would soon feel a chill wind. Now, in the final days before his agency is disbanded, there is a palpable bitterness among its inspectors at having been sold out by Washington.
After the effective end of inspections a year ago, it took many months for the Security Council to decide what to do next. It is telling that when the new plan was drawn up, the United States left most of the work to others, stepping in only at critical points to make sure the Iraqis will have months of work to do before they can get to even a temporary suspension of sanctions.
If America's attitude toward working with the United Nations on Iraq has seemed ambivalent and opaque to other countries, so too has the attitude of Secretary General Kofi Annan seemed confusing to Americans and the United Nations' arms inspectors.
It has been almost two years since Mr. Annan went to Iraq to talk Mr. Hussein into a modicum of cooperation with the inspection agency, known as Unscom. The months that followed, in retrospect, can be seen as the moment when the United States began disengaging from the United Nations on Iraq.
Mr. Annan's mission led to sham diplomatic inspections of off-limits Iraqi palaces in the glare of publicity, while Unscom was prevented from doing any real work. But Washington was surprisingly uncritical. Then, after Iraq was bombed in December 1998, administration officials in Washington leaked reports of how the United States had long used Unscom and, by extension, the United Nations for spying on Iraq. Mr. Malone called these leaks "profoundly damaging" to Mr. Butler.
But in a recent interview, Mr. Butler said that much of the blame for what went wrong rested not in Washington but in the secretary general's office, where he found some staff members "deeply sympathetic" to Iraq. "They made it clear to me after a while that this actual pursuit of weapons was inadequately diplomatic," he said, still angry that Mr. Hussein, a documented liar in dealing with inspectors and a concealer of poison gas, germ warfare and a nuclear program, should get white-glove treatment from the United Nations.
There is a paradox here. In recent months Mr. Annan has become very outspoken and self-critical about the mistakes the United Nations makes when it tries to treat abusers of their own populations with the nonjudgmental neutrality accorded other heads of government. Some people are just evil, a recent report on the 1995 fall of Srebrenica and the subsequent massacre of its Muslim population recently concluded. Mr. Annan has been stung in Bosnia, Serbia and Rwanda -- and said so with extraordinary contrition. He has criticized Russian action in Chechnya and supported NATO in Kosovo.
But Iraq? By the evidence of United Nations Human Rights Commission monitors and human rights organizations, President Hussein rules with ruthless terror and is not squeamish about gassing his own population or using the suffering of civilians as a propaganda tool. Mr. Annan's entourage does not dwell on this.
Mr. Annan now has a huge challenge ahead of him. The Security Council has given him a month to choose a successor to Mr. Butler to head a new inspection commission. Signs of American interest are conspicuously absent. Although the strength or weakness of the choice will be important, American diplomats say the United States doesn't have a favored candidate in the race.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: High Society;
When You Got It, Flaunt It

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
"TO live on little, with contented mind," may be the classically proper attitude toward wealth, but "little" and "contented" aren't seen together very much these days. A more appropriate motto would be Oscar Wilde's "Nothing succeeds like excess."
Between the remarkable American economy, which has been growing for almost nine years, and the dot-com tsunami, which has not yet crested, the past decade has been a period of unprecedented wealth creation. Consider that in 1989 there were an estimated 1.9 million people in the country worth $1 million or more. Today that number has jumped to about 8 million. The number of American households worth $10 million or more has also quadrupled over the period, jumping to 275,000 from 65,000, said Edward N. Wolff, a professor of economics at New York University and an expert on wealth. 
 So much money is sloshing around that it seems to have overwhelmed the last vestiges of Puritan guilt over spending it. As the stock market and corporate profits rise, charities nationwide report that donations from both individuals and companies are falling. The very idea of wretched excess, of buying as vulgar and wealth as morally dangerous, has given way to a display-and-play ethos.
"They're all millionaires and billionaires by the time they're 30," said Leonard Ely, a 76-year-old Silicon Valley captain of industry turned philanthropist. Ask them for a chunk of their new-found wealth, he added, and "They'd say, 'Look, I don't have my Ferrari and my place in Tahoe, and you're telling me I should give money away?' "
The new attitude was on parade at the holiday party thrown by the society furrier Dennis Basso at the House of the Redeemer on East 95th Street off Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.
Two rows of black, chauffeured cars lined the block outside the candlelit Episcopal sanctuary, as guests nibbled caviar and ladies with newly sculpted faces worshiped, well, fur. Upstairs, Blaine and Robert Trump held court in the library of the former Vanderbilt mansion, while Kathy Hilton, wife of an heir to the hotel fortune, received rave reviews on her pink mink.
Despite Ms. Hilton's coup, sable is de rigueur among the pelt-wearing classes this year. "Darling, this was the year of sable," declared Mr. Basso. "They all had to have one." Downstairs, standing next to a cloakroom full of sable coats costing about $150,000 each, Joan Collins, the former diva on Dynasty, stood near several 30-something men in black-tie, who quietly questioned whether her high cheekbones were real. And Michele Herbert, a Park Avenue socialite, kissed Mr. Basso in gratitude for her $20,000 handbeaded Russian broadtail suit.
Even Locust Valley, N.Y., the capital of lockjaw and faded chintz, has lost its bearings. The parking lot of the Piping Rock Club, once filled with members' 10-year-old "beater" paneled station wagons, now fills up with 3-year-old BMW's instead (and the children own Porsches).
Is it a new Gilded Age, with many thousands of robber barons, instead of just a few dozen?
"There are striking parallels," said Jean Strouse, the author of "Morgan: American Financier" (Random House, 1999), who spent 15 years writing and researching the biography of J. P. Morgan (1837-1913). "The Internet is very parallel to the building of the railroads, the telegraph system, the transatlantic cable. People were buying and building yachts. Enormous floating palaces. Elaborate houses in Newport. It was an unbelievably lavish time."
It's an unbelievably lavish time now. " People seem to be shopping at two in the morning, three in the morning. That's when they buy the expensive items," said James A. Finkelstein, the founder of Luxuryfinder.com, an online merchant.
"We sold out of pashmina blankets at $995 apiece," he said. "We sold out of pashmina pillows for $335. We sold a lot of caviar. A lot, a lot of caviar." The caviar costs $1,150 per 500 grams, but it comes with beautiful mother-of-pearl caviar spoons.
One couple flies their palm trees from Southampton to Palm Beach in the winter ( to keep the trees warm). They also told their decorator to put down black and white floor tiles to match the coats of their terriers.
Anastasia Soare, the owner of Anastasia's salon in Beverly Hills, has grown accustomed to emergency calls from clients just in from Europe who must have their eyebrows done at once.
"She was desperate," said Ms. Soare of one midnight call. In response, Ms. Soare, whose shop also perfects the eyebrows of Naomi Campbell, Jennifer Lopez, Lara Flynn Boyle and Kate Capshaw, packed up tools in her own home in Benedict Canyon and drove across town to her client's home. There, she performed an emergency pluck, cut and wax. Charge: $400 to $3,000 (the latter price for flying cross country) for as little as a five-minute session.
Others fly their linens to Paris to be dry-cleaned. "It's well worth it," said one women at a Park Avenue cocktail party, as she tossed her purple pashmina shawl around her shoulders. It better be, since the tab in some homes runs to $6,000-a-month.
It's exhausting, all this spending. Ms. Herbert, who is married to the chairman of Pantone, a company specializing in color graphics, talked about how hectic it is to keep up with everything. "Let me put it this way, it would be easier if I had a job!" she said.
To help them keep up, the rich are hiring helpers, and even helpers for their helpers. Mark Simone, a 44-year-old bachelor who lives between New York and Greenwich, Ct., flipped through his black book the other day and recited how many women he knows who have multiple social secretaries.
"I don't think you know how common it is for these women who do nothing, to have two secretaries," Mr. Simone said. "I can think of 20 who have two." He equated it to having a cat. "When you're not home all day, you need to get another one to keep the first one company."
In the Hamptons, the magic number for summer help was four: A houseman (to change the light bulbs and make sure there's Diet Coke on ice), a laundress, a chef and a housekeeper.
Children are equally the beneficiaries of excess. It's there to be seen on any rainy day outside Nightingale-Bamford, an all-girls private school on the Upper East Side. Ten-year-olds stand in front, calling their very own town cars on their very own cellular phones. An entire seventh grade class at another New York private school flew to Barbados for a birthday weekend. And a doting father recently paid $17,000 to rent the F.A.O. Schwarz flagship toy store on Fifth Avenue for his 12-year-old daughter's birthday slumber party.
At 3 a.m. one 12-year-old turned to another, both dressed in flannel feetsy pajamas, and said "We'll be in business together." Her friend said, "We'll be Greenberg and Leff." And they would make lots of money because the first girl knew all the "lawyer words." She recited: "Malpractice, liability."
"Malpractice, liability," repeated her friend.
One young woman, who spent 13 years in the New York private school system and is a freshman at Cornell University, pointed out the importance of the status of such things. "Cell phones, town cars, country houses, and kids whose parents who have really cool jobs have no problem making friends," she said.
She said that vacations were really important, too. "If you go to Florida for vacation you're not going away," the girl said. Why? "On a vacation you have to see clear water; in Florida, the water is murky."
So, the rich at least, have got what they wished for. Which is exactly what the gods are supposed to give us -- before they drive us mad.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 3; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 314 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Look What's Hot A Hundred Years From Now

BYLINE: By KARI HASKELL 

 BODY:
"LIFE is short," Hippocrates once said. "Art is long."
Not until the end of World War II, with Europe and Asia physically and economically in ruins, did the importance of preserving antiquity, natural history and culture attract greater attention in the United States. Today, the United States is home to 15,000 museums. About 2.3 million people visit an American museum on an average day. 
 The Week in Review asked a sampling of museum directors and curators to pick one item from their own institution's private collection that they believed would have even greater importance at the end of the next century.
Choosing among thousands of items -- tens of thousands in some cases -- was challenging. As a result, a few second choices deserve honorable mention. Dr. Robert M. Batscha, president of the Museum of Television and Radio, said his runner-up was Sesame Street, "because it was the first time television was used as a teaching tool.The viewer was active, not passive and this technique was copied by other learning shows."
Second to cancer research, Dr. Adrianne Noe, director of the National Museum of Health and Medicine, chose "the invention the Band-Aid, which was developed this century, and was the beginning of home care." She added, "It will not be used through out the next century, we are already using spray-on antiseptics." Such products, she said, were "second skins, that will the replace the Band-Aid."
Only one museum official, Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, declined to single out an object. He said that to pick one piece out of the museum's collection would be like choosing one child over another.
Museums are guardians of civilization. One piece in a collection is an image of time, giving viewers a chance to understand and reflect upon history, and ultimately to influence future discoveries.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: Summer Days (1936), Georgia O'Keeffe Gift of Calvin Klein -- This work preeminently embodies an American sensibility and mood. Its constituent elements and the straightforward style in which it articulates metaphysical questions about the cycle and meaning of life mark it as singularly American. The work presents a distinctly American vision of nature as timeless, indomitable, and momumental; as a concrete aspect of existance whose timeless grandeur transcends the patterns, problems and vicissitudes of daily life. --Barbara Haskell, curator, Whitney American Museum of Art, New York. (c.1999 The Georgia O'Keeffe Foundation/ARS, New York); Chicken Carcinoma (1909) -- On October 1, 1909, Dr. Peyton Rous removed a tumor from an English hen and injected a cell-free filtrate from the tumor into another healthy chicken, which later developed this tumor. Although the concept of the virus was still in its infancy, this was the first experiment to demonstrate that cancer could be caused by a viral infection. Dr. Rous's conclusions were initially met with considerable skepticism, but research on viral origins of cancer became central to cancer research by the 1950's. Dr. Rous was awarded the 1966 Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine for his research. -- Dr. Adrianne Noe, director, National Museum of Health and Medicine, Washington. D.C. (National Museum of Health and Medicine, AFIP); Chrysler's Turbine-powered Car (1954) -- Chrysler developed 50 turbine-powered cars as test models, costing $50,000 apiece. This is the only operational turbine car on public display. Its versatile engine runs on diesel fuel, kerosene, unleaded gas, Jp-4 jet fuel, or any mixture of the four. By the late 60's Chysler engineers were reassigned to other programs relating to new emissions standards for conventional engines. However, the turbine-powereed car will continue to be significant in the future as we explore alternative sources of energy. --Jim Worton, director, Museum of Transportation, St. Louis. Each phase of our country's history has been, and still is, captured by our cartoonists, providing a cultural treasure of society's foibles never covered by traditional history books. -- Stephen Charla, curator, International Museum of Cartoon Art, Boca Raton. HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Waiting for Assad

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Sometimes you're reading along and a fact just jumps off the page at you. Like this one, for instance: Syria's economy, its G.N.P., is one-seventh the size of Israel's. That means Syria, with 16.5 million people, produces about 15 percent of what the Israeli economy produces with 5.5 million people.
I toss this out not to embarrass the Syrians. The Syrians actually have a talented merchant class, which, if unleashed, would quickly transform the Syrian economy. I toss it out to underscore the tremendous imbalance of power that exists today between Israel and Syria -- militarily, economically and technologically. 
 This imbalance of power is an important backdrop to the current Syrian-Israeli peace talks. Put simply, Israel, the vastly more developed and powerful country, is being asked to relinquish a strategic asset, the Golan Heights, to a weaker Syria, in return for security guarantees and a still-to-be-determined Syrian normalization with Israel.
What's interesting is that despite their power advantage Israelis aren't just saying: "Who needs this deal?" Instead, a slim majority of Israelis are leaning toward it, because they believe it has the potential to actually enhance Israel's strength -- by extracting Israel from its bloody quagmire in south Lebanon, by turning Syria into a buffer between Israel and Iran instead of a bridgehead through which Iran bleeds Israel, by transforming Syria from the vanguard of the Arab ideological struggle against Israel to a member of the circle of peace around Israel and by enabling Israelis to drive directly across Syria to Europe.
But while a majority of Israelis are leaning in favor, they're not there yet, because they still need to be convinced by President Hafez al-Assad of Syria not only that such benefits actually accrue to Israel if it relinquishes the Golan, but also that they will be grounded in a wholly different Syrian approach to Israel. If a Golan deal is to have a solid majority in Israel, and if it is to win the support of the American Congress, which will be asked to help pay for it, Mr. Assad is going to have to undertake his own initiative of reconciliation that says to Israelis this really is a new day -- and it's not just going to be one day, the day Israel relinquishes the Golan.
With the parties resuming negotiations in Washington on Jan. 3, Mr. Assad needs to move. If each act of reconciliation toward Israel that he makes has to be squeezed out of him, if there is no sense that each comes out of a real willingness to change the relationship between the Syrian people and Israel, there will be no impact. When things are squeezed out of you, you may feel as if you are giving, but the other person will not feel as if he is getting.
Anwar el-Sadat's genius was that he not only gave to Israelis the reconciliation they most craved without being squeezed to do so, he did it before talks even began. Also, by both his actions and his words, Mr. Sadat made Israelis believe that it was a new day -- that there was no going back for him so therefore there could be no turning away by Israelis. Mr. Assad has done neither yet. Why is Mr. Assad negotiating with Israel now? What is new for him? He has never explained.
There is going to be an Israeli referendum on this deal, so the Israeli public will be deciding. Only Mr. Assad can tip the balance firmly in favor, and he can do that best by opening the way, right now, to contacts between Israelis and Syrians, who want peace and an opening of Syria to the world every bit as much as Israelis. To his credit, Mr. Assad allowed a reporter from Israel's largest newspaper, Yediot, to visit Damascus last week, and the reporter's story in Friday's paper, including a picture of Syrian soldiers embracing him and his conversations with Syrian students and businessmen, was the buzz of Israel.
"The more Israelis can feel the Syrian response in the streets, the more they will be convinced that this isn't just a deal with a dictator," said the Israeli political theorist Yaron Ezrahi. "Assad doesn't have to democratize Syria today, but he has to democratize the peace, and he has to do it in a way that Israelis see comes from his initiative, not something being squeezed out of him."
Mr. Assad has already started conditioning the Syrian public with the new posters being plastered around Damascus: "We fought with honor. We will negotiate with honor. We will make peace with honor." That's a good start. Now he has to condition the Israelis.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: FUNDS WATCH;
At Closed-End Muni Funds, Insiders Are Often Buyers

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Managers and employees at closed-end municipal bond funds are apparently seeing bargains close to home -- shares of their own funds.
According to the Washington Service, which follows transactions reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission, managers of closed-end muni funds have bought about 75,000 shares in the last two months, 16 times as many as they sold. 
 The purchases come as closed-end municipal funds wrap up a brutal year -- with losses averaging about 17 percent at the 106 national closed-end muni funds tracked by Bloomberg as of Monday. Those losses have prompted many investors to sell their shares; as a result, many funds' discounts to their net asset value are their widest in five years.
"This is a cheap asset class," said Tom Fetter, who oversees about $7.5 billion as head of munis for Eaton Vance Management in Boston. "It's an attractive alternative to an overvalued stock market." He paid $84,211 for 7,200 shares in the Eaton Vance Municipal Income Trust over the last three months, according to the Washington Service.
Closed-end funds issue a fixed number of shares, which may trade at a premium or discount to their net asset values. While the net asset values of many funds have dropped because of rising interest rates, share prices have fallen even more. Other buyers, according to the service, were Vincent Giordano, head of tax-exempt closed-end funds at Merrill Lynch, who bought shares in its MuniHoldings Fund and MuniHoldings Fund II; Steve Krupa, a portfolio manager at John Nuveen & Company, who bought shares of Nuveen Insured Municipal Opportunity; Richard Moynihan, head of munis at the Dreyfus Corporation, who bought shares of Dreyfus Municipal Income, and Paul Disdier, a Dreyfus fund manager who bought shares in Dreyfus Strategic Municipal Bond.

HEADLINE: Americans' Secret Deal Shows a Trap for Russia's Transition

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

 BODY:
A few years ago, when an American company was seeking a toehold in the newly privatized and potentially lucrative Russian telecommunications market, it cut a secret deal with directors and officers at the Moscow telephone company.
As part of the arrangement, which has raised legal and ethical questions and thrown a light on how some Western businessmen have operated in Russia, the American company, Global Telesystems, paid at least $65 million in stock and cash. Global paid the money to a company the insiders had set up in the Bahamas to avoid public scrutiny and taxes. 
 In exchange, Global Telesystems ended up with ownership of a Russian telecommunications company that generates millions of dollars a year in revenues by providing service to 150,000 Moscow customers, most of them businesses willing to pay a premium. The eight Russians who took part in the deal each walked away with about $9 million in cash and stock, tax free.
The Russian government says the phone company insiders committed fraud and tax evasion, and has opened an investigation, as have law enforcement agencies in countries where the insiders stashed their gains. Global Telesystems, a fast-growing company based in McLean, Va., says the transaction broke no Russian or American laws.
The Global Telesystems deal illustrates how Western business maneuvers may sometimes undermine Western governments' efforts to promote Russia's economic transformation.
Western business and political leaders have lectured Russians over and over, saying that if they want to attract foreign investment, they must adopt laws to protect shareholders' rights and improve tax collection. But the Global Telesystems deal resulted in the Moscow phone company's being defrauded of more than $200 million, based on the value of the phone lines and projected revenues, according to the Russian Ministry of Interior and Western investigators.
Other shareholders in the company, Moscow City Telephone Network, include the Russian government and a handful of investors in the United States, where its stock is also traded.
In America, the insiders' dealings would provoke shareholder lawsuits, corporate and securities law experts say. That is unlikely in Russia.
"Even if this was not illegal, the question is, was it ethical and smart?" said Jonathan Winer, who monitored money laundering and other international activities as a deputy assistant secretary of state before stepping down recently.
An American investment banker in Moscow described the Global deal as "only the tip of the iceberg," just one example of how Western companies have engaged in business practices in Russia that they would not try at home. Most of the cases, he and other executives said, remain carefully guarded corporate secrets.
Details on the arrangement between Global Telesystems and the phone company insiders emerge from documents filed by Global Telesystems with the Securities and Exchange Commission and information on the company insiders gathered by law enforcement officials in the United States, Russia and Europe.
Global Telesystems was well positioned for opportunities offered by the new Russia, such as the 1994 privatization of Moscow City Telephone. The American company had worked in the old Communist Soviet Union in the early 1980's, when the company was based in California and called San Francisco/Moscow Teleport.
It changed its name to Global Telesystems in 1995, and issued stock publicly two years later, with a $200 million initial offering.
Two months ago, Global Telesystems put its Russian and other Eastern European operations into a subsidiary, Golden Telecom, sold off 34 percent in an initial public offering and raised $144 million more.
One of Global's biggest backers, from its early days, has been George Soros, the international financier who has been active, commercially and philanthropically, in the former Soviet Union. Two years ago, Mr. Soros and his affiliate companies owned 26 percent of Global Telesystems, according to a company filing with the S.E.C., though he never played any management role at the company. His stake in the company is now about 7.7 percent, a spokesman for Mr. Soros said. It is still one of the larger stakes in the company after some institutional holders like Fidelity and Putnam Investments.
The spokesman said that Mr. Soros had not been aware of the deal between Global Telesystems and the Moscow City Telephone insiders until asked about it by The New York Times.
The insiders and Global Telesystems used three companies to carry out their deal, which made it more difficult for government officials to trace. They were Invest-Project, registered in Russia, GTS-Vox, registered in Britain, and Swinton Ltd., which was registered in the Bahamas, a haven for corporate secrecy and tax avoidance.
Investigators said there were eight shareholders of Invest-Project and Swinton. They included five top executives and directors of the Moscow telephone company -- the general director, Vladimir Lagutin, and four deputy directors, Said Alimbekov, Viktor Panov, Semyon Rabovsky and Sabiryan Shambazov.
None of these individuals nor Moscow City Telephone responded to requests for comment, including a fax with detailed questions. Swinton's American lawyer, Jacob Laufer of Manhattan, would not disclose the names of the Swinton shareholders. "The principals value their privacy," he said. He would not say what business Swinton was engaged in, but said it was "lawful and proper."
Similarly, the general counsel for Global Telesystems, Grier Raclin, said in a written statement that the transaction between his company and the phone company insiders "was totally aboveboard, legitimate and consistent with the laws and business practices in Moscow."
The first step in the deal was for Moscow City Telephone to award the insiders' company, Invest-Project, the contract to provide telephone connections for 150,000 Moscow customers. Exactly how much the insiders paid has not been made public, but investigators and one person familiar with the deal estimate that it was about $8 million.
Five days earlier, the insiders and Global Telesystems had already agreed to sell 95 percent of Invest-Project to GTS-Vox. Since Swinton wholly owned GTS-Vox, this meant they were merely transferring ownership from a company registered in Russia to one whose owners were hidden behind Bahamian secrecy.
The next step was for Swinton to sell 53 percent of GTS-Vox to Global Telesystems. For that, Global Telesystems paid with stock worth about $26 million. This translates into $3.25 million in stock for each of the Russian phone company executives.
Putting in telephone lines increased the profit because most of the lines went to businesses willing to pay a premium, as much as $500 for a connection, in addition to monthly service charges.
Revenues of Telecommunications of Moscow -- the new name for Invest-Project -- grew from nothing in 1995 to $16.5 million in 1996, $29 million in 1997 and $21.5 million for the first six months of 1998, according to Global's S.E.C. filings.
From those revenues, the insiders and Global Telesystems paid themselves more than $7 million in dividends.
The final bonanza came last year when Global Telesystems bought Swinton's remaining interest in Telecommunications of Moscow for $40 million in cash. That produced a windfall of about $5 million for each of the phone company insiders and brought their total receipts on the deal to nearly $9 million each.
But when the insiders started moving their money around the world, they attracted unwanted scrutiny.
Swinton and each shareholder had an account at BankBoston. In September 1998, Global Telesystems paid $7.4 million into the Swinton account. Then Swinton quickly moved $895,000 into each insider's account, said a senior law enforcement official and another individual familiar with Swinton's financial activities.
The movement of so much money set off alarm bells at the bank, and it alerted federal authorities. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Customs Service opened an investigation, and in November 1998, a federal judge in Boston ordered the accounts frozen. The bank would not comment.
But early this year, the United States attorney in Boston, Donald Stern, decided not to prosecute, said lawyers for the companies. Federal investigators, who thought they had a case of possible money laundering, were dismayed. "The case was not aggressively pursued," said one senior law enforcement official. An investigator from another federal agency said the case had been "prematurely closed."
Through a spokesman, Mr. Stern declined to answer any questions about the matter.
Attorneys for Swinton and Global said the case was closed, but the court record remains sealed. The New York Times filed a motion last month to have it opened, contending that keeping the record from the public violated the First Amendment. A hearing is scheduled for January.
After the Boston accounts were unfrozen early this year, the insiders quickly moved their money abroad, this time to Denmark, according to law enforcement officials in Europe.
Acting on evidence provided by the Russians, the Danes promptly seized the accounts, on the theory that the money had been fraudulently obtained, according to American and European officials.
Proceeds from the deal were also sent to Israel and Switzerland, and authorities there are still investigating, officials said.

HEADLINE: Spain Rudely Awakened to Workaday World

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
With Spain under pressure to conform to the shorter lunch break habits in most of the 14 other countries in the European Union, its traditional workday -- with its three-hour siesta break to eat and sleep -- is disappearing.
Increasingly, large companies are cutting lunch to two hours and corporate culture is turning against the concept of nodding off during the day, seeing it as a sign of laziness.
Jose Luis Carranza Ortiz, the director of human resources for one of Spain's largest banks, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya, is clear on the subject. 
 "Those who can take siestas do," he said. "But those who are really serious about working do not."
Of course, not all Spaniards agree. Some openly rail at this sort of thinking. Others have become closet nappers, sometimes retreating to their cars or into nearby health clubs for a quick snooze. Mr. Carranza had no sooner disappeared down the hall to his next meeting when another bank official confided that he still slipped home every day for a 30-minute rest.
"It's very healthy," he said. "You feel much better." But please, he begged, he could not be identified.
The siesta question is a big issue here because abandoning the midday snooze amounts to a radical change in a traditional way of life. When the European Union tried in the early 1990's to get the Spanish to take the tilde -- the squiggle over the letter n -- from their keyboards to conform with the single market enshrined in the Treaty of Rome, howls of protest went up. The European Union eventually backed down.
Feelings about the siesta can run just as deep. The mayor of Plasencia, a town in the western province of Caceres, was so concerned about the growing noise during the lunch hour that he issued an order calling for silence between 3 and 5 p.m.
Studies suggesting that naps are healthy are routinely trumpeted in Spanish papers, proof that the rest of the world is finally coming around to something that Spaniards long ago discovered. Last summer, the national daily El Mundo devoted 10 pages to the subject. It said that siestas in America were called "power naps" and it cited Levi Strauss, Ben & Jerry's, and Mac World Magazine as some of the companies trying out "nap lounges."
The headline read, "It's proven -- the siesta is beneficial, and if in the United States they are starting to discover it, here it continues to be part of the national heritage."
But even its proponents say the siesta is under attack on many fronts. The economy is on the upswing, with more new jobs created here this year than in any other country in the 15-nation European Union -- 400,000.
This has increased traffic in the cities and allowed young people to move to the suburbs. More and more Spaniards are facing long commutes, and increasingly women are joining the work force although the unemployment rate for women remains at 22 percent, twice that for men.
Still, all this means that popping home is getting harder. And since couples are both working, no one is there cooking the hot meal that usually preceded the siesta.
The siesta has pretty much vanished from the cities of Latin America, though some rural areas carry on, especially in the most tropical climes. Last April it came to an abrupt halt in Mexico City when President Ernesto Zedillo imposed a new schedule that required officials to be at their desks from 9 a.m. until 6 p.m. That has quickened a lengthy erosion in the siesta there.
A Spanish mattress company, Pikolin, which recently did a survey on the subject, found that only 25 percent of Spaniards surveyed still take a siesta and, unlike 50 years ago, few actually get into bed anymore.
"The siesta is nothing more than a cliche for most working people in Spain," said Juan Ignacio Perez-Nievas, the company's marketing director. "They do not have time for it."
The survey indicated that the siesta is most popular among the older generation and rarest for young people, particularly in the most northern regions of Spain, where the weather is coolest.
Yet many young people mourn the loss of the afternoon nap, which they say gave a certain pace to the day and intimacy to their parents' relationship.
Roberto Suarez Santos, for instance, director of the labor relations department of the powerful Spanish Employers' Organization, said a siesta was out of the question for him.
Mr. Suarez, 31, said he is really expected to have lunch with his colleagues, talk about work and then get back to the office quickly. He looks on the siesta, however, as something that enhanced his parents' lives.
"They had this time to go back home and talk to each other," Mr. Suarez said. "They had two or three hours together in the middle of the day to discuss what was going on in their lives. It gave a coherence to the family. Now it seems there is less and less time to talk. There is time at the end of the day, but somehow it is perhaps not the right time."
In fact, the workday in Spain is a bit chaotic these days. Big department stores are open throughout the afternoon lunch break now and remain open way into the evening, usually until 8:30 p.m. But most small stores continue to close from 2 to 5 p.m. Almost everybody knows someone who still has a three-hour lunch, someone who has two hours and someone who is working an eight-hour shift.
Union officials say that new collective bargaining agreements are increasingly calling for continuous shifts, and many union officials say they are glad about it. Otherwise, they say, Spaniards tend to have a very long day.
"Some of our people are up at 6 a.m. to get to work and then they don't get home from work until about 9 p.m.," said Antonio Ferrer, the secretary of the General Workers' Union, which has nearly one million members. "Where else in the world do you have a workday like that?"
But many of those who still have the traditional Spanish day like it that way. In the historic district of Madrid, Florencio Cordoba, 46, closes his famous cape shop, Sesenin, at 2 p.m. and goes home for three hours, where he changes into his pajamas, eats his lunch and usually sleeps on the couch with the television on.
Back to work at 5 p.m., he closes at 8:30 p.m. He considers the siesta not only healthy, but a Spanish custom that should never be abandoned.
Still, he sees the changes coming even in his own household. His oldest daughter now works a continuous day, getting home at 6 p.m. "She is always complaining she is tired," Mr. Cordoba said.
And these days his wife has begun talking about going to work. But he hopes she will not. "I know that if she was not at home everything would change," he said. "We do not have two fancy cars, but we have been happy."
Some die-hard nappers have just found creative ways of getting a little nap in on a shortened lunch break.
A chain called "Masajes a 1000" -- which offers busy Spaniards a sort of McDonald's version of a siesta -- has opened 21 franchises since 1997.
At one of its newly opened health spas in downtown Madrid, the lights were dim and all was quiet as four customers napped in ergonomically correct chairs, wrapped in plaid blankets. Each had paid $6 for a five-minute massage and a chance to take a half-hour snooze.
The occupant of one chair was Sara Ibanez, a 35-year-old biologist. She happily leaned her head forward on the padded cushion and fell asleep sitting up.
Her employer, a Spanish pharmaceutical company, cut her lunch break from three hours to two six weeks ago. She is understanding about the company's need to have her at her desk when workers in other European countries are at theirs.
But she still wants her shut-eye. "Afterward you have energy for the rest of the day," she said.

HEADLINE: Growing Surpluses Extend Drop in Farm Prices

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Prices for most farm crops continued their decline this year as surpluses of grain and other commodities grew, and economists say they see no hope of a recovery in prices before 2001.
"There's not a whole lot of upside potential, basically because of large supplies," said Mike Kaus, an agricultural economist at Iowa State University. 
 The nation's net farm income reached $48 billion this year only because of a record $22.7 billion in crop subsidies and other direct government payments, a year-end analysis by the Economic Research Service of the United States Department of Agriculture has found.
The department predicted that net farm income would fall $7.6 billion next year to $40.4 billion unless Congress stepped in with another multibillion-dollar bailout, a move that is highly likely in an election year.
Crop sales fell to $95.7 billion in 1999 from $102.2 billion last year. But receipts from cattle, hogs and poultry edged up to $95 billion from $94.5 billion, driven largely by an increase in beef prices.
Cattle are selling for 67 cents to 69 cents per pound, up from 61 cents a year ago, and the agriculture department expects the price to reach 73 cents by spring. Hog prices are also up this year after diving at the end of 1998, but they are still only at about the cost of production.
Because of the low prices that producers are getting for most other commodities, one in four agricultural operations probably will not cover its cash expenses next year, the department says in its 2000 forecast.
Parts of the South and Southeast will be hit especially hard next year "by dramatic declines in prices for rice and tobacco as well as continued low prices for corn and soybeans," the agency said.
Farm income is expected to rise in the northern Plains, because of the higher prices for cattle and the relatively low prices for feed.
That forecast could go out the window if there are widespread crop failures in the United States or elsewhere that drive commodity prices up.

HEADLINE: Keeping Faith in an Era of Change;
3 Parishes Embody Challenges for New York Archdiocese

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
When Catholics go to Mass, there is a moment just before Communion. Parishioners turn their eyes from the altar, grasp their neighbors' hands and wish them peace.
At St. Stanislaus, a tradition-bound Polish church in rural Orange County, the greetings are muted, almost perfunctory, as if the worshiper hopes not to disturb the flow of prayer. At St. Patrick's in Westchester County, parishioners linger over the greetings, with some saying the fellowship encapsulates the reasons they go to church. And at St. Martin of Tours in the Bronx, the handshakes, smiles and flashing peace signs at a Spanish-language Mass crest in a wave of good will that washes over the pews row by row. 
 As the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York awaits a change of leadership -- Cardinal John O'Connor is in ill health and will turn 80 next month -- the worshipers he has led for 15 years have never been more diverse. Some 50 languages are spoken by the 2.4 million Roman Catholics in the archdiocese, which comprises Manhattan, Staten Island, the Bronx and seven counties north of New York. Its two newest parishes offer Mass in Albanian and Korean.
As recent visits to three parishes showed, the diversity of the archdiocese is not only ethnic, but also spiritual, with seemingly as many styles of worship as there are parishes.
Throughout the United States, the Catholic Church grapples with problems caused by similar population changes: a dwindling number of priests and nuns, a deepening alienation even among people who still attend church, the widening gap between the church's teachings and the choices Catholics make in their lives.
To many Catholics, the findings of a recent New York Times poll suggested, personnel changes in the hierarchy of the church seem remote, having little bearing on their lives. For them, the place where the possibilities, meaning and problems of faith intersect is closer to home. It is at their church.
 
St. Stanislaus
Nancy Foran, the organist, comes in with her 14 children from across the border in New Jersey. Lillian Blakener, a hairdresser, and her husband drive eight miles from Goshen. Richard Westpy, a field supervisor for an alarm company, makes his way alone each Sunday from Glenwood, N.J.
For none of them is Pine Island's white steepled Church of St. Stanislaus their neighborhood parish. But for all of them, the parish's strict adherence to tradition strikes a deeper chord, making the trek worthwhile.
Before the early Mass even begins, the voices of parishioners reciting the rosary float through the well-tended church. Altar boys -- never girls -- assist the Rev. Joaquim Olendzki in the eucharistic rite. Twice a week, Father Olendzki celebrates Mass in Latin for a small group of old-timers, said the deacon, Frank Dembeck.
"The great majority of parishioners want to maintain our traditions and transmit them to their children," said Father Olendzki, who came to the archdiocese from the state of Rio Grande do Sul, in southern Brazil.
Built for Polish immigrants in 1912, St. Stan's, as parishioners call it, rises from the black dirt fields of Orange County, where farmers have grown onions for generations. In recent years, successive seasons of flooding and, this summer, drought have punished the region, yielding puny onions that sell so poorly they go unharvested. More and more, farmers are selling their land for housing developments.
But Polish ways continue to shape the church. Once a month, Mrs. Foran, a soprano who studied Polish music to better fit in at the church, has a Mass with only Polish hymns. In the weeks before Christmas, St. Stanislaus holds a version of wigilia, a traditional Polish meatless dinner, usually served on Christmas Eve.
Mr. Westpy, 63, said he was raised in a conservative Catholic family. For many years, he worshiped at Presbyterian churches that his wife and children attended. But six years ago, he found himself returning to the teachings of his upbringing.
"This is as close to that in 1999, 2000, as you can get," Mr. Westpy said after Mass at St. Stanislaus a few weeks ago. "All the issues that arise these days, women in the priesthood, priests marrying, they don't say anything to me."
Mrs. Foran, who schools her children at home and has taken in runaways and troubled youths, said she saw the church as a fortress against moral decay. "It's a hard time we're going through, given where families are," she said, "and the church has to be strong. I think the church has to stand firm and uphold what is right."
Mrs. Foran said the parish's integrity sprang from its emphasis on following heavenly, rather than human, will. Other churches were "horizontal, rather than vertical," she said, meaning they were preoccupied with pleasing the people in the pews.
There are others, though, who raise questions about St. Stan's, but they do so as if ashamed, not allowing their names to be used. "Sometimes I look at other churches, and I see them doing a lot more for the poor," one parishioner said. Another, saying she had no doubts about Father Olendzki's integrity, complained that parishioners were never told the details of church finances, and would probably be more generous if they knew more.
But the questions fade into whispers under the blanket of tradition. Most parishioners at St. Stan's seem to have made their peace with the way things are. "They make the rules, and we just follow them," said Mrs. Blakener, the haircutter. "In order to be a Catholic, you have to abide by the rules."
 
St. Martin of Tours
Physically, St. Martin of Tours is a cavernous, drafty brick church not far from the Bronx Zoo, but spiritually, discerning its borders is nearly impossible.
St. Martin's roams Crotona in the person of the Rev. John Flynn, its pastor, trying to get neighborhood toughs to trade guns for crucifixes. It is Dolly de la Rosa and the rest of the food committee, delivering groceries to families in need. St. Martin's is the priests who show up after shootings, blessing the streets as a way of cleansing them from bloodshed.
"The church has been on the streets," Father Flynn said. "We're part of the streets, and they're part of us."
St. Martin's original worshipers were Irish and Italians, now largely replaced by Latinos, one of the fastest-growing segments of the New York Archdiocese. One recent Sunday, the church offered three Masses. The first, in English, filled slightly more than half the pews, and the last filled far less.
But the 10:30 Mass in Spanish, honoring a Puerto Rican patron saint, "took off like an airplane," in the words of Father Flynn.
For that Mass, the organ fell silent, replaced by maracas, guitars and songs honoring Our Lady of Providence. Children dressed in red suppressed giggles on their way down the aisle, carrying baskets of sugar cane, yucca, beans, pineapples and coconuts. Worshipers crowded the pews and spilled out the back.
Deacon Frankie Vazquez, an electrical contractor, said he felt St. Martin's offered an authentic bilingual Mass, while other churches that called themselves bilingual conducted perhaps a tenth of the Mass in Spanish. Nevertheless, he said, the church needed to work harder to create harmony among the different ethnic groups.
"There's tension at home, there's tension at work, there's even tension on the way to work," he said. "At least church should be a place of peace."
Like many Catholics in the New York Archdiocese who answered the Times poll, parishioners at St. Martin's said helping the poor and the homeless should be a priority of the church. In Crotona, poverty is not an abstraction.
"There's everything here," said Angel Cruz, 25, who sat through the Spanish Mass in his wheelchair. Mr. Cruz had fallen two stories on a construction site, breaking both legs. His former employer was helping Mr. Cruz through his recovery, but he said others at St. Martin's had worse problems.
"This is something the pope has to look at, how to help poor people a little more, to help people who are living in trains, and the children who don't have enough to eat," he said.
The church worked hard to rebuild housing after the Bronx went up in flames 20 years ago. Now, the worst of the violence seems past; Father Flynn was unable to recall any murders in the last few months.
These days, Father Flynn is turning his attention inward. Mindful of the shortage of priests, he plans to prepare his flock for the day it may no longer have a pastor, by building up a core of parishioners who could one day minister to the community themselves.
"The community doesn't need to die," Father Flynn said. "It stays, because it's been formed in the love of God."
 
Church of St. Patrick's
From its parking lot, the Church of St. Patrick's hardly appears a spiritual battleground. Through several Masses each Sunday, the lot is crammed with expensive cars and sport utility vehicles, which spill out onto the nearby road. Nestled among the horse farms of Bedford in suburban Westchester County, St. Patrick's is among the wealthiest parishes of the archdiocese. Its members adore the intimacy of St. Patrick's, which has remained true to character, adding Masses rather than buildings.
But drive around Bedford's streets on a weekday at 5 in the morning, as William J. Walsh, an orthopedic surgeon, sometimes does, and you may notice the lights already on in many houses. Outside, limousines wait for airport-bound executives, and commuters who get to work early. Here, many people have money but few have time. "They're doing well, but they're working hard to do well," said Dr. Walsh, a member of St. Patrick's. "That puts different strains on a community, and on a parish."
Patricia Perlstein, who was running the children's liturgy at St. Patrick's, realized she and the same core of three volunteers were showing up each week. She finally pleaded with other parents to pull their weight, which they then did.
"You ask them, they come," said her husband, Adam Perlstein.
The Rev. Joseph Koretski, a philosophy professor at Fordham University, contends that suburbs and economic prosperity pose unexpected difficulties that will demand creative new solutions of the Catholic Church in America. "City and country parishes have a whole different life of their own," he said. "Suburban cultures are very prosperous, but they're turned into themselves."
Msgr. James T. Gorman, 68, who came to St. Patrick's two years ago after a career at parishes in poor urban areas and the nearby women's prison at Bedford Hills, is still getting over the luxury of having generous parishioners with cash on hand.
But his mission, he feels, is drawing new families to the church. Though he is not the only monsignor at St. Patrick's, he attends every Mass, his white hair and beard reminding some parishioners of Santa Claus. "I believe in making people feel welcome," Monsignor Gorman said. "They want to belong."
