HEADLINE: Ivory Coast Coup Draws French Reply

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 25

 BODY:
In the wake of a coup in Ivory Coast, France said today that it wanted to send small numbers of troops to the country -- its former colony -- to protect the deposed president and to evacuate roughly 20,000 French nationals should that become necessary.
But tonight the Ivory Coast's new ruler refused entry to the French reinforcements, saying their presence could lead to a "coup de sang" or bloodbath. 
 "We say no to that," the new ruler, Gen. Robert Guei, said in a telephone interview with Agence France-Presse. The 550 French troops already on a base near the airport in Abidjan, the country's largest city, "is sufficient," he said.
The ousted President, Henri Konan Bedie, was reported to have taken sanctuary with the French garrison. Reports said 40 more French soldiers were ready to arrive by helicopter from Libreville, Gabon, and another 300 were awaiting orders in Dakar, the capital of Senegal.
At the moment there is no direct threat aimed at foreigners, but there has been looting and gunfire. The United States Embassy in Abidjan warned Americans to lock themselves in their homes, saying looters were going through the wealthy neighborhoods where foreigners live. However, one official said they seemed to be stealing only vehicles parked outside.
Armed soldiers have been joy-riding in stolen cars and taxis for two days, and have used their rifles and hand grenades to blow open the doors of downtown shops in the city of 3 million people. Today, orders were broadcast over the radio telling all soldiers to report to their units by this evening and to turn in all civilian vehicles at the central barracks.
General Guei, a former armed forces chief, had earlier said that Mr. Bedie should leave the country quickly because young officers who began the coup wanted to kill him. Tonight, he amended that, saying a nine-man national steering committee -- all military men -- would meet tomorrow to decide whether the former president could leave. He has already stipulated that Mr. Bedie's cabinet, many of whom are in the hands of mutineers, will stay.
Paris has condemned the coup and the Foreign Ministry said Mr. Bedie, at his own request, was at the Port-Bouet military base next to the Abidjan airport under the protection of the French 43rd Marine Infantry Battalion.
The French government, which has generally given up direct intervention in the affairs of its former colonies, has not demanded that Mr. Bedie be restored to power, but has called for the immediate re-establishment of order and security. News reports here were sketchy because it is Christmas Day and the coup caught almost everyone by surprise.
Ivory Coast has long been an island of relative stability, democracy and prosperity in the former French West Africa, and one of the pillars of French policy there. It is the world's biggest supplier of cocoa, and produces palm oil and other tropical products. Many French sun-worshipers vacationing in Africa head first for Abidjan on the direct Air France and Air Afrique flights and use it as a jumping-off spot to poorer countries.
The new military leaders said Abidjan airport, closed by the coup, would reopen on Sunday. The leaders of the army and police appeared on television tonight to pledge their allegiance to the new government.
Abidjan, the commercial capital, looks much like a French city. It has the same black-and-white arrow-shaped signs, traffic circles and red-and-white stone road markers. There are luxury hotels, nightclubs and restaurants, and the same stores and brands that can be seen in France are spotted there.
The government has been stable compared with those of other former colonies like Congo, Madagascar or the Comoro Islands. As a supplier of products that cannot be grown in Europe, Ivory Coast has become an important part of the French economy.
For decades, France had a much more interventionist policy in Africa than Britain, Portugal or other former colonial powers. It diplomatically embraced rulers that it approved of, and it also was ready to send troops -- often the Foreign Legion -- to prop up or restore presidents it favored.
Sometimes that contributed to stability in former French colonies. But it also contributed to resentment of some rulers who were perceived as puppets of France.
General Guei imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew in Abidjan today after two nights of looting and sporadic gunfire in some districts. He warned that violators would be summarily shot.
The streets were reported empty. Stores had been closed for 48 hours, but Friday night's curfew failed to curb looting. Unpaid soldiers mutinied on Thursday, leading to a breakdown of law and order; others joined in as generals tried to re-establish military discipline.
President Bedie was overthrown on Friday when General Guei, a former armed forces chief, took the reins of power. He set up a 10-man junta and urged politicians of the governing Democratic Party and the opposition to form a government of national unity.
Relations between France and its former colony have deteriorated in the last few months because of differences between President Bedie and Alassane Ouattara, a former prime minister and deputy director of the International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Ouattara, who is seen as a serious challenger to the long rule of the Democratic Party, wanted to run in next year's election, but Mr. Bedie's government barred him, claiming he was not a citizen and had forged identity documents.
Some French press comment today was equally severe toward both Mr. Bedie's and France's approach to its former colony. For the center-left newspaper Liberation, the tardy French reaction to the deteriorating political situation was a triple failure in political, military and diplomatic terms."

HEADLINE: A 15-Month Labor Dispute Turns Into a War of Attrition

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 22

 BODY:
The 15-month struggle between Kaiser Aluminum and the United Steelworkers of America is one of the biggest, longest and fiercest labor disputes in years, but it is far more than an old-fashioned labor war. It is a war of attrition, a test of wills and a propaganda war against the billionaire Texan who controls Kaiser, a man the union denounces as a latter-day robber baron.
It is also a battle over two clashing visions of the future of the American workplace. Kaiser's workers say they deserve job security in return for their hard work, while management favors contracting out hundreds of jobs as part of a drive to minimize costs and increase competitiveness, even if it means dropping longtime employees. 
 On Sept. 15, 1998, the steelworkers' union went on strike against Kaiser's five aluminum plants after rejecting the company's demand to cut health benefits and eliminate 240 jobs by contracting work to lower-paying nonunion companies. Then in January, with the strikers disheartened from four months without a paycheck, union leaders told Kaiser that the strikers wanted to go back to work while the two sides continued negotiating.
But Kaiser took an unusual step, imposing a lockout and refusing to let any of the union's members return unless the union accepted Kaiser's demands.
"It was a slap in the face," said Dean Wise, a 21-year veteran of the mills whose family is scraping by thanks to his wife's job at Kmart.
The company lockout was also a severe blow to Spokane, a blue-collar city of 180,000, where Kaiser is the second-largest private employer. Two of Kaiser's five aluminum plants and 2,000 of its 2,900 unionized workers are based in this city, which is known for bloody union battles early this century.
Now, two mornings each week, in the shadow of the evergreen-covered Mica Mountains, Mr. Wise braves the biting dawn chill and pickets outside a gigantic erector set of a mill that heats aluminum, stretches it out and rolls it smooth. Huddled next to an oil drum filled with burning firewood, the pickets use bullhorns to heap abuse on the replacement workers as they drive in and out, calling them "scabs" and worse. Under federal regulations, Kaiser's lockout bars any union members from working.
"People who showed me pictures when their kids were born, now they're crossing the picket line," said his wife, Wendy Wise, a leader of a support group called Spouses of Steel. "It's real tough."
The workers complain about how much the company has changed since its glory days under Henry J. Kaiser, the industrialist who built Hoover Dam, Grand Coulee Dam and many of the ships in the World War II Navy. He was renowned for his generosity toward employees and for being a pioneer in providing employer-financed health coverage.
Kaiser is now controlled by a very different man, Charles E. Hurwitz, whose Houston-based holding company, Maxxam Inc., controls 63 percent of Kaiser's shares. In the 1980's, he rocketed to prominence as a corporate raider, acquiring Simplicity Patterns and Pacific Lumber -- the target of thousands of environmental protesters because of its aggressive cutting of California redwoods.
The federal government is suing Mr. Hurwitz, seeking $820 million, saying that he and his company contributed to the collapse of the United Savings Association of Texas in 1988. The bailout of the savings and loan cost taxpayers $1.6 billion and was the third largest in the nation's history. Mr. Hurwitz's spokesmen say that the suit is unfounded and that the savings and loan collapsed not because of mismanagement, but because of Texas' economic problems at the time.
Mr. Hurwitz acquired control of Kaiser in 1987, and labor relations have soured ever since as Kaiser has sought to reduce its work force.
"Henry J. Kaiser believed that the people who ran the plant were valuable assets, and he treated them that way," said Tim Charboneau, a millworker. "Hurwitz just seems to want to throw people away."
Ray Milchovich, Kaiser's chief executive, defended the company's cost cutting, insisting that it aimed not just to increase profits, but to preserve jobs long term by keeping the company in business.
"These are high-cost plants battling for survival in a very competitive industry," he said. "To sit and argue over what level of slop, what level of lack of productivity is appropriate in the year 2000 and beyond in a very competitive business is ridiculous. Who does that benefit? It certainly doesn't benefit employees, and it certainly doesn't benefit the shareholders."
For many workers, the lockout has cast a pall over the holiday season, even with the union giving everyone $140 a week, running a food bank and providing emergency payments to make sure no families lose their homes or primary vehicles.
Some workers have stopped giving allowances to their teenagers because they can no longer afford it. Many families have been forced to sell their second cars. And many workers grumble about not being able to afford presents for their children or grandchildren, although the United Steelworkers, with donations from other unions, has arranged a $25 gift certificate for each child.
"I'm barely making it," said Rolfe Lauren, a machine operator. "I've had to take $8,000 to $9,000 out of my savings to pay my bills. It's tough right now. But sacrifices have to be made to win this fight, and that's fine by me."
Children are also pitching in. Dan Giachetti, a metal transporter, said, "My 15-year-old daughter is doing a lot of baby-sitting. She's doing this to help the family out anyway she can. I'm humbled to tears. I don't tell her no because it's her way of helping."
Surprisingly, some workers insist that Christmas 1999 is their best holiday ever, offering reasons that are hard for outsiders to appreciate.
Many workers have marveled not only at their own fortitude, but at that of their friends. They say the struggle has forged lasting friendships the way war does. And they are amazed that co-workers they once dismissed as muscle-bound grunts have turned into leaders and sometimes heroes.
For many workers, this is a Christmas when solidarity and togetherness are the most precious gifts.
Jody Viebrock, a data-entry worker, offered a bittersweet smile when she acknowledged not being able to buy gifts for her two daughters this Christmas.
"We've talked about getting back to basics," she said. "We've talked about what Christmas really means, and materialism isn't where it's at. It's about singing Christmas carols and making Christmas cookies."
The workers, who average about $14 an hour, voice a sense of betrayal. They say that in 1984 they accepted a $4.50-an-hour cut in wages and benefits to keep Kaiser competitive, with an implicit promise that those concessions would be made up in good times, something they say has never happened. A decade later, in 1994, the workers agreed to new concessions, worth $50 million, under which each worker took on more responsibilities, a move that resulted in cutting the work force at one Spokane mill to 1,100 from 1,400.
"We worked with them to trim jobs and combine jobs and they said there'd be no more cuts," said Wes Beck, president of that mill's union local. "They said they wouldn't throw any more of the work over the fence, and now they come back and say they want to throw all these other jobs over the fence."
Kaiser officials insist that the company made no such promises. "The argument that there have been some broken promises or broken trust is a false accusation," said Jeremy Sherman, Kaiser's chief labor negotiator. He said the company would cut the number of employees at the plants largely through attrition, and was offering the workers a $3.13-an-hour wage increase over five years in exchange for increased productivity.
Company executives say Kaiser needs to reduce costs continually to compete with larger rivals.
"Alcoa is far stronger than Kaiser is," Mr. Sherman said. "Its plants are newer, larger and operate with far greater efficiency. Unless Kaiser can find ways to compete more effectively, the world of the future will not treat companies like Kaiser kindly."
But union leaders say that Kaiser was already prospering before the strike, thanks to their concessions.
To squeeze the company, the steelworkers have formed an unusual alliance with environmentalists, backing their efforts to stop Mr. Hurwitz's cutting of California redwoods. Together, they crowded into Maxxam's shareholders meeting outside Houston in May, and they ran two candidates, Howard Metzenbaum, former United States senator, and Abner Mikva, a former White House counsel, for seats on Maxxam's board. The union candidates lost, but they received 40 percent of the votes not controlled by Mr. Hurwitz.
The union has dispatched more than a dozen workers around the country to urge Kaiser customers to stop buying aluminum from Kaiser until it ends the lockout. In a blow to Kaiser, the Pepsi Bottling Company announced this fall that it would stop buying Kaiser aluminum.
At the moment, the union is playing what could prove to be its trump card. The union, with its environmental friends and its allies in state legislatures and in Congress, is urging the Bonneville Power Administration to stop providing Kaiser with low-cost, subsidized hydroelectric power on the ground that it is not a good corporate citizen.
If the union could persuade the power authority, a federal agency, Kaiser's electricity rates would soar, making the company immediately uncompetitive.
"We're saying that people who receive preferred rates subsidized by everyone else should be held accountable," said Larry Strom, a smelter worker. "They shouldn't be locking out their work force or trashing the environment. What's going on now is not right."

HEADLINE: Senior Bush's Loss Set Course for Son's Candidacy

SERIES: LOOKING BACK/The '92 Presidential Campaign

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
For months, George W. Bush had sensed what was coming; he could see it in the news coverage of the campaign, feel it in the restlessness of the crowds he addressed on his father's behalf, hear it in acquaintances' apologies for their sudden fascination with a political insurgent named Ross Perot.
But Mr. Bush had tried, with intermittent success, to smile through it all, because that was his role: the tireless cheerleader, the dauntless optimist. 
 By 3 p.m. on Nov. 3, 1992, there was no more pretending.
"The exit polls look bad," Mr. Bush told his father, who had clung to the belief that he might beat back Bill Clinton's challenge in the end. Mr. Bush was actually underselling the truth. The exit polls looked awful.
And yet, hours later, when Mr. Bush listened to his father bid goodbye to the presidency in a concession speech in a Houston hotel, all the waiting and all the knowing that had preceded the moment did not make it any easier.
"I remember looking down at a White House photographer, a woman who just had tears streaming down her face -- and mascara -- and then I kind of looked at the ceiling," Mr. Bush said in a recent interview here. "If I'd looked at her, I would have been weeping like a baby."
To this day, his father's failed re-election effort stands as one of the most difficult episodes of Mr. Bush's life, a period when events seemed to spin out of his family's control and he watched a man he reveres suffer the ultimate public rejection.
But, just as important, the loss carried with it indelible lessons in the controllable and uncontrollable ways a campaign can go wrong, and it has a clear bearing on the kind of candidate Mr. Bush is today.
In 1992, he came to question the devotion of some of his father's associates from inside the Beltway. Now, he entrusts his presidential campaign to an "iron triangle" of three longtime advisers in Austin.
He saw his father tarred and feathered for agreeing to raise taxes after saying he would not. Now, Mr. Bush seems to avoid unnecessarily emphatic pledges that could come back to haunt him. He is also assiduous about articulating the themes and priorities of his campaign and projecting an inclusive image, two things his father was criticized for not doing well enough.
"His father's term in office -- and the campaign of 1992 -- have had as much impact on the way he's been governor and his current campaign as any other experience in his life," said Robert M. Teeter, who managed the re-election effort.
That bitter year was also a case study of the traits that distinguish the Bushes: their loyalty to one another, their stiff upper lips, their potent belief in their own worthiness.
It provided a similarly revealing glimpse of Mr. Bush, underscoring his capacity for anger and especially his competitiveness, so keen that he responded to his father's loss by insisting on a different kind of victory and training for a marathon, the first and only one he ever ran.
Political analysts, journalists and even some of Mr. Bush's opponents have speculated that his current quest is in part an effort to avenge his father's defeat. Mr. Bush has repeatedly laughed at this suggestion, but it is a sensitive enough point among his friends that one of them called a reporter to dispute it even though the reporter had not broached the subject.
Another friend, Joe O'Neill, a businessman in Midland, Tex., who grew up with Mr. Bush, acknowledged that the way President Clinton ended up comporting himself in office probably helped keep Mr. Bush's emotional memory of 1992 alive.
"The ignominy of losing to this guy, in particular, probably burns him," Mr. O'Neill said. "He has no respect for Clinton morally. And morals count in the Bush family."
Whatever Mr. Bush's tangle of motives, his friends and relatives say that what he witnessed in 1992 illustrated firsthand how quickly and dramatically political winds can shift and how little can be taken for granted. That perspective, they say, could stand him in good stead over the months to come.
"I think having seen his dad go through four national campaigns, particularly the last one, has given George a very realistic picture of what he faces," said former President Bush in a written response to several questions that were submitted to him, an interview format that he requested.
"When there is a bump in the road, I expect he will not be thrown off course," he added.
Although Barbara Bush has described her husband's interest in their eldest son's campaign as obsessive, the former president said he did not butt in with unsolicited counsel.
"I am available if George wants to ask my advice, but I was then and he is now," President Bush said. "I am yesterday. He is tomorrow."
President Bush receded into the past sooner than he wanted to, sooner than anyone around him thought he would. A year and half before the 1992 election, on the heels of the Persian Gulf war, he had a stratospheric job approval rating of 90 percent.
It dipped 20 points or so later in the year, but that seemed little cause for worry. "We went into the Christmas season upbeat," George W. Bush said.
Mr. Bush also had more personal reasons to be happy, because he was finally making the kind of name for himself that he would need if he wanted to run for governor, a prospect that had long been on his mind.
After living briefly in Washington to work on his father's successful 1988 presidential campaign, Mr. Bush had returned to his beloved Texas, settled in Dallas and put together a partnership that bought the Texas Rangers baseball team and paved the path toward the construction of a gleaming stadium.
Mr. Bush was the organization's managing partner and public face, an exuberant presence not in some distant sky box but in a seat above first base, where he beamed with pleasure as fans approached him for autographs.
But as 1992 began, his father's fate seemed increasingly uncertain.
Although Mr. Bush, feistier by nature than his father, had urged the president and his advisers to give the re-election campaign an early, aggressive launching, it was not moving as fast as it could have been, nor was it headed in a clear direction.
A downturn in the economy showed no sign of abating. And President Bush was still recovering from the departure of John H. Sununu, his chief of staff, who had been coaxed into resigning after doing and saying things that embarrassed the president, an unacceptable breach of loyalty in the Bush family's eyes.
Most ominous was the emergence of two protest candidates in addition to the herd of Democrats ganging up on President Bush. The first was Patrick J. Buchanan, whose attacks on the president in the Republican primaries badly bruised him. The second was Mr. Perot, a wealthy Dallas entrepreneur.
George W. Bush's business office was across the street from a small building where Perot posters, yard signs and bumper stickers were sold, and he had a perfect vantage point to observe the activity there.
"I remember seeing cars lined up, and these were nice, North Dallas cars," Mr. Bush said. "They should be screaming Republican."
Some of the drivers were people who were friendly with Mr. Bush or his wife, Laura, and she said he had called a few to seek explanations.
"They'd say, 'We love your dad, we love your dad, but we just feel we've got to,' " Mrs. Bush said in a recent interview. "And when that started, there was no way to figure out what was going to happen."
Her husband conferred with Mary Matalin, the campaign's deputy manager, as often as three times a day. He flew frequently from Dallas to Washington to try to pump energy and confidence into troops who seemed less spirited and focused than in 1988.
He also confronted the Republican opinion makers who were expressing doubts about his father.
"He was meeting with high-powered motormouths and trying to keep people on the reservation," Ms. Matalin said. But it seemed to Ms. Matalin and to Mr. Bush that they could not catch a break. President Bush's approval ratings sank lower, tugged in part by the country's economic doldrums, which the president had been slow to acknowledge. And the portrait of President Bush that took hold in news coverage was that of an elite, weak leader disconnected from the concerns of most Americans.
This characterization, as much as anything else, devastated his oldest son, who could not stand to see his father's character impugned.
"They so love each other," Ms. Matalin explained. "It's something to behold. I've been in a million situations with the father and son, and it's a movie -- I don't know how else to explain it. The relationship is so complete."
Perhaps because of that closeness, George W. Bush loudly berated reporters on a few occasions, demonstrating a temper that he has since controlled.
"I didn't act well," he conceded. "I got frustrated because of my dad. I got in some people's faces, out of frustration for him, out of love for him, not out of disdain for the person. In retrospect, those were such strong emotions for me, to see a good man get whipped."
Some members of the Bush family seemed amazed that voters might prefer Mr. Clinton or Mr. Perot over a man with such a long and distinguished political resume.
Barbara Bush scribbled in her diary, "I do not know whether George will survive this political year or not, but I do know that he is the only stable person running."
The last weeks of the campaign were tense. Laura Bush said she could still remember the dread she felt every morning when, in a ritual that she and her husband continue to this day, he would go to the front stoop to get the newspapers and bring them back to bed. Too often, she said, the publications carried newly discouraging polls or freshly critical editorials.
She said that she and her husband used to watch the morning news programs on television as well, but the habit died in fall 1992. "We just didn't want to hear another bad story," she said. "It was too much."
Her husband said that he knew it was all over before the actual moment of reckoning but that he tried not to let it show.
"I expect if he got down, he wouldn't burden me with that," his father said. "We don't work that way."
On Nov. 2, 1992, Mr. Bush was on the campaign plane with his father as it traced a path through various Southern states on the way to Houston, where the whole family would gather for the election. The Oak Ridge Boys, a vocal group that sometimes traveled with President Bush, sang "Amazing Grace" at his request.
The next day, as the returns trickled in, President Bush went to buy a fishing reel. Ms. Matalin remembered that he also joined George W. Bush and his brother Jeb in a game on the hotel grounds.
"Most candidates sit on the phone all day," Ms. Matalin said. "They were out there playing horseshoes."
It was not that President Bush had stopped caring.
"It's hard to describe the emotions of something like this," he said in a Nov. 4 diary entry that was included in his recent book of letters and other writings, "All the Best, George Bush." "But it's hurt, hurt, hurt and I guess it's the pride, too."
Mr. Bush took 38 percent of the popular vote, to 43 percent for Mr. Clinton and 19 percent for Ross Perot. The president's defeat, oddly, made his oldest son's current candidacy possible. George W. Bush said that he would not have felt comfortable about running for governor of Texas in 1994 if his father had still been in office. And without the five years he has spent as the leader of the country's second most populous state, Mr. Bush would not be in a credible position to seek the Republican nomination today.
But in the days immediately after the election he was mainly concerned with dissipating the frustration and disappointment he felt. So he laced up his running sneakers, put on the grubby outfit he typically used for exercise and hit the pavement.
He ran too far and too fast, opening the window to a severe cold and prompting a stern reprimand from his physician, who told him it was ridiculous to shoot for the Dallas marathon in December. Mr. Bush settled on the Houston marathon in January, still an ambitious goal.
His parents stood and waited at the 19-mile mark and, as Mr. Bush remembered it, cheered him on.
"There are some elderly women ahead of you!" his mother teased. "Why are you running so slow?"
His father just shouted, loudly and proudly, "There's my boy!"

SECTION: Section 4; Page 8; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: THEN/NOW: REFLECTIONS ON THE MILLENNIUM;
The Glory of Earth Treks and Star Treks

 BODY:
The last millennium encompassed the great age of geographic discovery, when hardy explorers penetrated the world's landmasses and mapped the great oceans that, much to everyone's surprise, turned out to cover 70 percent of the globe. So accessible has the Earth's surface become that today adventurers scale Everest and hike across Antarctica, tourists traverse Africa, and lone sailors circumnavigate the globe. Even the ocean depths, the last great frontier on Earth, have begun to yield their secrets to undersea explorers, revealing a world seething with bizarre life forms.
Now, as the millennium draws to a close, the frontier that beckons lies far overhead. Thirty years ago, Neil Armstrong took humanity's first small step on the moon, declaring it "one giant leap for mankind," only to have the space program retreat to tinkering in low Earth orbit. The question for the next century is whether this nation and others should invest heavily in space exploration, sending astronauts to Mars and unmanned probes to distant star systems, or use those resources instead to make the planet we inhabit a place no one would dream of leaving. 
 A thousand years ago, most people knew little of what lay beyond their immediate localities. Then, in the 13th and 14th centuries, Marco Polo and others followed overland routes to the Far East, returning with wondrous tales and goods. When those routes were closed, Western Europeans turned to the seas in search of new pathways.
The Portuguese, the first to make exploration a state enterprise, pushed down the coast of Africa and around to India. Columbus, seeking a westward route to Asia, discovered a continent whose existence he had not imagined. Magellan found the sea route around South America and died while circumnavigating the globe. The great age of oceanic exploration lasted three centuries and brought a change in perspective. The sea, once a barrier, was now a highway that led everywhere.
Meanwhile, on land, Spanish explorers pushed into most of Central and South America, English and French explorers traveled North America, and Lewis and Clark charted the American West. In the 19th century, explorers reached the interiors of Africa and Australia, and the coast of Antarctica. One decade into the 20th century, the last recesses, at the North and South Poles, were finally reached.
The Age of Exploration had been largely a European enterprise, driven by a mix of motives. The primary focus was a search for trade routes and riches, buttressed by a missionary zeal to convert the heathen, a drive for colonies, a thirst for knowledge about the natural world and a lust for the glory of it all.
Only a few of these motives are relevant to plumbing the ocean. Salvagers seek to retrieve gold from wrecked treasure ships on the ocean floor, and scientists seek new knowledge using undersea technologies originally developed for military purposes. But entrepreneurs who had hoped to mine the seabed for minerals can only wait for the economics to look better. The difficulty of operating in inky blackness under the crushing weight of the sea has ensured that progress will be slow. With only one-tenth of 1 percent of the deep seabed explored, we know less about it than about the surface of Mars.
As space enthusiasts gaze longingly at the solar system and the heavens beyond, they are entering a realm where few of the usual motives for exploration apply. The race to the moon was propelled by the struggle against Soviet Communism. But once that race had been won, the nation turned to less far-reaching efforts, like the international space station now under construction in low orbit. That is not the sort of venture to set pulses racing.
The best rationale for space exploration is to gain scientific knowledge and to search for life forms elsewhere, a task performed most cheaply and safely by unmanned probes. But the idea of sending astronauts to other planets remains a powerful, animating force. Some space officials predict that humans will be walking on Mars within two decades, or at least by mid-century. Visionaries are good at dreaming up reasons for such an arduous, three-year excursion -- the need to fulfill our destiny, to find extra resources and living space, to guarantee survival of the human species should an asteroid hit Earth. But the most compelling reason for humans to set foot on Mars is for the sheer thrill and glory of it. That passion should be indulged only when new tactics and technologies bring the costs and risks down to bearable levels, or private financing can be found. Meanwhile, there are even more formidable challenges -- in eliminating poverty, eradicating disease and educating the ignorant -- to be faced here on Earth.

HEADLINE: The 2 Million in America's Prisons

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Punishing the Country" (column, Dec. 21), by Anthony Lewis:
Mr. Lewis decries the two million population of America's prisons and jails, concluding that the growth of the number of prisoners in the last 10 years "has a profound social cost." 
 The significant decrease in crimes, especially crimes of violence, over that 10 years must be in part attributable to the reality that a substantial number of criminals are safely behind bars.
Perhaps Mr. Lewis should consider the social -- not to mention economic -- cost, of "thoroughly brutalized" criminals free to prematurely resume their careers in crime, violent or not, because of a shortage of prisons.
 
STUART C. SLOAME
Washington, Dec. 21, 1999

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report;
Millennium Bonanza Doesn't Pan Out in N.Y.

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
WHEN the clock strikes midnight this Friday, the throngs in Times Square will be welcoming in a new year at what is expected to be the biggest New Year's Eve party in the square's 95-year history. But not everyone in New York will be in a festive mood, especially those who banked on the changeover to the Year 2000 to usher in big profits as well as big crowds. For them, the giant ball descending from atop 1 Times Square will more than likely symbolize fallen expectations.
There was a general assumption that big millennium celebrations would translate into people's clamoring to attend. But as it turns out, many people have opted to stay home because of Y2K fears and worry about travel and crowds. And unexpected resistance to high prices has caused party cancellations, restaurants closing for the night of the 31st and much lower rates on hotel rooms. 
 The same pattern of resistance is true in other cities from Washington to Minneapolis-St. Paul to Los Angeles. Cruise ships also managed to fill their millennium cruises only by scaling back their inflated prices.
But for many Americans, New York is still the city most synonymous with New Year's Eve partying and revelry, so cancellation of the Celebration 2000 party scheduled for the Jacob Javits Convention Center on New Year's Eve was particularly embarrassing.
With Andrea Bocelli, Sting, Aretha Franklin and Tom Jones among the scheduled performers, the tickets, priced at $1,000 to $2,500, were presented as a bargain in a city where tickets to Broadway shows cost upward of $75. Although Celebration 2000 eventually scaled down plans and prices, the public stayed away, and the event was scrapped.
Many other big-name events still have space available. These include the dinner party with Champagne and dancing to three different orchestras at the Waldorf-Astoria ($1,500 a person); the Metropolitan Opera performance of Act II of "Die Fledermaus" followed by dinner and dancing on the tiers of the Opera House ($1,500 to $2,500); World Yacht dinner cruises with open bar and live music ($550 to $999); dinner and dancing at the Rainbow Room ($3,000); a Madison Square Garden concert with Billy Joel, followed by dinner and drinks ($153 to $1,002); Windows on the World ($300 in the bar, $2,000 with dinner in the dining room), and Samplings restaurant, on the second floor of the Crowne Plaza in Times Square (where for $550 guests can enjoy a six-course dinner meal with Champagne and a close-up view of the crowd and the ball drop).
Some of those prices have been lowered from original levels, and some hotels that had planned to sell millennium packages have abandoned the idea.
Yet most city hotels will be full or close to it, because occupancy is always high over New Year's, and because New York has only about 65,000 hotel rooms, compared with about 120,000 in Las Vegas and 94,000 in Orlando, Fla. Moreover, even on a normal day -- and New York is anything but normal on New Year's Eve -- the city's hotels are the costliest in the United States. At an average $178.60 a day this year, according to Smith Travel Research, rates are more than $40 higher than in San Francisco, the next most expensive.
To increase occupancy, many New York hotels lowered room rates and dropped the four-night requirement to three or even two nights.
For example, $695 rooms at the Waldorf-Astoria -- that's for one day -- sold for $389 through Hotel Reservations Network, a consolidator that still has rooms available in 12 New York hotels (although the Waldorf is full). Rooms from $550 at the Hilton at 53rd Street and Avenue of the Americas sold for $179, while two weeks ago the Central Park Inter-Continental New York listed its rooms for the holiday with Priceline.com, discounting its posted $389 daily rate to $250.
The Michelangelo, at 51st Street and Seventh Avenue, considered setting its four-night millennium packages at between $4,000 and $8,000, but eventually made them $1,800 to $2,700 for three nights. And three hotels that offered to rent their building and hotel staff over New Year's Eve did not receive any takers.
The 627-room Millennium Broadway in Times Square was asking $3 million rental from Dec. 31 through Jan. 2, but now has two-night packages beginning at $550 a night. The 155-room Fitzpatrick Grand Central Hotel at 44th between Lexington and Third Avenues was asking $1.5 million rental, while the 92-room Fitzpatrick Manhattan at Lexington and 57th Street was available for $1 million. When neither found takers, they put together packages for $1,999 total per room with a four-night minimum stay, or $400 a night per room with a two-night minimum stay. All three hotels still have packages available.
This price cutting is little different from the yield management widely practiced by airlines and cruise ships, which raise or lower fares according to demand. Or from sales on clothing or other slow-moving items in shops or department stores. What is different is the refusal of many people, even during flush economic times, to pay sky-high prices.
Yet there are still bargains to be had in New York, including the light show, fireworks and other free entertainment in Times Square on Friday and into the new year. It will cost $7 for a bird's eye view of the waning hours of the old year in 2000 from atop the Empire State Building, which will open at 9:30 a.m. on Friday and remain open until 7 p.m.
And there is the city itself, the one that never sleeps. Especially over New Year's.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 12-26-99: Word & Image;
Only Yesterday

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
To guess where we're headed, it helps to appreciate how far and fast we've come. As an obliging media person, I am measuring: not the millennium, merely a century. Not any century, just the one I've inhabited, surmising that it set a record for stretching human experience and endurance.
My family's journey is one good measure of our astonishing leaps. My parents were born at the turn of the last century in villages that in swift succession flew the flags of Austria-Hungary, Poland, Nazi Germany, the Soviet Union and now Ukraine. They bore me in Germany (for a time, the German Democratic Republic). I had kids in New York and Washington, and one of them closed the century by giving birth in Hollywood. We went west, Mr. Greeley, at a pace you never imagined. 
 En route, like much of the world -- whose population quadrupled to six billion -- our family survived Hitler and Stalin, several hot wars and a cold one, and celebrated the demise of colonialism, fascism and communism. Like much of the world, we became converts to democratic capitalism. Quite a trip.
Even without such extensive migration, most Americans experienced a similarly wild ride: from rural isolation and industrial drudgery to communities and comforts once unimaginable. The country's population grew from 76 million to 275 million, but that only hints at our dizzy metamorphosis. Consider instead how 14,000 motor vehicles in 1900 exploded to more than 200 million in 2000, with vast reverberations of density and dispersion. Or consider the psychic dislocations that occurred as a day's travel was redefined from 10 miles by horse to 10,000 by jet.
And how can we grasp the effects of the 100-year surge in the typical American's life span from 47 years to 76? Or the growth of the over-65 population from 3 million to 35 million, even as the workweek has shrunk from 60 hours to 38 and most labor has come to require more brain than brawn? Fewer than one in 10 of our teenagers went as far as high school in 1900, but eight out of 10 now graduate and nearly a third of these finish college as well.
Still, our learning seems hardly adequate to our vaulting technologies. Electricity and telegraphy were still novelties when this e-mail century began. The Wrights were three years from their first 12 seconds aloft. Without radio, films or television, oratory was our main communal entertainment. Most people in 1900 washed with pitcher and basin in the bedroom, and not until 1907 did Ellsworth Statler offer every hotel guest a private bath at moderate prices -- in Buffalo, the nation's eighth-largest city.
Our democracy was no less primitive in 1900. The electorate was not yet trusted to choose senators directly. Women were not trusted to vote, period. Black Americans, barely a generation out of slavery, were being lawfully subjugated, even lynched in much of the country, and economically deprived everywhere. Corporations were managed mostly by their owners, who gave slim public accounting. The federal budget totaled $500 million, a sum comparable to $10 billion today (when the budget is $1.8 trillion); it required no income tax. The president's visible staff (now represented as 500) numbered 10, including four messengers and doorkeepers.
While culling these facts, I was reminded by Frederick Lewis Allen's midcentury history, "The Big Change," that despite our spectacular transformations, some aspects of the American temperament have remained surprisingly constant, in both admirable and deplorable ways.
On the proud side of the ledger, there is our tendency to meet both foreign challenge and domestic failure with reasoned effort, experiment and reform. Though capable of passionate mood swings, we have never relied for long on ideological orthodoxy or been seduced by radical nostrums. We have gradually democratized our economic and political systems without dismantling them. We have expanded but also restrained the role of government. We have let the creativity of individuals determine the direction of our progress.
But we have failed to tame the selfishness that is deemed the source of our energy. We have been stingy with communal projects. We have rarely been generous with the poor among us and around the world.
At the beginning of the century, as at the end, too many of our businesses have strained to avoid the competition they claim to value. Through trusts, monopolies and mergers, and with legal bribes to politicians, our capitalist elites have maneuvered to escape taxation, corner markets, rig prices and otherwise trick customers and taxpayers. In 1999 as in 1900, the profit motive that we employ to inspire us ends up also corrupting us -- until with deductible charities we try to repurchase conscience.
That charity remains essential to the survival of so many Americans is a further constant of our century. One study in 1900 concluded that about 10 million Americans -- or 13 percent -- were "failing to obtain sufficient necessaries for maintaining physical efficiency." That's a pretty good parallel to our contemporary "poverty line," the federal standard of minimally adequate income for a family of four. And behold: the current standard of $16,600 defines a needy population of precisely 13 percent.
We would appear even more coldhearted if we quantified the disparity between the richest and poorest Americans or between the median income of American families -- $39,000 -- and the vast majority of the families around the world.
Surely the 21st century will be no less transforming than the 20th. I can foresee human habitats in space and beneath the seas, artificial environments to grow our crops and transcontinental parliaments, courts and cops. But however great our progress, I fear we will still not properly share our bounty with the poor. It is a blind spot as great as that of our forebears who insisted, only yesterday, that wars, and even slavery, were necessary to their prosperity.

HEADLINE: High-Tech Industry, Long Shy of Politics, Is Now Belle of Ball

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
At a time when Congress is bitterly divided and unable to reach consensus on issues like gun control and health care, Democrats and Republicans are happily reaching across party lines to pass legislation backed by high-tech companies.
The high-tech industry, at the same moment, is lavishing new attention on Washington and changing its once-aloof posture toward the federal government. 
 Republicans and Democrats are both eager to win the loyalties of high-tech companies and executives, knowing that they represent untold jobs, wealth and ultimately votes and campaign contributions.
For its part, the industry has realized that the federal government can do its members as much harm as good. Microsoft, and its battle with the Justice Department, along with a spate of other threatened legal problems, drilled this point home.
"Microsoft was a poster child for our industry," said Connie Correll, director of communications for the Information Technology Industry Council, a trade organization that represents America Online, Dell and I.B.M., among others.
Now, the city the industry once eschewed -- along with standard-issue, inside-the-Beltway practices like lobbying and writing campaign checks -- is full of visiting high-technology barons and marquee lobbyists who are working long hours to press the industry's agenda.
When representatives of Silicon Valley arrive in Washington they often receive the kind of red-carpet treatment once reserved for Hollywood stars. In September, Meg Whitman, the founder of the auction site eBay, made her third trip to Washington this year. In a single day, she met with more than 20 senators and House members, dividing her attentions carefully between the political parties. She was feted by Republicans at lunch and Democrats at dinner.
"They are stars," said Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who heads the telecommunications subcommittee that oversees many Internet start-ups. "People want to know them, touch them," added his colleague Representative James P. Moran, Democrat of Virginia.
Like suitors cooling their heels on the front porch, Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill have spent the last year doting on the high-technology industry and its kingpins, often working in rare harmony on issues dear to the heart of high-tech companies.
"We've been able to get stuff through Congress at a time that it is hard to do that," said Marc Andreessen, the co-founder of Netscape Communications who has now started his own company. It is tough, he said, for members "to be anti-high tech."
Last year, Congress granted the industry a three-year moratorium on e-commerce sales taxes, increased the number of job visas for high-tech workers and tightened restrictions on class-action lawsuits against high-tech companies whose stock prices plummet. This year, Congress extended a tax credit for research and development to five years and limited lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures, among other things.
More complicated issues await Congress next year, including new bouts on visas and taxation and a debate over expanding access to Internet lines.
"A few years ago you had a handful of bills that affected the industry," said John Scheibel, the point person for Yahoo in Washington. "This year you have literally hundreds of bills."
And both Republicans and Democrats are unrelenting in their devotion to the industry. Congressional Republicans point proudly to their "e-contract," Democrats promote their "e-genda." But the two packages of bills have one thing in common -- they greatly benefit the high-technology industry. In fact, high-tech issues are so popular, the House and Senate both formed high-tech working groups this year, and members virtually stampeded to sign up.
"The level of interest is as high or higher than any other set of issues I'm aware of," said Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader from South Dakota. "It's a new paradigm."
The most important victory for the industry this year was passage of a bill that will limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures. The measure, one of the few high-technology issues of the year with partisan overtones, pitted big business, which aggressively pushed for the measure along with the industry, against trial lawyers. The matchup put Democrats in an uncomfortable position, because trial lawyers are an important Democratic cash constituency. Still, such is the power of the high-tech industry that enough Democrats banded together to pass the bill.
Then just before the recess came another victory. Mr. Moran and other moderate New Democrats bucked their Democratic leaders to help salvage a digital signature bill, which would give cybersignatures the legal weight of ink-and-paper signatures. That measure must be reconciled with the Senate version next year. Lawmakers also extended a crucial research and development tax credit to five years from one year.
The battle over the digital signatures bill is a textbook example of how the new politics of high-tech has changed the workings, and the old alliances, in Congress. Just before Congress went home for the holidays, 30 lobbyists piled into Mr. Moran's office to try to resurrect the bill before the end of the session. "They knew they needed our votes," Mr. Moran said. "They realized we understood the issue, and that we wanted to be helpful and that we had the largest caucus in Congress -- 64 members."
The New Democrats, a collection of moderate House members who bill themselves as high-technology's sweethearts, then banded with Republicans to defeat the Democratic leadership bill, which included consumer protections the industry deemed objectionable.
Republicans looked on that Democratic battle with glee -- along with the fight over Y2K lawsuits -- convinced many more would follow, including next year's possible vote on China's trade status.
Unlike the titans of the old economy, like the oil companies and farmers, the high-tech sector has no particular home in Congress, no single committee to fight its battles, like energy or agriculture. Instead, it has a plethora of benefactors, working across party lines to get things done on issues they consider nonpartisan and nonideological. "You have to work hard to make technology issues Democrat or Republican, liberal or conservative," said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts. "It's not the contras versus the Sandinistas."
That is an important change. In 1996, when Congress passed a bill that would make it a crime to distribute indecent material on the Internet, there was a partisan free-for-all in which social conservatives rallied against pro-business Republicans and Democrats. It was one of the first efforts Congress had made to grapple with the Internet. The United States Supreme Court found the law unconstitutional.
Nowadays, on many high-tech issues, it is not unusual to find a liberal Democrat, like Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, working closely with conservative Republican colleagues, like Senators John Ashcroft of Missouri and Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, on encryption legislation. Representative Christopher Cox, a conservative Republican from California, bonded with Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, in battling efforts to tax sales on the Internet. Typically, these coalitions hew to their constituents -- I.B.M. is Vermont's largest employer and Novell has its headquarters in Utah.
In the House, Representative David Dreier, Republican of California, Robert W. Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia, and Thomas M. Davis III, a Virginia Republican whose district includes a growing number of high-tech companies, among others, are viewed as industry experts.
The New Democrats are often willing to buck their own leadership to live up to the label as technology boosters. In the past two years, their numbers have grown, to 64 this year from 41 in 1997.
These New Democrats have breakfast with high-tech executives every week and visit Silicon Valley routinely. "I think they are trying to create a mini high-tech party in a way," said Wade Randlett, a co-founder of TechNet and now an executive at Red Gorilla, an Internet company. "It's a smart political approach."
The bulging docket of high-tech issues had led to dramatic growth in the industry's lobbying on Capitol Hill. Internet and software companies have snagged some of Capitol Hill's best talent this year -- former Congressional aides whose expertise blends technology and politics. While Microsoft built a large battery of lobbyists, beginning two years ago, few other high-tech companies had Washington lobbying operations. Suddenly, companies, including Yahoo and Gateway, are busily opening Washington outposts, hiring lobbyists and starting trade associations. And in yet another coming-of-age gesture, executives are beginning to dip into their coffers.
"It's so critical that Silicon Valley be involved in Washington right now," said Chris Larsen, the 39-year-old founder of E-Loan who has made six trips here this year to meet with members. "The stakes are really high."
High-tech lobbying has become so profitable that some high-powered lobbyists are carving out specialty niches and crossing party lines to do it. Edward W. Gillespie, a former policy and communications director for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, and Jack Quinn, Vice President Al Gore's former chief of staff, have teamed up to start a firm. The two have worked together on legislation to ease encryption export restrictions, a high priority for the high-tech industry. Tony Podesta, the brother of John D. Podesta, White House chief of staff, has also taken on a number of high-tech clients and even renamed his firm Podesta.com.
Other notable Washington names have been recruited. Michael D. McCurry, the former White House press secretary, and Susan Molinari, a former Republican Congresswoman, are working in tandem for iAdvance, a recently formed coalition that seeks to widen access to broadband Internet lines. Various high-tech companies on the West and East coasts have banded together on various legislative issues.
Silicon Valley, meanwhile, has become a favorite destination for lawmakers during the Congressional recess. Members of both parties have embarked on fact-finding missions to stay abreast of new technology and the issues they may spawn, and, to mine for campaign cash.
Two weeks ago, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, still weary from budget wranglings on Capitol Hill, led five colleagues, including his No. 2 man, Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, to the West Coast. They attended tutorials with executives from Autoweb.com and Flextronics International, among others, and came home with a bushel of campaign money.
Not to be outdone, Mr. Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, touched down in Silicon Valley the next week with 12 colleagues. The delegation raised even more money than the Republicans. Others visited as well: Mr. Hatch, a Republican presidential candidate and Microsoft nemesis, attended a glitzy fund-raiser; Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts also visited.
For now, though, industry campaign contributions have not kept pace with the rapid growth of the high-tech sector and are nowhere near the size of other corporate giants like AT&T, or labor unions or ideological groups like the National Rifle Association.
As of Dec. 1, the computer industry, including Internet companies, gave more than $4.4 million through individual contributions, political action committees and unregulated, soft money. It gave double the amount for the first six months of this year than in the corresponding period in 1998. Fifty-four percent went to Republicans, according to the Center for Responsible Politics, a nonpartisan research group.
So far, the high-tech industry has promised itself to no one.
"We're the prettiest girl at the dance right now," said Ms. Correll of the Information Technology Industry Council. "Everyone wants to curry favor with the high-tech industry."

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS;
Parents on Their Knees, Begging for Baby Sitters

BYLINE: By LESLIE BERGER

 BODY:
MICHAEL Z. WISE is a doting, well-prepared father. He and Tania Taubes, his equally conscientious wife, keep a list of three baby sitters for weekends, evenings and holidays, in addition to their full-time nanny. They also keep the names of half a dozen teenagers in their Upper West Side neighborhood who are available to watch children.
But for the evening of Saturday, Oct. 30, the night before Halloween, even the resourceful Mr. Wise and his physician spouse were unable to reserve a sitter. So, since they felt they could not miss a party given by an old and dear friend, Mr. Wise and Dr. Taubes attended the gathering in shifts. 
 "First, Tania went from about 8 o'clock until 10 o'clock, and then I went and stayed until about, oh, quarter till 1," recalled Mr. Wise, a journalist whose specialties include architecture and German culture.
As any city parent will affirm, procuring a baby sitter has become as hard as getting a restaurant reservation, and the competition can get ugly. Like junkyard dogs fighting over scraps of meat, otherwise genteel people have been known to outbid friends, flaunt social connections and bully college personnel in a quest that has become another urban obsession.
"Those are the two hot topics: real estate and child care," said MaryAnn Liberatore, owner of Park Avenue Nannies. "During a recession, people will stay home or someone's sister-in-law will do the baby sitting. What I've seen is tons and tons of weekend sitters, and nannies to travel to the Bahamas at Christmastime. People just don't think at all about spending another $1,000 or $2,000 to take their nanny to Barbados."
Records kept by Barnard College's baby-sitting registry, a nonprofit service that refers students to families, confirm this impression. The number of families signed up for Barnard's baby-sitting service is 2,148 in this academic year, up from 1,400 families in 1995-96. Similarly, the number of one-time or occasional jobs has grown steadily, from 2,700 in 1997-98 to 2,803 last year and 2,963 so far this year.
In a time of high demand, expectations are also on the rise. Parents not only prefer mature women, they also want sitters who know CPR, speak Mandarin Chinese or play chess. "All my parents expected was that we were alive when they got home," said Kathleen Lewis, the founder and owner of Pinch Sitters, a Manhattan agency. "Today, parents want a fairy godmother."
Still, Ms. Lewis and the owners of similar businesses say their stables of sitters are booked solid, all the time. Demand at Barnard has prompted student managers to begin discouraging families outside Manhattan from signing up at all. A new rule this year bars Barnard baby sitters from working more than four days a week.
Barnard's minimum charge is $6.50 an hour, an apparent bargain compared with the $10 an hour that is standard on the Upper East and West Sides. But minimums can be irrelevant in a sellers' market. Most Barnard sitters get market rate, and some parents pay $15 and up for a sitter-tutor.
Some families lose out in this bidding war. "It's unfair that single parents and the ones who really need the help are the ones whose jobs go unfilled," said Adrienne Davis, a sophomore and one of the service's managers. "But we try our best to help them."
One family holding a New Year's Eve party is offering $250 per sitter for the evening, and has requested several Barnard students to mind guests' children, Ms. Davis said. Some services report that the millennium has not generated the onslaught of bookings anticipated, but Pinch Sitters, for one, is refusing to book any sitters at all despite high expected demand.
"I could make a lot of money that night if I wanted to, but I don't want work myself and I don't expect it of my sitters, many of whom are probably invited to the same parties as my clients," Ms. Lewis said. "I've had calls from people who say they're desperate and I tell them, 'What's so bad about spending this moment at home with your loved ones?' "
The city is filled with tales of desperation throughout the year. Jennifer Edelson, a poet and an East Side mother, told of two women who started out sharing a baby sitter and wound up nursing a grudge. After several months, one offered the sitter a raise and an extra day's work, effectively cutting out the other.
"It really caused a division among a whole circle of friends, with people siding with either one or the other," she said.
When money alone isn't enough, there are perks. One of Ms. Liberatore's weekend nannies tooled around Greenwich, Conn., in a new Cherokee Jeep provided by her employers for her use. Vacations abound. "Remaining in the New York City area over Christmas break?" read one recent ad posted at Marymount College in Manhattan. "If you love kids and sports, come spend it with us in our large lake house in a hemlock forest one hour north of Manhattan. Your job is to entertain our sociable, sports-loving 9-year-old boy. You'll have your own room and bath with TV and lake view. Good eating. Access to car and computer."
Marymount doesn't have a baby-sitting service, but its director of professional and career development, Joan Baum, has found herself fielding more requests from parents. They tell her that students "will find it extremely rewarding to be in the company of wonderfully cultured and connected people," Ms. Baum said. "This is quid pro quo with a vengeance!"

HEADLINE: Could This Be the New World?

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, is the author of "The Coming Anarchy," a forthcoming book.

DATELINE: QUEBEC

 BODY:
Ancient and medieval mapmakers would better understand the world of 2100 than would the politicians of 2000.
Nations as we know them have existed for only a few hundred years. But cities have been with us since the dawn of civilization. And while the future of the city is not in doubt, modern nations will probably continue to weaken in the 21st century. By 2100, the organizing principle of the world will be the city-state, along with the urban radials of prosperity that follow major trade routes. 
 Indeed, loyalty toward the polis will gradually overwhelm the traditional state patriotism of the 20th century. Empires will be agglomerations of urban areas. Cities and their hinterlands will make alliances and fight wars with and against each other -- less over territory than over bandwidths in cyberspace and trade privileges. Power politics will prove eternal.
Neither states nor cities by themselves provide stability; elaborate institutions of finance and tax collection, manned by responsible officials, do that. In areas that already have such institutions (North America, Europe, China), the weakening or elimination of traditional nations will unleash further economic growth. By 2100, North America will be a loosely knit nation of competitive urban regions, a new version of the ancient Greek city-states.
In areas without strong institutions, like sub-Saharan Africa, the transition to city-states will cause instability and suffering in the first decades of the 21st century. Lebanon, Syria and Jordan will fade as the Arab world reverts to the Phoenician city-state system, dominated by Greater Beirut, Greater Damascus and Greater Amman.
Cultures able to produce exportable goods and services will dominate those that can't. Because Communism did more damage to Central Asia and the Caucasus than Islamic fundamentalism has done to Iran, Greater Persia, oriented around the city-states of Tehran, Tabriz and Mashad, may dominate the weaker Turkic societies that used to be known as Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan. By 2100, Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan will have broken up into various khanates.
Of course, this map is impressionistic. A more accurate map would be a hologram in constant motion, showing how power and sovereignty shifts and overlaps. It would include new cults and ideologies, as well as corporate empires, surveillance networks, and crime groups and the technologies they control.
Political systems in 2100 will be elegantly varied, unconstrained by the sanctimony of the late 20th century, with its simple call for "democracy." The next century will be the age of high-tech feudalism.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Map/Chart: "VAST CITY-STATES WILL BE THE MAIN POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS"
People will increasingly live in big metroplexes. The Pacific Northwest, for instance, will become the city-state of Portcouver. The fact that Portland was once in the United States and Vancouver was once in Canada will have only vague, unbinding significance.

HEADLINE: Y2K/PULSE;
For Worriers, Winding Down On Year 2000

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
They have devoted months and sometimes years to raising consciousness about potential Year 2000 computer disruptions. Now, many of the most prominent worriers are folding their tents.
Jay Golter and his fellow advocates at the Northern Virginia Year 2000 Community Action Group wrapped up their group efforts with a "New Year's Eve" party on Dec. 18. 
 Peter de Jager, the Canadian programmer who became a Year 2000 Paul Revere in 1993, said he would be on the interview circuit through next weekend. But Year2000.com, the popular Internet site he set up with the Tenagra Corporation, is already on the auction block at eBay.com.
"The crusade part of this is just about over," said Edward Yardeni, a Wall Street economist who still believes there is a 70 percent chance that Year 2000 breakdowns will usher in a worldwide recession. "Now it's just a matter of what happens. There's no point in being alarmist anymore."
Apparently, though, it is time to send in the clowns. As the rollover approaches, enough people are paying attention for comedians to shift into full gear. Mr. de Jager can hope the rising urge to laugh at Year 2000 may help sales of one of his sideline ventures, a Year 2000 cartoon book called "The Bug Stops Here."
But the field is getting crowded, mostly with survival tips that run the gamut from wry to lewd.
The Onion, a Madison, Wis., satirical newspaper, suggested, among other things, in its Dec. 15 issue: "Develop the ability to convert sunlight into energy using the chlorophyll in your body." The paper, viewable at www.onion.com, also advises: "If disaster strikes, it's God's wrath -- quote the Old Testament. But if nothing happens, God is merciful -- quote the New Testament."
Euro RSCG/DSW Partners, a Salt Lake City-based advertising firm that is a unit of Havas Advertising, has been distributing "31 Ways to Prepare for Y2K", a December calendar pamphlet with one suggestion a day. For Dec. 11, the suggestion was "Have plenty of clean towels. It's not specific to any millennial disaster but when have you ever not needed clean towels?"
A week later, DSW suggested collecting spoons because, "Right now spoons are everywhere but after January 1, who knows?"

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Technology Bankers Work To Give Merrill A Silicon Shine

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
WHEN the Goldman Sachs Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter announced upbeat earnings news last week, a cheer could be heard in Silicon Valley. There, both Wall Street investment banks have flourished, riding the wave of dot-com companies that have enriched themselves by offering shares to a rapacious public or selling out to each other.
But in recent years, another big Wall Street name has been conspicuously scarce in the Silicon Valley gold rush: Merrill Lynch. The firm's sideline status has been puzzling, given that as much as one-quarter of the revenue generated by investment banking departments these days comes from advising technology companies on mergers and public stock offerings. 
 So why has Merrill largely missed out on technology bankers' big bull market?
To hear Merrill Lynch explain it, the firm has not missed out at all; it simply got a late start. Tom Davis, executive vice president of Merrill's corporate and institutional client group, said the company was only three years into a multiyear effort to expand its technology presence worldwide.
"We are at the beginning of what is a long secular shift in the economy," Mr. Davis said. Of Merrill's strategy, in particular, he said, "I think we are at the early stage of this game."
Of course, technology executives have heard that before. When Merrill set up an office in Palo Alto, Calif., in 1996, it was the third attempt to crack Silicon Valley's clubby community, after abortive efforts in the 1980's and early 1990's. Mr. Davis said the company had been too busy expanding other departments to focus much on technology in those days.
Given its relatively late start, Merrill has made a respectable showing this year. According to Thomson Financial/Securities Data, Merrill ranked fourth in taking new technology companies public in 1999, as measured by the amount of money raised. That is a far cry from 1997, when it did not even rank among the top 20.
Merrill's total of $2.2 billion in technology underwriting this year, as calculated by Thomson, gave the firm a market share of 7.8 percent through Dec. 22. Those numbers do not tell the full story, though. That is still only about half the market share of more influential rivals like Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse First Boston and Goldman Sachs -- which rank first, second and third, respectively, in Thomson's lineup.
And with the exception of the Internet Capital Group, a Merrill loyalist that invests in Internet concerns and which Merrill took public in August, Merrill has yet to attract the roster of superstar companies that their larger competitors have.
Investors in Goldman and Morgan have been handsomely rewarded this year, in part, because of their prowess in the technology sector. Goldman's share price is up 53 percent since the firm went public in May; Morgan's is up 85 percent for the year. Merrill's share price, though, is up only 17 percent.
"It is not clear to me that they are going to make strides quickly enough," Steven Galbraith, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said of Merrill. The concern, Mr. Galbraith said, is that by the time Merrill might catch up in technology, the market will have moved on to the next hot sector.
Some analysts have said that when merger talks between Merrill and the technology investment boutique Hambrecht & Quist broke down two years ago, Merrill missed a ripe opportunity to increase its presence in technology underwriting.
Merrill suffered blows, too, with the loss of high-profile executives like its president, Herbert M. Allison Jr., a favorite in Silicon Valley who left the firm earlier this year and joined the ranks of political fundraisers, and, more recently, Scott Ryles, head of technology investment banking, who had helped build that practice. Mr. Ryles left last month to become chief executive of a new online investment bank backed by Charles Schwab.
What is more, Merrill has not been a believer in the "star system," Mr. Galbraith said. Having a name-brand stock picker, like Mary Meeker, the celebrated Morgan Stanley analyst who helped put that Internet practice on the map, is essential, he argues.
On that count, though, Merrill may now be trying to cultivate a rising star. In February, it hired a 33-year-old CIBC Oppenheimer analyst, Henry Blodget, who went way out on a limb last year by predicting that Amazon.com would hit $400 a share -- a target the stock not only reached but surpassed. Hiring Mr. Blodget, who has quickly gained a Silicon Valley following, is simply one indication of the way Merrill Lynch has expanded its technology research effort, said Steve Milunovich, the firm's global team coordinator for technology research.
"I'm a big believer that changing perception is hard," Mr. Milunovich said. "Our perception is probably better outside the valley than in the valley."
Certainly, Merrill's perception problem was not helped by comments one of its top executives made about the Internet last year. A Merrill vice chairman, John Steffens, was criticized after newspapers quoted him as saying that online trading was akin to gambling and a "serious threat to Americans' financial lives." Some in Silicon Valley took umbrage, suggesting that if Merrill did not understand the impact of the Internet on its own business, how could it understand theirs?
When Mr. Steffens, who is known as Launny, subsequently began extolling the Internet, the perception that he was scrambling to recover from a faux pas only seemed to make matters worse.
Mr. Davis said that Merrill had not lost a piece of business because of Mr. Steffens's comments. But others at the firm wonder how much potential business landed elsewhere. "We got tarred for that," Mr. Milunovich said. "There's no question that Launny's comments hurt."
One of Merrill's best technology credentials has been serving as a mergers-and-acquisitions banker to the networking giant Cisco Systems. Merrill got the job because it is one of Cisco's largest equipment customers. Cisco has an in-house team that does most of the heavy lifting on its transactions, but Merrill has retained the client on merit.
"They do a nice job and we've been pleased with the level of service," said Mike Volpi, Cisco's senior vice president for business development.
Still, Merrill's career as a merger adviser has hit some snags. Merrill had a very close relationship with the At Home Corporation, a provider of high-speed Internet service for cable television subscribers. Merrill had helped take At Home public and arranged for subsequent financings. So it was not surprising the firm was tapped to advise At Home on its $6.7 billion stock-swap merger in January with Excite Inc.
But the night before the Excite@Home merger was to be announced, executives at Excite noticed a problem: the total that At Home would pay in stock was lower than the agreed-to price. In effect, a miscalculation had been made in the documents, and At Home's board of directors had to be reconvened to vote again on the correct amount, according to George Bell, president of Excite@Home and the former chief executive of Excite.
"We were up until 4:30 a.m., they fixed it, and we announced that morning," Mr. Bell said. "Because it wasn't our company, I can't say it was the bankers' fault."
Whoever was to blame, industry executives say such last-minute mishaps are rare.
Thomas Jermoluk, who had been At Home's chief executive, could not be reached for comment. But people involved in those talks say he and executives from the AT&T Corporation, which owned a large stake of At Home, were enraged at the time. And when the merged Excite@Home, led by Mr. Jermoluk, announced its acquisition of BlueMountain.com recently, it was not Merrill that was hired to advise on the deal.
Mark Shafir, who is in charge of Merrill's technology merger department in San Francisco, was hard pressed to comment on the mixup with Excite and At Home except to say the terms were "discussed and vetted" with executives and their lawyers. "Unfortunately, there must have been some misunderstanding," he said.
If the technology boom continues, as many analysts expect, Merrill may now bear watching. Executives there say that the firm's technology effort for the first time has the full backing of Merrill's management. And if the company can transform indeed itself into the stock-offering powerhouse that it is in other industries, the next few years could improve Merrill's standing in Silicon Valley.
"Perception," Mr. Davis said, "lags reality."
