LENGTH: 1703 words

HEADLINE: Seeking Upset, Bradley Enlists Unlikely Model

SERIES: THE STATE OF THE RACES: The Bradley Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
In his professorial style, former Senator Bill Bradley reminds some people of Adlai E. Stevenson. Others hear the liberal idealism of Robert F. Kennedy in his speeches, or find his distaste for hardball politics reminiscent of Michael S. Dukakis.
But the candidate that Mr. Bradley invokes most often in his insurgent campaign for president is not a liberal or even a Democrat. It is former President Ronald Reagan, in whose political playbook Mr. Bradley and his advisers have found much to admire, and perhaps emulate, as they battle Vice President Al Gore for the Democratic nomination. 
 Like Mr. Reagan, Mr. Bradley has sought to project a sunny optimism, calling for a "world of new possibilities" that echoes Mr. Reagan's "morning in America." Like Mr. Reagan, he has focused on a few issues, hoping that expanding health care and reducing poverty will grab voters' imaginations the way shrinking government and fighting Communism did for Mr. Reagan.
And like Mr. Reagan, a former actor, Mr. Bradley, a former basketball star, is running as a celebrity outsider, trying to build an anti-Washington rebellion against a White House scarred by scandal.
"I admired the focus that he had when he ran," Mr. Bradley said of Mr. Reagan in an interview. "He told people what he wanted to do. And when people voted for him in sizable majorities, it gave him a mandate."
It is a game plan that has helped Mr. Bradley mount a surprisingly potent challenge to Mr. Gore. Just 15 months ago, he was not a candidate and Mr. Gore was a shoo-in for the party's nomination. Today, he has matched Mr. Gore in fund-raising, pulled even with him in polls in New Hampshire, built a national organization and given himself a shot, though still a long one, at upsetting the vice president.
But the coming weeks will provide a critical test of Mr. Bradley's staying power.
First up are the Iowa caucuses on Jan. 24 and the New Hampshire primary a week later. Then come five weeks of coast-to-coast campaigning for the primaries on March 7 in New York, California, Ohio and several other major states. If either candidate stumbles badly, the race could be over by mid-March.
And with that daunting schedule, many analysts have begun questioning whether Mr. Bradley's campaign is up to the task.
Did he fail to take advantage of a wave of positive news coverage in the early fall? Is he winning attention mainly because of his basketball celebrity? Is he in a seemingly strong position now simply because he is the only challenger to an opponent who seems to be constantly trying to reinvent himself to connect with voters?
Many analysts have also begun sensing vulnerabilities in his Reaganesque strategy. They say Mr. Bradley seems to be trying too hard to stay above the fray. And some assert that in focusing on just a few issues -- health care, poverty, campaign finance and race relations -- he has failed to address problems people care about as much or more, like education and the economy.
But most important, a large number of analysts argue, Mr. Bradley has yet to demonstrate that he has built the kind of national movement needed to upset a vice president who dominates the party's organization and has spent seven years recruiting endorsements.
"He must throw Gore into disarray to have a shot in California," said Fred Siegel, a history professor at the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art in New York. "He needs to win decisively in New Hampshire and New York, and I don't know if all those things can happen."
Mr. Siegel and other experts point to Mr. Reagan's failed primary challenge against President Gerald Ford in 1976 as evidence of just how difficult Mr. Bradley's task is.
"Reagan ran an extraordinary campaign in 1976, but it still wasn't enough" Mr. Siegel said. "Sure, Gore has made plenty of miscues. But I'm not sure it's enough to knock him out."
That year, Mr. Reagan had an important advantage that Mr. Bradley does not: he was viewed as the leader of the Republican's conservative wing, a group disaffected with Mr. Ford. Mr. Bradley cannot claim any such base and is widely viewed within the party as centrist, on the same ideological plane as Mr. Gore.
Mr. Bradley has tried to outflank the vice president among the party's liberal base, which includes blacks, women, labor unions and environmentalists. In every stump speech, he talks about improving race relations, protecting the environment and reducing poverty. And he has proposed increasing the minimum wage automatically when inflation rises.
But while Mr. Bradley has made inroads on the left, the Gore campaign still holds more cards. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has endorsed the vice president and polls show that black voters and women remain supportive of the administration and, by extension, Mr. Gore.
With those obstacles in mind, Mr. Bradley has mapped out a strategy to "expand the electorate" by energizing first-time voters and people who have become apathetic or disgusted with politics. His pledges to reduce the influence of money in politics and to speak from his heart are aimed directly at disaffected independents and Democrats angry with President Clinton.
It might seem an impossible task to build a national movement in just a few months. But Mr. Bradley has actually been laying the groundwork for a national campaign for more than a decade. By the time he announced his candidacy in late 1998, he had a group of devoted longtime advisers and a network of fund-raisers in place -- much like Mr. Reagan in 1976.
By October this year, Mr. Bradley had raised nearly $20 million dollars, and his frugal spending had left him more cash on hand than Mr. Gore. Mr. Bradley also won much national attention by unveiling a plan to subsidize health insurance for 95 percent of Americans.
As he campaigns, Mr. Bradley often tells audiences that he decided to release a detailed health plan partly because he thought the strategy had worked for Mr. Reagan in 1980. By being specific, Mr. Bradley argues, Mr. Reagan could claim a mandate for his budget and tax-cutting policies when he won, helping to soften opposition in Congress.
But the specificity that Mr. Bradley considers a strength is a tempting target for Mr. Gore.
For two months, the Gore camp has picked apart the Bradley health plan. And Mr. Gore and his supporters have broadened their criticisms to include Mr. Bradley's record on education, campaign finance and agriculture.
Mr. Gore's aides say they think their combative approach has tied the Bradley campaign in knots. "It's a conundrum for them," said one aide. "If they engage us, it's a mistake, because his strength is being a philosopher-king. If you stay out there and don't do anything, you get defined negatively." Either way, the aide said, the Gore campaign has managed to muddle Mr. Bradley's message and knock him off stride.
In recent weeks, Mr. Bradley has become somewhat more forceful in his responses. During a testy debate with Mr. Gore on "Meet the Press," Mr. Bradley repeatedly shouted "That's not true!" when Mr. Gore criticized his health plan. And when Mr. Gore offered a hand-shake deal to eschew television commercials, Mr. Bradley sarcastically rejected it.
Still, some analysts said Mr. Bradley should have delivered a more forceful blow directly at what they consider Mr. Gore's Achilles' heel: the much-criticized fund-raising practices of the Clinton-Gore campaign in 1996.
Mr. Bradley hit at some of those problems when he staged an event recently with Senator John McCain, a Republican presidential candidate, where both pledged to forsake so-called soft money if they are nominated. Then Mr. McCain took some potshots at Mr. Gore.
But analysts say Mr. Bradley himself may need to take those shots. "Sooner or later he's going to have to engage Gore in hand-to-hand combat," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's urban research center.
For his part, Mr. Bradley says his greatest challenge will be to amplify his message above the noise of Mr. Gore's attacks. So far, he has had some success with that in Iowa and New Hampshire, where small-group campaigning dominates and his folksy style seems most effective.
The fight for March 7, however, will be played out mostly on television, which has not always been kind to Mr. Bradley, who can come across as sleepy-eyed or stiff on camera.
Mr. Bradley has worked hard, with some success, at appearing comfortable on television. And his campaign is preparing commercials that will try to evoke his plain-spoken, earnest style, probably by relying on shots of him speaking into the camera or to groups of voters.
"The traditional answer is you hire political consulting firms and they turn you into a cookie-cutter production," Mr. Bradley said. "And what I decided was, no, I wanted to convey who I am and what I believe and where I want to take the country to the widest audience."
"Now," he added, "we are going to test whether I am able to do that."

HEADLINE: Two Visions on Health Care

 BODY:
Recent debates between Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley have put health care squarely on the campaign agenda, but no doubt confused many voters about complex cost and coverage issues. Mr. Bradley proposes an expensive plan that invites uninsured people to buy coverage, with the help of federal subsidies for families with incomes of up to about $50,000, from any one of hundreds of private plans that serve federal employees. Mr. Gore, arguing that Mr. Bradley's plan would lead to unacceptably high tax increases or federal spending cuts, proposes taking modest steps that would reduce the number of uninsured people by expanding existing federal-state programs to cover more low-income children and their parents. He would also offer tax credits to individuals and small businesses that acquire coverage.
The difference between the two approaches poses the central question that divides liberals from moderates in the Democratic Party: Is universal access to health insurance worth its costs? 
 There are two ways to achieve universal coverage. The first imposes a legal mandate. But with mandates come complexity and intense political opposition, as President Clinton learned to his regret in 1994. The second -- Mr. Bradley's way -- relies on voluntary purchase. The problem here is cost. If Mr. Bradley were to subsidize coverage only for uninsured people, he would encourage employers to drop coverage, use some of the savings to boost wages and invite workers to switch to the subsidized public program. That would drive up costs and possibly increase the number of uninsured workers. So Mr. Bradley is forced to offer subsidies to low-wage workers who remain insured through their employers, eliminating any incentive to drop their private coverage. He says his program, including a drug benefit for the elderly, would cost up to $65 billion a year. Mr. Gore's advisers say it could cost twice that much. In fact, Mr. Bradley's figure is probably low.
Mr. Bradley provides a maximum subsidy of $1,800 for a single adult. The problem, as Mr. Gore never ceases to point out, is that in many parts of the country there are no federal plans that offer coverage for only $1,800. In practice Mr. Bradley's subsidy would probably have to rise to an average of between $2,100 and $2,400. Mr. Bradley's drug plan would also probably cost more than he estimates. It would cover 75 percent of all drug costs for the elderly above $500 a year. By contrast, Mr. Gore's drug plan would pay 50 percent of the costs up to an initial maximum of $2,000 a year. Mr. Bradley says the two plans would cost about the same amount, but his more comprehensive coverage might cost 50 percent more.
It is when the debate shifts from costs to coverage that Mr. Bradley has a chance to score with voters. Mr. Gore's advisers say his plan would provide coverage to 12 million uninsured people, while Mr. Bradley's would reach 15 million. Mr. Bradley's advisers counter that the Bradley plan plan would cover 30 million Americans, Mr. Gore's only 7 million. Mr. Gore also accuses Mr. Bradley of eliminating Medicaid. But Mr. Bradley says he is doing what Mr. Clinton proposed in 1994, enrolling the poor into the same health plans that cover everyone else. He says he provides enough money to keep their benefits from falling.
On narrow calculation, Mr. Gore's plan gets more coverage per dollar. It covers approximately 10 million people at a cost of about $25 billion a year. Mr. Bradley's plan would cover between 15 million and 30 million people for $85 billion to $100 billion a year. But Mr. Gore's strategy of incremental steps is unlikely to ever produce universal coverage. Once he tries to extend coverage beyond the least privileged people, he will run into Mr. Bradley's problem that any effort to subsidize uninsured workers requires subsidizing insured workers as well.
A realistic look at budget options starkly outlines the question underlying their differing approaches. In a $9 trillion economy that is experiencing the best economic times ever, is it worth spending $100 billion a year on universal coverage, something other, less wealthy industrialized countries have already achieved? Mr. Bradley's plan would mean less money for Medicare, education and other programs and might require higher taxes. Mr. Gore says, in effect, that the benefits are not worth these costs. That is the right debate for an election year.

HEADLINE: Russia's Future: Bright or Grim?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Good News From Russia (Yes, It's True)" (Op-Ed, Dec. 23), Martin Malia praises Russia's fledgling steps toward reform and democracy. But he doesn't offer a solution to Russia's empty value system, and therein lies the undoing of his hopeful analysis. 
 The reason for Poland's success and Russia's failure in making the transition to a lawful, bustling society has to do with values, not Western loans or a lack of patience. Poland had a strong Catholic tradition to build on. Russia, on the other hand, had a significantly weakened Orthodox tradition. Russia presently has a values vacuum, and until it is filled, we will not know what kind of society will evolve on the great plain of Eurasia.
 
DENNIS J. DUNN
San Marcos, Tex., Dec. 23, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of history at Southwest Texas State University.

HEADLINE: U.S. Back on Top in Industrial Research

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
American industry is pouring extraordinary sums of money into research and development in an effort to nurture strong growth, private and federal officials are reporting.
Analysts had once feared that American industry in the 1990's, faced with rising global competition, tightening budgets and growing demands for quick profitability from investors, was quietly abandoning the kind of high-risk research that historically has produced the biggest payoffs and breakthroughs. Worrisome examples cited by experts are W. R. Grace and Eastman Chemical, which recently closed the doors on corporate laboratories. 
 But a new study by the Industrial Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington that represents large companies, says overall trends turn out to be strongly the opposite -- and federal officials in interviews echoed the upbeat numbers and analyses.
The report, titled "Basic Research in Industry," is based on federal data and institute surveys, and concludes, "Industry is doing more long-range, high-risk, discovery-type research than ever before." It was released on Dec. 15 by Charles F. Larson, executive director of the institute.
"I was amazed at the growth," Mr. Larson said in an interview. "I've been sensing this for some time but was delighted to find that it was true in terms of the hard numbers. It's a new era."
From 1994 to 1999, the study said, American industrial research and development grew to a projected $166 billion from $97.1 billion, a rise of 71 percent, or slightly less if adjusted for inflation, and in any case more than double the spending of the federal government, which in 1999 is putting about $70 billion into research and development. Until the 1980's, the government was the nation's unrivaled research leader as it probed new frontiers with innovative technology from atom smashers to orbiting telescopes.
By soaring during the past five years, industrial research and development is rebounding from a flat period in the early 1990's, when companies cut back on research in an effort to try to raise efficiencies and cut redundancies. By 1992, Japan was seen as having equaled or surpassed the United States as the world's top patron of industrial research and development, giving it a powerful weapon in the trade wars to produce a new wave of innovative goods and services.
But America is now indisputably back on top, with Japanese industry spending some $95 billion last year, far less than the United States.
Most of the industrial money goes into the relatively prosaic work of development, like engineering, making prototypes and testing products. A lesser amount goes into applied research, which focuses on making new products, processes and services for tomorrow.
A major surprise of the study, Mr. Larson said, is that directed basic research -- the blue-sky pursuit of products and services that might lie a decade in the future -- has grown even faster than overall research and development in the past half decade. It is up 79 percent, to $10.9 billion in 1999 from $6.1 billion in 1994.
The Industrial Research Institute found that the rise came mainly from companies doing business in the life and information sciences, including enterprises like Cisco Systems, Compaq Computer, Lilly & Company, Lucent Technologies, Merck & Company, Microsoft, Monsanto and Sun Microsystems. Microsoft is reportedly investing 17 percent of its sales in research and development, and many companies are putting in more.
The feverish growth, Mr. Larson said, comes in reaction to strong global competition and is made possible by healthy corporate profits and cash flows. Other factors, he said, include the spread of the idea that the economy is increasingly knowledge-driven, and that raising intellectual capital is good a way to manage the corporate enterprise for growth in sales, profits and shareholder value.
He added that many companies, including Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Lucent, International Business Machines, Texas Instruments and Xerox, have begun "skunk works," or independent start-ups, to help foster innovation.
John E. Jankowski, a financial analyst at the National Science Foundation, a federal agency that tracks science spending, said the Industrial Research Institute study was right on target. "Our statistics show strong positive growth," he said. "We've had a very positive trend in terms of industrial research and development."

HEADLINE: The Defining Styles of Capitalism

 BODY:
Malt liquors and boots were among America's 10 largest industries at the beginning of the 20th century. A third of Americans worked in agriculture. Fifty years later, cars, aircraft and chemical manufacturing dominated the economy and only about 4 percent of Americans worked in agriculture. The United States started the century on an economic par with Great Britain. By the middle of the century, living standards were 50 percent higher in the United States than in Britain.
Now, at the end of the century, Americans, mostly employed in white-collar jobs, account for only 4 percent of the world's population but for more than 20 percent of its output. The American brand of capitalism -- democratic, lightly regulated and full of opportunities for individuals to fail as well as succeed -- is widely seen as a model for others to emulate. As the end of the century draws near, there is no longer any doubt that the state-dominated economies that competed with capitalism for much of the modern era have failed. Less clear than many Americans might imagine, however, is which model of capitalism -- American, European or Japanese -- is likely to prove most dominant in the decades ahead. 
 America's economic success began before this century. The country had abundant natural resources from the start, and in the 19th century, immigration and huge investments in railroads helped create a continent-expanding economy. Entrepreneurs developed the "American system" of interchangeable parts, first in firearms, to cut down the costs of producing complex products. In the 20th century came the assembly line, churning out cars that workers could afford. Long before Europe, the United States provided free high school education, laying the foundation for a knowledge-based economy. From the 1920's on, economic growth was tied to science-based technologies, and in the 50 years after 1910 output per hour more than tripled.
A mostly hands-off, decentralized system rewarded personal skills, entrepreneurial investment and innovation. The flexibility of largely unfettered labor markets also helped the economy triple in size in the 30 years following World War II. More people working with more machines account for some of the growth. But most of the spectacular gains arose from something more profound: educated people working with smarter machines. By 1975, productivity -- output per worker -- was twice as high in the United States as in Britain.
The economy has been so hot in the past few years that there is a natural temptation to declare that America's freewheeling "cowboy" capitalism has triumphed permanently over European or Japanese versions. But economic historians, taking the longer view, consider such a conclusion premature. Each of the models has its own strengths and each has stumbled at times in recent decades.
The American economy, for instance, stalled in the 1970's after the oil price shocks. For nearly two decades unemployment rates remained high and wages of all but the highest-paid workers stagnated. Inequality soared. Americans looked abroad for answers. Europe's system of generous social insurance and regulated labor markets produced comparable living standards and more equal income distribution. But then unemployment took hold. In the 1980's attention turned to the success of Japan's system of corporate cartels and lifetime employment. But by the 1990's Japan had entered a decade-long slumber.
Attention returned to America's hurly-burly economy, which has achieved the lowest unemployment in the industrialized world in part by throwing millions of people out of work each year only to hire them back (in different jobs) along with millions more. The United States prospered in part because of the accelerating pace of globalization and technological change. Rapid change puts a premium on flexibility, America's greatest economic asset. Europe's more stable system of long-term employment may return to favor in more tranquil times.
Indeed, for all these ups and downs, economists and historians see more similarities than differences among successful economies in Japan, Europe and the United States. All are vibrant, literate, science-oriented democracies with a base of private property. They rely on relatively open markets, trade and mature legal systems for resolving conflicts. None of the governments are hands-off. All of them, including the United States, tightly regulate financial markets. The current dominance of the American model rests, in historic terms, on a fleeting experience. Only in the last few years of the current recovery has the economy created both large employment gains and wage increases.
But for scholars reflecting on the economic history of the century, there can be no doubt on one central point. Measured by the feature that best defines economic prosperity -- productivity growth -- the market economies of the United States, Western Europe and Japan far outpaced state-run, autocratic, anti-trade regimes throughout Latin America and Africa.

HEADLINE: Progress on Medical Errors

 BODY:
The Department of Veterans Affairs recently reported that veterans' hospitals around the country committed about 3,000 medical errors leading to about 700 deaths between June 1997 and December 1998. These frightening statistics reflect what can go wrong in the veterans' health system. But they also reflect what is being done right.
Veterans' hospitals are not the only ones plagued by mistakes. The Institute of Medicine reported last month that medical mistakes kill more hospital patients than car accidents, AIDS or breast cancer. The report goaded politicians to promise corrective action, and last week eight executives of major companies disclosed the formation of an organization -- the Leapfrog Group -- designed in part to steer employees to hospitals that make the fewest mistakes. 
 The veterans' hospitals had already begun putting error-catching systems in place before the institute's report was released. When Dr. Kenneth Kizer took over as under secretary of veterans affairs in 1994, he found an unorganized health system lacking modern quality control or standards. The system had a reputation for bloated costs and sometimes substandard care.
Dr. Kizer brought hospitals, outpatient clinics and nursing homes together into integrated networks. He paid the networks a fixed amount of money for each veteran the network treated independent of the diagnosis, giving them a powerful incentive to spend money wisely. The doctors were paid salaries, eliminating any economic reason to under-treat or over-treat patients. Dr. Kizer closed hospitals and eliminated administrators.
"The Veterans Health Administration has made a more serious commitment to improving health safety than any other large system in the country," said Dr. Donald Berwick of the Institute for Healthcare Improvement, a nonprofit research center in Boston.
Beyond structural reforms, Dr. Kizer initiated a policy that requires employees of the veterans' health system to report medical errors. This policy produced the data on thousands of mistakes and hundreds of deaths over 19 months. There is no evidence that the veterans' hospitals are treating patients less safely than other institutions are, Dr. Berwick said. He argues that private hospitals would look just as bad if they reported medical errors as accurately.
The first step in overcoming errors is to report them accurately. The data from the veterans' hospitals, as grim as they are, reflect the fact that the system is moving in the right direction. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Cuba's Infant Death Rate Drops Again

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Cuba's infant mortality rate, already one of the lowest in the world, fell further in 1999, health officials said.
Health Minister Carlos Dotres, in a news conference over the weekend, said the preliminary figure for this year was about 6.5 deaths per thousand births, down from a rate of 7.1 per thousand the previous year and 11 per thousand a decade ago. 
 Free health service for all, a rarity in Latin America, has been one of the main features of President Fidel Castro's government since he seized power in 1959.
In an overview of their ministry's work, Mr. Dotres and other officials added that Cuba currently has 3,140 medical personnel assisting international organizations in 58 countries around the world, including the poorest regions of Central America, the Caribbean and Africa.
Some 447 medical workers also have flown to Venezuela in recent days to provide free emergency services in the flood-ravaged South American nation, the officials added.
Cuba offers a free medical education to 1,913 students from 18 countries in the region at the new Latin American School for Medical Sciences in Havana.
Mr. Dotres acknowledged that the country still had shortages of medicine, largely owing to the United States' economic blockade, but he said that the situation was improving slowly.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
The Prices Of Treasuries Rise Slightly

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
As shoppers returned to stores and malls looking for post-Christmas bargains yesterday, a faint echo of that trend was heard in the Treasury market as scattered bargain hunting lifted prices off 27-month lows.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 95 18/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.46 percent from 6.49 percent at Thursday's close. The market was closed on Friday before Christmas Day. 
 Analysts said a smattering of bargain hunting and favorable financing rates buoyed prices. But they also said the modest upward move occurred on such light trading that it held little significance.
"It didn't take much to push yields around, just because volume is so thin," said George Simon, debt strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc.
Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said the levels in place "when we took the baton this morning were overdone, some bargain hunters came in and, given the thin volume, had a more pronounced effect."
Mr. Flanagan said traders tried to buy on the dips. "There was no news and sentiment didn't shift. The market just wasn't ready to go through 6.50 yet," he said, referring to the benchmark 30-year bond yield.
A trader at a primary government securities dealer said: "People think the low was put in last week or maybe overnight. The market is drastically oversold."
The federal funds rate traded in the afternoon at 5 1/2 percent, which is the Federal Reserve's target rate, and at a relatively soft 5 7/16 percent early in the day. The Fed also added $8.98 billion in temporary reserves to the banking system through 17-day fixed-system repurchase agreements.

HEADLINE: World Bank's Aim: Beef for China

BYLINE: By Neal D. Barnard; Neal D. Barnard is president of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The World Bank has proved again that the pen is mightier than the sword. The sword -- in this case a scythe harvesting the grains that have kept the Chinese free of the diet-related health problems plaguing Westerners -- was defeated last week when, with the stroke of a pen, the World Bank signed off on a $93.5 million loan to build 130 feedlots and five processing centers for China's nascent beef industry.
The World Health Organization would have had it differently. Its figures show that the traditional Chinese diet, rich in rice and vegetables, with little meat and virtually no dairy products, has kept heart disease and myriad other Western health problems at arm's length. An improved food distribution network has eliminated the shortages suffered by some other Asian countries. Today, per capita food intake is actually higher in China than in the United States. Unfortunately, steak, fast food and cheese have started to replace traditional rice and noodle dishes in some regions even without the World Bank's help. Those areas have shown the highest incidence of Western-style medical problems. 
 While smart Americans recognize the need to "Easternize" their own diets with rice, soy products and more vegetarian options, World Bank bureaucrats decided to promote a Westernization of China's diet. Instead of supporting the use of grain as a cholesterol-free dietary staple for people, the grain will be fed to cattle to produce meat.
This practice promotes not just poor health, but also the inefficient use of food. Kilo after kilo of grain proteins fed to cattle yield only one-tenth this amount of protein in meat.
Of course, the World Bank's efforts to promote cattle farming in China are concerned less with good health than with economic investment. No doubt some cattle ranchers will profit, as they edge out vegetable and rice acreage. But why is the World Bank, so roundly criticized over for years for its self-defeating economic development schemes, falling into the same old trap?

HEADLINE: On the Year 2000 Front, Humans Are the Big Wild Cards

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
With four days until the year 2000, government officials, company managers and computer experts are waiting anxiously to see if the public will remain calm.
It is not that everyone is sure the computers and the machinery in which they are often embedded will perform flawlessly as they roll past midnight and encounter Year 2000 dates -- far from it. Repair work has lagged behind in many countries and some domestic sectors, like small businesses. And even the most stringent programs will inevitably have some overlooked flaws. 
 Still, the prevailing view is that the technical glitches are likely to have limited economic and social impact. Bigger disruptions could come, the experts say, from unwarranted stockpiling, withdrawals of large sums from banks, or other sudden efforts by millions of people to insulate themselves from possible technical failures.
"The biggest remaining variable is public attitude," said Harris N. Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America. (For the moment that attitude is more confident than ever: The Associated Press's latest poll found that 92 percent of Americans expect minor problems at worst.) "One incident can change it quickly," he added, "but if we stay on this track, the whole thing could end up as a major victory for common sense."
Such thinking is disputed by Year 2000 readiness advocates who contend that it is reckless for individuals not to prepare for major disruptions just as the government and major companies have done. But whatever happens, there is wide agreement with John A. Koskinen, chairman of the President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion, that Y2K, as the computer problem is known, has become "the greatest management challenge of the past 50 years."
Had nothing been done, the world's financial systems would already be sagging from errors in software that relies on future dates -- like programs tracking debt payments -- with an almost certain collapse early next year. Manufacturing, food distribution, power and phone networks and most other basic services would have begun slowing within weeks if not minutes after midnight Dec. 31. Computer users not hit directly would nonetheless have been quickly crippled by breakdowns among suppliers or key customers, experts say.
To prevent such a fate, tens of millions of people have been involved in preparations ranging from fixing computer code to developing contingency plans to deal with any remaining glitches. More than $250 billion has been spent in the effort, mostly in the last three years, according to several estimates.
The Year 2000 problem came as no surprise to programmers. It stems from a decades-old space-saving tactic of using just two digits to represent the year. Many programmers recognized that 00 would be ambiguous -- some computers would interpret it as 1900 and others not recognize it as a valid date -- but they mistakenly assumed that the two-digit programming practice would die out long before the new century and the software using it would be retired.
It was not until the late 1990's that most senior managers recognized how deep the problem ran. Now, even computer novices realize that Year 2000 flaws can crash their systems or pump vast amounts of faulty data into files, billings or other documents before they are recognized.
It has turned out that faulty computers in machinery like phone switches, industrial robots and video recorders are rarer and usually more trivial than many experts originally feared. In fact, officials in the airline and electric industries said recently that their repairs turned up no embedded computers that could have caused major failures.
Still, because there are billions of embedded processors, even a small percentage of date-sensitive units adds up to millions of devices that could cause trouble if incorrectly handled. Chrysler has identified 6,000 robots, controllers and other electronic devices in 50 plants that it will reset on Jan. 3 before it restarts its production lines. No one knows how many have been overlooked or inadequately tested.
For all the work that has been done, tough challenges remain.
While some embedded flaws will remain invisible until machines are turned off or on for the first time in the Year 2000, which could be months from now, the worst of that threat will be over quickly in January. Most managers are more worried about office systems and software. The information technology that runs the world's offices, banks and government agencies could continue to have problems for months as different programs, like payrolls or tax accounting packages, deal with Year 2000 dates for the first time.
Major computer users may have hundreds of millions of lines of code in their software, and research shows that even the programs that have ostensibly been fixed and tested still have flaws, some serious. Managers in this country are confident that they have found enough of the major problems to be able to fix new ones that come to light before they do much damage.
One hopeful sign is that flaws have, so far, been showing up at slightly lower rates than analysts had projected. For example, the Gartner Group, a technology consulting firm in Stamford, Conn., expected Year 2000 problems to create 75 percent more breakdowns than normal this month but its latest projections suggest that the increase will be 65 percent. But Gartner is sticking by projections that programmers will be twice as burdened as normal thanks to Year 2000 flaws for the first two months of next year.
"The issue will be, you've got a boat, you've got a hole in it, how fast can you bail?" said James Woodward, the Dallas-based head of North American Year 2000 services for Cap Gemini, Europe's largest computer services company.
As Dec. 31 nears, concerns about computer viruses and intruders are also on the rise. Managers fear that the vast amount of work on systems may have left them more open to security breaches. In addition, publicity about Year 2000 "acts as a draw for those who want to make a statement," said Richard Landes, director of the Center for Millennial Studies at Boston University.
A growing number of computer users are erecting defenses like those of the Regional Medical Center in Orangeburg, S.C., which is shutting off computer access from its system to the Internet on Dec. 31; executives in its command center that want to track information on the World Wide Web will use a separate computer installed for the rollover.
Security threats aside, many companies are preparing to execute elaborate precautions affecting employees, suppliers and customers alike. Many large chemical plants and oil pipelines are shutting down for the transition. Major freight railroads and Amtrak are suspending service on New Year's Eve to go through one last round of equipment and signal checks after midnight.
Perhaps most of all, government and company officials will be struggling to separate fact from rumor, and a vast number of public and private information networks are being pieced together for the occasion. A recent test of the Government's Y2K Information Coordination Center included telecommunications links to counterparts in 80 countries and 50 states and many numerous emergency management officials.
"We are going to be asking what is happening with everything all over the world," Mr. Koskinen said. "Our major requirement is to put out accurate information, but we have to be timely, too. There has never been anything like this in all of history."
Reliable information is crucial for contingency planners, because the computers and human actors they have been worrying most about are those beyond their control.
International businesses say information is particularly hard to come by overseas. All assessments describe Russia as the largest nation far behind in preparations. China by virtue of its size and heavy reliance on pirated software is seen as a higher than average risk. Japan started late but seems to have largely caught up, at least among its larger companies.
Nigeria is one of several African countries considered especially risky; the national Year 2000 group was given $1 million of the $200 million it said it needed. But oil companies have said they expect exports as usual from there, the Persian Gulf and Venezuela.
Of course, many of the countries least prepared for the problem are those most accustomed to coping with disruptions. Only a handful of nations with major Year 2000 problems are likely to suffer substantial economic consequences, according to projections by the International Data Corporation, a consulting firm based in Framingham, Mass. Even then, I.D.C. says, worldwide losses will be less than $24 billion.
No one thinks Americans will stay relaxed if major disruptions develop. Indeed, for most of this year, many of the biggest debates have swirled around how to encourage some preparations without inciting unusual behavior or panic.
Authorities have been warning homeowners against storing gasoline or taking large amounts of money out of the bank. The Gartner Group predicts lines and possible spot shortages of gasoline the last two days of this month as Americans top off the tanks in their cars.
"It's going to get hairy for a couple of days," said Lou Marcoccio, Year 2000 research director at the Gartner Group.
The actual arrival of the Year 2000 might seem like a letdown, experts say. But most experts agree that it will take several quiet weeks to be confident that the first global technology challenge has been met successfully.
Even if it all unfolds as smoothly as the optimists project, a potentially titanic legal battle over who pays is shaping up. Xerox, Nike and Unisys are among the eight companies that have already sued for reimbursement from their insurers for spending hundreds of millions of dollars on Year 2000 repairs.
They cite language in business contracts dating from the 19th century, when insurers would pay ship owners for money spent trying to prevent a ship from sinking. The insurers argue they owe nothing because Year 2000 losses were completely foreseeable, and Congress acted last summer to limit their exposure.

Following are some suggestions from the government's preparedness checklist:
 
FOOD AND WATER: At least a three-day supply (1 gallon of water a person a day).
OTHER SUPPLIES: Flashlights, batteries, battery-powered radio, first- aid kit and adequate clothing.
RECORDS: Keep copies of financial statements, medical records and drug information for several months; check credit card charges and other transactions against statements; have phone numbers of hospitals, police and fire departments and neighbors.
CASH No more than normal for a holiday weekend.
MEDICINE: Refill, if less than a week's supply left.
GASOLINE: Keep your tank above half full.
CONSUMER ELECTRONICS: Check Year 2000 readiness of essential equipment like programmable thermostats, security systems and home computers with manufacturers.
PHONES AND INTERNET: Use only if necessary on Jan. 1.
CAMS: Beware of scams. Never give out bank account, credit card or Social Security numbers unless you initiated the contact. (pg. C4)
 
Graph: "Year 2000: The Economic Impact"
 
A BIGGER WORKLOAD
Year 2000 problems come on top of the steady stream of normal software breakdowns that keep programmers busy. Earlier this year, the Gartner Group, a technology consulting firm, projected that Year 2000 problems might double the workload of computer workers by January. But so far, actual increases are running below their projections. The graph shows the additional workload because of Y2K since October 1998.
 
SOME COUNTRIES WILL FARE BETTER THAN OTHERS
Some countries are unlikely to have serious Year 2000 problems because of extensive preparations. Analysts say others, with only small portions of their economies computerized, will also do well. At greatest risk are computerized countries that are not prepared -- but even these, according to the International Data Corporation, may lose less than one-half of 1 percent of 2000 business revenues. HEADLINE: Gore Path to 'Promotion' Hit A Glass Backboard in Bradley

SERIES: THE STATE OF THE CAMPAIGN: Al Gore

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
It was all so simple for Al Gore back in the days when he expected a coast to the Democratic presidential nomination.
He had the money, the endorsements and a careerist staff comfortable in the corridors of power. Potential rivals concluded that it would be foolish to challenge him. And his airy campaign slogan of "practical idealism" encapsulated just what Mr. Gore wanted the world to know about him: he was pragmatic yet optimistic, visionary even. 
 But his glide to the nomination hit a brick wall -- in the person of Bill Bradley -- and the common assumptions about Mr. Gore's once-inevitable candidacy have shattered. It is hard now to think of a candidate who has tried more transformations in a shorter period.
Now with the Iowa caucuses just four weeks away, Mr. Gore faces what could be the most critical weeks of his 23-year political career. The frantic primary pace after Iowa, taking in New Hampshire, New York, California and the Deep South by mid-March, will most likely reveal whether his self-makeover and the doubts he has tried to raise about Mr. Bradley have worked, or whether he will be denied what he once viewed as his rightful "promotion."
Gore strategists believe that the vice president, who already has a lock on hundreds of the so-called superdelegates to the Democratic National Convention and is ahead in the national polls, can win the nomination under several scenarios.
But they say Mr. Bradley can win under only one -- by making a strong showing in Iowa on Jan. 24 and winning in New Hampshire a week later. Without those states, especially New Hampshire, whose voters tend to favor insurgents, Mr. Bradley would be hard pressed to convince the rest of the country that he is a winner.
"If they do not stop us there, we will not be stopped," a top Gore strategist said. "They understand that."
Mr. Gore is leading Mr. Bradley in Iowa polls by 20 percentage points and claims a strong organization there. But with Mr. Bradley pouring everything into Iowa next month, including more than $800,000 for television and radio commercials and a full schedule of daily appearances, the Gore campaign says it intends to match him dollar for dollar to make sure that lead does not slip away.
Gore advisers do not yet know how much time Mr. Gore will spend in Iowa because he also needs to campaign in New Hampshire, where the most recent poll showed him behind Mr. Bradley by 12 points. Their hope is that if Mr. Bradley fails in Iowa the loss may prompt some supporters to cross party lines and vote for Senator John McCain, a Republican, in New Hampshire.
Darrell West, a political scientist at Brown University, said the stakes were higher for Mr. Bradley than for Mr. Gore in New Hampshire.
"Bradley really does have to win it because New England should be a very good place for him," Mr. West said. "It has a tradition of independence, and the Northeast is the most liberal region in national politics."
But Mr. Bradley's lead in New England is not replicated across the country, and in most states, Mr. Gore is ahead by healthy margins.
Mr. Gore is laboring under the impression, voiced by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York in his endorsement of Mr. Bradley, that he cannot get elected in the fall against the leading Republican, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Mr. Gore has lagged behind Mr. Bush in hypothetical matchups, and although that gap is narrowing, even Mr. Bradley does better against Mr. Bush in some states than Mr. Gore does.
Though he moved his campaign to Nashville from Washington, pared his staff, cut salaries and shed the off-putting, cumbersome entourage that once enveloped him on the campaign trail, Mr. Gore is still burdened by his aura as a cautious, calculating Washington insider.
Even more galling to the Gore staff is that the man he is campaigning against spent 18 years in the Senate, is bankrolled by Wall Street and has still managed to cast himself as the nonestablishment, noncalculating nonpolitician.
Peter Hart, a pollster not affiliated with any campaign, said his most recent surveys showed that 38 percent of voters nationally had a positive view of Mr. Gore while 35 percent had a negative view. By contrast, he said, Mr. Bradley had a positive rating of 42 percent and a negative rating of 10 percent.
"Al Gore has a lot of work to do to warm up the electorate," Mr. Hart said. "He is perceived as a politician, who comes across more with a rotelike performance than a human performance, and while that may have changed over the last month and a half, I'm not sure the electorate has seen that."
These numbers, combined with the simultaneous Bradley surge and Mr. Gore's disappointing poll results in the hypothetical race against Mr. Bush, sent Mr. Gore into a tumult of reinvention at the end of September and spawned a painfully public makeover. The competition jolted him out of his blue suit, out of his predictable stump speech and out of the arms of Bill Clinton. The remodeling was so extensive that it raised questions of his essential self and whether he was a subservient "beta" male who could morph into a dominating "alpha" male.
In addition, the continual recalibrating and focus on the performance aspects of politics began to overshadow what his supporters saw as his strongest assets: his experience and command of the issues.
That point seemed to be at the heart of the heated exchange between Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley in their Dec. 19 debate on "Meet the Press." Hoping to unmask Mr. Bradley as a conventional politician who could not survive without high-priced television spots, Mr. Gore proposed that both he and Mr. Bradley drop all 30-second commercials and instead hold twice-a-week debates.
Mr. Bradley spurned the offer, as the Gore camp expected he would, and ridiculed it as a gimmick. "The point is, Al," he said derisively, "and I don't know if you get this, but a political campaign is not just a performance for people, which is what this is, but it is, rather, a dialogue."
For Mr. Gore, the offer was about more than performance, or even saving money on commercials. He wanted to show himself as the true "reformer" and paint Mr. Bradley as beholden to the status quo. Despite the negative press reviews of thetheatrics, Gore advisers said they were pleased with the gesture because the public did not like 30-second commercials, even if it got most of its information from them.
"I think people are sick of these old advertisements and the old approach to campaigning," Mr. Gore said a few days later on the PBS program "The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer." He dismissed campaign commercials as "filled with fuzzy images and little, short slogans" and cast Mr. Bradley as cautious and timid, precisely the words often used to describe Mr. Gore.
Curtis Gans, director of the nonpartisan Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, said that the Gore campaign was determined to portray Mr. Bradley as just another politician. "What Gore was trying to establish in that debate was that Bradley couldn't run above it all," Mr. Gans said.
Whether or not Mr. Gore succeeded, many analysts say that his aggressive approach has thrown Mr. Bradley off his game. "Gore has stemmed the bloodletting," Mr. West said. "He's been a better candidate."
Mr. Gore has also sought to draw Mr. Bradley into an argument over policy details -- and away from the former basketball star's big themes and compelling personal story.
"Bradley was saying to people, 'Here's who I am,' " Mr. Hart said. "People aren't going to pick a president on the basis of that. At this point, I don't know that Bradley has the message that overrides the constituency groups that Gore has put together. Gore has the backbone of the Democratic Party -- women, labor, minorities."
Mr. Gore has been working to solidify that base, with his sharp attacks on Mr. Bradley's proposals. In particular, he has warned relentlessly that Mr. Bradley's health care proposal would "shred the social safety net," because it would eliminate Medicaid; he does not mention that Mr. Bradley has proposed a replacement for Medicaid.
Although Mr. Gore has been running behind in New Hampshire polls, he has cause for optimism. After New Hampshire, attention turns to the March primaries in New York, Ohio, California and a dozen other states. Mr. Bradley could receive a tremendous lift by winning in New York, perhaps his best state after New Hampshire, but polls in California show Mr. Gore strongly ahead.
Beyond that, Mr. Gore has the underlying advantage of official party support and the endorsement of labor, including the teachers' unions. He has locked up endorsements from more than 520 of the 799 superdelegates to the convention. These are the governors, senators, members of Congress and other party worthies who are automatically delegates. Mr. Bradley has endorsements from about 20 superdelegates.
The first to claim 2,169 delegates wins the nomination; without a single vote yet cast, Mr. Gore is nearly a quarter of the way there.
Bill Carrick, a Democratic strategist based in California and not affiliated with either campaign, put it this way: "Bradley almost has to get a nuclear blast out of Iowa and New Hampshire to carry him out of March 7 and March 14."
After Iowa and New Hampshire, he said, "you begin to play to the vice president's strength, which is broad support across many demographic groups. Even in New York the numbers are moving for Gore."
But other challenges remain. In voter surveys, Mr. Gore ranks poorly in the category of leadership. On money, he has two problems. He is vulnerable to charges of overzealousness in raising it at a Buddhist temple, and vulnerable to concerns that he might not have enough of it to campaign effectively against Mr. Bush through the summer.
In addition, if Mr. Gore wins the nomination, he may have to convince moderate swing voters that he is not as liberal as he may have seemed in his fight with Mr. Bradley.
"Bradley has forced Gore to the left on a wide range of issues, from education to health care to gay rights," Mr. West said. On education, he has promised to increase federal spending to $115 billion over 10 years. He is now framing his health-care plan as one that would lead to universal coverage, as Mr. Bradley proposes, and he has followed Mr. Bradley in his public support for allowing gays to serve openly in the military.
Ominously, a Pew Research Center poll on Dec. 16 found Mr. Gore losing a hypothetical matchup against Mr. Bush, 55 percent to 40 percent, with two important segments of the traditional Democratic base -- women and senior citizens -- favoring Mr. Bush.
But perhaps no challenge is stickier than what to do about Mr. Clinton. Mr. Gore seems caught in a revolving door of walking out on his mentor and then walking back in. Mr. Clinton is a strong force in mobilizing black voters for Mr. Gore. But he is also a drag on Mr. Gore with other voters, especially the independents and Republicans whom Mr. Gore would need in a general election.
"Al Gore's biggest problem is that he represents the equivalent of a Clinton third term," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for the Bush campaign. "And no one is of a mind to give Bill Clinton a third term."
 
AT A GLANCE: The Gore Campaign
 
HEADQUARTERS Nashville
STAFF SIZE 160 full-time paid workers.
TOP CAMPAIGN STAFF Chairman is Tony Coelho, a former congressman from California. Campaign manager is Donna Brazile, a veteran political organizer. Top media strategists are Carter Eskew, Bob Shrum and Tad Devine, longtime Democratic advisers.
CASH ON HAND The campaign refuses to release an estimate, but at the end of September, it had about $10 million.
PROMINENT ADVISERS Chief domestic policy adviser is Elaine Kamarck, formerly of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, now with the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Others who work closely with Mr. Gore are Karenna Gore Schiff, his older daughter; Naomi Wolf, the feminist author, and Andrew M. Cuomo, the housing secretary. He talks informally with several other advisers, including Henry L. Gates, Harvard professor, on racial issues; Robert F. Kennedy Jr., on the environment; Gov. Gray Davis of California, on education; Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, on agriculture, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, on general political matters. Among his closest associates are Tom Downey, the former congressman from Long Island who is now a Washington lobbyist.
BEST MOVES SO FAR Locking up the support of the Democratic establishment early so that he staved off all but one challenger for the nomination; amassing most of the superdelegates early; revamping his campaign in September with a renewed sense of vigor; winning the endorsement of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
WORST MOVES SO FAR He says his biggest mistake was exaggerating his role in the creation of the Internet. More broadly, he underestimated the Bradley challenge; he started his campaign on K Street, Washington's corridor of power and influence, and coasted for months with a bloated staff and a sense of entitlement to the nomination.
CHALLENGES AHEAD Erasing doubts about his electability in the fall; escaping his association with his impeached political benefactor, Bill Clinton, but getting credit for the booming economy; shedding the image of a career politician and appearing less programmed.
 
State of the Campaigns
 
This is the second in a series of status reports on the campaigns of the top contenders for the Democratic and Republican nominations as they enter the primary season. Next: The Bush campaign.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Another Model for Schools

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Schools on military bases, run by the Department of Defense, have a better record than most public schools in this country. Student test scores are high. Black and Hispanic children far outperform those elsewhere. Children from poorer families do almost as well as the better-off.
I learned about the base schools in an article by Daniel Golden in The Wall Street Journal last week. It was an eye-opening piece, reporting remarkable facts about a little-known institution and leaving us with important questions about what makes those schools work and how our society can learn from their success. 
 The Pentagon has 71 schools for children of service members at bases in this country, and 153 overseas. In the last six years, pupils have taken 13 National Assessment of Educational Progress tests; in 12 their results were above the national mean. More than 80 percent of the graduates go on to college, compared with the national figure of 67 percent.
Of the 34,000 students in the domestic base schools, more than half qualify for free or reduced-price lunches because of low family income. They did almost as well as other students in demonstrating writing proficiency.
Forty percent of the domestic students are black or Hispanic. On writing proficiency, 26 percent of the black children scored at or above passing level, compared with 7 percent nationally; 32 percent of the Hispanics did, compared with 10 percent nationally.
Mr. Golden's story quoted Roy Truby, executive director of the board that administers the National Assessment tests, on those results: "This debunks the notion that demography is destiny."
How is it done? The article mentioned a number of distinctive factors.
One is money. The domestic schools spend $7,279 per pupil, 23 percent more than public schools do on average. Among other things, the money goes for art and music classes -- which have been trimmed in many public schools as marginal extras but which I think are a vital part of the learning atmosphere. And some goes for technology: more computers for the students.
Parent involvement is a second factor. The military gives parents of children in base schools an hour off a week or a half-day a month to volunteer in the schools, and many do.
A third is discipline. If a student misbehaves and moderate measures do not work, a parent will be called in for a conference. If he or she does not show up, the school may get in touch with his or her commanding officer. Enough said.
Some of the practices that help account for the good showing of the base schools could readily be duplicated in ordinary public schools. If a community is able to spend more on its schools -- and, crucially, has the political will to do so -- students may benefit.
Other elements are peculiar to the military. We would not want a school principal to telephone a private employer of a parent who has not come in for a conference about a misbehaving child.
Underneath the particular reasons for the performance of the base schools there are, surely, larger social factors. For one, military families may have modest housing, but they are not likely to live in the desperate ghettos that exist in our inner cities. To put it mildly, it is harder for a child to learn when she lives amid decay and danger.
The gap between high and low incomes is less stark among military personnel, and less distorting, than in our civilian society today. The difference between rich and poor school districts is a major problem for public schools in many states. There are one-parent families in the military, but probably not so many as in civilian America.
Finally, I think there is a deeper sense of community among military families. The free market and the race to get ahead have given us, along with their economic benefits, an atomized society. We do not care for each other as we believe, perhaps romantically, Americans once did.
We do not want to be militarized as a nation. But we have to recognize that the military is one of our most successful institutions: profoundly effective in achieving racial integration in the services and now, we find, in educating its children. We should be able to learn from its successes.
