HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Away From Bid To Cut Off Aid to Russia

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
The United States will not seek to block economic aid to Russia as punishment for that country's widely condemned campaign against separatist rebels in Chechnya, a Clinton administration official said today.
The official, speaking after Russia won the release today of a $100 million loan from the World Bank, said aid packages to Russia from the United States, the World Bank or its sister agency, the International Monetary Fund, would be considered on a case-by-case basis. But he said the Clinton administration would not apply a umbrella political standard when reviewing aid programs and has no plans to cut off aid in general as a way of punishing Russia for its military campaign in Chechnya. 
 "We support this disbursement of funds, which will be used to restructure the coal sector," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "It is fully consistent with the common objective of promoting market reforms in Russia."
The World Bank loan released today to help Russia restructure its coal industry did not require formal United States approval. But Washington often uses its influence at the bank and the International Monetary Fund to block loans that it considers contrary to its national interest.
Last week, the administration sent a different signal when Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright ordered the Export-Import Bank to reject a $500 million loan for Russia. Dr. Albright cited concerns about the Russian state-affiliated oil company that would have received the money and State Department officials said the decision had nothing to do with Chechnya. But other administration officials suggested at the time that the Chechnya conflict had heightened the political sensitivity of economic cooperation with Russia.
The approval of aid from the World Bank immediately raised Russian hopes that the United States would not block a much larger aid package from the monetary fund. The fund must decide whether to release $640 million to Russia that it delayed in September, citing Russia's failure to meet certain conditions of the loan. A decision on whether Russia has met those conditions could come as soon as next month.
"It is good news, a good event," Alexander Livshits, a senior Russia economic envoy, said today on Moscow television. "The World Bank has grasped positively what is happening in the Russian economy. I think this is not the last good news."
Clinton administration officials said they did not intend to signal that their support for World Bank loans would necessarily carry over to aid from the monetary fund, which is intended to help Russia pay back earlier loans it has received from international agencies. But they said that the United States was not applying a political litmus test to economic aid and that the administration would continue to pursue its broad economic objectives in Russia despite the Chechnya campaign.
What the war in Chechnya has done, one administration official said, was to make the United States reluctant to approve any new loan disbursements if Russia had not strictly adhered to the terms of using previous aid. In other words, Russia is not going to get much latitude in the way it uses aid, but could still see a steady flow of foreign loans as long as it uses them properly.
Russia had fully met the conditions of previous World Bank loans to its coal industry, and therefore the bank and the United States had no grounds to hold up aid, officials at the bank and the Clinton administration said.
The World Bank loan will mean little to the Russian economy or the country's ability to wage war against Chechen separatists. The money is earmarked exclusively to "cushion the impact" of mass layoffs in the coal industry. Russia has agreed to close 116 inefficient mines as a condition of receiving the aid.
But the loan is still an important symbol for the Russian government, which has been working to show that its economic relations with the outside world are still on track despite international condemnation of its military actions in Chechnya.
Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, whose centrist political party did well in Russia's recent parliamentary elections, has promised to jumpstart economic reforms advocated by the West even as he leads the uncompromising military effort. His party includes a number of politicians who say they would like to speed up efforts to remake Russia's economy in the Western mold, changes that came to a standstill when Russia devalued its currency and defaulted on some of its debt in August 1998.
The Clinton administration has also been eager to show that economic engagement with Russia, a broad policy of helping Russia manage its economy and its finances, has paid dividends despite an increasingly strained relationship with Moscow over geopolitical issues. Officials said halting aid to Russia now makes no sense, given that politicians with favor economic changes are ascendant and that Russian markets have begun to recover from their sharp reversal last year.
Human rights groups also criticized the World Bank's decision to release the loans. "We are seriously disappointed by the bank's decision," Holly Cartner, executive director of Human Rights Watch's Europe and Central Asia Division, said in a statement. "The bank's stated commitment to addressing the 'human aspects' of development rings hollow when its funds are paid directly to a government pursuing the kind of abusive campaign we are witnessing in Chechnya."
The World Bank staff considered the Chechnya conflict when reviewing whether to release the aid, according to a bank spokeswoman, Gina Ciagne. But that review focused soley on the financial impact -- whether the war effort would so deplete Russia's financial resources and scare away investors that the country would have a hard time paying back the loans, she said.
The war could have that effect in the long run, Ms. Ciagne said. But it did not threaten to do so now. She said the bank was legally obligated to disburse money agreed to in the 1997 coal-sector reform package, provided that Russia met the loan's conditions.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asian Markets Ending 1999 On Steep Internet Ascent

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Stock markets across Asia are riding out the millennium on a cloud of euphoria generated by -- what else? -- the Internet.
Shares in Tokyo, Seoul, Hong Kong and Kuala Lumpur rose again today, providing fresh evidence, if any were needed, that the information revolution has replaced the Asian economic crisis as the preoccupation of investors in this part of the world. 
"Asia has lagged the West in information technology," said Dong Tao, a regional economist with Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong. "But with Asia recovering from the crisis, companies are now willing to invest in this area. People see the possibility of a real breakthrough."
In South Korea, the market rose 2.2 percent to a five-year high, while stocks in Taiwan were up four-tenths of 1 percent, in the last trading sessions of 1999 for those markets. The gains capped a rally that began early in the year, as fears about Asian finances receded. After a setback during the summer, the rally reignited in October as companies began pursuing a flurry of Internet-related ventures in the region.
This jolt of excitement helped the benchmark South Korean index gain 82.78 percent for the year -- and more yet in dollar terms, 92.58 percent -- the best performance of any Asian market outside Japan. Taiwan's exchange, despite the devastating earthquake there in September, rose 31.63 percent from its final trading session of 1998.
Nowhere has the giddiness over technology been more pronounced than in Hong Kong. The benchmark Hang Seng index has moved from strength to strength over the last week, up more than half a percent today, to 16,928.29. It has risen 68 percent so far this year, and is higher now than it was at the peak of the territory's real estate boom in the mid-90's.
Analysts said today's gain was led by a company that did not exist a year ago: Pacific Century Cyberworks, which invests in Internet start-ups and is creating its own satellite-delivered Internet service. Its shares jumped 22 percent today, after soaring 44 percent last Thursday and Friday. The surge began in the United States last Wednesday, when the company's shares doubled in over-the-counter trading.
Pacific Century Cyberworks -- which was founded by Richard Li, the son of the Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing -- loses money and will for several more years. Still, the company is being hailed as the vehicle that could turn Hong Kong into a technology mecca. And the younger Mr. Li spent last week denying rumors that he was about to swap shares with Microsoft or seek a listing on the Nasdaq market.
"Pacific Century does not even have a core business yet," Mr. Tao of Credit Suisse First Boston said. "But it has demonstrated its ability to raise funds, and that's what's important in this business."
With a market capitalization exceeding $30 billion, Pacific Century is worth almost as much as the elder Mr. Li's flagship company, Cheung Kong Holdings. Mr. Tao suggested that Richard Li had created as much wealth, on paper, in five months as his father did in 50 years.
Hong Kong's Internet bubble has expanded to encompass Internet-related companies like Cable and Wireless HKT, Hong Kong's local phone provider, and China Telecom (Hong Kong), the publicly listed arm of the entrenched mainland Chinese phone company.
China Telecom, which owns the gateways that Chinese use to gain access to the World Wide Web, is regarded by investors as a way to capitalize on the rapid growth of the Internet there. Cable and Wireless HKT recently signed a deal with Star TV, an Asian satellite television company controlled by the News Corporation, to provide high-speed Internet access and television programs throughout the region.
Despite the resurgence of Asian stocks, many analysts do not think that Hong Kong and other Asian markets are as steeply priced as those in the United States. Brokerage firms here predict that the Hang Seng index will finish next year significantly above its current levels, even with 1999's ascent.
"The Hong Kong market could easily pull back a bit from here," acknowledged Richard Margolis, a regional strategist at Merrill Lynch here. "But it's not as heavily underpinned as the U.S. markets by companies whose only valuation is a multiple of their losses."
One reason for the optimism is that Asia's underlying economies have recovered faster than almost anyone predicted. Mr. Tao, for example, recently increased his forecast for Hong Kong's economic growth in 2000 to 5.1 percent, from 3.2 percent. He says the territory is enjoying a sharp, "V-shaped" rebound.
With exports from South Korea booming and foreign investors pouring money into stocks there, the Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade estimated that the country's gross domestic product will increase this year at an outsized rate of 9.5 percent, and a very respectable 6.5 percent in 2000.
Still, analysts are wary of projecting a future of unbroken gains. The enthusiasm for Internet shares is an export of the United States, and it has made Asian markets more dependent than ever on stock performance in New York, especially on the Nasdaq in recent months. If either the Nasdaq or the Dow Jones industrial average were to fall significantly from their current levels, analysts said it could halt the rebound in the region.
Simon L. Ogus, former head of Asian economics at Warburg Dillon Read, said: "There has always been a lot of correlation between the U.S. and Asian markets, because many of them are small, trading economies. But there is more correlation than ever now. We've got one huge correlative bet going on here."

HEADLINE: Coup Leader Tells Diplomats He Will Honor Ivory Coast's Debts

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Portraying himself as a responsible leader, the former army chief who seized power here last week met today with foreign diplomats and vowed to honor Ivory Coast's huge foreign debts.
Since the largely nonviolent coup, Gen. Robert Guei has been meeting with people from various sectors of society to outline his vision for the future. 
 General Guei met with political party leaders on Monday and invited them to submit candidates for a transitional cabinet that he said could be announced next week.
General Guei, who earlier had promised an "orderly" return to democracy, said today that he would improve on the record of the ousted president, Henri Konan Bedie, whose government was accused of rampant corruption that led the International Monetary Fund and European Union to cut aid this year.
General Guei has not said, however, whether presidential elections scheduled for October would go ahead.
An American Embassy official, speaking on condition of anonymity, cautiously praised General Guei for "making the right noises."
But the official said the United States would continue to push for a return to constitutional rule and democracy.
General Guei told diplomats that the coup had not been planned. He said he had merely responded to a spontaneous army uprising for better conditions and improved governance.
"I had to make a choice to guarantee peace," General Guei said, and assure "security to all Ivoirian men and women." He also accused Mr. Bedie of deliberately fomenting political and ethnic divisions, including hiring private security companies to terrorize civilians. His claims could not immediately be verified.
The Canadian ambassador, Don McMaster, however, condemned the overthrow. Canada has suspended all direct aid to Ivory Coast.
Ambassador McMaster said: "Guei's response was: 'This wasn't a coup d'etat.' But whatever term you want to use, this is something we have to condemn."
The military uprising began last Thursday with troops racing through the commercial capital, Abidjan, in seized luxury cars and shooting in the air.
On Friday, General Guei declared that the military was in control and suspended the Constitution, courts and Parliament. He then appointed nine officers to a National Committee of Public Salvation that will oversee the country, with himself as president of the committee.
Many Ivoirians welcomed the coup, saying they hoped that the army would improve Ivory Coast's declining economic and political conditions.
Ivory Coast, a nation of 19 million people, had long been considered a model of stability in volatile West Africa. The military takeover was the country's first since it became independent from France in 1960.
Political and social tensions have increased in recent months. President Bedie was widely criticized for banning outdoor political demonstrations and jailing opposition politicians.
On Sunday, Mr. Bedie fled with family members to Lome, the capital of nearby Togo.
The ousted president made a brief trip on Monday to Abuja, Nigeria, where he promised not to oppose the coup with violence and said he planned to spend his "forced asylum" trying to rally support for his government.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Record for Dow Jones; Nasdaq Falls Shy of 4,000
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed to a record. Led by Alcoa, United Technologies and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the Dow closed at 11,476.71, up 85.63 points, or 0.8 percent. 
 Highflying technology shares suffered a late-day sell-off, and the Nasdaq composite index -- which traded above the 4,000 level for most of the session -- gave up a 47-point gain and closed lower. The Nasdaq fell 3.27 points, to 3,972.11. Meanwhile, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index barely budged, edging up 0.56 point, to 1,457.66. Page C9.
 
Internet Propels Stocks in Asia
Stock prices in Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Malaysia rose again, riding a wave of euphoria over the Internet, providing fresh evidence that the information revolution has replaced the Asian economic crisis as the preoccupation of investors in the region. C3.
 
The Belle of the New Year's Ball
Tama Starr, the third generation of her family to run Artkraft Strauss, the company known for its giant animated signs in Times Square and the New Year's Eve ball that it has tended and lowered for 88 years, never expected to run the company. Her background was in liberal arts. After a year of graduate study in comparative religion, she moved to Hawaii, built a house, was a writer and was in a performing arts group. But she returned to the company, where she has spent 18 New Year's Eves atop the tower where the ball drops. Management. C6.

Goldman Sachs agreed to acquire a stake in Argentina's Grupo Clarin, the publisher of the largest-circulation newspaper in the Spanish-speaking world, for $500 million. C3.
 
New Jersey Company Recalls Foods
D'Artagnan, a New Jersey company, is voluntarily recalling 26 of its products, including foie gras pates, mousses and terrines, and has closed the Huntington, N.Y., plant that produced them because of possible contamination with a sometimes deadly bacteria. A20.
 
Commodity Rally Not a Warning Sign
As the prices of commodities like heating oil, crude oil, copper and nickel make a run at the end of the year, some analysts say that the rally is built on a bet that the global economy, led by Asia and Europe, will continue to rebound in 2000. But the rise in industrial commodities is not, as it has been in the past, an early warning signal for inflation. Market Place. C8.
 
Consumer Confidence Stays Strong
Consumer confidence rose in December to the highest level in three decades. The Conference Board said its index of consumer confidence rose to 141.4 this month, the second-highest reading in the 32 years. In a separate report, the National Association of Realtors said that sales of existing homes surged 6 percent in November, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.09 million units. C8.
 
$100 Million Released to Russia
Russia won the release of a $100 million loan from the World Bank, and the United States said it would not seek to block economic aid to Russia as punishment for its campaign against separatist rebels in Chechnya. A8.
 
Millennium Celebrations Fizzle
Fears of terrorism have caused organizers to cancel some New Year's Eve events and prompted some travelers to cancel airline and hotel reservations, but the biggest dampener has proved to be the high price tags for parties and entertainment packages. But that is not stopping preparations for 2001, the real start of the next millennium in many eyes. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. C8.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: IDEAS INTO ACTION/FRED ANDREWS;
A Man of Words Is Still Partial to One: Loyalty

BYLINE: This column about management issues appears every other week. Fred Andrews's e-mail address is frandrew@nytimes.com.

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
IN the 90's, a tough, impatient decade that has given loyalty a drubbing, Frederick F. Reichheld has always been loyalty's champion in business. Mr. Reichheld produced the hard numbers showing that a seasoned employee, treated properly, was two or three times as productive as someone just in the door.
No one ever questioned that customer loyalty was a good thing. But precious few companies actually understood how powerful a lever a committed customer was. Mr. Reichheld, a management consultant at Bain & Company in Boston, had the tally: A company that keeps just 5 percent more of its customers from sliding away could lift profits by 50 percent. 
 Times have changed, but he still preaches that loyalty, an old-fashioned virtue, is fundamental to business success on the Internet. This season Amazon.com, for one, with its obsession with serving customers, is singing Fred Reichheld's song.
Everyone understands that e-commerce economics requires enormous expenditures upfront to attract a clientele. This holiday season was a critical test of which e-tailers could win out in pulling customers to their sites.
But that's only a start. Those customers have to stick around. The Internet measures a site's "stickiness" in minutes; profitability is reckoned in years. According to preliminary research by Bain and others, it will take three to four years of loyal patronage just to break even on what is now being spent to drag customers in the door.
"The economics of loyalty just gets applied so much more powerfully," Mr. Reichheld said in an interview on Dec. 17. "If you think about the true economics of an Internet business: they've got this big acquisition cost, and then they've got a potential annuity of income if they treat people right and earn their loyalty."
Mr. Reichheld believes the Internet has enormous potential for serving customers better, with richer information, interactive relationships and innovative services. "There are so many creative things you can do for the customer's lifetime experience," he said, "lots of ways to create a unique, distinctive and much better customer experience."
From what he has seen so far, however, "very few" companies are going to be able to hold their customers for three to four years. Acquisition costs for the pure Internet e-tailers are "going up like crazy," he said, while the customers they attract tend to surf from one retail site to another. "They're snagging fundamentally disloyal butterfly kinds of customers," he said.
The preliminary research on consumers' Internet shopping habits and projected loyalties shows some traditional merchants like Lands' End and L. L. Bean doing very well. Their customers are Velcro, not Vaseline.
"I'm pretty convinced that the existing firms, as they add Internet capabilities, are going to cream pure-play Internet," Mr. Reichheld said. Some traditional merchants enjoy customer retention rates 10 to 20 percentage points higher than their newer competition. Normally, trailing the competition by 20 points in customer loyalty "is enough to put you out of business," he noted, adding that "10 points is very weak returns."
Mr. Reichheld's core doctrine is engraved in stone: Companies that cultivate loyal customers, loyal employees, loyal investors, consistently outperform their competition. Mr. Reichheld first built a Bain practice and then a philosophy on that observation.
"One, it all starts with trust," he said. "If you don't earn your customer's trust, you won't make money on the Internet. Two, unless you have superior economics -- a strategy for building real economic advantage -- you're not worthy of trust. Three, customer selection is more vital than ever. There is so much churn out there."
Mr. Reichheld is an idealist and a perfectionist. On average, he notes, American companies lose roughly half their customers in five years, half their employees in four. The huge expense of replacing them offends his perfectionist streak. And the emerging career pattern of workers jumping from employer to employer strikes him as a sad failure. It is "sheer hogwash" to preach that message to young people, he said.
"A great company is where you want to end up and spend most of your life," he said. "Most of life is a search for people and institutions worthy of your loyalty and commitment. People yearn for that. That's why the Marines are not short on recruiting."
At 47 and financially secure, Mr. Reichheld has retired from client engagements. His Bain partners made him the first Bain Fellow, a half-time senior position that permits him to concentrate on extending his loyalty research. He gave a score of speeches this year, and he is three-quarters through writing a book on corporate leadership.
"This idea of treating people right, principled relationships -- it doesn't just happen naturally," he said. "It takes leaders who have the ability to put others' interests ahead, to take a long time frame, and to bring things into that framework."
Every year or so, most recently in October, Mr. Reichheld assembles a a circle of chief executives from companies he admires. The collection is as varied as Intuit, Vanguard, Harley Davidson, Chick-fil-A, Northwestern Mutual Life, State Farm, A. G. Edwards, Enterprise Rent-a-Car, ServiceMaster and Bright Horizons Family Solutions. That circle provides sketches from life for his book on leadership -- far-sighted executives like Scott Cook of Intuit, Benjamin F. Edwards III of A. G. Edwards and S. Truett Cathy of Chick-fil-A.
"These businesses structure themselves in a way that would make it logical that you would commit to them," Mr. Reichheld said. "The way people are treated, the principles they run on, the real results, are worth that commitment." Among other things, "they align people's interests, so that if the team wins, they drag along everyone who contributed."
His favorite instance is Chick-fil-A, the fast-food chicken chain, which is based in Atlanta. Its store operators put up only $5,000 and pay the parent company 15 percent of sales for various services. Above that, parent and operator split all the profits 50-50. Incomes of $100,000 or more are common; a handful of operators earn $300,000 or more, typically from two outlets. By contrast, the competition might pay $40,000 or $50,000.
"Chick-fil-A -- they celebrate when their people do well," Mr. Reichheld declared. In his view, Mr. Cathy, who founded Chick-fil-A, got it exactly right: "There is no way in heaven he can get rich unless his store operators get rich." And Mr. Cathy is quite rich.
Four years ago, Mr. Reichheld's first book, "The Loyalty Effect" (Harvard Business School Press), debunked the notion that loyalty was dead. It also put loyalty economics on the map. It showed, for instance, that when a brokerage house improved its retention of brokers to 90 percent from 80 percent, it more than doubled the potential value of a new hire.
For one credit card company, a 5 percent increase in customer retention translated into a 75 percent increase in the average customer's lifetime value to the company. Typically, a customer generated $40 in profit the first year, $106 in the 10th and $161 in the 20th. Customers who stick around tend to buy more, are much cheaper to serve, bring in friends as referrals, and accept premium pricing. Over the years, that all compounds.
"In the old world," Mr. Reichheld said, "you can have medium loyalty and still make a buck," protected by a convenient location or the customer's lack of information. In the Internet world, there will be no place to hide, no substitute for earning high loyalty. "The economics are going to be obvious," he predicted. "People are going to be forced to do the right thing or get out of business."

HEADLINE: Another Destructive Coup

 BODY:
The news out of Ivory Coast this week may seem all too familiar for a West African nation: an armed forces mutiny, widespread looting, the armed seizure of radio and television stations, and finally the announcement of a coup by soldiers who say they are promoting national "salvation." On Sunday the ousted president, Henri Konan Bedie, was airlifted to neighboring Togo and may seek asylum in France.
But this not just another African coup. Ivory Coast has long been regarded as one of the most stable and prosperous countries in Africa. It is the world's largest producer of cocoa, with good roads and a modern capital, Abidjan, boasting glass-and-steel office towers and a cosmopolitan middle class. It has been a friend to the United States. 
 Yet the coup has exposed the illusory nature of stability in countries where even the best-intentioned leaders have relied on coercion and patronage to secure their power and where democracy and accountability are extremely fragile. After independence from France in 1960, Ivory Coast was dominated for more than three decades by Felix Houphouet-Boigny, who presided over rapid economic growth and skillfully balanced the interests of regional groups, but failed to lay a firm institutional foundation that could withstand the ambitions of a less nimble successor.
Mr. Bedie, who took office when Mr. Houphouet-Boigny died in 1993, oversaw a steadily more corrupt and repressive regime. His fate may have been sealed in 1995 when he won a full five-year term in balloting sullied by government rules that eliminated the president's strongest rivals. His security forces bullied opponents and the press, creating a groundswell of ill will. The country is now being run by a nine-man junta. Its leader is Gen. Robert Guei, a former chief of staff of the armed forces who has said he will create a government that will include civilians -- but has not said when.
France is the real power to reckon with in Ivory Coast. The French too often acquiesced in Mr. Bedie's transgressions for their own strategic and commercial reasons. Nevertheless, both France and the United States have rightly condemned this armed seizure of power, as did Nigeria and South Africa, the two most powerful countries in sub-Saharan Africa. They should insist that the soldiers promptly set a date certain when they will hand the country over to genuine democratic rule.

HEADLINE: Iowa Turf War Over Transplants Mirrors Feuds Across the Nation

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Like a baseball team that recruits a winning pitcher, administrators at Iowa Methodist Medical Center gave themselves a hearty pat on the back when Dr. Maureen Martin signed on to their staff. A nationally recognized liver transplant surgeon, Dr. Martin, 49, possesses the self-confident charm and star power that hospital marketing people love.
She had worked with Dr. Thomas E. Starzl, who founded the field and turned the University of Pittsburgh into a magnet for liver transplants, and went on to build her own program at the University of Iowa, 120 miles from here in Iowa City. Two years ago, when the university rejected her plans for satellite centers around the state, Iowa Methodist was only too happy to start its own liver transplant center, with Dr. Martin as chief. 
 What Iowa Methodist did not anticipate was the nasty turf war that would ensue. The chief liver surgeon at the University of Nebraska, which draws patients from neighboring Iowa, has questioned whether the region needs another transplant program and has accused Dr. Martin of "self-serving baloney." When Iowa Methodist sought, and received, state approval for its plans, the opposition from the University of Iowa was so fierce that Dr. Martin no longer speaks to her former partner there.
Such is life in the liver wars. At a time when human organs, particularly livers, are in short supply, the skirmish in Iowa provides a window into a national feud over the Clinton administration's plan to require that donated hearts, lungs, livers, kidneys and pancreases go to the sickest patients first, rather than those who live closest to the organ donors. The debate polarized Congress at the end of its last session and is expected to resume when the lawmakers return in January.
But the debate is not just about saving lives, according to people on both sides as well as experts outside the transplant field. The fight, they say, is about which transplant centers -- not which patients -- will get the scarce organs, and the profits and prestige that go with them. It is being driven by surgeons, they say, whose careers and egos depend on the success and size of the transplant programs they run.
"This is a power struggle," said Dr. Martin, who will leave Iowa in January for Beth Israel Deaconness Medical Center in Boston, to replace a surgeon who took his entire liver transplant team -- 28 people -- and 2,000 patients to a competing hospital, the Lahey Clinic. "It's a tug of war, and the patients are the rope."
The administration's proposed rule would give Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of Health and Human Services, broad authority over organ allocation policy. Dr. Shalala has ordered the United Network for Organ Sharing, the nonprofit agency that runs the distribution network, to devise a new system that meets her sickest-first criteria and would allow for broad sharing of organs across state lines. Although the details have not been worked out, the mere idea of change has split liver centers into roughly two camps.
Because nearly every liver surgeon in the nation has either trained under Dr. Starzl or trained under someone who has, the dispute is at its core a family feud, although the patriarch from Pittsburgh, now semiretired, has maintained a conspicuous silence throughout.
On one side are seven very large programs, led by Pittsburgh's, which tend to treat very sick patients and would presumably benefit from rules that put the sickest first. These centers support Dr. Shalala. On the other is the Patients Access to Transplantation Coalition, a collection of several dozen mostly midsize hospitals like the University of Iowa that have thrived under the current system, in which geography, as opposed to medical urgency, dictates the flow of organs. These centers want to maintain the status quo, and say that Dr. Shalala has no right to intervene in medical decisions.
Both sides are busy lobbying Congress, where members are lining up not by party affiliation but by how they believe the plan may affect doctors in their states.
"It's the politics of local interest, which are partially economic but also a question of prestige and status and competitiveness among surgeons and institutions," said Bruce Vladek, a health policy analyst at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, which is in the Pittsburgh camp. "There is something to me that is tawdry about very highly compensated, high-prestige professionals engaged in such a naked turf fight with the interests of patients so far down in the pecking order of what gets worried about or paid attention to."
Mr. Vladek is not the only one who is disgusted. Dr. Lawrence G. Hunsicker, the kidney specialist at the University of Iowa to whom Dr. Martin no longer speaks, accuses his fellow transplant professionals of "squabbling like spoiled children."
Dr. Byers W. Shaw Jr., the Nebraska surgeon who raised questions about Iowa Methodist's program, says friendships with doctors he once respected have gone sour.
"This is about our failure as a profession to solve our own problems," Dr. Shaw said. "The arrogance that I have heard from some of my colleagues is unimaginable."
Yet as the debate drags on, and the organ shortage grows more acute, more and more hospitals are trying to jump into the transplant business, creating regional feuds similar to the one that erupted in Iowa. With the transplant field maturing, the academic medical centers that dominated the landscape are now facing competition from community-based hospitals like Iowa Methodist. Often, there is little they can do.
When a hospital in Norfolk, Va., sought permission to start a liver program this year, the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond objected. When heart and pancreas transplant centers opened in Portland, Ore., the Oregon Health Sciences University raised a fuss. In New York, Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx and Westchester County Medical Center received state permission in November to begin doing heart transplants, provoking private grumbling, Mr. Vladek said, from others in the field.
Nationwide, the number of liver transplant programs has leaped to 125 in 1998 from 70 in 1988, according to the United Network for Organ Sharing.
"Most people would say there are certainly more programs than are warranted," said Roger W. Evans, a health policy analyst who has advised the government on transplant matters.
Yet building a transplant program, which requires not only highly trained surgeons but also a highly trained staff to support them, is not easy, as Dr. Martin has found.
Despite its state approval, Iowa Methodist has not begun offering liver transplants because it has not met the organ-sharing network's requirement that a hepatologist, a nonsurgical liver specialist, be on staff. A hepatologist has been recruited and will join the hospital in June, officials there say. And with Dr. Martin's departure for what she described as a job offer too good to resist, they will also have to find a liver surgeon.
Fast-talking and blunt, with blue-rimmed oval glasses and a dime-sized diamond on her ring finger, Dr. Martin is one of the very few women in her field. She chose the liver as her specialty, she says, because "it requires guts to operate on." The remark is telling, reflecting the legacy of Dr. Starzl, who is widely considered brilliant, irascible and bold.
Dr. Starzl declined to be interviewed. "He feels it's beneath him" to get involved in the dispute, explained Dr. John Fung, who now runs the Pittsburgh transplant program, adding that the dispute had "genuinely hurt" Dr. Starzl. "It's like a parent giving birth to Abel and Cain."
Dr. Martin, who describes Dr. Starzl as a "Rasputin" yet keeps his picture and a signed copy of his book in her office, went to work for him in 1989, when Pittsburgh dominated the field. Of 2,201 liver transplants in the United States that year, Pittsburgh surgeons performed 441. By the time Dr. Martin left for the University of Iowa three years later, new liver transplant centers, many run by Pittsburgh-trained surgeons, were popping up, changing the economics of the business.
Pittsburgh performed just 160 liver transplants last year, according to the organ-sharing network. The price of a transplant has been estimated at $244,600, said Mr. Evans, the health policy analyst, although health-plan reimbursements may be much lower. So for a big center like Pittsburgh, the drop-off in business is a significant loss.
For small to medium-sized hospitals like Iowa Methodist, the financial picture is different. The hospital does not plan to get rich doing transplants; an economic analysis found it would actually lose $1 million a year for the first three years, although those losses would be significantly offset by other liver disease patients the center would bring in. By the third year, the analysis found, the entire liver program would turn a profit of $94,433.
But money was not the only consideration. Transplant centers project a cutting-edge image and are important for attracting doctors and patients. And half of Iowans needing liver transplants go out of state.
As for Dr. Martin, she says her motivation is simple: treating patients close to home.
"If you can supply a service to a community that is cost-effective, with the same results, why send these people miles away?" she said.
But across the state in Iowa City, Dr. Hunsicker of the University of Iowa questions whether results would really be the same. Medical research shows patients fare best in centers that perform at least 20 transplants a year, he said, adding that the number of transplants in Iowa is now limited by the number of usable donated organs, about 40 a year.
"So if we had two programs," Dr. Hunsicker said, "and we split evenly, then we would both be at the very lowest end of the numbers necessary to maintain competence."
So doctors and researchers are looking for a way out of the organ crunch. Several hospitals, including the University of Iowa's, are experimenting with "living donor" transplants, which involve using part of a healthy adult's liver. (The liver has a remarkable capacity to regenerate.) And several companies are trying to develop pig livers for transplant use. Dr. Martin says Iowa Methodist is positioning itself to take advantage of these procedures.
That the hospital is laying its plans against the backdrop of the Clinton administration's proposed changes does not seem to faze her, perhaps because the national dispute shows no signs of a quick resolution. On Dec. 17, President Clinton signed a bill that in theory could put the new rule into effect by mid-March. But that is unlikely, because Congress plans to reopen the issue as part of a bill reauthorizing the National Organ Transplant Act, the 1984 law establishing the organ donor network. The House is considering legislation to revoke Dr. Shalala's authority.
Now Dr. Martin is readying herself for her next battleground: Boston. She is eager to get back in the operating room, she said, and in typical take-no-prisoners fashion, she laid out plans to wrest back some business from Dr. Roger Jenkins, the surgeon who left Beth Israel Deaconness for the Lahey Clinic. Already, Dr. Martin said, she has entered into a partnership with a hepatologist who refers some business to Dr. Jenkins.
"It is going to be," she predicted, "an interesting year."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Weighs Tax Increase On Gasoline Despite Big Surplus

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
New Jersey's treasury has been fattened by so much unexpected money this year that it may surprise many taxpayers that state officials are considering an increase in the gasoline tax.
Like other states basking in the nation's continuing economic boom, New Jersey reported a record budget surplus this fiscal year -- $782 million -- as steady increases in business profits and personal income swelled incoming revenues. The national settlement with tobacco companies will bestow an additional $7 billion windfall on the state, to be paid over 25 years. 
 Yet when New Jersey officials are not boasting about the robust economy, many -- including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Jack Collins, the speaker of the Assembly -- acknowledge that the state is considering an increase in its 10.5-cent-per-gallon tax on gasoline early next year to pay for several costly plans.
A plan to rebuild many of the state's aging public schools is expected to cost up to $10 billion. Governor Whitman has pledged to use most of the tobacco settlement money for health care and has proposed a $100 million plan to help provide insurance to 125,000 low- and moderate-income families. A property tax rebate program enacted last year will return $200 million more to taxpayers.
In addition, state officials must devise a way to replenish New Jersey's Transportation Trust Fund, which was established 15 years ago to finance construction of roads and bridges. After relying heavily on borrowing during the administrations of Governor Whitman and her predecessor, Jim Florio, the fund is now essentially broke.
Last November, voters approved a $450 million bond issue to tide the fund over until June. But with New Jersey roadways among the country's busiest, state leaders are under growing pressure to find a long-term money source for the program in the next several months.
Among major state officials, only the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, has contended that New Jersey can pay for its transportation fund, school construction and tax rebate programs while ruling out a gas tax increase. Mr. DiFrancesco recently proposed a four-year, $4 billion transportation plan that would restore the fund without touching the gasoline tax.
But some New Jersey officials and Wall Street analysts say that Mr. DiFrancesco's proposal calls for the state to shift money out of the general operating fund, and would require politically unpalatable steps like layoffs, cuts in services or a surge in borrowing.
Mr. Collins, the Assembly speaker, said recently that he saw few fiscally responsible alternatives to a gasoline tax increase. And Governor Whitman, whose attempt to increase the gasoline tax in 1998 was rejected by the Legislature, said she might support an increase this time if the legislators proposed it.
"We all try to look for other ways, other than raising taxes," Governor Whitman said early this month. "It certainly wasn't my favorite thing to do. But certainly a gasoline tax has been how we've funded the Transportation Trust Fund before."
New Jersey's current gasoline tax is one of the lowest in the nation, even with the additional state fees that raise its level to 14 cents per gallon, according to the American Petroleum Institute. New York charges 30.4 cents, and Connecticut levies 35.1 cents. The federal government also adds an 18.4-cent tax to each gallon of gasoline.
Still, it is not surprising that elected officials are moving cautiously, given New Jersey voters' angry reactions to recent tax increases. In 1990, Governor Florio, a Democrat, pushed through a $2.8 billion income tax increase to help the state comply with a court ruling on school financing. The plan so angered voters that Democrats lost control of both houses of the Legislature and Mr. Florio was denied a second term in 1993.
Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, defeated Mr. Florio by promising to cut income taxes by 30 percent, and boasts that she followed through on that plan. But despite the Governor's frequent reminders that she has reduced taxes 34 times, New Jersey property taxes are among the nation's highest and many public opinion polls list taxes as a top concern.
"There wouldn't be a need for any tax increase if the governor and legislators hadn't overextended themselves," said John Sheridan, director of New Jersey Citizens for Tax Reform. "The whole problem is there has been no cuts in spending."
But others say that since the transportation system is crucial to the state's economy, it makes good fiscal sense to shore up its financing while times are good. Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, began the transportation fund in 1984 and said it was intended to operate on a pay-as-you-go basis. His successors, Governors Florio and Whitman, have borrowed to finance many transportation projects, and the fund is now $4 billion in debt.
The fund takes in about $480 million a year in taxes, tolls and vehicle registration fees, $360 million of which comes from the gasoline tax. It was authorized to spend $900 million this year, including $157 million on building roads and rail lines and $367 million on debt service.
Many state officials say a gas tax can help the fund move back toward a pay-as-you-go approach and reduce its high debt costs. The governor has said that a gas tax is one of the least objectionable ways to raise money for roads because it is levied on people who use the transportation system and produces a tangible benefit. Mr. Collins, who has stopped short of saying he will definitely support a gas tax increase, said another advantage was that about a third of the gasoline sold in New Jersey was bought by nonresidents.
Mr. DiFrancesco's alternative proposal calls for diverting taxes now collected on auto sales and wholesale fuel products, money that now goes into the general spending fund. But even his fellow Republicans say that Mr. DiFrancesco, who would like to succeed Mrs. Whitman as governor, will have to offer specific spending cuts to sell the program to legislators, the public and Wall Street analysts who rate New Jersey's bonds.
Richard H. Bagger, a Republican who is chairman of the Assembly appropriations committee, said he would not support any more borrowing for the trust fund, and would wait until Mr. DiFrancesco released more details on his proposal before deciding whether a gasoline tax increase could be avoided. If the increase is unavoidable, Mr. Bagger said, voters can be convinced that it is sound policy. "If people see what they're getting for their money -- better roads -- I think the public can accept that," he said.

HEADLINE: In Manhattan, a Battle Over Nine Acres w/Rvr Vu

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
It is a developer's dream: nine acres along a prime stretch of the East River, just south of the United Nations, the kind of property that rarely comes on the market anymore in this real estate crazed city.
Now, the Consolidated Edison Company is selling the site, which includes a 99-year-old steam-generated power plant, one of the last vestiges of Manhattan's industrial past. Two developers are locked in a last-minute battle for the chance to demolish a power plant on the property and build up to five million square feet of luxury apartment towers and office buildings. The price tag? A half-billion dollars. 
 The property is more than twice the size of the Columbus Circle development site at the southwest corner of Central Park, which was sold last year for $345 million, but it is smaller than the historic 12-acre Rockefeller Center complex. In a city where the skyline is writ larger every year, the sale of such a rare piece of land has already drawn the intense interest not only of developers, but also of their inevitable combatants, community preservation advocates.
"It's probably the most important parcel left in New York City," said Stephen M. Ross, the chairman of Related Companies, which is developing the Columbus Circle site but lost out in the bidding for the Con Ed parcels. "And it should have a master plan for development. The biggest problem in New York today is that there's nothing else around."
Con Ed executives said that the company had not picked a buyer for the four parcels along First Avenue, between 35th and 41st Streets, that compose the nine acres. Real estate executives, however, said that the Fisher real estate family, and its partners -- Sheldon Solow, a developer, and the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter investment bank -- appeared on Monday to be the winners of the hotly contested, 14-month-long auction for the site. But yesterday morning, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the chairman of Boston Properties, and his partners -- the developers Leonard Litwin and Donald Zucker -- unexpectedly made a slightly better offer, setting off other another tense round of negotiating.
"We don't have a winner yet," said Robert P. Stelben, the treasurer of Con Ed, who oversaw the auction. "We'll be talking a little later this week and be able to tell you what's going on. Anything other than that is premature."
Whichever developer wins, the deal will have to be approved by Con Ed's board of directors. It will also take another month or two to negotiate the final details of a contract.
But once a developer is selected, the project faces myriad obstacles before the first spade can go in the ground.
For one, Con Ed has to obtain approval from the Public Service Commission to demolish the huge Waterside Steam Plant, which sits on the largest of the four parcels, between 38th and 40th Streets, at the East River. To do that, the company has to enhance the steam-generating capacity at its 14th Street plant, a process that could take three years. The renovated plant is to have a larger generating capacity than the two current plants together.
At the same time, the properties must go though the city's always contentious land use review process and an environmental review before residential and commercial development is allowed in the existing manufacturing site. One unknown is the extent of environmental problems, possibly including asbestos removal, that might emerge with the demolition of the power plant.
Several bidders said that Joseph P. Rose, chairman of the city's Planning Department, had indicated to them in private meetings that the city would ultimately permit towers of up to 45 or 50 stories for a development that is required to include green space and an esplanade.
"Rose's implicit statement was: No Donald Trumps," one bidder said, in a reference to that developer's planned 72-story residential tower at First Avenue and 48th Street, which provoked protests because it will loom 300 feet over the United Nations.
The three parcels are not contiguous: two blocks of residential towers separate the riverfront properties.
Although many local residents might be glad to see the smokestacks at the Waterside plant disappear, they do not want to see them replaced by a forest of tall towers that would overwhelm the United Nations or the nearby apartment houses at Tudor City. In the last decade, soaring residential towers have sprouted nearby on the sites of former warehouses, factories and bottling plants.
This fall, the East Midtown Coalition for Sensible Development, which includes thousands of condominium and cooperative owners in the neighborhoods of Turtle Bay and Murray Hill, sought unsuccessfully to persuade Con Ed to halt the land sale until the company could devise a design acceptable to the group. Since then they have been joined by the Municipal Art Society and the Natural Resources Defense Council, and the groups have vowed to intervene with both the city review process and the Public Service Commission.
"We have an opportunity to do something at the level of Battery Park City in terms of urban design, architecture and waterfront access," said Richard Kahn, an urban planner and a leader of the coalition. "These opportunities come up once in a generation. We look forward to working a development team that shares those objectives."
Some of those concerned about Con Ed's plans are veterans of the battle against Riverwalk, a proposed development along the East River near Stuyvesant Town, which succumbed in the early 90's after a decade of community opposition, lawsuits and a downturn in the economy.
"We feel it's better, safer and quicker to start dealing with the community early on," said Edward Rubin, a longtime member of Community Board 6, which includes the Con Ed property. "All large projects in this town inevitably end up in a lawsuit that could drag on for 10 years. That's destructive. If we could work together, it could go quicker."
The Fisher family has built about 10 million square feet of office space, most of it in Manhattan, and owns a string of hotels, while Mr. Solow has built both commercial and residential buildings on the East Side. The Fishers' construction company is building a headquarters for Random House on Broadway at 55th Street.
Mr. Zuckerman's company, a real estate investment trust, owns 132 commercial properties totaling 35.3 million square feet in New York, Boston, Washington and San Francisco. Early next year, Boston Properties will start building an office tower in Times Square for Ernst & Young, the accounting firm. Mr. Zuckerman's partners have built apartment houses up and down Manhattan avenues.
The land sale is part of Con Ed's state-mandated transformation from a regulated monopoly to a company that transmits and distributes electric power and gas provided by other companies. Earlier this year, the company sold three New York City power plants for $550 million, and announced plans to acquire Northeast Utilities in a $3.3 billion deal that would make it one of the largest utilities in the country.
Con Ed and its adviser, Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage, first offered for sale three parcels along First Avenue. More than a year ago, they added the Waterside plant to the mix.
With three of the four properties facing the East River, the auction process drew dozens of developers, including Mr. Ross, Jerry I. Speyer, George Klein and the Pritzker family, before Con Ed selected the two finalists. Large construction sites are so rare today that developers are afraid of being caught without any land to develop.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Dolan Seen as Winning As Jet Bidding Heats Up

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS and MIKE FREEMAN 

 BODY:
The bidding for the Jets isn't over, but Charles Dolan is expected to be announced in the next couple of weeks as the new owner of the team, a person with knowledge of the negotiations said yesterday. Dolan, whose Cablevision owns two basketball teams and a hockey team, is so eager to acquire the Jets that he has agreed to pay $615 million, the person said.
Dolan's bid exceeds the current offer of $600 million by Robert Wood Johnson IV. However, another person involved in the negotiations said last night that Johnson would submit a revised bid today that would exceed $600 million. 
 Earlier yesterday, National Football League officials said there was a chance that Johnson would outbid Dolan, but not a very likely one.
The $615 million price, one expert on the purchase of sports teams said, is an enormous one to pay for a team that until this year was a perennial loser financially. The Jets have projected a profit of about $11.5 million this year.
The person with knowledge of the negotiations said it seemed apparent as the sale proceeded that the strategy of Goldman, Sachs, the investment-banking concern conducting the sale, was to use the interest of Johnson -- who is an heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune -- as a way to induce Dolan to raise his bid. That strategy may still be at work in Johnson's new bid today.
Dolan, 73, who unsuccessfully bid for the Washington Redskins and expansion Cleveland Browns, has had to deal with another hurdle in his quest of owning an N.F.L. team. Although the league said this month that its finance committee would wait until the estate of Leon Hess, the late owner, made its decision on a buyer before reviewing the prospective owner, league officials have already been dealing with the ownership issue that Dolan would present.
The N.F.L. bars corporate ownership of its teams because of the concern that a large corporation would have endless economic resources with which to operate. Dolan is buying the team as an individual, but the league wants to put controls in place that would ensure that his ownership of the Jets remains separate from Cablevision. One person described those talks as being difficult.
As chairman of Cablevision, Dolan has a stable of teams that include the Knicks, the Rangers and the Liberty of the Women's National Basketball Association and other enterprises that include Madison Square Garden and the MSG cable network. Dolan has also been negotiating to buy the Mets. An announcement about the baseball team had been expected by the end of the year, but nothing has been forthcoming.
If Dolan takes over the Jets, he is expected to try to increase the team's revenue by getting a new stadium. The Jets' lease at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., runs through 2008 and severely limits the Jets' income. Although some people believe Dolan would like to return the Jets to New York, one friend said yesterday that he would be happy to have the team play anywhere in the metropolitan region where he could obtain a new stadium.
Dolan, in the estimation of league officials, is also expected to be a hands-off owner in the manner of Hess. Thus, as Bill Parcells continues to weigh his decision on whether to remain as the team's coach and general manager, the fact that he may soon have a new owner unlikely to prowl the sideline may sway him toward remaining at least one more season.
As for when a new Jets owner might be named, N.F.L. owners will gather in New York for a special meeting on Jan. 18, at which time they are expected to address the Jets' situation. It is quite possible they will vote to approve a new owner at the meeting, based on a recommendation from the finance committee.

HEADLINE: Bush Is Loosening His Image In Effort to Counter McCain

SERIES: STATE OF THE CAMPAIGN: George W. Bush

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
For George W. Bush, a typical day on the campaign trail used to involve a $1,000-a-head fund-raiser or two, several skin-chafing marathons of hand shaking and a few rote recitations of his maxim-laden stump speech.
But in New Hampshire over the next several weeks, Mr. Bush plans to change all that. He will stage more of the free-wheeling, question-and-answer sessions that have been the strength and staple of Senator John McCain of Arizona, his chief rival for the Republican presidential nomination. 
 Mr. Bush's television commercials will also take on a new look and feel. In addition to the carefully posed, painstakingly produced spots that the Bush campaign has already put on the air, New Hampshire voters will see advertisements that bear the legend "campaign update" and show uninterrupted, straightforward snippets of Mr. Bush engaging the state's voters.
To aides like Mr. Bush's chief media adviser, Mark McKinnon, these newsreel-like, miniature documentaries are intended to affirm "just how hard the governor is working to earn every vote in New Hampshire."
But both of these adjustments seem like unmistakable acknowledgements of the deep trouble Mr. Bush finds himself facing in New Hampshire with the presidential primary just a month away.
Although Mr. Bush remains the overwhelming favorite to win the Republican nomination with tens of millions of dollars just waiting to be spent, he has failed to repel the pesky challenge posed by Mr. McCain, whose campaign is short on money but long on spirit. In fact, even Mr. Bush acknowledges that Mr. McCain is now the front-runner in New Hampshire.
While the moves clearly reflect Mr. McCain's surge in the New Hampshire polls, they also address a wider perception of Mr. Bush as a heavily scripted candidate who became the Republican front-runner by dint of his name and a collective Republican hunch and has yet to subject himself to the kind of sustained, exacting scrutiny that he must.
"We've agreed upon steps that we're putting into place, mid-course corrections," said Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief strategist, speaking in particular of New Hampshire, where some members of the Bush team recently complained publicly about the paucity and formality of Mr. Bush's appearances.
For much of the period since he officially kicked off his campaign in June, Mr. Bush, the Texas governor, was busy canvassing the whole country, raising an unprecedented amount of money and giving himself ample family time and rest. Rare was the weekend when he scheduled a campaign appearance outside of Texas; a typical week put him on the road for no more than three and a half days.
But with only about a month to go before the Iowa caucus and New Hampshire primary jump-start a frenzied nominating process, that, too, is about to change.
"It'll be wall to wall in January," said Ari Fleischer, a campaign spokesman. "And it'll be geographically confined to the following states: Iowa, Iowa, Iowa and Iowa. New Hampshire, New Hampshire, New Hampshire and New Hampshire. And South Carolina, South Carolina and South Carolina."
That is not to say there is anything even remotely resembling a sense of panic among those around Mr. Bush, whose position remains the envy of his five Republican opponents.
In national polls, he continues to trump Mr. McCain by dizzying double-digit margins of more than 40 percentage points. Outside of Arizona, Mr. McCain's home state, and New Hampshire, which Mr. McCain could claim as a second residence at this point, Mr. Bush seems to have a lead in every state with an early contest.
Additionally, his campaign's estimated haul of more than $65 million in contributions means that Mr. Bush has the financial resources to advertise heavily anywhere his lead seems to be slipping. Mr. McCain's tally is less than a third of that sum.
"I have no doubt that Governor Bush will be the nominee of this party," said Ralph Reed, one of his advisers, in a recent interview. "None."
Mr. Rove added that Mr. Bush has an insurance policy that most candidates do not: an army of about 4,000 workers, mostly volunteers, including campaign chairmen and chairwomen not just in many states, but also in many counties, cities and towns.
"What that means is that when the little local Republican club has its meeting, there's a Bush surrogate there, there's Bush material being distributed," Mr. Rove explained. "We have an organization everywhere, and we can deliver a message everywhere."
Yet the adjustments that Mr. Bush's campaign is making suggest an awareness that a few mistakes have been made and a few problems created, that the once-magical spell enveloping his candidacy has been broken and that any residual glimmer of overconfidence could shrink the long odds against an upset victory by Mr. McCain.
A few recent polls contained some encouraging news for Mr. McCain. The surveys showed that while Mr. McCain still trails Mr. Bush by large margins in South Carolina and Michigan, he has collapsed the distance between him and the front-runner considerably. And in Iowa, where Mr. McCain has devoted virtually no time or energy, he nonetheless has double-digit support.
Small wonder, then, that Mr. Bush's advisers said that in both his public remarks in January and in upcoming commercials, Mr. Bush will more boldly underscore the distinctions between him and Mr. McCain, principally by focusing on two areas, taxes and education, where Mr. Bush and his team feel they have put forward more detailed, coherent and innovative proposals than Mr. McCain has.
Mr. McCain's crusade for changes in campaign finance laws has proven popular with independent voters, but Mr. Bush will continue to try to counter that with an effort to persuade Republicans that the McCain plan is flawed and would give Democrats an unfair advantage in elections.
At the same time, Mr. Bush's advisers have, over the past few weeks, begun to acknowledge that Mr. Bush may indeed lose New Hampshire. And they have begun to talk about why that does not matter or why that would be good for Mr. Bush, in that his eventual capture of the Republican nomination would then seem more like a mettle-proving triumph and less like an easy coronation.
But the attention they are poised to pay to New Hampshire indicates that they have by no means ceded the state and that, if they lose it, they want Mr. McCain's victory to be too narrow to give him any real momentum elsewhere.
Mr. Bush and his advisers also seem to see the way they campaign in New Hampshire over the coming weeks as an opportunity to repudiate some of the negative appraisals of Mr. Bush as an overly programmed and excessively cautious candidate, a task that political analysts said could affect how deft a segue Mr. Bush is able to make into the general election.
"The greatest challenge for Governor Bush is justifying the confidence that numerous Republicans and contributors have placed in him," said Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster. "A great many people gave him money and lined up behind him before they knew him that well. He needs to give them some reassurance that their initial judgment is wise."
Indeed, Mr. Bush's tepid performances in debates earlier this month created a palpable sense of unease among some Republican officials and contributed to a gelling image of Mr. Bush in the media as a smug student ill-prepared for the exam he has sauntered into.
"I find it hard to buy the lightweight line, but the Democrats are repeating that mantra, and it's getting play in the press," noted Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist. "He needs to be conscious of it."
Bruce Buchanan, a political scientist at the University of Texas, said that the success of Mr. Bush's candidacy down the road could hinge on whether journalists and other opinion makers keep raising questions about Mr. Bush's gravity and depth and whether that creates qualms among other voters.
"I don't think it's a lead-pipe cinch they will care," Mr. Buchanan said, "but they could take cues from that media emphasis, and then the question is whether he can establish that kind of credibility."
Several of Mr. Bush's advisers dismissed the recurring questions about Mr. Bush's mastery of policy or intellectual dexterity as insider chatter that will seem condescending to most Americans, and Mr. Bush has professed little or no concern about it.
"In the '94 campaign, the same thing happened," Mr. Bush told reporters in Manchester, N.H., a week ago, on a last swing through the state before the holiday break. He was referring to his first, successful race for governor.
"People said he's Daddy's boy and they said he's not smart enough to be governor, he hasn't had the experience," Mr. Bush said. "Look who's standing here as governor of Texas."
Still, his advisers' unbridled elation after the third December debate, in which Mr. Bush appeared much more forceful and confident than in the previous forums, suggested that they were more troubled by criticisms of Mr. Bush than they had let on.
And Mr. Bush's response when Larry King broached the subject in an interview on CNN on Dec. 16 gave the impression that Mr. Bush is just as anxious to put the topic to rest.
Although he often mentions his abhorrence of name-dropping and pretension, intellectual and otherwise, and prides himself on being more of a Texan than a Northeasterner, he invoked the ivy-draped atmospheres of his college and business school when talking to Mr. King about political opponents who questioned his smarts in the past.
"They ignored the fact that I went to Yale and Harvard," Mr. Bush said, neglecting to point out that his last name undoubtedly helped his admission to both places.
Mr. Bush had not previously appeared on Mr. King's CNN program, and his agreement to the interview, along with a last-minute extension of it to a full hour from a half, reflected his campaign's conclusion that Mr. Bush generally did better in one-on-one situations than in group formats, according to one adviser.
But the adviser said Mr. Bush and his aides understood that he must take care to ward off accusations that he was trying to exert too much control over his public showcases.
To that end, Mr. Bush has agreed to at least four more debates in January, even though his campaign had once expected that Mr. Bush would do a total of two debates in December and January combined.
The game has changed since then, and so has Mr. Bush's game plan, although some advisers said that the alterations were inevitable.
"Iowa and New Hampshire have a cherished history of punishing complacent front-runners," Mr. Reed said. "So all this activity conveys the message: I'm working hard, I'm not taking you for granted."
 
AT A GLANCE: The Bush Campaign
 
HEADQUARTERS: Austin, Tex.
STAFF SIZE: 185 full-time paid workers.
TOP CAMPAIGN STAFF: At the head of George W. Bush's campaign is a troika of longtime aides: the campaign manager, Joe Allbaugh, who has never guided a national effort; the chief strategist, Karl Rove, a veteran Republican operative, and the communications director, Karen P. Hughes, who has been Mr. Bush's spokeswoman since his successful race for Texas governor in 1994. The top media strategist is Mark McKinnon, a former Democratic operative who joined Mr. Bush for his 1998 re-election campaign.
CASH ON HAND: Mr. Bush's aides would not release a figure, but the campaign's estimated fund-raising of more than $65 million and its spending through September suggest that he still has tens of millions of dollars.
PROMINENT ADVISERS: Chief foreign policy adviser is Condoleezza Rice, a former provost of Stanford University who was a Russia specialist on the National Security Council under Mr. Bush's father. Chief domestic policy adviser is former Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis. Chief economic adviser is Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Harvard-trained, supply-side economist who worked under Presidents George Bush and Ronald Reagan. Mr. Bush is also close to several other Republican governors, particularly Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, John Engler of Michigan and Marc Racicot of Montana.
BEST MOVES SO FAR: By raising so much money and lining up so many Republican endorsements early in the year, Mr. Bush established himself as the most formidable candidate in the field. And with his catch phrase of "compassionate conservatism," he signaled to Republicans that he was ready to compete with any Democratic nominee for the political center.
WORST MOVES SO FAR: Mr. Bush's absence from two early Republican candidate forums in New Hampshire led to complaints that he was an aloof front-runner, and his limited investment of time in the state may have helped Senator John McCain pull ahead there. Mr. Bush's flubbing of a televised pop quiz on lesser-known international figures gave rise to questions about his preparedness for the presidency.
CHALLENGES AHEAD: Mr. Bush must try to deny Mr. McCain any kind of resounding victory in New Hampshire. And he needs to convince voters that he can think on his feet and speak without resorting to slogans and canned remarks.
 
State of the Campaign
 This is the third in a series of status reports on the campaigns of the top contenders for the Democratic and Republican nominations as they enter the primary season. Next: The McCain campaign.
