HEADLINE: GIULIANI PROCLAIMS SUCCESS ON PLEDGE TO CURB WELFARE

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he had fulfilled the pledge he made 18 months ago to end welfare as New York City knows it by shifting thousands of recipients into work, job training or treatment, and taking away benefits from the rest.
Mr. Giuliani said that all able-bodied welfare recipients without infant children were now either in jobs or taking steps to get them. "Today marks the milestone of replacing the culture of dependency in New York City with the culture of work and employment," he said. 
 But City Council members immediately challenged the mayor's numbers, pointing out that fewer than a quarter of the people he classified as able to work were actually documented as working. For example, he counted as successes recipients who had merely been referred for evaluation for work or other programs.
City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza said that while the mayor was implying that 137,542 people were now working for their benefits, City Hall had stretched the definitions so much that "for thousands upon thousands of them, it simply means they got a letter."
The councilman added, "They've created this tough piece in search of a headline so the mayor can say he fulfilled his promise, and I think it's complete hype."
Keeping his welfare promise is of great importance to Mr. Giuliani, who is the likely Republican candidate for the United States Senate next year. He made the pledge in July 1998, vowing, "By the year 2000, New York will be the first city in the nation, on its own, to end welfare."
The mayor wanted to go beyond the federal government's workfare requirements by moving every recipient who was able to work into jobs or programs intended to prepare them for jobs. And in the last four months, the city's Human Resources Administration has been under intense pressure to meet the mayor's goal as he and the welfare commissioner, Jason A. Turner, defined it: reducing to zero a target population of 48,141 adult recipients considered able to work, or about 15 percent of those on the rolls when the mayor made his pledge.
Yesterday, Mr. Giuliani declared that that goal had been met. "The most important thing is, we have everyone engaged, either in working in the private sector, working in the public sector, in the workfare program or engaged in a process of being evaluated in order to work," he said. "The purpose of this is to make sure that people if they can take care of themselves are given the opportunity to take care of themselves."
Mr. Giuliani demanded more than the federal welfare overhaul of 1996, which set limits on benefits but did not require all adult recipients to work. But in arriving at his target population in July 1998, the mayor discounted the vast majority of recipients -- who now number 630,000, two-thirds of them children. About 52,000 of the adults on the shrinking caseload were exempt by federal law from working, including those over 60, mothers of infants under 3 months and people with AIDS.
Another 66,000 were indefinitely or temporarily incapacitated because of poor health or disabilities, while 123,000 were classified as already working or in "work-related activities," and 41,000 had been cited for missing appointments or failing to follow welfare rules.
By Mr. Turner's count, that left the target population of 48,141 -- people who had not been assigned by the city to any of a variety of programs combining job search, work, education or treatment in what is supposed to simulate a 35-hour work week.
Complicating the task was that people are constantly moving on and off the rolls, Mr. Turner noted.
One of the mayor's main strategies for further shrinking welfare was to transform welfare centers to "job centers" where applicants were turned away and told to seek work or charity instead. But the plan was halted earlier this year when a federal court found that welfare workers had violated the law by denying Medicaid and food stamps to those entitled to them.
Though a higher percentage of people applying for assistance continued to be rejected this year than under previous administrations, tougher procedures also resulted in a sharp drop in recipients classified as temporarily unfit to work for health reasons. That number fell from 39,000 in July 1998 to 6,824 in the week of Aug. 24, 1999, before reaching a plateau of about 7,500.
In late August, with time running out, Mr. Turner by his own count was still 24,000 recipients from the goal. One group of people not counted as available to work by Mr. Turner's definition were those under sanction for missing appointments or breaking other welfare rules, a figure that had risen modestly from 15,704, when the mayor made his pledge, to 17,306 more than a year later.
But in less than four months, between late August and mid-December, as the pressure to reach zero intensified, that number jumped 32 percent, by more than 5,700 people, to 23,000 parents. Also no longer counted were another 34,000 adults cited for failing to follow the rules, but not yet penalized.
Critics of Mr. Giuliani's policies on welfare say that the homeless and the mentally ill are especially vulnerable to sanctions for missing notices or failing to supply documentation. The sanctions include loss of all benefits for adults without children, and loss of a parent's portion of the grant for families. And for the homeless, new policies under legal challenge make those under sanction ineligible for shelter.
Since the city's own figures show an average of only 41,000 recipients in workfare assignments, the critics ask what is being done by the rest of the 137,542 recipients classified by the mayor as "engaged" -- up from 123,254 in July 1998.
Mr. Turner said 32,000 work at private jobs paying too little to disqualify them from aid, and 69,000 are in work-related activities, the rest in treatment or referral stages.
"He's been under the gun," said Liz Krueger, director of the Community Food Resource Center. "You either get them in 35 hours' work, or you get them off welfare. One person at H.R.A. joked to me, 'If we tell you to ride the subways for 35 hours a week and look at the posters, we call them engaged, so the mayor can have his state of the city address and say, 'Eureka, I did it.' "
Asked about the spike in welfare sanctions, Mr. Turner described them as a necessary tool to push people into helpful programs, including new contracted services aimed at training the more disabled and troubled population left on public assistance in a strong economy.
"It's naive to think otherwise," he said, adding that sanctions were bound to increase. "We had 48,000 who were sitting on the sidelines, and by definition could not be subject to being sanctioned, because they were doing nothing."
Mr. Turner said last summer that he was trying to set a "float" -- a number of people who could be discounted -- because they were so new to the system that it was unrealistic to expect them to be evaluated, let alone working.
But by Dec. 17, reviewing his progress with four aides, Mr. Turner said the definitions had been readjusted to eliminate the need for such a category, and a new level of management scrutiny had been applied to the target group, which had been whittled to 304 by Dec. 12.
The pressure became so intense that his staff worked weekends to find and contact the last 72 on the list before Dec. 20. But during those eight days alone, city numbers show, another 169 recipients were also discounted because of new punishments that docked their benefits, usually by a third to half the normal grant.
"It all comes down to creating bureaucratic opportunities for closing cases," said Richard Blum, a lawyer at the Legal Aid Society.

SECTION: Section A; Page 25; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1069 words

HEADLINE: What Happened to the Asian Century?

BYLINE: By Ian Buruma; Ian Buruma, the author of "Anglomania," is writing a book on Chinese dissidents.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Some 15 years before the end of this millennium, the cry went up that the Asians were coming; the Japanese had bought Rockefeller Center, then chunks of Hollywood, and soon they would rule the world.
Politicians, pundits and even novelists rode the bandwagon, explaining why Japan, with the rest of East Asia in tow, was about to conquer the world. Some were panicked, while others were more admiring and wanted us to mimic the Japanese in one way or another. The shrillest critics sounded oddly like extreme nationalists in Japan, who ascribed Japanese success to unique cultural traits and were quite confident that the 21st century would be theirs. 
 The supposedly advantageous Asian traits, or "values," included collective discipline, hard work, ethnic homogeneity, omnipotent bureaucracy, autocratic government, strict morals or Confucian ethics (whatever that meant), and an unshakable belief in national destiny. The main point, in any case, was that Asians, and the Japanese in particular, were on the verge of economic dominance and Westerners, Americans in particular, were soft, lazy, decadent dupes. The West was suffering from too much messy democracy. It needed a swig of bitter Asian medicine.
It all sounds a bit silly now. Michael Crichton's 1992 novel "Rising Sun," in which predatory Japanese conglomerates virtually take over Los Angeles, looks as quaint these days as Sax Rohmer's stories about the demonic Dr. Fu Manchu.
Still, it would be foolish simply to dismiss Asian achievements and potential now that Americans feel richer and many Asians have taken a cold bath. For Asia will have its ups again, just as the West will have its downs. One need only look at Silicon Valley's dependence on expatriate Chinese, Koreans, Japanese and Indians. What they can do in California, they could surely do at home, if only they got half a chance.
And therein lies the rub. Will they get the chance? That is the question we must answer if we are to speculate about Asian success in the next hundred years. The idea of an Asian century is in itself absurd. "Asia" is too big, too vague and too diverse to serve as a useful concept. Only Singaporeans and Malaysians like to refer to themselves as "Asians," and that is because they are not sure how else to describe themselves.
In all likelihood, parts of Asia will do very well in the coming century, but not for the reasons boosters, paranoids and nationalists were talking about a decade ago. The formula of state discipline, efficient workers, low wages and an absence of nonsense about independent unions is all very fine in a country that needs to get heavy industries going. But these advantages are less obvious in more sophisticated economies.
Low crime rates, often held up as a mark of Japanese or Singaporean superiority, are obviously a good thing, but perhaps not a necessary condition for economic success in the 21st century. After all, the United States has relatively high crime rates, yet its economy has surged ahead.
Likewise, ethnic homogeneity might appeal to Japanese nationalists, but American and, increasingly, European success depends on precisely the opposite. Even Singapore is now trying to attract foreigners with useful skills.
One thing is certain: For a country, a city or a region to thrive in the age of information technology, its citizens must be flexible, creative, individualistic, cosmopolitan, free and, preferably, conversant in English. And these are just the qualities that East Asian "Confucian" education, with its stress on rote learning and obedience, is set up to discourage, if not actively stamp out.
But not all of Asia lies under the shadow of Confucius, and even those parts that do are loosening up. There are enough people in Asia who think for themselves, and they will thrive wherever they are freest -- that is, in the most democratic, least hidebound parts of Asia. These may sometimes be the very places with high crime rates, much ethnic mixing and slack social discipline: Bombay, not Pyongyang; Bangkok, not Rangoon. Even Tokyo now has a large population of immigrants, and the Japanese are beginning to jaywalk -- a positive sign if ever there was one.
Japan is unlikely to dominate the century, but it will surely continue to dominate Asia well into the next century. Despite its problems, the Japanese economy is still richer, larger and more sophisticated than any other in Asia.
More interesting, as I see it, will be the rise of several cities of great potential, including Jakarta and Manila. These cities have a large number of highly educated, cosmopolitan young people and have recently acquired political liberties that will surely give them a boost. (People forget that only 40 years ago Manila was the most modern Asian city west of Tokyo.)
The most vertiginous rise of all, however, might happen in India, or at least parts of India. Already many commercial transactions initiated in London or New York are in fact being carried out on computers in Bangalore. Once Indian governments unlearn some of the more dogmatic lessons of Fabian socialism imbibed by earlier generations at the London School of Economics, and give young Indians the freedom they need, India could quickly overtake China. And then? Rockefeller Center, perhaps?
That leaves China, the last large Asian country still trying to combine authoritarian government with capitalist enterprise: freedom is to be sacrificed to the promise of collective prosperity. It is, if you like, the test case of those vaunted "Asian values." And I can see it ending in tears.
It is hard to imagine how a nation's economy can keep on growing without freedom of information, without its citizens having the right to question their leaders and without laws that are based on popular consent and that people will obey. Leaders who are above criticism will make terrible mistakes. And laws that are constantly abused will make business impossible.
And yet, anyone who has recently been to Shenzhen, Canton or Shanghai will have seen young Chinese, computer-literate, enterprising, free-spirited and almost frighteningly eager to take on the world. The will and the talent are there. If only China were to follow South Korea, Taiwan, the Philippines, Thailand and, one hopes, Indonesia, then I would raise my glass with confidence and propose a toast to the coming Chinese century.

HEADLINE: Yarmouth Journal;
Indian Affairs Heat Up (Witness the Lobster War)

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: YARMOUTH, Nova Scotia

 BODY:
For Ashton Spinney, who has fished the Bay of Fundy since the early 1960's, the conflict this fall with Mi'kmaq Indians over the lobster catch was "the only time in my lifetime we were at the brink of civil war in my community." At stake is Atlantic Canada's most valuable fish harvest.
In the "Lobster War," the obscenity-laced confrontations on the town wharf here had relatively mild consequences: only one Indian boat sunk and several dozen lobster pots sabotaged. 
 But up north, in Burnt Church, New Brunswick, 2,000 Mi'kmaq lobster pots were vandalized, a prayer tower was burned to the ground, and three Indians were hospitalized after whites rammed their pickup truck. Whites also vandalized three plants that were processing lobster for native fishermen. Indians apparently retaliated by burning an empty house and two pickup trucks owned by whites.
The dispute was set off by a Canadian Supreme Court ruling in September that interpreted a 1760 British treaty to allow the Mi'kmaq tribes of Atlantic Canada to fish for profit year round without license or limit. The turmoil that ensued so startled the court that in November it issued a rare clarification, reimposing federal seasons and licenses on native fishing.
But with Mi'kmaq fishermen vowing to fish out of season this summer, people in this village of white-painted cottages fear that they are only living through an uneasy truce.
This fall's violence may be a harbinger of an increasingly common clash. On one side, Indian tribes, who are growing more assertive, are winning support from urban judges. On the other side, rural non-Indian Canadians are watching familiar geography change hands before their eyes.
The federal government is now reviewing about 280 new Indian land claims and is negotiating 210. By one government estimate, settlement of Indian land claims could cost $140 billion over coming decades. When the process is over, Indian control over land in Canada's 10 provinces may rise from 0.3 percent today to as as much as 10 percent. By comparison, Indians control about 2 percent of the United States.
A judge in Saskatchewan recently awarded the Lac La Ronge tribe a reserve of 1,216 square miles, the largest Indian land settlement in the history of that prairie province. Under an 1876 treaty, the federal government was to set aside 128 acres for each tribe member, 484 people at the time. But with the tribal population now nearing 7,000, it could cost taxpayers as much as $200 million to buy needed land from neighboring white farmers and ranchers.
On Canada's Pacific Coast, in British Columbia, a treaty was drawn up giving the 5,000-member Nisga'a tribe its traditional homeland, 770 square miles, and committing the federal and provincial governments to pay the Nisga'a $380 million, transition costs that fiscally conservative critics call excessive. The province's House of Commons voted to approve the treaty on Dec. 15 after a 42-hour filibuster, the longest in Canadian history.
Noting that overlapping claims by British Columbia's 197 tribes now exceed the size of the province, Diane Francis, a columnist for the newspaper The National Post, attacked the treaty as "a hideous giveaway," adding that many tribes "already get excessive and unjustifiable special entitlements."
In Nova Scotia, Mi'kmaq claims have clouded the opening this winter of the largest economic project in the province's history, a $2.7 billion natural gas development that is to ship 460 million cubic feet of gas a day to New England. But around Canada the sharpest white-Indian clash this year was the Lobster War.
 Here on the tip of Nova Scotia that faces Maine, the 963 holders of lobster licenses pulled around $120 million worth of lobsters from the ocean floor during last year's six-month season, which started at the end of November. The catch has become so lucrative that lobster licenses have jumped in value over the last 30 years from 25 cents to $250,000.
With young men mortgaging their parents' houses to buy licenses, lobstermen felt deeply threatened this fall when the Supreme Court threw open the fishery to all registered Mi'kmaq, a tribe that numbers about 12,000 in Nova Scotia.
"They felt their whole livelihood was at stake," said Tim J. Surette, the regional federal fisheries officer here. Recalling the sight of 600 lobster boats massing in the harbor here, he added, "It was a very dangerous situation."
On the other side of the racial fence, Mi'kmaq elders remember that many white lobstermen got into the business in the 1970's when the provincial government gave them loans for boats. The province did not extend these start-up loans to Indians, saying that they were a federal responsibility.
In addition, Mi'kmaq grew up believing that all fishing resources here are traditionally theirs. Frank Meuse, a chief here, said, "It is a resource that belongs to every Mi'kmaq man, woman and child."
Mike Pictou, one of a handful of Mi'kmaq fishermen to be granted a lobster license recently, agreed, saying: "The resource belongs to us. We shared it for all these years, but somewhere along the line, 'share' became 'take.' "
A lifelong fisherman who openly admits that he fished on the "so-called black market" for years, Mr. Pictou believes that tensions will jump again this summer, when he intends to fish outside a season he says does not apply to Mi'kmaq.
Two months ago, his cousin, James Pictou, sailed to Grand Bank, Newfoundland, to fish crabs out of season. On the night of Oct. 26, four white vigilantes invaded the house where he was staying, took his clothes and other belongings into the street, and burned them.
Recounting the story, Mike Pictou, concluded laconically, "I guess they didn't want him up there."

HEADLINE: The $1.2 Trillion Spigot;
Capital Spending in U.S. Just Keeps On Keeping On

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Exodus Communications Inc., born of the Internet, lost money this year. And last year. And the year before. But it is spending hundreds of millions of dollars anyway on new high-technology centers to house and operate the Web sites of hundreds of clients.
Forget about the Year 2000 date switch. Companies like Exodus -- young, profitless, but gambling on a golden future -- help to explain why capital spending has not faltered despite all the fears among experts that business investment would slow in the fourth quarter as corporate America braced for the millennium. 
 The investment slowdown has not happened and is not likely to happen early next year either, even after all the spending to fix the Year 2000 computer problem slows to a crawl. Quite the contrary: The capital spending boom that has lasted for much of the decade appears to have plenty of steam to continue well into the new year, sustaining in the process the nation's robust economic growth of roughly 4 percent a year since 1995.
"If you are a corporate executive, and the economy is strong and labor is scarce and financing is inexpensive, as it is today, what do you do?" asked David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI forecasting unit. "You buy new equipment, or more equipment, and increase output that way and cut production costs in the bargain."
Strong consumer demand, new technology and relatively low interest rates, which reduce the cost of new investment, have all contributed to the investment boom. So has the frequent replacement of office computers with faster and more powerful ones. High on the list of contributing factors is the constant retooling to make new products. Consumers are increasingly willing to pay more for new models or new twists on existing models, and these changes are made more frequently now than in the past.
That is the case at the DaimlerChrysler Group, where model changes now come every five years instead of every six to eight years, and $8 billion in capital spending in 1999 is expected to rise to $9 billion in 2000 in the United States. "Almost all of this is direct spending to develop and make new models," said Wynn Van Bussman, chief corporate economist at DaimlerChrysler. "Computer spending for Y2K is lost in the rounding off of these billions."
Capital spending represents the total cost of all the new factories and office buildings, machinery, software, computers and other equipment that companies acquire to produce their goods and services in this country or to expand and modernize their operations here. Such spending in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported last week, came to $1.2 trillion at an annual rate, or 12.7 percent of the value of the national economy.
That is the highest percentage since the early 1980's, a decade in which businesses around the country revamped operations to meet the challenge of formidable Japanese and European competitors.
In contrast to the 1980's, very little of the $1.2 trillion is being spent on new factories, office buildings and other structures. Most of the investment, $910 billion, has gone for machinery and equipment, particularly computers and software. In the late 1990's, spending in these high-technology sectors has risen faster than any other aspect of capital spending, reaching an annual rate of $247 billion in the third quarter. The rise reflects substantial real gains, but it also flows, in part, from a peculiar way of pricing computers in the official statistics.
If a computer cost $2,000 in 1998 and a more powerful version in 1999 still sells for $2,000, the Commerce Department assigns a value to the extra power, say $500. The computer then enters the government's investment account at $2,500. That sort of bookkeeping, a rough guess that may overestimate the genuine advances in computing, has fattened capital spending in an age of frequent breakthroughs in technology.
The investment boom is easier to see and touch in other industries. Aircraft orders, for example, have more than doubled since 1996 as airline passenger traffic has risen. Electric power shortages that first appeared in the Midwest and Southeast three summers ago have set off a rapid expansion of generating plants fueled by natural gas. The demand for more gas, in turn, has raised investment in that industry.
"The price spikes that accompanied the electricity outages were a signal to step up investment," said Lawrence Makovich, director of electric power research at Cambridge Energy Research Associates. Power companies have increased their investment to $8 billion a year in the United States from $2 billion in 1997. Further, during the last 18 months the industry has announced projects, Mr. Makovich said, that should eventually increase the generation of electricity in this country by more than a quarter.
New technology is a big source of capital spending. The Internet is an eye-catching industry in mid-construction, giving rise to hundreds of start-ups like Exodus, which operates computer networks for companies with Web sites. On Wall Street, investment firms like Merrill Lynch are spending hundreds of millions of dollars for Internet links and online trading. And big telephone and cable companies are rewiring American homes, hoping to provide each with a single new connection that will carry not only voice communication but also cable television, e-mail and high-speed Internet traffic.
"What is driving us is the exploding technology, not the strong economy," Eileen Connolly, a spokeswoman for AT&T, said, though she acknowledged that the two can be hard to separate.
Optimistic investors are also a prod to capital spending. Their enthusiasm finances the expansion plans of companies like Exodus, whose stock price has soared 985 percent this year.
"People are convinced," said Kenneth J. Matheny, a senior economist at Macroeconomic Advisors Inc., "that Internet-based methods of distributing information and products will turn out to be much more profitable than traditional methods."
Exodus, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., with 700 employees, operates at 15 locations around the United States and one in London. The buildings resemble large warehouses from the outside. Inside are the computers, servers and communications gear that store and manipulate Web sites and make them appear on computer screens around the world at the click of a mouse.
Each location cost Exodus about $50 million, and from the start of this year to the end of 2000, the company expects to spend more than $750 million -- most of it next year -- on 15 more locations, the majority to be erected in this country.
That is quite a feat for a company with only about $200 million in revenue this year from 1,700 customers. Making the feat possible are the rising stock market and the optimism of investors who gamble that Exodus will emerge from intense competition as a dominant player and thus a cash cow in a key industry in the new information economy.
"We are well positioned in a market where the demand is outstripping the supply," said Adam Wegner, vice president and general counsel. He says that without the heavy spending on expansion, Exodus would be profitable today. But he also points to a Catch-22: Without the expansion, competitors would push Exodus out of the business of managing Web sites. "The whole name of the game is to expand to supply the growing demand," Mr. Wegner said.
That takes money. Exodus went public in March last year, raising $70 million with an initial public offering at $15 a share. Since then, the stock has split two-for-one three times, and its shares closed yesterday at $86.625 in Nasdaq trading. With that strong performance as backdrop, Exodus has raised $1.52 billion on the bond market, through four high-yield offerings. These are the securities that in the 1980's were called junk bonds, a term now out of fashion even though the high risk is the same.
The last and biggest offering, $1 billion, took place this month, and Exodus now faces $100 million a year in interest payments. That represents a huge chunk of its annual revenue but is a burden made lighter through its soaring stock price.
The expectation that share prices will keep rising has become "a big component of capital investment," said Robert Pollin, an economist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst.
A rising stock market also encourages capital spending among companies that do not need to raise money from the markets. That is because a rising market makes an investment in new equipment automatically worth more as a company's share price rises, effectively raising the resale value of the new equipment.
But if capital investment is rising in many industries, it is notably absent in others. Some oil companies are just beginning to respond to higher petroleum prices, announcing that if prices hold up they will increase spending on exploration and drilling. Excess production capacity inhibits the steel industry and paper and pulp companies, which have shut down older mills. Phelps Dodge, the big copper producer, is holding back, too, even though the demand for copper is strong.
"All the interest that people have in quality of life drives copper demand," said Thomas Foster, vice president and controller at Phelps Dodge. "Telephones in every room, pop the trunk with a button rather than a key -- all these things use copper. But the market can't handle more investment now."
Even a high-technology company like Motorola is cautious, preferring to outsource its production to manufacturers in Taiwan, Singapore and Thailand. "We don't have to pump the capital into expansion," said Scott Stevens, a spokesman for Motorola's semiconductor business, "but we are locking in the available capacity that we need and faster than if we went and built it with our own bricks and mortar."
That is certainly not the mood, however, among the thousands of companies, many of them newly incorporated, that are opening Web sites. iVillage is in this herd, creating an Internet site that offers all sorts of information and shopping leads, of interest mainly to women.
"We are spending between $5 and $8 million a year on capital investment, primarily for computers, servers and communications gear," said Craig Monaghan, chief financial officer at iVillage, which is four years old and has 400 employees.
Even a stock market correction might not inhibit iVillage, although the profitless company pays for capital spending by raising money through share offerings, the most recent last summer.
If its stock price fell sharply, would iVillage cut back on investment? Not right away, Mr. Monaghan said. "We have sufficient cash on hand so that we can fund our operations for a while."

HEADLINE: Board Reports Rise in Index Of Indicators

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators rose last month as stock prices and consumer demand climbed, the Conference Board reported yesterday, indicating that the economic expansion will continue after setting a record in February.
The index grew three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the second consecutive monthly gain and higher than the rise of two-tenths of 1 percent that analysts had expected. The increase comes after a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in October, which had initially been reported as unchanged, and two previous months of stagnant readings. 
 The rising index "points to sustained economic growth in 2000," said Peter Kretzmer, senior economist at Banc of America Securities in New York. While Federal Reserve policy makers will probably raise interest rates further to cool demand, he said, "the momentum heading into the new year remains very significant."
The November increase in the index, a composite of 10 indicators, was the largest since a matching three-tenths of 1 percent gain in July. The index fell in August and stalled in September because of disruptions from a severe hurricane season that included Hurricane Floyd, which closed factories and other businesses along the East Coast.
A jump in stock prices and factory orders for consumer goods accounted for almost all of last month's rise. Higher consumer confidence, expansion of the money supply, an increase in building permits and low numbers of initial claims for state unemployment benefits also contributed.
A shorter factory workweek and a narrower spread between current and future interest rates subtracted from the index, as did a drop in orders for nonmilitary capital goods and a faster rate of vendor deliveries -- a sign of weak demand.
The economic expansion is poised in February to become the longest ever at 107 months -- just short of nine years. It shows no signs of ending "without more evidence of some underlying weakness in economic fundamentals," said Ken Goldstein, a Conference Board economist.
Enthusiastic consumers are behind the expansion. Consumer confidence rose in December to its second-highest level ever, according to Conference Board statistics released on Tuesday. As in yesterday's report, gains in the stock market bolstered optimism.
Demand for goods led manufacturers to raise output a half-percent in November, the 12th consecutive monthly gain, Federal Reserve figures show. Growth abroad also is fueling demand.
The rebound in United States manufacturing as Asian and other economies began to recover from the slowdown that began in 1997 is one reason the economy probably expanded at a 4.7 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, the average in a recent survey of 24 economists. That would put growth for all of 1999 at 4 percent, the third consecutive year of expansion at that rate or higher. The last time that happened was 1976 to 1978.
The November index suggests "there has been no fundamental change in the underlying conditions of the economy over the second half of 1999," Mr. Goldstein said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
German Stock-Sale Plan Stirs Only Limited Opposition

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 29

 BODY:
At first, it seemed unlikely, perhaps even a little preposterous: a tax break that would allow Germany's banking and industrial conglomerates to untangle more than $100 billion worth of cross-shareholdings.
It did not enhance the idea's credibility that it came from a left-of-center government with sometimes frosty relations with business. Or that the government buried it as a footnote in a much larger tax plan, two days before Christmas. 
 Yet now, nearly a week after the proposal was circulated, it appears to have a serious chance of becoming law. If it does, Germany's corporate landscape may never be the same.
"It would pull the carpet out from under Germany Inc.," said Thomas Mayer, senior economist here for Goldman, Sachs. "I think it has a pretty good chance of getting through Parliament."
Under the plan, companies will be allowed to sell their holdings in other companies without paying taxes -- now 50 percent -- on the profits.
If approved, it would eliminate a huge obstacle that has thus far made it prohibitively expensive for financial institutions like Deutsche Bank and the big insurer Allianz A.G. to streamline and reduce their vast portfolios of stock in other German companies.
Analysts say it would free up tens of billions of marks that have been blocked from reinvestment because of tax liability. It could also be expected to accelerate the pace of mergers and acquisitions. German banks and insurers would have new resources for such deals, but would themselves become more vulnerable to hostile takeovers as well.
Yet even though the plan would provide an enormous tax break for big business, it has not yet generated much political opposition. Left-leaning leaders within the governing Social Democratic Party have praised the idea as a way to spur flexibility and new growth in German industry.
Such a change would spur "more growth and employment by creating more efficient corporate structures," said Joachim Poss and Jorg Otto Spiller, two leading Social Democratic members of Parliament, in a joint statement on Tuesday. The move, they added, "lies within the logic" of current tax principles.
Leaders in the Green Party, the junior member in Germany's ruling coalition, were more emphatic in their support. "This gives the economy the push that it needs," said Klaus Muller, a Green member of Parliament who speaks for the party on economic issues. "I am presuming that the governing coalition will stand by it."
The main rumblings of discontent have come from the center-right opposition parties, the Christian Democratic Union and its Bavarian affiliate, the Christian Social Union, which are normally advocates of tax relief and other pro-business policies. But most economists doubt that those parties would block the measure, because doing so would enrage important supporters.
Though German stocks have leveled off after rising 4.46 percent last Thursday, some investors appear euphoric. Indeed, people close to the Finance Ministry say that the government delayed disclosure of its proposal to derail opposition from the Social Democratic Party's left wing.
Social Democrats in Parliament were told nothing about the plan until the stock market began to soar on Thursday. The market's reaction -- sending the benchmark DAX stock index to a record high and lifting some financial issues by more than 15 percent -- made it difficult for opponents to speak out against the idea.
"For the German markets, the German system, this can only be seen as positive news," said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank, the country's fourth largest. Commerzbank, which has a stock portfolio of less than $2 billion, would be only mildly affected by the change. But the changes at other institutions would be potentially much greater. Deutsche Bank's stock portfolio is worth about $22 billion, and its holdings include major stakes in DaimlerChrysler A.G., the bankrupt construction company Philipp Holzmann, Allianz and a number of retailers.
If German financial institutions begin to sell their cross-holdings, they could become more exposed to takeover attempts. Thus far, the big banks have remained aloof from the kind of merger activity that has occurred in France, Italy, Spain and the Netherlands.
Still, Allianz holds 21.6 percent of Dresdner Bank, the country's third largest, and Dresdner in turn owns 10 percent of Allianz. Munich Reinsurance and Allianz each own 25 percent of each other, and both insurers have stakes in scores of industrial companies.
The issue goes beyond banks and insurers. Big utility companies like Veba and manufacturers like Siemens hold shares in far-flung companies, and in the midst of a large-scale shuffling of ownership this would almost certainly increase.
These networks of interlocking holdings have been at the center of postwar corporate Germany, in which banks, insurers and industrial companies supported each other through good times and bad. But the old ties have become too restrictive, dragging down profits at big financial institutions by making it difficult to move money from weak investments to more promising ones.
Political leaders have recognized the problem for years. But the idea of giving big banks and insurers a tax windfall worth billions had been dismissed as unacceptable.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has apparently decided to take on the problem circuitously. He could afford to bury the plan because it does not affect his government's budget. The tax liabilities for big banks are so high that they were not about to sell their holdings, and the government could not include potential revenue in its budget planning.
Mr. Mayer of Goldman, Sachs is increasingly convinced that the plan will get through Parliament, maintaining that the political left has been pre-empted by the reaction from investors and that opposition from the right would infuriate its business supporters.
The proposal has angered the owners of small and medium-size companies -- the "mittelstand" -- which form much of the backbone of German business. Small-business owners complain that the proposal does not help unincorporated companies.
But government officials respond that such companies are free to incorporate and avoid taxes on capital gains if they choose to do so.
"If that stands up," Mr. Mayer said, "the most severe criticism of the proposal will have been deflated."

HEADLINE: The Boy, 6, From Cuba: So Missed

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: CARDENAS, Cuba, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Elian Gonzalez is everywhere and nowhere on the streets of his hometown. As if summoning a phantom, his neighbors point to the narrow sidewalks where he used to scamper about with his friends or to the rooftop where they often saw him flying his kite. They cling to his memory almost as dearly as Elian himself held on to the inner tube he was strapped to when a boat carrying him, his mother and several other Cubans capsized as they tried to flee to Florida last month.
"I never had children, I am too old," said Diria Rosa Ojeda, 60, a neighbor. "But the child I never had, I see in him." 
 For more than a month, the 6-year-old boy has been at the center of an international tug of war and hearts that has roiled Cubans on both sides of the Florida Straits as they await the decision of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which is to hold a hearing on the case on Jan. 21.
Since his mother and most of the other would-be refugees died on the journey, Elian was taken in by his father's relatives in Miami, who want him to stay with them for a chance at a better life. But his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and both sets of grandparents are very much alive here in Cardenas and want the child returned, a demand that has been echoed by thousands of Cubans in rallies throughout the island organized by the government.
As with other issues and people caught in the limbo of United States and Cuban relations, the case has been enmeshed in exile intrigue and international policy. Like the homages to Che Guevara and President Fidel Castro, a snapshot of Elian, his hand touching his chin in a pensive moment, has become an icon here, put on T-shirts, billboards and posters. In Cardenas, where the houses are as worn and weary as the people inside, his neighbors hold a vigil that is more personal than political.
"The people have no lives here," said Giralda Diaz, 70, a neighbor who stood in a friend's doorway across the street from Mr. Gonzalez's house. "We do not work. We spend the day waiting for a car to stop in front. People are sad. If you had a child, you would feel it in your spirit. It is not humane."
Elian's parents had divorced, but neighbors said the parting was amicable.
They said the boy lacked for nothing because the parents, whom they described as devoted to him, held tourism jobs, which gave them access to dollars and, more important, life's elusive daily necessities.
More often than not, the neighbors saw Elian at his father's house, spending the night when his mother had to work late or awaken early because of her maid's job at a hotel in the nearby resort town of Varadero. The father would often take him to a restaurant and resort complex where he worked, or treat him to outings and toys.
"He was obsessed with that child," said Isabel Alarcon. "Everything he wanted, he got."
So it was all the more shocking when they learned that Elian's mother had spirited him away when she left Cuba. The neighbors can only believe that she had fallen under the sway of her new husband, who organized the failed escape. Among themselves, they talk about how the mother must have known that the boat was not seaworthy.
"I do not know how that woman was crazy enough to follow that man," said Elsa Diaz Vidal. "She took the boy because of him. She had no one over there to go to. Then she died in that horrible sea."
As the oldest residents on the block, Hilario Sanchez Menendez, 88, and his wife, Ramona, 80, feel a special kinship with the Gonzalez clan, remembering when they used to cradle Juan Miguel in their arms. On days when they did not pass by for a chat or a cup of coffee, Juan Miguel would pass by their home to make sure everything was all right. Mr. Sanchez Menendez said that his mood brightened recently when he was at the Gonzalez home when Elian called.
"When are you coming here?" he asked Elian." 'I will be there in a few days when my vacation is over,' " he said the boy replied. "Then he started crying."
Tears are shed inside Mr. Gonzalez's home, too. The neighbors said they often saw him sitting depressed in his living room, where pictures of Elian outnumber those of Mr. Castro and Che. In the last few days, they have not seen him in the neighborhood. The man they described as a hard worker for his son had become barely able to summon the strength to go to work.
"When I moved here, he was born," Ms. Ojeda said of Mr. Gonzalez. "Now he is an old man because of this. He is in a lot of pain. He is suffering. His co-workers come by and say, 'Let's go to the hotel.' He feels bad, because the hotel is by the sea. He sees that and is traumatized again."
The neighbors say they cannot understand why Elian's relatives in Miami are so intent on keeping the boy, and they dismiss any suggestion that he could have a better life there. At home, they said, despite the country's economic hardships, he had free schooling and health care and the chance to be with the people he has known all his life.
"What better opportunity does he have being raised among strangers?" Ms. Alarcon said. "How many other children from other countries have to go back? Why not Elian? Because he is Cuban? Be we poor or rich, whatever we are, we have the right to have our child next to us."
So, too, do his grandparents on both sides. It was not that long ago that the grandparents or the father would pick up Elian at the Marcelo Salado Primary School, where his desk now sits empty as his classmates await his return. It is a homecoming, Cuban officials have promised, that would be without any fanfare or public celebrations.
"That would only affect him even more," said Maribel Casas Reyes, the school's director. "We are struggling to have him in a happy situation, not to bruise his emotions more. If we did that, it would be worse than what he experienced in the United States."
The students, in T-shirts that proclaim "We Will Save Elian," sing songs and recite poems for him each day, while others have drawn pictures that are on exhibit at the town's museum, along with photographs of Elian in Miami under the heading "The Child They Kidnapped."
In one classroom, a banner declaring "Happy Birthday Elian" still hangs, a reminder of the day this month when Mr. Castro himself visited the school. To commemorate the occasion, he signed a guest book with the inscription, "For Elian's Liberty, Motherland or Death."
The slogan has been a familiar refrain at the many rallies held in recent weeks. At one at the University of Havana, students recited poetry and read essays about how Elian should return to the island where he has his family, his flag and his comandante, and how the only things he would learn about in the United States were drugs and violence.
Many praised Mr. Castro while denouncing American imperialism as well as the gifts and attention bestowed on the boy by Miami's exile community.
The events calling for Elian's return have begun to annoy some Cubans, who agree that the boy needs to be with his father but have nonetheless tired of turning on their radios or televisions only to encounter yet another rally with revolutionary songs or demonic caricatures of exile politicians.
Recent rallies have been smaller than the earlier ones that brought the city -- and workplaces -- to a standstill. The feeling in some quarters has been that the government seized on the public's sympathy with the custody issue to bolster political enthusiasm at home.
"People are fed up with this," said one Havana resident who declined to give her name. "I think there has to be something deeper politically."
And the strong words uttered by the youngest demonstrators have led some critics to accuse the Cuban government of politicizing the case just as much as the exile community has.
"What would happen if a child stood outside and shouted 'Down with Fidel'?" said another Havana resident. "They would detain his family because someone taught him that. Here, they put 5- and 6-year-old children at rallies making political statements about North American policy. They say that Miami is playing with the child? Here they are playing with him too."
Beyond the talk of toys and politics remains a motherless child with a father who wants him back. On his street in Cardenas, it is a constant refrain. No plaything or great-uncle in Miami, they said, could ever replace his father.
"All you need is a little humanity," said Maria Alian Scott, a teenage neighbor. "To see how that father suffers for his son while he is not returned to him. And that boy has had the trauma of seeing his mother die in front of him. What better psychiatrist than his father? What better hospital than his home?"

HEADLINE: Little-Known Provision in U.A.W. Contract Gives Election Day Holiday

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 29

 BODY:
Election Day will be a paid holiday for 400,000 unionized auto workers under a contract clause that union leaders hope will increase labor's influence and that Republicans call a corporate sellout.
Republican leaders fear that more union workers, who tend to vote Democratic, will go to the polls and that activists from the United Auto Workers union will use their day off to urge nonunion Democrats to vote. Republicans are particularly concerned because the bulk of the workers are in Michigan and Ohio, two big states that have played pivotal roles in recent presidential elections. 
 Republican Party officials are angered at their traditional corporate allies at General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler, the companies that agreed to the contracts.
"That will be the biggest corporate contribution in American political history," Gov. John Engler of Michigan said in an interview, "because the corporations will be paying the wages and the U.A.W. will be using the manpower to attempt to defeat Republican candidates."
The combined daily payroll of G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler for the auto workers is about $100 million.
Stephen P. Yokich, the union's president, said that the union's goal was not to elect more Democrats, but rather to elect more candidates who advocated issues important to workers. By increasing labor's importance on Election Day, the union hopes to give candidates an incentive to take stances more sympathetic to the unions, he said in an interview.
"It isn't the party that matters, it matters what they do for us and where they stand on issues," Mr. Yokich said, adding that, "If I were a candidate, I'd be talking not about free trade but about fair trade."
The auto workers union was a leader of peaceful protests at the recent World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle and outspokenly opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement. Tens of thousands of auto parts manufacturing jobs have gone to Mexico and other low-wage countries even while assembly plants have tended to stay here.
Union members will be asked to go to the polls on Election Day, and not just treat it as an extra day of vacation, Mr. Yokich said, adding, "It's not a holiday; it's a day to show you're a good American citizen."
Mr. Engler predicted that candidates would address some of the union's concerns, although he said Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, whom he has endorsed for the Republican presidential nomination, continued to support free trade in general.
"There are a lot of openings for Bush to speak to some of the issues the U.A.W. is talking about, and be pro-fair trade as well as free trade," he said.
Mr. Engler said he doubted that the automakers had thought carefully about the political implications of their Election Day concession, including the risk that Democrats elected with union support to state offices might favor laws that could prove burdensome to employers.
An auto executive, who insisted on anonymity, said the political consequences were not a major concern of the companies in contract negotiations this fall. The automakers, he said, were more concerned about the risk of absenteeism on the Monday before Election Day and preferred to give workers an extra Monday or Friday off, but the union insisted on Election Day. Workers will have only three days off on the Fourth of July weekend rather than four, but most factories are closed that week anyway to retool for new models.
With factories running day and night to meet record demand, the automakers agreed to almost all of the union's demands this year, fearing a strike otherwise.
For two decades, the auto workers union was in a poor position to demand new concessions for the domestic automakers, which were struggling for survival. But that changed this year, as a strong economy produced record sales for the automakers and allowed the union to win many demands, including annual wage increases exceeding the inflation rate by 3 percent.
The auto workers union has consistently supported Democrats for president but has endorsed some Republicans in other elections. Surprisingly little is known about the voting habits of the auto workers, who tend to be lumped in with other union workers in polls.
Mr. Yokich said the union's own polling showed that members were somewhat more likely to vote Democratic than Republican. Yet many of the so-called Reagan Democrats of the 1980's -- Midwestern union members who began voting Republican -- were auto workers.
A 1995 study by the Bureau of National Affairs, a research and publishing group in Washington, found that only 6 percent of the nation's unionized workers had half or all of the day off on Election Day. Lane Windham, a spokeswoman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said it was still rare for workers to get part of the day off on Election Day and even rarer to have the entire day off.
Pollsters and Mr. Engler agreed that the biggest effect from the holiday would lie not in increased voting by union members but in greater political activity by union advocates, who will be able to drive voters to polling booths and staff telephone banks.
"It may give them manpower to get out the vote, not necessarily of union members but in heavily Democratic areas," said Robert M. Teeter, a pollster in Ann Arbor, Mich., who was chairman of President George Bush's 1992 re-election campaign.
"There may be 400,000 who have the day off, but more important is that 5,000 will be able to work all day," added Mr. Teeter, who is not affiliated with a presidential campaign this year.
But Curtis Gans, the director of the nonpartisan Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, said that giving union workers the day off might actually depress their turnout slightly on Election Day, by preventing the union from urging them at their workplaces to vote.
Mr. Engler said that while he had been discussing the union's contract provision with Mr. Bush's campaign strategists, he did not believe that its effects would be limited to the presidential campaign. Giving auto workers the day off will also affect next year's Senate race in Michigan, in which Senator Spencer Abraham, a Republican, faces a tough race for a second term, Mr. Engler said.
Closely matched Senate and governors' races in Missouri, where the auto workers union also has tens of thousands of members, will be influenced by the labor contract provision too, Mr. Engler added.
Buried in the union's inch-thick contracts with each of the automakers, the provision escaped most public notice.
While the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has already endorsed Vice President Al Gore, the auto workers opposed the early choice. Mr. Yokich said the union's executive committee would meet in the first week of February to discuss endorsements and was likely to choose candidates in the Democratic and Republican presidential primaries. No decision has been made on whether to endorse a Reform Party candidate, he added.
G.M. and Ford officials declined to comment on the provision, while DaimlerChrysler is closed this week, and seven officials did not return calls to their homes and offices. The union negotiated its contract first with DaimlerChrysler, including the Election Day provision, and then demanded that G.M. and Ford accept identical terms.
The contracts, which run through September 2003, also call for Election Day in 2002 to be a paid holiday.
G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler are the world's three largest companies in sales.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
Deciding to Give in Season of Getting

BYLINE: By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
At a time of year when parties are on many people's minds, at least one New York couple thought of New York's neediest when they gave a holiday bash.
Vicky and Dominic Picca invited 37 friends and relatives to their Tudor City apartment for a party on Dec. 4, asking each guest to contribute $25. Their "Party with a Purpose" raised $930. 
 Mr. Picca, 33, said he and his wife, who are both lawyers, wanted to make a difference this holiday season.
"We don't have children yet," he said. "My view is the holiday season is a time for children, and you give gifts to children. We decided to give the money we would have been giving in the form of gifts to charity."
As for why the amount of money raised is not divisible by 25, Mr. Picca said some of his guests went above and beyond the call of duty. "A couple of guys have a sense of humor," he said. "And they said, 'Here, here's $26.' "
Ellen Lubell, a spokeswoman for the Children's Aid Society, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, said the $930 could provide eyeglasses for 10 children, or pay for a child to go to camp for a whole summer. It could provide a year's worth of after-school activities for two children, support the society's free dental van for two days or provide two to three children with full dental and medical care for a year.
As of yesterday, 4,178 contributors had sent in donations as large as $30,000 and as small as $5, for a total of $3,428,006.94, only slightly ahead of the total raised at this time last year, even as the stock market and other economic indexes are setting records month after month.
Like the Piccas, Alison Jones of San Francisco donated to the Neediest Cases Fund for the first time this year. "I hope that this begins an annual tradition for me," she wrote with her $100 contribution. "Your organization takes the fear and uncertainty out of giving."
Because The Times pays the fund's administrative costs, every dollar donated goes to help those in need.
While some donors gave for the first time this year, others, like Janice Gorn of Greenwich Village, donate year after year. Ms. Gorn has donated to the fund in honor of her late husband, Staff Sgt. Lion Gorn, every year since his B-17 bomber was shot down in World War II on Nov. 29, 1943.
Other donors also have quite specific reasons for contributing, like Sally and Alan Epstein of Rye, N.Y., who donate each year in honor of the birthday of their daughter Peggy.
This year they sent $143.
The Epsteins wrote: "$42 of the above is for her 42nd birthday; $1.00 is to grow on; $100 is towards inflation to make the contribution somewhat meaningful."
Inflation is a factor for another donor, Alfred Jaffe of Chapel Hill, N.C., who each year sends a gift based on the number of years he and his wife, Mimi, have been married.
"Each year the gift has been $2 for each year of our marriage," he wrote. "(The $2 was the cost of our marriage license in 1939!) And this being our 60th anniversary, I'm springing for 10 bucks for each year she's put up with me."
Like many donors, J. Allan Pryor of Greenwich, Conn., made a contribution in memory of loved ones. He sent in $365 in honor of his parents, Ernestine and Marvin Pryor.
"Even as the economy flourishes," he wrote, "the needs of the less fortunate are very great -- perhaps greater than ever before."

HEADLINE: NASDAQ ENDS DAY ABOVE 4,000 POINTS FOR THEFIRST TIME

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index, on its way to the best year ever for a major American stock index, closed above 4,000 points for the first time yesterday. The milestone came less than two months after the index first topped 3,000, and was based largely on the strength of the technology stocks that have come to dominate the Nasdaq market.
The index rose 69.35 points, or 1.7 percent, to 4,041.46 and is now up 84.3 percent since the end of 1998. Three stocks in the index have gained more than 1,000 percent this year, with Qualcomm, a leading company in mobile phone technology, surging 2,444 percent since the end of 1998. 
 No broad index of American stocks has ever risen as much in one calendar year as the Nasdaq composite has this year. In only eight previous years did any major index rise by even half as much as the Nasdaq has this year, and in all but one of those cases the market was rebounding after prices had fallen the previous year, usually during a recession.
Conditions now are far different, however. The current economic expansion of more than eight years will soon become the longest in American history. The Nasdaq composite gained at least 20 percent in each of the last four years, and the 1998 gain of 39.6 percent was the third biggest in its history.
Computer and Internet-related stocks have been the strongest components of the index for most of 1999, but biotechnology stocks have come on strong in the last two months. Many other stocks, particularly those in the financial and transportation industries, have lagged far behind these technology leaders.
Many of the largest gains have come in stocks with little or no current earnings, but with expectations that they may flourish in the new Internet-based economy. "Certainly there are a lot of stocks in Nasdaq that are overvalued," said Edward Kerschner, the chief investment strategist at Paine Webber, "but companies like Cisco and Microsoft are growing rapidly and deserve high valuations."
The Nasdaq average's gains have come amid the greatest volatility in the history of the Nasdaq stock market, which dates to 1971. "Five years ago you'd see a 1 percent move every two weeks," said George Cohen, a portfolio manager at Cohen, Klingenstein & Marks, referring to the wide swings in price, mostly up, this year. "Now you see a 1 percent move almost every day." That is only a small exaggeration. So far this year, there have been three such days a week, on average.
The old record for a major American index was set by the Dow Jones industrial average in 1915, at a time when the economy was moving from a recession into a boom caused by demand for industrial products from European countries then fighting World War I, which the United States had not yet entered. Barring a collapse this week, the Nasdaq will finish with a gain well in excess of the 73.9 percent recorded by the Dow that year.
The only other years in which a major United States index rose by more than 50 percent were 1933, when the Dow leaped 66.7 percent, and 1991, when the Nasdaq composite rose by 56.9 percent. There were five other years -- 1904, 1908, 1928, 1935 and 1954 -- when one or more indexes rose at least 40 percent.
While other major indexes also set records yesterday, their 1999 gains do not even approach that of the Nasdaq. The Dow industrials are up 25.1 percent in 1999, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks has gained 19.1 percent and the Russell 2,000 index of small stocks has added 17.8 percent. The record set by the Russell was the first one for that index since April 21, 1998. Many small stocks suffered in 1998, and many of them still have not recovered their losses that year.
The latest rally for the Nasdaq composite has been a relatively narrow one, centered on the computer and other technology stocks that have excited investors. The Nasdaq computer index, which now makes up more than half of the value of the entire Nasdaq index, is up 103.8 percent for the year, and 40.0 percent since the composite index hit 3,000 on Nov. 3. The Nasdaq biotechnology index has done even better recently, leaping 51.6 percent since Nov. 3, to raise its annual gain to 103.7 percent. Of the 200 stocks in the index, 32 have more than doubled since Nov. 3.
The Nasdaq 100 index has outperformed the broader Nasdaq composite of nearly 5,000 stocks and is up 38.1 percent since Nov. 3 and 101 percent for 1999. Among the large stocks that make up the Nasdaq 100, six have doubled since the composite index reached 3,000 points, according to calculations by Bloomberg Financial Markets. In addition to Qualcomm, they are CMGI, a company that invests in Internet companies; Yahoo, a pioneering Internet company, and three software makers, i2 Technologies, BroadVision and Intuit.
While the Nasdaq composite's gain for 1999 is on course to be the best year ever for a widely followed broad index of American stocks, some foreign indexes, as well as narrower ones of American stocks, have done even better. An Internet stock index maintained by TheStreet.Com, for example, is up 186 percent this year, and an index of South Korean stocks is up 100 percent.
Among the largest gains for general American indexes -- those more than 40 percent in a calendar year -- all but one before this year had come following years in which stock prices were hurt by poor economic conditions. The exception was the 48.2 percent gain for the Dow industrials in 1928, following a period in which it had shown gains of at least 20 percent in three of the four previous years. In that case, the strong gains continued until the following September, after which the market crashed.
The big gains of 1904, 1908, 1915, 1954 and 1991 came after the index in question had declined during an economic recession the prior year, with the 1914 drop intensified by nervousness over the possibility of war in Europe. The other two years with big gains -- 1933 and 1935 -- came as the stock market was starting to recover from the historic lows reached in 1932, at the depths of the Great Depression.
In 1915, when the Dow rose 73.9 percent, the index had only 12 stocks. In 1916, the index was enlarged to 20 stocks, including many that had been excellent performers. That new enlarged index, would have risen 81.7 percent had it existed in 1915. That figure has sometimes been cited as the best performance ever for a general American index, but is misleading because the index did not contain those stocks at the time. The Dow was enlarged to its current size of 30 stocks in 1928.
The Nasdaq composite index now has 4,832 stocks, and adds new stocks as companies go public. But the index is weighted according to market capitalization, and the 10 largest companies in it account for more than 40 percent of the index.
Of those 10, through yesterday, 6 outperformed the overall index while the index was rising 33.4 percent from its previous milestone on Nov. 3, led by Qualcomm's gain of 153 percent. But the laggards included three of the best-known companies on Nasdaq. Microsoft rose 28.2 percent and Intel was up 5.2 percent. MCI Worldcom was the only one of the 10 to decline over the period, falling 4.4 percent amid concerns about its planned takeover of Sprint.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Office Pool, 2000

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Whenever another performer adopted his techniques, Jimmy Durante, mock-furious, would expostulate: "Ev'rybody wants ta get inna de act!"
At millennium's end, we are environed by great piles of pompous prognostication. If you wanna get inna de act, you gotta start off each guess wid a smile. 
 1. Next fall's vice-presidential debates will be dominated by (a) Al Gore's Dianne Feinstein; (b) John McCain's Colin Powell; (c) George W. Bush's Richard Lugar; (d) Bill Bradley's Bill Richardson.
2. The most riveting speech of the year will be (a) Bill Clinton's early valedictory in Davos; (b) Lenora Fulani's fiery concession; (c) Hafez al-Assad's "I have returned" speech atop the Golan Heights.
3. The turning point of the G.O.P. nomination will be (a) the unexpected Bush performance in a one-on-one debate with McCain; (b) the breaching of the Bush fire wall in South Carolina by McCain's brigade of veterans; (c) the Michigan tussle that will affect the mood in all-important California.
4. The most unexpected Wall Street development will be (a) the early pricking of the high-tech bubble; (b) the oil-induced rise in inflation followed by higher interest rates; (c) the raising of margin requirements to discourage speculation.
5. The least-expected campaign issue to emerge will involve (a) voter anger at gambling's "slots for tots"; (b) the return of Quemoy and Matsu; (c) the Mary Jo White House indictments; (d) hanky-panky with Russian oligarchs; (e) the backlash against mega-mergers that help snoops and eavesdroppers.
6. New York's U.S. Senate campaign will be decided by (a) an ill-considered Giuliani outburst; (b) non-prosecutable acts described in damning detail in "The Ray Report"; (c) a Gore-Clinton falling-out that cannot be papered over; (d) invasion of the Brooklyn Museum of Art by the brick-bearing homeless.
7. Oscar winner of the year will be (a) "Eyes Wide Shut"; (b) "American Beauty"; (c) "Toy Story 2"; (d) "The Blair Witch Project"; (e) "The Winslow Boy"; (f) "Sixth Sense."
8. Sleeper best-selling book will be (a) Peggy Noonan's severe look at Hillary Clinton; (b) "I, Che Guevara," heart-stopping fiction by the pseudonymous John Blackthorn; (c) "From Dawn to Decadence," Jacques Barzun's stunning five-century study of civilization's cultural retreat; (d) "Behind Closed Doors," Robert Ellis Smith's expose of privacy invasion.
9. The vaunted Internet will (a) bring the world into loving, beeping communication, or (b) become the vehicle for e-larceny, e-terror and e-anarchy; (c) prove that untaxed commerce is a boon to humankind, or (d) provide the tax revenues to redistribute wealth throughout the world; (e) be replaced by the Outernet, a rigorously policed method of thought control throughout the solar system; (f) be devoured by incensed mall rats rebelling against computer hermitism.
10. Clinton, in legacy mode, will (a) personally take the Cuban boy to Havana and thereby re-establish relations with Castro; (b) after learning of new Iraqi weapons, exercise Article 15 of the ABM treaty notifying Russia of our intent to withdraw in six months, opening the way to a U.S. shield against rogue-nation missiles; (c) promise $10 billion in aid to the Syrians, Israelis and Palestinians to obtain a signing ceremony on the White House lawn as a pre-election "October surprise"; (d) replace Alan Greenspan at the Federal Reserve with Robert Rubin.
11. Before the decade ends, (a) the independent nations of Palestine, Kosovo, East Timor and Chechnya will be in the U.N. General Assembly, warning Quebecers to stay in Canada; (b) the Baltic nations will be welcomed into a NATO concerned about Moscow's adventurism; (c) Wei Jingsheng, today's exiled dissident, will after a painful evolution become China's foreign minister, able to make the deal to bring Taiwan home.
My picks: 1(a), 2(c), 3(b), 4(a), 5(c), 6(b), 7(f), 8(c), 9(c), 10(all), 11(c) (so sue me for optimism).
Can pundits read the future? In a sinister voice on old-time radio, the Shadow would ask, "Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men?" And in his TV spotlight, Jimmy Durante would rasp, "Da Nose knows."
