HEADLINE: Anti-Politician McCain Shows Political Skills

SERIES: STATE OF THE CAMPAIGN/John McCain

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29

 BODY:
In wood-paneled V.F.W. halls and drafty high school gymnasiums, Senator John McCain likes to summon audiences to join a "great crusade" to seize government back from the monied interests. Then in the very next breath he strikes a discordant note of fatalism: he talks about defeat.
"I don't know if I'll win this election," Mr. McCain characteristically told a standing-room-only crowd in Burlington, Vt., on a recent blustery Sunday afternoon. "I can't tell you that I'm going to." 
 As the rapt audience listened, he added the clincher that signals he is someone quite different from all the other combatants for the presidency.
"I'm not afraid of losing," he said, "because I know that I'll act on principle if I'm not afraid of losing."
Such sentiments are hardly unfamiliar for a senator known more on Capitol Hill for his passionate embrace of lost causes than for signature accomplishments. But now these quixotic strains are at the very heart of Mr. McCain's insurgent candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination, marking him as the anti-politician, the man of integrity for whom winning isn't all.
In the aftermath of President Clinton's lies about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky and the subsequent impeachment, Mr. McCain and his advisers have calculated that voters are longing for a new quality in their president.
"Every presidential election is a reaction against the incumbent's worst flaw," said Dan Schnur, Mr. McCain's communications director. Or as Mr. McCain recently mused about the mood of the voters, "perhaps they want someone who tells it exactly as he sees it."
That is probably as good an explanation as any for what has happened to Mr. McCain in the past five months. Riding a campaign based on his maverick positions and personality and on his gripping biography as a former prisoner of war in North Vietnam, Mr. McCain has outlasted other more prominent Republicans to become the only realistic challenger to George W. Bush.
The senator's unscripted, free-wheeling style of campaigning through town meetings where he gamely invites "questions, comments, insults," has added to his mystique. He has risen steadily in popularity in New Hampshire, piercing Mr. Bush's aura of inevitability and establishing himself as the current front-runner in the nation's first primary state.
And across the campaign, he has managed to turn the tables so thatdespite his 17 years in Congress, he can stand as the outsider against the governor from Texas whose broad support from party leaders has made him the establishment insider.
The question now as the 2000 presidential campaign approaches a fast-moving series of caucuses and primaries is whether Mr. McCain can really compete beyond New Hampshire against Mr. Bush's formidable organization and a money advantage so overwhelming that the governor has chosen not to accept federal matching funds and the spending limits that go with them.
"When I look at those numbers," Mr. McCain jokes mordantly of Mr. Bush's campaign funds, "I'm reminded of the words of Chairman Mao, who says it's always darkest before its totally black."
To husband his limited resources, Mr. McCain made an early and unconventional decision to skip the Iowa caucuses, the first telling vote of the 2000 race, because they would consume too much money. Instead the Arizona senator put most of his effort into New Hampshire, a gamble that appears to have paid off.
To secure the nomination, Mr. McCain hopes to upset Mr. Bush in New Hampshire and then ride a wave of news media exposure to victory in South Carolina on Feb. 19. Three days later come the Arizona and Michigan primaries. Mr. McCain expects to win his home state, and aides see a long-shot chance of winning Michigan as well, despite Gov. John Engler's endorsement of Mr. Bush.
Should Mr. Bush stumble badly and lose all four states, Mr. McCain's advisers argue that the Texan would be seriously, if not fatally, damaged going into the March 7 primary day when a multitude of states vote, including New York and California. "We'll need to win Michigan to finish Bush off, and he needs to win it to survive," said John Weaver, Mr. McCain's political director.
Still New Hampshire has a history of favoring mavericks, and many Republicans predict that Mr. Bush's formidable campaign war chest and 50-state organization would resurrect him should he lose New Hampshire, barring any significant blunder.
"I don't think McCain can beat Bush unless Bush gives him the opportunity to do so," said Eddie Mahe, a Republican strategist unaligned with any presidential campaign. "There's a heavy component of organization in primaries," Mr. Mahe said. "If you don't have the organizational capacity to get people out to vote, you have a tremendous handicap."
Mr. McCain's advisers counter that his fund-raising has improved with his surge in New Hampshire, making it easier to begin organizing in places Mr. McCain would not have hoped to contest just a few months ago. The campaign announced today that it had taken in $6.1 million since the beginning of October and its fund-raising total would soon reach more than $21 million. That figure includes $6.2 million in federal matching money that becomes available after the New Year as well as $2 million transferred from a Senate campaign account.
In previous election years, that kind of money would have been enough to mount a strong primary campaign. But against Mr. Bush's $63 million, Mr. McCain has had to focus narrowly and intensively on a few states. "The $20 million in 6 states can beat $60 million in 50," said Mike Murphy, a strategist to Mr. McCain.
With money growing, the campaign has now expanded its organizing into Virginia, Michigan and Washington. And it went on the air with a third television commercial this week, showcasing Mr. McCain's pledge to protect Social Security.
Analysts say an important challenge for Mr. McCain, as his poll standings bring him new plausibility and more scrutiny, is to move beyond his biography and start to show where he stands on issues like education, tax cutting and the economy.
So far, his campaign has been based almost entirely on his personal story of heroism in Vietnam and on his free-wheeling style with voters and journalists alike. The signature issues on which he is running -- a restored military, a campaign finance overhaul and a crusade against pork-barrel spending -- all seem to relate to his personality and background.
Even the first serious broadsides against Mr. McCain this fall came not over issues but on personality -- the accusation by critics that his hot temper would make him a bad president. In defending himself, Mr. McCain argued that he would need a temper to fight for the public against entrenched special interests in Washington.
The senator has started to deliver a series of policy speeches to flesh out his positions. He has already spoken on military policy, health care and the environment and plans to move on across the next few months to citizenship, tax cuts, Social Security, education and technology.
But in contrast to his ease at town meetings, he is impatient in giving speeches, rushing through them in a sing-song as if they bore him. And once off the topics of the campaign finance law or national security policy, he can seem surprisingly uninterested in detail.
The limits of his bare-bones staffing also start to show. After a recent speech in Charleston, S.C., about health policy, Mr. McCain was unable to answer questions about program costs, saying he had misplaced his fact sheet. His staff gave out one set of numbers then paged reporters at night to say some of the figures were wrong.
Setting out his positions also runs the risk for Mr. McCain of highlighting how conservative he is and possibly diminishing his ability to reach out to conservatives and independents alike in New Hampshire and South Carolina, where the primaries are not restricted only to party members. His tendency is to sound Democratic on issues while putting forward conservative programs.
That can become a difficult balancing act, as Mr. McCain learned the hard way when he talked with editors of The San Francisco Chronicle on abortion last August.
Asked about the Supreme Court's landmark Roe v. Wade decision, he said, "I would love to see a point where it is irrelevant and could be repealed because abortion is no longer necessary." He added that "certainly in the short term or even the long term, I would not support the repeal of Roe v. Wade" because repeal would "force X number of women in America" to undergo "illegal and dangerous operations."
The answer drew a wave of criticism from conservatives, who thought he was backtracking from his anti-abortion record. Now, whenever he is asked about abortion, Mr. McCain immediately points out that he has consistently voted against abortion in his 17 years in Congress and says that he would support repeal of Roe v. Wade. He then goes on to argue that both sides on the polarized abortion issue should try to work together on adoption. But this response often proves unsatisfactory to social moderates in New Hampshire, who are trying to decide whether to vote for him or Bill Bradley.
It is when goring special interests that Mr. McCain becomes most animated and passionate. In fact, he revels in being downright contrarian.
At a recent county Republican dinner in St. Johnsbury, Vt., he happily told his listeners "you have to tell the American people sometimes what they don't want to hear," and talked about how he had spoken out against ethanol subsidies during a debate in Iowa, where the subsidy for corn-based fuel is popular.
As the crowd applauded, he could not resist mentioning provocatively that he also opposed the Northeast Dairy Compact, which the state's Congressional delegation had vigorously fought for to maintain milk prices favorable to Vermont dairy farmers. "I don't support it because I think it raises the price for average citizens," he said, drawing no immediate response from the crowd.
Yet it is precisely this quality that is winning him converts. In a V.F.W. hall in Berlin, N.H., Margaret Hill, 87, bundled in a white ski jacket, suddenly stood up recently and told Mr. McCain in a quavering voice, "It would be so wonderful to get a President of the United States who doesn't say what they think you want to hear."
"Pack up," shot back Mr. McCain. "I'm taking you with me wherever I go."
 
State of the Campaign
This is the fourth in a series of status reports on the campaigns of the top contenders for the Democratic and Republican nominations as they enter the primary season. Next: The Forbes campaign.
 
AT A GLANCE -- The McCain Campaign
 
HEADQUARTERS -- Alexandria, Va.
 
STAFF SIZE -- About 50 full-time staff members.
 
TOP CAMPAIGN STAFF -- The campaign manager is Rick Davis, who was deputy campaign manager for Bob Dole in his 1996 presidential campaign. The political director is John Weaver, who led George Bush's general election presidential campaign in Texas in 1988 and was national field director of Senator Phil Gramm's presidential campaign in 1996. The strategic consultant is Mike Murphy, a political strategist from Virginia who worked for Lamar Alexander and later for Mr. Dole in 1996.
 
FINANCES -- The McCain campaign has $1.5 million cash on hand and says it will qualify for $6.2 million in federal matching funds next year, with $4.1 million of that money becoming available just after the new year.
 
PROMINENT ADVISERS -- Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, on foreign policy; Lisa Graham Keegan, superintendent of public instruction at the Arizona Department of Education, on education; Kevin A. Hassett of the American Enterprise Institute on fiscal and tax policy. Advising on politics are Kenneth M. Duberstein, a former chief of staff to President Ronald Reagan who is now a Washington lobbyist and Vin Weber, a former congressman from Minnesota.
 
BEST MOVES SO FAR -- Skipping the Iowa straw poll that drove other candidates from the race; building up credibility as the chief challenger to Gov. George W. Bush; staging a joint appearance with former Senator Bill Bradley, the Democratic presidential candidate, on campaign finance reform.
 
BIGGEST MISTAKE SO FAR -- Courting the wrath of conservatives by giving the appearance in an interview with The San Francisco Chronicle that he was backing away from his anti-abortion record.
 
CHALLENGES AHEAD -- Carrying his campaign beyond New Hampshire; overcoming Mr. Bush's 50-state organization and large lead in campaign funds.

PUB-DATE: December 30, 1999

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 5246 words

HEADLINE: Bold Effort Leaves Much Unchanged for the Poor

SERIES: LIFE AFTER WELFARE/Last article of a series.

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
So, did it work?
Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things. 
 It left far fewer people on welfare. It put more people to work.
Yet here is the dawning surprise: it may end up making less of a difference in the lives of the poor, socially or economically, than much of the public imagined.
Less welfare and more work -- it sounds like an impressive achievement, and surely in some ways it is. After imposing the nation's toughest work requirements, Wisconsin has cut its welfare rolls more than 90 percent, far deeper than expected. At any time, about two-thirds of those once on welfare are clinging to some sort of job, a level of employment that few experts thought could be achieved.
For tens of thousands of Milwaukee families, the story seems -- and on the surface is -- one of profound change. And in arriving first at welfare's end Wisconsin may offer the rest of the country a preview of changes to come.
But after three years of tracking the nation's boldest antiwelfare campaign, what seems most noteworthy about the lives of the poor is not the change at all. It is the long list of things that remain the same: violent neighborhoods, absent fathers, bare cupboards, epidemics of depression, the temptations of drugs.
Those hardships endure not just for the families who are obvious failures, those left with neither welfare nor work. They endure for the seeming successes. They endure for those with jobs.
After dozens of visits and hundreds of interviews inside a welfare revolution -- at public-aid offices early in the morning and in slum-district homes late at night -- the real surprise is how rarely a life seems truly transformed.
Welfare's end left Lashanda Washington at a Taco Bell at midnight, as a shift manager closing the store. But it also left her still quarreling with a violent boyfriend, evicted from her home, and worrying that child-welfare officials may try to take away her son.
Welfare's end left Nicole Keeler at a bus stop at 5:45 a.m. on her way to an assembly line at an electronics factory. But it also left her and her six children with no health insurance, and they still cannot afford to leave the gang-dominated neighborhood where they have lived for seven years.
If welfare's end brought progress for anyone, it did for Michelle Crawford. After two decades on public aid, she has completed a year as a machine operator at a plastics plant, where she earned nearly $16,000 this year -- more than twice the average earnings of former welfare recipients. But she still races to food pantries to feed her three children and blames her long workday for a daughter's new behavior problems at school.
The national conversation about urban poverty has focused so intensely on welfare, it almost defies the imagination to think that welfare could end and the lives of the poor remain the same in so many important ways.
"Work is more than just a weekly paycheck," President Clinton said this spring, in arguing that poor communities were being transformed. "It is, at heart, our way of life. Work lends purpose and dignity to our lives, instills in our children the basic values that built our nation."
But putting people to work was only one of the goals of the 1996 federal law that put an end to the guaranteed welfare checks. The other was to reduce the percentage of children born to unmarried women, a front on which progress has been slight if at all.
In the end, the prospects of poor children may depend more profoundly on whether they have the support of their fathers than whether their mothers move from subsistence welfare checks into subsistence jobs.
Of course, the real test -- of work and family -- rests not in one year, but over a generation. The nation takes it as an article of faith that, if nothing else, the children of working parents will be better off, inspired by their discipline, raised under a new social code.
At Pulaski High School here, the senior class president, Keona Marsh, articulates the ideal: "If you have a working parent, you have a positive image to look up to."
But as visits to poor neighborhoods sometimes show, life is often more complicated. They are filled with examples of hard-working mothers, occasionally fathers, too, whose children succumbed to familiar ills: teenage pregnancy, educational failure, the fast life of the drug trade.
Ms. Marsh was reared by a working single mother who knew little of welfare. But her mother was working so much that Ms. Marsh's older sister got pregnant at 12. Now at 17, Ms. Marsh is pregnant, too, which may end her plan to join the Army after graduation. "It wasn't that I wanted to have a child," she said. "It's just something that happened to me."
Whatever the hurdles at welfare's end, they bring little yearning for welfare's past. In retrospect, the old system seems even more flawed than it did at its abolition -- providing little, demanding little, derided by taxpayers and welfare recipients alike.
Even with low wages, many former recipients share Ms. Keeler's pride in her identity as a worker. "I can say this is Nicole's money, not welfare's money," she said.
And whatever else it has done, the movement from welfare to work has taken the edge off taxpayers' anger at the poor, bringing new investments in support services like child-care and the possibility of public policy breakthroughs to come.
This sense that ending welfare will prove less epochal than it seems -- it is not a firm conclusion. It cannot be proved with charts and graphs. It arises instead as a nagging suspicion, a word of caution, the more one travels in poor neighborhoods behind doors typically kept closed.
It arises with confessions from many women on welfare that they were secretly working all the time. It arises when a woman with a seeming success story confides she is bolstering her income by selling cocaine. It arises when another returns from work to a boyfriend who shoots up the house.
It arises with the growing impression that welfare was just one in a swirl of influences that shaped the lives of the urban poor, a force that meant less to most welfare families than the outside world believed.
If that is the case, ending welfare may mean less, too.
 
The History
Urban Woes Rooted In Rural Past
It does not look like a big-city ghetto, Milwaukee's near north side. The streets are lined with duplexes, once-proud structures built nearly a century ago for factory workers awash in new prosperity. The factories and the prosperity are gone, and so are many of the houses, replaced by vistas of vacant lots.
Sunrise is still two hours away as William Love guides his No. 12 bus up Teutonia Avenue, through the heart of Milwaukee's welfare belt. In more than 25 years as a city bus driver, he has had plenty of opportunities to witness the area's decline. Since the end of welfare, he has also engaged in some high-profile speculation about its revival.
When he learned that Wisconsin was going to require welfare recipients to work for their checks, he was enthusiastic. "I thought, 'If I can get up at 4 in the morning, they can, too,' " he said. In 1998, when a reporter from The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel rode with him, Mr. Love said that he saw more women with children on the early-morning bus and surmised they were former welfare families on their way to work.
The subsequent article portrayed a "startling change," sweeping the central city, and soon it was quoted everywhere by supporters of the tough new laws. In a radio address this spring, President Clinton cited the article, which also quoted two other drivers, as "evidence of our progress."
But by then Mr. Love was having doubts. A central-city bus driver, he is a landlord, too, and like many others he was finding that welfare's end made it harder to collect the rent. "In the past, they had their check, so you pretty much knew you were going to get your money," he said. Now he finds families doubled up, and when the rent is due, "you get these excuses."
This particular morning brings no clear sign of uplift or decline. A passenger heading to work at a food pantry grumbles that ending welfare left "a lot of people in need." A child care center worker acknowledges that the tougher laws pushed her to get a job. "I was getting welfare money, so why should I work -- that's the idea I had at the time," she said. But economically, she said the job has left her "about the same."
Behind the wheel, that, more or less, is Mr. Love's reconsidered opinion. Although he was once a tribune of social progress, he now says, "So far, haven't seen a big difference, one way or another."
If the problems of the inner city do not end with welfare, that is in part because they did not begin with welfare. On Milwaukee's north side, they often began, in a historical sense, 750 miles to the south, in the poverty and subjugation that black families experienced on plantations in the Mississippi Delta. One of the first things one notices in talking to Milwaukee welfare families, 79 percent of whom are black, is how many came from the Delta, the epicenter of sharecropper life. Another is how recent the escaoe has been. For a middle-aged woman on welfare in Milwaukee, the legacy of rural disenfranchisement is not a distant memory. Sometimes it is the story of her own mother's life.
One evening last spring, one such family head -- young, at 62 -- told the story of her own migration from a Mississippi plantation in the late 1950's, to a Chicago housing project, from which her daughter then moved to Milwaukee. It was a story of grinding poverty. She worked the fields and was paid in scrip, redeemable only at the plantation store. It was a story of family disarray. She scarcely knew her father, and she had the first of her eight children at 13.
In other words, it was a story with many of the same problems that came to dominate the urban, welfare-dependent North.
But it was not a story of welfare; for decades, local officials in the South kept most black families from getting welfare. "I didn't know nothing about welfare," she said.
Nearly 100,000 Wisconsin families ultimately came to rely on welfare, formally called Aid to Families with Dependent Children, and the number in Milwaukee peaked at nearly 39,000. Now just 5,800 Milwaukee families are on the successor program, Wisconsin Works or "W-2." But welfare was almost never their only means of support, another factor that helps explain why its demise may change things less than might be expected.
Kathryn Edin, a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia has estimated that A.F.D.C. typically provided just 34 percent of the average recipient's monthly income. Another 25 percent came from food stamps, where reductions have been less extreme. The rest came from boyfriends, charities, relatives and jobs, including under-the-table work.
Likewise, checking wage records, John Pawasarat, a researcher at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, found that 30 percent of the city's A.F.D.C. recipients were already working -- half of them in secret, to keep their benefits from being cut.
"There's more people working now, sure," Mr. Pawasarat said. "But the difference is not as large as people think, because a lot of people were already working under the old system."
He estimates that even at its peak, welfare accounted for less than 4 percent of the total income in Milwaukee's central city. "If you can't get that, you can't understand why there hasn't been more of a dramatic change," he said.
For all the political focus on welfare, the problems of the inner city also persist in families where parents are busy at work. Consider the case of Tremayne Franks, a charming if troubled 10-year-old who caught a reporter's attention last spring with his flamboyance on an after-school job at a corner grocery store. At 4-foot-6, he stood on a milk crate to reach the cash register, swore at his customers and awarded himself a fancy title: the "Always, Only, Assistant Boss."
In one light, his family's problems might seem those of a permissive welfare culture. His mother collected welfare checks for years while running with fast men, ignoring her son and giving little thought to a job. When officials took away her check, the boy said she left town to work as a stripper.
Certainly Tremayne's paternal grandmother, Glendora Johnson, who is raising him, blames welfare for rewarding his mother's irresponsible behavior. "They just made a bunch of sorry people, welfare did," Ms. Johnson said.
Yet similar problems have run through her side of the family, though she is the very epitome of a worker. After arriving from Mississippi in the mid-1960's, Ms. Johnson held her family together with a series of factory jobs -- her hard-drinking husband was little help -- and for nearly two decades she has worked the late shift as a hospital housekeeper.
In other words, Ms. Johnson is an embodiment of the working mother the new system hopes to create -- a hard-at-work provider whose disciplined example might save her children from the streets.
It did not: Four of her five children developed problems with drugs, and two wound up behind bars, including the Tremayne's father, Terry Johnson, who served 17 months for selling cocaine. Released last summer, he is back at work as a maintenance man at $8.50 an hour, trying to set an example for his son. A recent visit found him scolding the boy after one of his frequent suspensions from school, this one for selling Pokemon cards.
But as Mr. Johnson knows from his own childhood, a beleaguered parent's earnest example is sometimes no match for the streets.
"My mother showed me what it means to be a citizen in this country -- you got to work, you pay for what you get," he said. "But when you hit that jungle out there, there's all kinds of things you think you want. You got gold people with gold cars. They got money. They got guns. They got posses behind them. I'm just Fred Flintstone going to work."
 
The Program
An Impressive Effort That Can Be a Mess
Welfare may not have been the only problem in the inner city, but it was a problem nonetheless -- disliked in almost equal measure by the taxpayers who financed its modest benefits (A.F.D.C. offered a family of three about $6,200 a year in Wisconsin) and the families who received them.
"The welfare people, they didn't care what you did," said Lashanda Washington, the Taco Bell worker. "They just gave you money to keep you from snapping in their face."
Wisconsin Works, or W-2, is the nation's most ambitious effort to redesign a social safety net. It is far more strict than the system it replaced. Almost everyone who receives assistance is required to work at community service jobs like sweeping schools or answering telephones at nonprofit agencies.
But W-2 can be much more generous, too. Wisconsin raised the standard grant to nearly $8,100 a year. It also poured tens of millions of dollars of state and federal money into new services for workers who left the welfare rolls, most notably for child care, health care and wage subsidies.
Conceptually, it is an impressive effort to demand work and support it. But operationally, it has often been a mess, a tangle of unresponsive bureaucracies, uninspired casework and so much initial chaos and confusion that many needy families still express contempt at the name W-2.
Personalized casework to guide people into jobs was supposed to be a hallmark of W-2. But at the program's start in 1997, one caseworker's idea of job counseling reached the level of farce. He spent an hour reading aloud from an occupation almanac to a roomful of restless women:
"Mathematics -- reading graphs and stuff like that, it gets real deep when it comes to mathematics. Agriculture, that thing with cows, gets real deep -- giving them those hormones. . . . Forestry. Why don't we see any more wolves. Somebody eating them?"
Unwilling to work for a welfare check or endure more pointless classes, the poor voted with their feet. Most simply left. At the end of the transition from A.F.D.C., W-2 had been projected to enroll 54,000 families statewide. Instead, it had 13,000, and in the last 18 months the number has fallen to 7,100.
To the extent that W-2 has worked, it has done so despite itself, by wrapping welfare in so many new obligations that the poor have sought other options.
Where, then, did they go?
The good news is that most went to work on their own, in numbers much higher than expected. The bad news is that the journey from welfare to work is, so far at least, typically a story of running in place.
This month, researchers at the University of Wisconsin quietly released the most extensive study yet of families leaving the state's rolls. Examining the wage records of 16,000 former recipients, they found that 68 percent were working a year after leaving welfare. More than 80 percent had worked at some point in the year.
Hailing the ability of the poor to find jobs, Lawrence Mead, a welfare expert at New York University, argues that such work levels "represent the greatest achievement in antipoverty policy since the Great Society."
Yet for most families the work has failed to translate into economic progress. Among those who went to work in 1998, average annual earnings were just $7,700. That is $400 less than they would have received by staying on welfare. And it is just 59 percent of the $13,100 the government says a family of three needs to escape poverty.
The numbers look better when they include wage subsidies, called earned-income tax credits, which at these levels typically total about $3,000 a year. But those subsidies are partly offset by the reduction in food stamps many families experience when they work.
Adding up wages, subsidies and food stamps, the researchers did a more sophisticated set of calculations and still found limited progress.
After a year in the work force, only 36 percent of the former recipients had more total income than they had on welfare. Only a quarter lifted themselves above the poverty line. Just 4 percent exceeded what might be called a threshold of great change, incomes of above 150 percent of the poverty line -- in other words $19,700 for a mother with two children.
Examining a group of women who began working in 1996, the researchers did find they made modest progress over time, increasing earnings by about $1,200 a year.
Averages obscure the subplots, of course. If here and there some families have made it, about 16 percent have been left with neither welfare nor work. Surveys indicate that about half of them have other means of support, like boyfriends or disability payments; the rest may be experiencing significant new hardships, as Milwaukee's growing homeless shelter population suggests.
Between the two poles of failure or advancement, the most striking thing is that for most families little has changed. "On average, for the middle family here, in terms of their overall economic well-being, W-2 hasn't had a whopping impact," said Robert Haveman, one of the authors of the study.
A similar portrait of families largely running in place was drawn this year in a survey of 375 former welfare recipients sponsored by the state. Again, about two-thirds were working and most said they preferred doing so to being on welfare.
But most also said the movement from welfare to work had done little to ease material hardship, and in some cases might have increased it. Significant percentages reported problems paying for such basics as utilities, 47 percent; housing, 37 percent; and food, 32 percent.
After leaving welfare, poor families were 50 percent more likely to say they did not have enough money for groceries, a finding that rings true after many conversations with former welfare families who spontaneously talked about their struggles for food.
"You can go to my house, look in the refrigerator -- you'll be lucky if there's a gallon of milk in the house," said Tiffany Fiegel, 17, a senior at Pulaski High School whose mother recently left welfare for a job as a receptionist.
Contemplating the empty refrigerator, Ms. Fiegel broke down in tears. "We've got to struggle just to buy toothpaste," she said.
Why do earnings remain so low? In part, the problem is low wages. The state survey found former recipients averaging $7.42 an hour. But an equal if not bigger problem is that few women keep working full time year round. Even at $7.42 an hour, a full-time worker would earn $15,400 a year -- twice the actual earnings documented in the recent wage study.
For single parents with few skills, the problems that prevent full-time work run the gamut. Jobs are sometimes part-time or temporary. New workers grow discouraged and quit. Crises erupt at home: sick children, violent boyfriends, unreliable baby sitters and cars.
Ms. Keeler, the electronics assembly worker, is on her third job in the last year and she counts more than six since 1997. She has been fired for absences, laid off during slow-downs, and forced to quit during an illness related to pregnancy. Three years after first leaving welfare, she once more has a temporary job. "It's good to be working, but you're steady crawling," Ms. keeler said.
State officials say work will bring new order over time. Still a third recent study planted a seed of doubt, while underscoring the chaos in many poor families' lives. The study examined an experimental work program in Milwaukee called Project New Hope, which offered needy workers a guaranteed job at a wage sufficient to lift them out of poverty. But despite that guarantee, the average participant worked only 27 hours a week, and 73 percent remained poor.
A team of psychologists studying New Hope also found that it brought no declines in depression or growth in self-esteem. After two years in the program, the average worker still registered levels of depression above the threshold that most psychologists consider cause for clinical referrals.
In the end, whether the studies are seen as good news (requent employment) or bad news (continued high poverty) depends on two things. One is the value ascribed to work itself, even when the pay merely keeps pace with welfare. "John Q. Citizen would say that it is reasonable to expect people to get their income from work," said J. Jean Rogers, the state official who oversees W-2. "This program has helped tens of thousands of people do that. That's a huge change in a positive direction."
The other is expectations for the long term -- will work bring order and advancement to difficult lives, or will the difficulties continue to interfere with work?
Ms. Rogers takes a positive view. "When you move into the work force you have the opportunity to move up," she said. "What opportunity did they have when they were spending year in and year out on a welfare check?
"We're in the first few years of a new system after 60 years of welfare. You have to give people time."
 
The Lives
Sometimes Work Is Not Enough
Off welfare and at work: if the goal is that alone, Lashanda Washington is a portrait of success. She got her first job as soon as she turned 16. She left high school to work two jobs at once. And her spells on welfare have never lasted more than a couple of months. "I felt that was lazy, just sitting around getting a check," she said. "That would lower my self-esteem. I've always been a worker."
But if the goal is something deeper -- less chaos, more order; reason for confidence in her young son's future -- Ms. Washington's story takes on a different meaning.
Yes, she works and she has for years, even at the age of 20. But her life continues to be thrown into disarray by her troubled family, especially an alcoholic mother who mocks her efforts to get ahead. And her jobs never overcome the chaos at home. Whether she is bagging groceries, wrapping burritos, or standing on an assembly line, she is a textbook example of the major difference between a new job and a new life.
An earnest, street-smart woman, she thought she was turning a corner in July, shortly after an article about her in The New York Times. Her mother checked into a sobriety program. Ms. Washington found the job at Taco Bell. And after an eviction, a social worker helped her find a new apartment.
Then chaos erupted again, this time with her unemployed boyfriend. They fought; he hit her; she put him out. He retaliated by calling child welfare officials to complain, without reason she says, that she was mistreating her two-year-old son. Afraid to leave the boy with a baby sitter as social workers investigated, Ms. Washington simply walked off the job.
A recent visit found the house, as ever, engulfed in midday turmoil. Her short-staffed boss was at the door, asking her to return. A new boyfriend was lying around the house, trying to get her attention. Her mother was drinking near beer and asking for cigarette money. Ms. Washington, the weary family linchpin, returned to her bedroom where she had spent the entire day.
"I'm tired of starting all over again," she said. "Sometimes I just want to cry."
Though it has not happened to Ms. Washington yet, every now and then a real transformation does occur.
If anyone offers an example of deeper success -- a new job and a new life -- it is Michelle Crawford, a 39-year-old Milwaukee woman who went to work last year at a plastics plant, after two decades of desperation and chronic dependence on welfare. Thirteen months later she is still on the job despite a cascade of challenges, and a recent visit to her home served up two reminders.
Few people seem similarly transformed. The other is how difficult life remains, even at the upper-echelons of post-welfare experience.
The story of triumph is one she told to the Wisconsin Legislature in January, at the request of Governor Tommy G. Thompson, the four-term Republican who created W-2. Though much of the program's casework has been impersonal and ineffective, Ms. Crawford's was a marked exception. Beginning in the spring of 1998, the private agency that handled her case, Y-W Works, coaxed her through months of psychological counseling for her chronic problems with depression before pushing her to work at a plastics plant it bought to train clients.
Then, after two months of training, her supervisor drove her to an interview in the suburbs where she landed a full-time job. "Thank you, Jesus," she said at the time, falling to her knees.
While her public story was powerful, it was also incomplete. Behind the scenes, her 19-year-old son had just gone to prison for selling cocaine; her depression was at times galloping out of control; and she was locked in constant, sometimes physical fights with her unemployed husband, Donald Crawford, a recovering addict. Each had been arrested in recent months for attacking the other.
Things are a bit quieter now. Though Ms. Crawford said, "I still just have fits sometimes -- I go off," she and her husband have prayed and sought counseling to avoid the escalations to violence. "The punching and the blah-blah -- that's stopped," she said.
Mr. Crawford found a job, as a hotel maintenance man, and he is up shortly after midnight to work a 2 o'clock shift. Ms. Crawford is up at 4 a.m., to catch the first of three buses to the suburban plant where her shift starts at 6:55.
Financially, life remains in turmoil, even with her annual income of nearly $16,000. No longer eligible for food stamps, Ms. Crawford struggles simply to keep food on the table. She is a regular at food pantries, and her husband recently sold a car, for $250, to re-stock the freezer.
Even a commodity as basic as a gallon of milk remains a prized household item. To trick her children into drinking it in cheaper, powdered form, she started sweetening the watery substitute with sugar and slipping it into regular milk jugs. "Then we ran out of sugar," she said, laughing at her predicament.
In speaking to the Legislature, Ms. Crawford drew the biggest applause when she pointed toward her three minor children -- Lorenzo, 14; Lavita, 11; and Yolando, 7 -- who were watching from the gallery.
"I was so proud when I got the job," she said. "Now I tell my kids this is what happens when you do your homework. My kids see a difference in me." Nothing captures the national hopes about ending welfare more than that, the faith in example-setting.
In separate recent conversations, Ms. Crawford and her children did not exactly reject that notion. But they certainly did complicate it, tempering its appeal with real-world nuance. Whatever future benefits her example of hard work sets, it has also brought new stress, especially for the two girls who miss their mother's attention.
Both have begun acting up in school, and Yolando, a second-grade charmer with a million-dollar smile, was recently suspended for punching a classmate. To steal back her time with her mother, Yolando has even begun getting up with her at 4 a.m. "I thought I was going to have my kids go see a whatchacallit -- child therapist," Ms. Crawford said. "But they just want attention."
In describing the effect of the job the household, the children spoke less of abstract pride than of concrete stress.
"She don't want to cook -- she said she's too tired and stuff," Yolando said.
"When she's tired, she's crabby," Lorenzo said.
"She says, 'Just leave me alone.' She acts mean," Lavita said.
"She don't act mean," Lorenzo said. "She just don't want to be bothered."
Lavita predicted she might turn to welfare one day because "I'll probably have kids before I have a job," and she does not want a husband. "He'd probably get on my nerves."
But Lorenzo mocked her. "That's ghetto!" he said.
Ms. Crawford told much the same story of stress, saying she is typically too tired to help her children with their homework, and she is often too tired to cook. For a moment, her words took an uncharacteristic turn toward the bitter. "Right now, I got to concentrate on myself and what I got to do," she said. "I'm sorry my kids are taking it the way they are. They're acting like little selfish brats."
But mostly she talked in the weary tones of working mothers everywhere. "I sometimes feel like I'm not taking care of my family like I should," she said. "But a lot of times, when I come home, I'm just so tired."
 
Life After Welfare
With the nation's welfare rolls down 43 percent, President Clinton, as well as his Republican critics, count the landmark 1996 welfare law as the cornerstone of their respective legacies. That law replaced a 60-year-old cash safety net with a program of time limits and work requirements.
No place has come closer than Wisconsin to the goal of "ending welfare." A decade ago, 100,000 Wisconsin families relied on public aid. Now 7,000 do.
The changes taking place in the state, particularly in its largest city, Milwaukee, continue to reverberate in broad and unpredictable ways. Throughout 1999, The New York Times returned to Milwaukee to plot the pattern of change. This is the last article of the series.
The articles and related coverage of welfare issues are available on The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/politics.

HEADLINE: MEN'S BASKETBALL;
Orangemen Off To a 9-0 Start

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:

SYRACUSE 90, HARTFORD 69
 Damone Brown had 15 points and helped power an 18-1 run as No. 7 Syracuse pulled away from visiting Hartford for a 90-69 men's basketball victory last night. 
 After pulling to 34-26, Hartford (2-6) went scoreless the final four minutes of the first half and did not get its first field goal in the second half until Mantas Storpirstis's layin at the 15-minute-45-second mark.
 Syracuse (9-0) scored the final 6 points of the first period and then, with Brown contributing 7 points, the Orangemen went on a 12-1 spurt to open the second half, building a a 55-29 lead before Storpirstis's basket ended Hartford's drought.
 
STANFORD 119, NEW HAMPSHIRE 60
 Mark Madsen, the Cardinal's only returning starter from last season, made his comeback after missing eight games because of a strained right hamstring as No. 1 Stanford (10-0) beat New Hampshire (1-8) in the opener of the Stanford Invitational.
 Stanford tied a school record with 15 3-pointers. Madsen made an emphatic return, blocking a shot in his first few seconds on the court and then making a layup at the other end. He had 8 points, 8 rebounds, 2 assists and 2 blocks in 21 minutes.
 
OHIO STATE 79, AMERICAN UNIVERSITY 43
 Ken Johnson blocked two more shots than American University made in the first half as No. 15 Ohio State (8-2) rolled. Johnson had eight blocks in the first half against the visiting Eagles (5-5), who made just 6 of 29 shots (21 percent) in the first 20 minutes.
 
WISCONSIN 62, TEMPLE 44
 Jon Bryant and Charlie Wills each scored 12 points as host Wisconsin (8-4) routed No. 17 Temple (6-3). Bryant scored all of his points on 3-point baskets as Wisconsin made a season-high nine 3-pointers. Andy Kowske added 10 for the Badgers.
 
WAKE FOREST 84, OHIO 78
 Robert O'Kelley, held to 1 point in the first half, scored 7 of his 17 points in the second overtime as No. 19 Wake Forest (9-2) beat Ohio (7-5) in the consolation round of the Rainbow Classic in Honolulu. Wake Forest took an 80-78 lead on Chris Dawson's basket with 1:12 remaining in the second overtime. O'Kelley then hit a field goal and added two free throws.
 
A.S.U. HOLIDAY CLASSIC
 
BUCKNELL 70, MANHATTAN 66
Dan Bowen and Dyrika Cameron each scored 15 points to lead Bucknell (6-4) past Manhattan (4-5) in the consolation game of the AZCentral.com-A.S.U. Holiday Classic in Tempe, Ariz. Bryan Bailey scored 13 points, including three free throws in the final 45.2 seconds for the Bison (6-4), who snapped a three-game losing streak. Brian Muckle added 10 points, 9 rebounds and 8 assists for Bucknell.
 
HOLIDAY INN EXPRESS TOURNAMENT
 
MAINE 84, L.I.U. 63
Nate Fox scored 21 points on 8-for-12 shooting as Maine beat Long Island University in the first round of the Holiday Inn Express tournament in Stony Brook, N.Y. Julian Dunkley added 17 points for Maine (8-3), and Huggy Dye had 16. Richie Parker had 21 points for L.I.U. (2-6), which lost its third in a row.

Steve Pratta scored 13 points as Stony Brook (2-12) outlasted Army (2-7) in a first-round game. Seth Barrett had a game-high 15 points for the Black Knights.

HEADLINE: For Dinner: New Choices at China's Table

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The World Bank's Aim: Beef for China" (Op-Ed, Dec. 28), by Neal D. Barnard: That the Chinese people have traditionally eaten more vegetables and rice than meat is because for most of Chinese history most of the population has lived at a poor level. 
 Having lived in China for several years, I know that Chinese people who have a reached a certain level of disposable income will invariably choose to eat high amounts of beef, chicken and, most of all, shellfish, which is as bad if not worse for you than beef. One need only look at Taiwan and Hong Kong to see what middle-class Chinese people prefer to eat. The eating habits of the Taiwanese and the Hong Kong Chinese are decidedly not vegetarian, and this is related to income levels and not any sort of "Eastern" diet.
JOSEPH LEVINSON
New York, Dec. 28, 1999

HEADLINE: Restoring the Charm to Madison Square Park

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Some of the ornaments on the granite fountain are missing and it no longer spews water. Stretches of the wrought iron fence are broken and twisted. And the lawns are blotchy from neglect.
Bit by bit, over the years, Madison Square Park, nestled in a corporate canyon just north of the Flatiron Building at 23rd Street and Broadway, has been losing its charm, even as its neighborhood prospers. 
 But next month, workers are to begin a $5 million face lift that Deborah Landau, the executive director of the City Parks Foundation, says is intended to restore the park to its original 19th century beauty, when neighbors like Edith Wharton and Theodore Roosevelt strolled its meandering paths.
The fountain will be brought back to life, Ms. Landau said, and a reflecting pool will be built in the north end of the park's 6.2 acres. Dozens of trees and shrubs will replace scraggly counterparts. New grass will be sown and a flower garden planted. At the southeast corner, at 23rd Street and Madison Avenue, the renovators will also reclaim a wedge of ground that had been sliced off as a short cut for trolleys and is now a parking lot for motorcycles. Antique-looking street lamps of fluted cast iron will be brought in and clunky concrete benches will give way to less bulky ones of wood and wrought iron; the benches, styled like those used at the 1939 New York World's Fair, are being increasingly used in the city. The park will remain open.
Following the lead of people who live on the edges of Central Park and have poured a fortune into improvements there, the businesses that surround Madison Square Park -- giants like Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, New York Life Insurance, Credit Suisse First Boston, Rudin Management and Bell Atlantic -- decided to join together to beautify what amounts to their front yard. Ms. Landau worked out a deal with the city: If the businesses could come up with $2.5 million, the city would provide the rest of the necessary $5 million.
In addition, the parks foundation and some neighbors, including residents and new Silicon Alley companies, have been chipping in to raise an additional $6 million to form a trust that will pay for a park director, a gardener and workers to maintain the park's grounds, as well as its World War I memorial, dog run, small playground and monuments.
Two big insurance companies led the way for the project. Sy Sternberg, the chief executive of New York Life, whose gold-domed headquarters rises at the north end of the park at Madison and 26th Street, had his company contribute $900,000. Robert H. Benmosche, the chief executive of Met Life, whose 50-story turn-of-the-century tower rises at the southeast corner of the park, at Madison and 23rd Street, had his company give even more: $2.4 million, and, as one neighbor put it, "used his influence on neigbors" and the tenants of the adjoining Art Deco office block owned by Met Life, to raise much of the rest of the money.
One contributor who did not need encouragement was Danny Meyer, the restaurateur, who has leased the entire first two floors of the Met Life office block facing the park between 24th and 25th Streets. Mr. Meyer, who opened a pair of new dining places, 11 Madison Park and Tabla, in the building, not only pitched in $100,000 but persuaded others to contribute.
Mr. Meyer knows what a beautiful park can do for business. He opened the Union Square Cafe 15 years ago and was one of the pioneers in the long-running improvement of Union Square Park, which helped pep up the whole area. "We could not afford space off Union Square if we were just coming in now," Mr. Meyer said the other day.
He jumped at a chance to lease space facing Madison Square Park, he said. But he wanted assurances that Met Life would take "a substantial leadership role" in sprucing up the park.
"This is going to be an extraordinary agent of community wealth," he said in a conversation at his 11 Madison Park restaurant, which blends metal and marble features in the Art Deco style with flourishes of the park's greenery and park photographs from yesteryear. "Even if you're not the type of person who cares for the health of his front lawn, you would want to help develop this economic engine."
Mr. Sternberg agreed. "If we can make some contribution to the stability of the neighborhood," he said, "it ultimately accrues value to the company."
The park was named for President James Madison and designed by Ignatz Pilat, an assistant to Frederick Law Olmsted, the designer of Central Park. Built on the remnant of a former Army parade ground, it opened in 1847. Madison Square Garden went up 32 years later on the corner now occupied by New York Life. In 1925, Madison Square Garden moved uptown to 34th Street.
Ms. Landau's foundation and other citizens' groups have been working to improve more than a dozen of the city's hundreds of parks. The parks that get the special attention, she said, are those whose neighbors get the ball rolling. "We don't get involved unless there is community support," she said.
Henry J. Stern, the city parks and recreations commissioner, there was only so much money available for park maintenance. "But this partnership with the city and businesses and residents gives us a chance to completely overhaul the park," he said. "It's going to be a jewel of a park."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: December 31, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the restoration of Madison Square Park misstated the history of Madison Square Garden. The original Madison Square Garden, at 26th Street and Madison Avenue, was razed in 1925. It then moved to Eighth Avenue and 50th Street before moving to its current site atop Pennsylvania Station in 1968.

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend, including New Year's Eve celebrations. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
 
ANTIFOLK Y2K PARTY, Sidewalk Cafe, 94 Avenue A, at Sixth Street, East Village, (212) 473-7373. Ring in the new century the East Village way, at a conclave of local poets, satirists and rabble-rousers led by Lach, the man who has almost singlehandedly kept antifolk alive in the Clinton era. He will play with his new band, the Secrets; other performers include the wonderful Heather Eatman, the Humans, Joie DBG, David Gragov, the Grey Revell Band, Patsy Grace, Joe Bendik and Maj. Matt Mason U.S.A. Tonight at 8; admission is free (Ann Powers). 

GATO BARBIERI QUINTET, REGINA BELLE, MIRI BEN-ARI TRIO, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. All gatos have a few lives, and Mr. Barbieri, the saxophonist, has had three: first as a free-jazz wailer in the early 1970's, then as the soloist on the celebrated "Last Tango in Paris" soundtrack and now as a smooth-jazz balladeer. He is on the bill with the singer Regina Belle and the up-and-coming violinist Miri Ben-Ari, whose attack is so ferocious that she may give you your necessary second wind. The first party is tonight from 7:30 to 12:30; $500 a person at the tables, including a four-course dinner, open bar and Champagne toast; or $300 per person for table seating without dinner; or $250 at the bar (minus dinner). The second show starts at 1 a.m. and lasts until whenever; the price is $180 a person at tables, without dinner and open bar, and $100 at the bar. Regina Belle performs tomorrow and Sunday night at 9 and 11:30; $45 cover with a $5 minimum (Ben Ratliff).
 
DAVID BERKMAN QUARTET, Detour, 349 East 13th Street, East Village, (212) 533-6212. More often than not, in clubs without a piano, Mr. Berkman reminds his audiences why the Fender Rhodes electric piano is a beautiful instrument in its own right, not just a substitute for the real thing. When he does have the real thing, he's even better. He's a burner in the straight-ahead jazz style, with a good debut album, "Handmade" (Palmetto), to his credit. Music starts tomorrow at 9:30 p.m.; there is no cover charge (Ratliff).
 
BLACK 47, Connolly's Pub, 14 East 47th Street, Manhattan, (212) 867-3767. Black 47 plays Irish neighborhood music from the Bronx, not Dublin. Bainbridge Avenue runs through a Bronx neighborhood where new Irish immigrants meet the New York mosaic. In Black 47's songs, jigs and reels mesh with rock and hip-hop. Music begins tonight at 10; admission is $20 (Jon Pareles).
 
ANGELA BOFILL, Iridium, 48 West 63rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. The singer Angela Bofill, a virtuoso with a four-octave range, has moved in and out of jazz and pop. She lavishes lung power and ornamentation on her love songs. Two shows tonight: one at 7:30, including a three-course dinner, for $125 a person, and one at 10:45, with a four-course dinner and unlimited Champagne, for $295 a person (Pareles).
 
CLAUDIA QUINTET, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. This imaginative band, led by the drummer and composer John Hollenbeck, lays vibraphone, clarinet and accordion on top of bass and drums. It's sensitive, thinking music, continually changing shape and texture. And it's clear that Mr. Hollenbeck's goals lie beyond jazz, but all the same he swings, neatly and unostentatiously. Sets are Sunday night at 8 and 9:30; admission is $7, with a one-drink minimum (Ratliff).
 
PAULA COLE, THE ROOTS, Life, 158 Bleecker Street, at Thompson Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 420-1999. In keeping with its thriving system of hierarchical V.I.P. rooms, Life presents a three-tiered party tonight. The priciest ticket includes a buffet dinner at 6:30 p.m. and a performance by the bohemian pop-soul singer Paula Cole; $100 less gets you no chow but a 10 p.m. set by Ms. Cole. And for $125, and well worth the price, you can show up tipsy at 3 a.m. and welcome 2000 with the best live band in hip-hop (and one of the best in any genre), the Roots. Shows are at 8 and 10 p.m., and 3 a.m.; tickets are $350, $250 and $125 (Powers)
 
RICHIE COLE'S ALTO MADNESS ORCHESTRA, the Phoenix Room, 570 Amsterdam Avenue, at 88th Street, Manhattan, (212) 544-2210. The alto-saxophonist Richie Cole was in Buddy Rich's big band for three years in the early 70's, which helped him understand jazz as a sort of perpetually exploding dynamite shed. He's a good player, influenced by Phil Woods, and he's been underrecognized for a few decades. Tonight: limited seating from 8 to 10 p.m.; six-course dinner plus open bar is $200, and a late-night buffet with admission to one set is $100; Champagne toast at midnight. Seating in the Cherokee Room with a late-night buffet and champagne toast for $50 is also available (Ratliff)
 
DEEP BANANA BLACKOUT, Wetlands Preserve, 161 Hudson Street, at Laight Street, TriBeCa, (212) 966-4225. For this big night, the team that runs Wetlands could have highlighted any number of musical styles that pass through the club, from Grateful Dead homages to neo-bluegrass, techno-tinged progressive rock or earthy hip-hop. But who could blame them for choosing a band that adheres to the fundamentals of body-shaking funk? Deep Banana Blackout is one of the Northeast's favorite party bands, so the vibrations in the room should be excellent. With Electric Hill. Doors open tonight at 8, and music begins at 10; admission is $60 (Powers).
 
DR. ISRAEL, Knitting Factory, Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. The deep, leisurely bass lines of dub reggae are the foundation of jungle, which layers jittery electronic drumbeats on top of those bass lines. Dr. Israel (alias Douglas Bennett), a reggae singer, reunites the two branches of reggae's family tree, singing uplifting messages over vertiginous grooves. Music tonight at 11; admission is free (Pareles).
 
EMINEM, Tunnel, 220 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 695-4682. With his cutting, nasal voice, droll productions by Dr. Dre and an imagination that turns carnage into comedy, Eminem (for the initials of Marshall Mathers, his original name) was the leading bad-boy rapper of early 1999. He mocks every propriety and everyone including himself, and while he is not the most skillful rapper onstage -- he needs backups to keep him somewhere near the beat -- it hardly matters when his fans are eagerly shouting along. The Tunnel has also scheduled eight disc jockeys in three rooms, among them Ivan Gonzo and Eddie Baez. Doors open at 9 p.m. Tickets are $99, or $175 with open bar; the club is also offering a weekend pass for New Year's Eve through Jan. 2 for $150 (Pareles).
 
* TOMMY FLANAGAN TRIO, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Mr. Flanagan helped define an elegant postwar mainstream in jazz piano; he plays with such refinement that he makes bebop seem like a natural fit with the American song tradition. And his small-group arrangements in his longtime trio with Peter Washington and Lewis Nash are models of economy and imagination. Tonight's first set is at 8, with a three-course dinner, for $100, or without dinner for $50; the second set is at 11, with a three-course dinner, show, party favors and dancing, for $225, or $150 for the show only. Sets tomorrow night are at 8 and 10:30, with a cover of $25 and a $10 minimum; on Sunday night, sets are at 7 and 9, and the cover charge is $18 with a $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
DAVID HAZELTINE, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662. This pianist plays with a cooperative quartet, including the trumpeter Jim Rotondi, the bassist John Webber and the drummer Neil Smith; they can play hard-hitting, involved music, and this new, small jazz club, frequented by students, seems like a cheerily low-key place to spend the evening. Music tonight is from 10 p.m. to 3 a.m.; there is an open bar, a raw bar with shellfish, party favors and a Champagne toast for $195. From 1 to 8 a.m., there is one more live set and a D.J. dance party for a $15 cover; early guests may stay for no additional charge (Ratliff).
 
JAVON JACKSON QUARTET, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Without staging a full-scale subversion of jazz, the tenor-saxophonist Javon Jackson makes good decisions about material and instrumentation; there might be a Hammond organ on the bandstand, and you might hear music written by Frank Zappa, Caetano Veloso or Carlos Santana. And as a soloist he is a thoughtful player, laid-back enough to savor the horn's natural gargles. Tonight's celebration is from 9 to midnight, with an all-inclusive dinner package for $175; the late show is from 1 to 3 a.m., with a $40 cover and a $25 minimum, including Champagne toast. Sets tomorrow at 9 and 11 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. and Sunday at 9 and 11 p.m.; cover charge is $25 with a $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
BILLY JOEL, Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue at 32nd Street, (212) 465-6741. Billy Joel's huge catalog of hits includes songs that touch on every idiom from doo-wop to sea chantey to bossa nova to barrelhouse pop, driven by formidable piano technique and an underlying pugnacity. He's the bard of the suburbs, assuring fans that even if they've settled down they're still rebels at heart. While he has said he's giving up pop songwriting for instrumental music, he'll be rolling out the hits for New Year's Eve. Tonight at 9; tickets are $150 to $999.99 (Pareles).
 
KID CREOLE AND THE COCONUTS, Greatest Bar on Earth, 1 World Trade Center, lower Manhattan, (212) 524-7000. August Darnell, or Kid Creole, runs his band like a compact Broadway revue, with Kid Creole -- a suave would-be Casanova who's not always lucky -- flanked by the Coconuts, who are both all-purpose temptresses and a chorus line. Long before the rediscovery of Latin rhythms, he performed as if Manhattan were the northernmost Caribbean island; more recently he has raised the quotient of funk. Music begins tonight at 10; admission is $300 with open bar (Pareles).
 
LI'L ED AND THE BLUES IMPERIALS, Chicago Blues, 73 Eighth Avenue, at 14th Street, West Village, (212) 924-9755. Ed Williams, or Li'l Ed, plays his blues basic and rowdy. His band stomps out Chicago blues and shuffles while Li'l Ed belts the tunes, makes his guitar squeal and slide, and jumps all over the stage. It's primal good-time music, and once it revs up there's no stopping it. Sunday at 9 and 10:30 p.m. and midnight. Admission is $10, with a two-drink minimum (Pareles).
 
JOE LOVANO TRIO, GLORIA LYNNE, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. A gig not to miss, if you want to be reminded why jazz quickened your pulse in the first place. Mr. Lovano just winds up and lets his broad, powerful saxophone sound go, ripping up ballads and open-ended originals with a superb trio that includes the bassist Cameron Brown and the drummer Idris Muhammad. He's a generous performer who gives it his all. Tonight beginning at 9; table seating $150 per person plus $25 minimum, $100 at the bar with a $25 minimum. Includes a Champagne toast at midnight. Performances tomorrow are at 9 and 11 p.m.; cover charge is $30 with a $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
* MANOLITO Y SU TRABUCO, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940. A top Cuban band leader with his eye on the world, the pianist Manolito Simonet has his ear to music across Latin America, from older Cuban styles like charanga (with violin and flute answering voices) to trumpet-topped Cuban conjunto to cumbia to current salsa romantica and songo. He's a traditionalist on one song, up to the minute on the next as the singers announce his intention to reach listeners in Venezuela, Colombia, Puerto Rico and New York. Since Cuban bands play constantly for dancing crowds, Manolito y Su Trabuco (War Machine) has honed its music to keep people in motion. Tonight the club is offering packages at $95 a person (general admission after 1 a.m.), $195 (general admission after 10 p.m., with hors d'oeuvres and a Champagne toast) and $395 (including a five-course dinner and breakfast at dawn) (Pareles).
 
MEAT LOAF, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, Manhattan, (212) 496-7070. Meat Loaf recently made his latest comeback as an unhandsome character in the movie "Fight Club." Onstage, however, he's still applying his rock heldentenor to Jim Steinman's proudly, campily bombastic songs about fondly remembered teenage lust and the possibility of love. Tonight at 8; tickets are $75 to $250. Tomorrow night at 8, tickets are $50 to $100 (Pareles).
 
BUDDY MILES, Chicago Blues, 73 Eighth Avenue, below 14th Street, West Village, (212) 924-9755. Buddy Miles was the quintessential singing drummer of the 1960's, playing in Electric Flag and then in Jimi Hendrix's Band of Gypsies and belting a hit of his own in 1969, "Them Changes." After some hard years, including a jail term for theft in the 1970's, he has returned to the circuit, still an exuberant singer and a splashy, hard-hitting drummer. Shows are tonight at 9:30, 11:30 p.m. and 1:30. General admission is $50; seating is $75 for the first set and $100 for the second set (Pareles).
 
MURPHY'S LAW, Continental, 25 Third Avenue, at St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 529-6924. Still bratty after all these years, Murphy's Law is one of New York's long-running, die-hard punk bands. It shares a guitar-charged lineup with Helldorado, Candy Snatchers and Suicide King. Tonight at midnight; tickets are $30 (Pareles).
 
TITO NIEVES, JOSE ALBERTO (EL CANARIO), JOHNNY PACHECO, Copacabana, 617 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 582-2672. A salsa triple bill leans toward romance amid the rumbas, cha-chas and boleros. Tito Nieves is one of Latin pop's longtime Romeos, promising "salsa con clase" (salsa with class). With a sincere, ardent tenor, he vows his love in Spanish or English. Jose Alberto sails above the salsa grooves with fervor and improvisations that have earned him his nickname, the Canary. The flutist Johnny Pacheco has been one of salsa's most important band leaders since Fania Records ruled Latin music in the 1970's. Music begins tonight at 10. Table seating is $125 a person; general admission, $60; admission after 3 a.m., $30 (Pareles)
 
* MACEO PARKER, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. There was a reason James Brown used to shout "Maceo!" in the middle of a funk workout. Maceo Parker was the alto saxophonist who drove the horn section in Mr. Brown's groundbreaking J. B.'s and went on to work for George Clinton's Parliament-Funkadelic when Mr. Clinton latched on to members of the J. B.'s. After sparking two definitive funk bands, he leads a group that knows the secrets of getting on the good foot. Special guests are also promised. Doors open tonight at 9. Tickets are $200 (Pareles).
 
P. M. DAWN, CRYSTAL WATERS, SUGAR HILL GANG, Shine, 285 West Broadway, at Canal Street, lower Manhattan, (212) 941-0900. Two hip-hop groups and a dance-floor diva share this triple bill. P. M. Dawn has made some of the dreamiest albums in hip-hop, combining psychedelia with a quest for Christian faith. Its music floats understated raps and Prince Be's ethereal singing on tracks that melt in the ear. Crystal Waters brought social consciousness into discos with her 1991 hit, "Gypsy Woman (She's Homeless)," and has since switched to singing about love and basketball. "Rapper's Delight" by the Sugar Hill Gang, released in 1979, is the cornerstone of recorded hip-hop: just a party tune that happened to set off a musical revolution. Now the Gang has turned itself into a hip-hop oldies act, performing its own rhymes and others from back in the day. Tickets tonight are $250 to $450, including open bar from 9:30 p.m. to 2 a.m. (Pareles).
 
* GIL SCOTT-HERON, ROY AYERS, Cooler, 416 West 14th Street, West Village, (212) 229-0785. With assertively political poems like "The Revolution Will Not Be Televised," Gil Scott-Heron was integral to the consciousness-raising poetry movement that was part of the roots of hip-hop and the 1990's revival of spoken-word performance. But while his convictions remain intact, he has turned from recitation to singing, slipping his ideas into easygoing jazz-funk vamps. The vibraphonist Roy Ayers has built a career on sleek pop-jazz grooves that have lately found a second life as hip-hop samples. The disc jockeys Franco and Bugaloo Mike are to fill in between sets. Doors open at 9:30 p.m.; open bar until 11. Tickets are $120 (Pareles).
 
* MICHELLE SHOCKED AND THE PHILOSOPHER KINGS, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-6300. Michelle Shocked is a radical artist, unafraid of sharing her political views and her bare emotions. She has run into trouble with the mainstream music industry, but she hasn't quit; she just retrained her focus on the grass-roots following that got her in the first place. Now she will share the latest fruits of her unwavering work ethic: all new songs at her three performances this week, to ring in a new millennium of constructive troublemaking. Doors open tonight at 7:30 for a 9:30 show; tickets are $50 (Powers).
 
* SUN RA ARKESTRA WITH MARC RIBOT, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Sun Ra's Arkestra couldn't be more appropriate for the first night of 2000. Its founder, who died in 1993, long ago had his eye on the future, with its 21st-century promises of space travel and interplanetary communication. The Arkestra, now led by the saxophonist Marshall Allen, is a big band that bristles with exuberant loose ends, and its sets move from barely warped swing-band arrangements to vamp tunes (like "Space Is the Place") to squalls of free jazz. It turns typical swing-band arrangements into something richer and stranger by adding layers of dissonance and percussion that only make the music sound more joyful. The guitarist Marc Ribot, who has played with Tom Waits and Chocolate Genius, can pick through jazz changes or make his guitar clank and boing; he should be thoroughly compatible with the Arkestra. Tomorrow at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; admission is $14 (Pareles).
 
TIJUANA CARAVAN, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Get down to the basics of rootsy funk-rock with this Philadelphia-based party band. Three sets, party favors and a Champagne toast keep the mood high. Doors open tonight at 8; tickets are $35 (Powers).
 
THE VOLUPTUOUS HORROR OF KAREN BLACK, CBGB, 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 982-4052. Punk, heavy metal and plenty of mascara add up to the Voluptuous Horror of Karen Black, a long-running punk-rock show band whose songs hark back to the Cramps and early Blondie. Kembra Pfahler, the band's semiclad singer, makes promises like "Take my hand and you will see/What a maniac I can be." The bill also includes Motor Betty and Probe. Music begins tonight around 10; admission is $35 the day of the show (Pareles).
 
DR. MICHAEL WHITE'S ORIGINAL LIBERTY JAZZ BAND OF NEW ORLEANS, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Dr. Michael White takes his chosen idiom, New Orleans jazz of the 20's, very seriously, and his band, nearing a decade of New Year's shows at the Vanguard, performs lively versions of tunes associated with Louis Armstrong, King Oliver and others from the Crescent City. If the concept is strictly classical, the players have presence and nerve. Tonight doors open at 10, with a set at 11; $125 a person includes the $25 drink minimum, party favors, a New Year's Eve T-shirt and New Orleans-style food. Sets tomorrow and Sunday are at 9:30 and 11:30 p.m., with a third set tomorrow night at 1 a.m.; cover charge is $20 with a $10 minimum. No credit cards (Ratliff).
 
PAUL WINTER, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1071 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 662-2133. In the cathedral's annual New Year's Eve concert, hopes for peace are expressed in New Age music with multicultural ambitions. The Paul Winter Consort plays one-world music full of reassurance, good intentions and candy-coated exoticism. It shares the stage with the African-style Forces of Nature Dance Company and with Madafo Lloyd Wilson. The concert begins tonight at 7:30; tickets are $75 to $100 (Pareles).
 
BERNIE WORRELL AND THE WOO WARRIORS, Grange Hall, 50 Commerce Street, at Barrow Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-5246. As the keyboardist in Parliament-Funkadelic, Bernie Worrell put the oozing, organic textures in the P-Funk groove machine. He can take credit for the slow-bubbling synthesizer bass lines that are still ubiquitous in hip-hop and rhythm-and-blues; he also has an encompassing knowledge of jazz, funk, gospel and rock that he tosses around lightly. Seatings tonight are at 10, 10:30 and 11. Admission, with dinner, is $150 (Pareles).
 
* JOHN ZORN'S MASADA, MARC RIBOT Y LOS CUBANOS POSTIZOS, CYRO BAPTISTA'S BEAT THE DONKEY, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7503. Masada is a collection of 205 klezmer-tinged tunes by John Zorn, who oversees various ensembles that play them, including a quartet that recalls Ornette Coleman's pianoless lineups. With Joey Baron on drums, Greg Cohen on bass, Dave Douglas on trumpet and Mr. Zorn on alto-saxophone, Masada moves from the pulse of dance music to modal Middle Eastern inflections to Romantic filigree. Less fragmented and more melodic than most of Mr. Zorn's music, Masada finds connections to Jewish tradition everywhere. The guitarist Marc Ribot started Los Cubanos Postizos to play songs he loved from Cuba in the 1940's and 50's, from the repertory of Arsenio Rodriguez; he honors the tunes, but he isn't afraid to add some downtown clank and down-home twang in his solos. Cyro Baptista is a Brazilian percussionist who is fond of melody and humor as well as rhythm. Mr. Baptista's "Vira Loucos," an album that reclaimed and utterly transformed the Brazilian folk tunes once adapted by Heitor Villa-Lobos, featured Mr. Ribot and was produced by Mr. Zorn; they may well collaborate again. The triple bill appears tonight at 6:30, with tickets at $45, and at 10:30, for $65 (including a Champagne toast). Tickets for both shows include admission to Sub-Tonic with the D.J. Toshio Kajiwara (Pareles).

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 2; Column 3; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk
