HEADLINE: ON STAGE AND OFF

BYLINE: By Jesse McKinley 

 BODY:

Of Holidays Not So Happy
It may just be a quirk of the calendar or a legitimate millennial dread, but this holiday season has proved to be far gloomier than expected for many Broadway shows. 
 A year after record-breaking box office and packed-to-the-rafters audiences, Broadway had one of its slowest-selling weeks of the year last week, with big drops in grosses and attendance.
For the week that ended on Sunday, 18 Broadway shows were playing to under 60 percent of capacity, including three at under 30 percent. The demoralizing effect of playing to a half-empty house must have been particularly acute at the cavernous 1,933-seat Gershwin Theater, where "Tango Argentino" was playing to 27 percent of capacity, or an average of 530 people a night.
In blunt economic terms, the situation was even harsher. Grosses for the week were down $2.6 million from a year earlier, when the industry pulled in just over $14 million that week. Attendance during Christmas week this year was off by nearly 50,000. The holidays are usually one of Broadway's happiest times as entertainment-starved tourists and family-weary locals seek out even the weakest shows. Last year every show on Broadway saw a bump in business during New Year's week, even such soon-to-die spectacles as "On the Town" and "Parade."
The sluggish sales were especially hard on smaller shows, which need big holiday sales. "This is always, far and away, one of the strongest weeks of the year," said David Richenthal, producer of "The Price." "This year, it's a near-disaster."
Theater executives said there were three culprits: the calendar, the countdown and the cut-rate shopper. First, there was the timing of Christmas and New Year's: both holidays fell on Saturday and their eves on Friday. Weekend nights, of course, are usually big moneymakers for Broadway, but this year most shows canceled on Christmas Eve.
Tonight all of Broadway is dark, except for the home of "Marie Christine," the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, which is at West 66th Street and thus will be spared the crush of revelers in Times Square. (It will be the first time since the assassination of President John F. Kennedy that the industry has so dimmed its bulbs.) Most of performances canceled this month were rescheduled for Monday nights or weekday matinees, but matinees, falling during work hours, are less popular and harder to attend.
"It's the case of the vanishing holiday week," said Jed Bernstein, the president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, the Broadway trade group.
Mr. Bernstein said that Broadway was being affected by the same ambivalence or apprehension that has muted millennial sales in the entertainment and travel industries worldwide. "Whether it be Y2K or what have you, people are feeling they want to stay at home," he said. That means fewer tourists in seats.
Finally, producers say many ticket buyers are taking advantage of the peculiar schedules to pick up half-price tickets at the last minute. That assertion was borne out by figures from the Theater Development Fund TKTS Booth in Times Square, where ticket sales were up 27 percent from the same holiday period last year. On Wednesday afternoon, large crowds rerouted because of Times Square preparations spilled up and down Seventh Avenue and Broadway. There is hope, of course, that the numbers will be better when this week's sales are counted.
 
Open and Shut
All right, all right, a few milestones to note. The last show to open this century is "Much Ado About Everything!" by Jackie Mason, who opened last night and must love having the title. And the last closing will be "Epic Proportions," which folded on Dec. 19 and whose producers can't be happy about it.
And the hottest ticket, at least as the numbers go, is still "The Lion King," which enters its 26th month at the top of the box office heap. When nearly everything else was down last week, it grossed over $1 million.
 
A Chariot Awaited
The last time Broadway watched a century pass, electric light was all the rage, copyrights for playwrights were a new concept and the hottest show in town featured eight live horses in a live chariot race. The play? You guessed it: "Ben-Hur."
The production, a six-act extravaganza, opened on Nov. 29, 1899, at the Broadway Theater, the same place where that famous helicopter (in "Miss Saigon") would land nearly 92 years later.
Based on the novel by Lew Wallace, "Ben-Hur" was the brainchild of producers who evidently figured you couldn't miss with a show where the men and the women wore short skirts. Just to back up the bet, however, producers invested in 120,000 square feet of scenery, a live camel (and two fake ones) and what the writer William W. Ellsworth called "one of the greatest stage contrivances of our day": an eight-part treadmill complete with a rolling panorama of a Roman stadium to simulate Ben-Hur's staggering victory over the evil Messala.
It worked like this, according to Bernard Hewitt's "Theater U.S.A.: 1668 to 1957," a history of American theater. Behind a darkened scrim, each of the horses was led onto a separate treadmill activated by the animal's running. Equipped with whips and racing skirts, the actors playing Ben-Hur and Messala climbed into actual chariots and started, well, whipping the horses to run. And run they did.
When the sound built to a fever pitch, the scrim flew up, exposing a chariot race in full stride. As the panoramas rolled, Messala's treadmills were slowly shifted upstage so that the Ben-Hur chariot would appear to be gaining. In the finale, the wheels were pulled off Messala's chariot, the horses reared, and the lights fell.
Now, that's theater.
The illusion helped seal the show's popularity. "Panoramic, pictorial, musical, terpsichorean, religious," Edward A. Dithmar wrote in The New York Times.
"Ben-Hur" ran out the season at the Broadway and later became a favorite on the road. Then the motion pictures came along, of course, and made those elaborate treadmills extinct.

HEADLINE: Labor Market Even Tighter As Jobless Claims Decline

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30

 BODY:
Fewer workers are seeking jobless benefits than at any time in more than a quarter-century, government figures showed today.
The number of new claims fell by 9,000, to 274,000, in the week that ended on Dec. 25, the Labor Department said. That brought the four-week average, a less volatile gauge, down to 279,750 last week, the lowest since Dec. 15, 1973. The average for the entire year is also likely to be the lowest in 26 years. 
 "There are no signs of an unraveling of this tight labor market," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. "This is good for the consumer, and this is good for the economy."
The weekly figures reinforce analysts' projections that the nation's unemployment rate in December will remain at its lowest in almost 30 years at 4.1 percent for the third consecutive month.
A separate report today by purchasing executives showed that manufacturing in the Midwest expanded in December, while fewer companies reported being charged higher prices.
The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said its monthly index fell to 54.6 this month from 56.8 in November. Readings above 50 mean that factories are reporting increased business. The index of prices paid for raw materials fell to 65.5 from 70.9.
Central bankers have expressed concern about the diminishing supply of workers, reflected in monthly figures showing that job growth has slowed even as the unemployment rate has declined. Almost 2.7 million jobs have been added so far this year, compared with 2.9 million for all of last year. Increased labor demand can drive up costs, leaving companies to decide whether they can pass the added expense to customers.
Jobs are being created on all fronts: manufacturing, computers and food service. General Motors, the world's largest automaker, said earlier this month that it would create 1,000 jobs in North Carolina by the end of next year with a new call center for its OnStar in-vehicle information service.
The Unisys Corporation, the computer services company, plans to expand its work force by 11 percent next year, to better challenge I.B.M. in installing and maintaining computer networks.
Unisys plans to hire 7,000 people; accounting for normal attrition, that will add about 4,000 employees to its force. About 85 percent of the new employees will work for the company's services business, Larry Weinbach, the chief executive at Unisys, said in an interview. The rest will work in computer manufacturing.
The new jobs come on top of 7,000 people that Unisys hired this year, bringing its global work force to 35,000. Many of the new employees will be technicians who install computers and work with customers.

HEADLINE: Remembering Wealth: Life in Post-Crash Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
My New Year's resolution is to file my columns early. This one was written 10 years before deadline. SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 30, 2009
ONLY a decade ago, the Silicon Valley of California was viewed as technology's promised land, a place where bungalows cost $1 million and even the youngest computer programmer had stock options that seemed likely to be worth millions soon. 
 But now, years after the Internet crash of 2003, it has become a region of jealousies and recriminations. Working relationships were poisoned when employees learned that top executives secretly hedged their positions, and thus did not suffer. Banks sued formerly wealthy entrepreneurs, saying they hid assets to avoid paying their debts.
All that has happened even though many of the Valley's technology companies remain very successful, and the Internet-based economy continues to gain at the expense of the older bricks-and-mortar economy. But few of the companies have lived up to the high expectations that were factored into stock prices before they fell. Many of the highest fliers have vanished from the landscape, either going out of business or being acquired by competitors for a fraction of the prices their shares once fetched.
Among the survivors, employees scarred by the collapsing value of their stock options now prefer the certainty of higher salaries.
It is the fate of the once-bountiful stock options that has most determined the current pecking order in Silicon Valley. At the top are those who cashed in their options before the fall. Next come those who worked for companies that prospered. Their salaries have helped to offset the paper losses, and many companies repriced their options after prices fell, thus saving some value for the employees, before angry shareholders forced a halt to that practice.
At the bottom, and perhaps the largest group, are those who did not cash out and whose companies were not among the winners. While many of them landed jobs at other companies, their wealth has vanished and some have lost their homes. Housing prices fell sharply after the options lost value, and have only recently begun to recover. Some financial institutions were severely damaged when loans secured by stock options became uncollectible.
The inevitable jealousies reflect the seeming randomness of success and failure. There are tales of employees who did poor jobs but ended up rich, while their more competent and creative neighbors went bankrupt. Younger engineers are angry that they have no chance for the quick wealth their elders gained, and scornful of those who lost it.
Nationally, the effect on the economy has not been as great as was feared. While some other regions with big stakes in the Internet economy were hurt, most notably Seattle and New York City, the effect on most of the country was limited. Consumers cut back, but not by as much as was expected considering the declining value of investment portfolios. Growth since 2003 has been far higher than it was in Japan in the years after that country's bubble burst in 1990. In part, that was because American nontechnology stocks were not nearly as overvalued.
Investors have grown much more cautious. That is reflected in the diminished amount of capital available for start-ups, and in other ways as well. Even Microsoft, which became the world's most valuable company long before it paid its first dividend in 2004, now finds that it must raise its payout every year to attract investors.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Extra Cash Awaits a Rush That Has Not Materialized
For months, American banks and regulators have been bracing themselves for a year-end rush of withdrawals by depositors fearful that Year 2000 computer problems might cause automated teller machines to fail or credit card transactions to be rejected.
In the last several months, extra money has been printed and sent to banks in the United States and abroad. Normally, about $150 billion in cash sits in the Federal Reserve and United States bank vaults worldwide. But an extra $70 billion has been printed and stored in vaults this year, and there it sits. Several of the country's largest banks say they have not experienced unusual demand for cash at their branches or teller machines. Page A1. 
 
Stocks Pull Back From Records
Stocks drifted lower, with most market gauges slipping back from the records set on Wednesday. Early gains evaporated as demand waned in the last full session of 1999. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.80 points, to 11,452.86. Broader stock indicators were mixed. The Nasdaq composite index finished with a modest loss of 4.59 points but remained above the 4,000 level at 4,036.87. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.01 points, to 1,464.47. In the bond market, the yield on the benchmark 30-year issue fell to 6.42 percent from 6.44 percent on Wednesday. C6.
 
Bird Dispute Worries Utilities
The criminal prosecution of Moon Lake Electric, a Utah utility company, for causing the deaths of birds has raised concerns among electric companies, particularly in the West. Utilities say they could face large expenses, possibly running into millions of dollars, if they are forced to prevent the electrocutions. C2.
 
Work Becomes Holiday Power Sign
During any other holiday season, power is measured by the number of party invitations received and the relative hipness of one's vacation plans. But in an odd twist in the corporate power equation, one that will be played out all over Manhattan tonight, the most important people in an organization are the ones who will be working. B1.
 
26-Year Low for New Jobless Claims
Fewer workers are seeking jobless benefits than at any time in more than a quarter-century. The number of new claims fell by 9,000, to 274,000, in the week that ended on Dec. 25. That brought the four-week average down to 279,750 last week, the lowest since Dec. 15, 1973. A separate report by purchasing executives showed that manufacturing in the Midwest expanded in December, while fewer companies reported being charged higher prices. C8.
 
Singapore Air Capitalizes on Image
A deal by Singapore Airlines to acquire a 49 percent stake in Virgin Atlantic ends a long search to expand its route network. Analysts attribute the growth in part to a management that has never reported a loss and carries no debt. But equally important has been the airline's ability to parlay its image -- featuring the politically incorrect "Singapore Girl" flight attendants --into an award-winning global reputation for service and safety. C4.
 
Investors Clear Holzmann Bailout
Shareholders of Philipp Holzmann, the troubled German construction conglomerate, approved a $2.2 billion bailout plan, but not before some accused the chairman of the company's supervisory board, Carl von Boehm-Bezing, of being incompetent and self-serving. Mr. Boehm-Bezing, who is also a Deutsche Bank executive, attributed the problems almost entirely to the company's old management, which was dismissed two years ago during a previous bailout. C4.
 
Court Approves MetLife Settlement
A federal court in Pittsburgh has approved a $1.7 billion payment to policyholders of Metropolitan Life Insurance to settle allegations of deceptive sales practices. C6.
 
Financial Markets to Close Early
Markets in Canada and the United States will be open for a half day of trading today, closing at 1 p.m. Eastern time for the New Year's holiday. Many European and Asian markets will be closed today.

HEADLINE: Goldman Strategist Remains Bullish, Though Less So, for 2000

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Abby Joseph Cohen, one of Wall Street's most influential strategists, said yesterday that the stock market's stunning 1999 ascent had turned her into a regular bull.
"I used to be a superbull. Now I'm just a bull," the chief United States market strategist for Goldman Sachs said in an interview on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. 
 For 2000, Ms. Cohen is forecasting single-digit percentage gains for blue-chip stocks, in contrast to the double-digit percentile advances the Dow Jones industrial average registered in each of the last five years, including 1999.
Ms. Cohen spoke a day after the Nasdaq composite index closed at more than 4,000 points for the first time, up 84 percent for 1999.
"What we're telling our portfolio manager clients is that technology deserves to be a core holding. That said, 'we're not as super-enthusiastic because they're not as cheap,' " as at the start of 1999, she said, when they were undervalued.
In the past, she said, many investors treated technology as a cyclical industry when it deserved better. She noted that technology-related capital spending had quadrupled as a percentage of United States gross domestic product.
"In 1999, investors said 'Eureka.' It's a secular industry that's brought about an enormous structural change," she said. "This was an important year of inflection. Technology stocks finally got some respect."
She said that the sector was now fairly valued. "People should not have just one or two names, but a handful. And it should not be the driving force in a portfolio," she said.
Ms. Cohen has won open praise from floor traders and gained the esteem of Wall Street with the accuracy of her bullish forecasts and her down-to-earth style.
She was ranked the top portfolio strategist three years running in the Institutional Investor survey, and as the ninth-most powerful woman in the world by Fortune magazine, and yet she continues to take the bus to work from her home in Queens.
At the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Ms. Cohen was surrounded by her family as she formally closed the trading session. And her own exuberance was in evidence as the gavel she used to strike the end of trading smashed in half.
The stock market did not cooperate with the occasion, however. For the day, the Nasdaq and Dow closed with modest losses. The Dow, at 11,452.86, is now up nearly 25 percent for 1999.
But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the subject of intense research by Ms. Cohen, edged up to a record 1,464.47. It is now up more than 19 percent for the year.
For 2000, Ms. Cohen expects more moderate gains with the S.& P. 500 closing out 2000 at 1,525 points. Her Dow target is 12,300.
At this point, it looks like Ms. Cohen may get caught in the same situation as last year, when, she said, "I thought it would be a good year, but it turned out to be a great year."
When she made her 2000 forecasts in mid-December, her S.& P. target suggested an 8 percent gain for next year. Two weeks later, her forecast would represent just a 4 percent gain because the index has risen.
This year, Ms. Cohen ratcheted up her targets as the months progressed. In 1999, "everyone thought the economy was in trouble," she said. "We were seen as extremely aggressive. In 2000, I think the consensus is closer to being right.
"We have stated that if there is a risk to our forecasts, it's likely that they are too low, because the global economy get stronger," she said.

LENGTH: 1068 words

HEADLINE: Banks Stocked Up on Cash But Hoarders Stayed Away

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
For months, American banks and regulators have been bracing for a year-end rush of withdrawals by depositors fearful that Year 2000 computer problems might cause teller machines to fail or credit card transactions to be rejected.
Piles of extra money have been printed by the federal government and shipped to banks here and abroad. Normally, about $150 billion in cash sits in the Federal Reserve and American bank vaults worldwide. But this year an extra $70 billion -- or about $255 for each man, woman and child in the United States -- has been printed, dispatched by planes and armored cars and stored in vaults, awaiting the onslaught. 
 And there it sits.
Several of the country's largest banks say they have not experienced unusual demand for cash at their branches or automated teller machines. On some days recently, these banks said, cash demand has been lower than it was a year ago.
"Up to date, we have seen no increased demand for cash," said Thomas Sladowski, vice president in charge of Chase Manhattan's automated teller machine network. "We're all hoping this will be the biggest nonevent of the century."
And if all that cash ultimately is not needed, banks will return it to the government, to be recirculated some day or shredded and left in landfills.
The complacency about cash is just the latest sign that the public is taking the prospect of Year 2000 computer disruptions in stride. Of course, problems could yet occur, sending depositors flocking to their local branches. Bankers and regulators acknowledge this, noting that even in a world grown accustomed to the pleasures of plastic credit cards, there is nothing quite as reassuring as cold hard cash. "The biggest variable in the equation remains public perception," said Doug Tillett, a spokesman with the New York Federal Reserve. "We really don't know how people will react."
So far, there has been little to give consumers pause, although flare-ups have occurred. On Tuesday, about 20,000 credit card terminals in Britain began to stall because of computer glitches, holding up holiday shoppers. A spokeswoman for HSBC Holdings, the large British bank that operates most of the terminals, said the devices could not recognize the year 2000 but that the problem would be resolved by Jan. 1.
Nonetheless, at least in the United States, bankers feel prepared for Year 2000 headaches and are satisfied that they have plenty of cash to dole out should people want it.
Simply getting all that cash into the system has been a challenge. Earlier this year, the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department directed the Bureau of Engraving and Printing to begin printing the extra billions. And banks were directed by regulators to order more cash for their vaults.
Most of the $220 billion in reserve cash is held in Federal Reserve coffers around the country, awaiting orders from banks should they need it. A smaller portion, about $72 billion, is already in bank vaults, about $20 billion more than banks typically keep on hand this time of year.
So long as the reserves are not drawn down, the mere printing of extra cash has no inflationary effect. For banks, holding more of their assets in extra cash means that they can lend less and thus earn less money. So far analysts are not concerned that the impact on bank earnings or the economy itself will be substantial, as long as the need for extra wads of cash remains a short-term event.
If and when the all-clear is sounded, banks will quickly ship that pool of extra cash back to the Federal Reserve -- setting the vast conga line of planes and armored cars back in motion.
For its part, Chase has set up 27 special command centers to monitor its banking network 24 hours a day between Dec. 31 and Jan. 11. The bank even increased its paper supply in the event that a flurry of receipts or bank statements needed to be printed, and it has been funneling extra cash into its branches since October.
Chase, which is based in New York, said it planned for increased cash demand of 30 percent in October and November and an increase of 200 percent in December, but that none of that demand had materialized. Still, extra cash is in the branches, and that presents security concerns for Chase, other banks and the armored car companies that serve them.
Banks and armored car companies say they have bolstered security to protect this momentary cash hoard. "The holiday season is always tough, but with additional money out there we're putting more security on the street and around our cars," said Kevin Dunbar, chief operating officer of Dunbar Armored, an armored car company that operates from 80 locations around the country.
Banks also have been simulating crises to prepare themselves for a range of computer-related disasters, not just a run on cash. Wells Fargo, the large San Francisco bank, has completed three practice runs in which its personnel had to negotiate 25 potential problems. The last one was completed a month ago and Wells said it had "developed a strong sense of confidence" about its ability to handle anything that arises as 2000 arrives.
Some banks already have had a taste of crisis management. In the fall, Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., had to rush cash to branches on the Atlantic coast so depositors could get their money before evacuating in advance of a hurricane. That event involved a rapid series of armored car trips to the coast and back -- excellent preparation, a spokeswoman said, for any Y2K hysteria that might emerge.
Oversight for Citigroup, one of the largest and most ubiquitous financial institutions in the world, is a tad more complex. The bank said it had seen no heightened cash withdrawals at its global branches -- but it has to monitor activity in 100 countries. To do that, Citigroup has set up a special central command center in an undisclosed location in the United States. Information about the bank's activities is fed to that center from 15 regional command centers in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Latin America.
Most banks in the United States, meanwhile, are just keeping their fingers crossed. And counting on consumers to keep their heads.
"We've tried to make it clear to people that the safest place for your money is in the bank," said Steve Dishart, a spokesman for Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh. "People seem to be taking that at face value."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Making Enough to Go Around"
Earlier this year, the government realized it might be facing a Year 2000 crisis that had nothing to do with computers: people might hoard cash as the turn of the century approached because they were afraid of a catastrophe. To prevent a disaster, the government decided to print and distribute $70 billion to add to the $150 billion already in reserves. Here is how it was done.
 
GETTING THE MONEY INTO CIRCULATION
 
1. An order was sent to the Treasury Department's Bureau of Engraving and Printing to print money -- 11 billion bills in all.
 
2. The bills were distributed to processing centers run by the Federal Reserve's 12 district banks.
 
3. Commercial banks, which were reminded to have enough cash on hand, ordered currency from the Federal Reserve.
 
4. The banks' accounts with the Federal Reserve were debited and the currency was shipped to each bank.
 
5. Customers who were worried could withdraw more money than usual.
 
TAKING THE MONEY OUT OF CIRCULATION
 
1. If customers find they do not need extra cash, they are likely to redeposit some of it.
 
2. Banks may end up with too much cash on hand and return some of it to the Federal Reserve.
 
3. Most of the bills that are returned will be stored in the Federal Reserve distribution centers.
 
4. Some bills that are no longer any good will be shredded. Most will go into landfills. (Illustrations by Mark Kseniak)(pg. C2)

HEADLINE: A Lavish Run Leaves Forbes Laboring for Nation's Notice

SERIES: STATE OF THE CAMPAIGN/Steve Forbes

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
On late-night television last week, David Letterman and Tom Brokaw were bantering about the presidential candidates. Mr. Letterman was repeatedly ridiculing George W. Bush and jokes were flying over the Al Gore-Bill Bradley debate over whether to debate every week. Even John McCain took some hits over his temper.
But nowhere in this exchange was any mention made of another presidential candidate, the Republican Steve Forbes, even if in jest. 
 Despite spending $16.3 million of his own money so far in this campaign, on top of the $37 million on his failed 1996 presidential effort, Mr. Forbes is in danger of becoming an inconsequential candidate, someone who cannot even be the butt of a joke on late-night TV.
Even as he doggedly crosses the primary states of New Hampshire, Iowa and South Carolina in his "New Birth of Freedom" bus cavalcade, Mr. Forbes has failed to generate strong poll numbers, grass-roots enthusiasm or a national identity -- anything to indicate he might have a chance of reaching his goal.
"Languishing is the best term for his campaign," said Larry J. Sabato, a political science professor at the University of Virginia. "The irony is that Forbes is a much better candidate than he was four years ago and he has finally broken into the inner circle of conservatives. And yet he has made very little progress in this election and is worse off today than he was at this point four years ago."
Four years ago, Mr. Forbes entered the Republican primaries late in the game and, and after gaining a reputation as a spoiler for his harsh attacks on Bob Dole and earning a small, but respectable showing, he calculated that the 2000 election might just be his moment.
He figured that, with unlimited money from his $440 million fortune, and a broadened conservative message that incorporated social issues as well as his signature call for an overhaul of the tax code, he could appeal to the right wing of the Republican Party and position himself an alternative to the front-runner, Governor Bush of Texas, carrying on in the Reagan tradition while Mr. Bush tried to steer the party to more centrist ground.
But it has not turned out that way.
"I think his message is a correct one," said Rich Galen, a former aide to Newt Gingrich and now a conservative columnist. "But it might be the wrong messenger. Or it is the right message but for a different time. And I don't see how Forbes's people can pull it out. He's got a lot of smart people on his campaign staff, and he is spending a ton of money. But he needs some kind of a remarkable breakthrough, and there's nothing to suggest that will happen."
Still, with his enormous resources, his willingness to do battle in every primary state and his record of harsh television advertisements against fellow Republicans, Mr. Forbes remains a force within his party, though frequently as a spoiler.
While he may not win, he is able to inflict damage on other candidates: He is forcing Mr. Bush to spend time and money in Iowa, a state Mr. Bush would sweep handily if not for Mr. Forbes, and Mr. Forbes has upped the ante on campaign costs for all Republicans with his lavish spending.
Moreover, Republicans remember Mr. Forbes's harsh attack advertisements against Bob Dole in Iowa four years ago that left Mr. Dole victorious but wounded, and are fearful that Mr. Forbes might do it again closer to the Jan. 24 Iowa caucus. So far, Mr. Forbes has restrained himself, but Mr. Galen said that if Mr. Forbes fell too far behind by mid-January, that might change.
"He might just turn his mother's picture to the wall and go for it," Mr. Galen said.
In New Hampshire, the latest polls show Mr. Forbes, a publishing executive from New Jersey, barely in double-digit territory, far behind Mr. Bush and Senator McCain of Arizona. In Iowa, where Mr. Forbes came in second in a highly promoted straw poll in August, with 20 percent of the vote, recent polls show him with about the same amount of support.
But in Iowa, polls are not always reliable, given that votes are taken in open public caucuses, and a candidate with a strong organization like Mr. Forbes's can come up with a surprise. That said, Mr. Bush is also well organized and, polls show, a lot more popular with Iowa voters.
In South Carolina, the race is between Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain, with Mr. Forbes not breaking into double digits, despite much campaigning there.
Still, the Forbes staff remains optimistic. William Dal Col, the Forbes campaign manager, predicts that if Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain start taking shots at each other in New Hampshire, then the large number of independent voters could become disgusted and switch to Mr. Forbes, who, Mr. Dal Col predicted, could take up to 30 percent of the New Hampshire vote.
In Iowa, Mr. Dal Col predicts that the strong Forbes organization will turn out enough voters on the caucus night to put Mr. Forbes "in a solid second place."
If all that does not happen? "We just keep running," Mr. Dal Col said. "We are prepared to go through with this. It's a marathon and we will continue to be in the race."
Mr. Forbes has also been hurt by the appearance on the primary scene of Mr. McCain, considered far too much of a maverick by conservative Republicans. As a result, many conservatives have flocked to Mr. Bush, whom they find acceptable on their scorecards and, more important, potentially electable. After having backed losing candidates like Patrick J. Buchanan and Pat Robertson, many Republican conservatives are now trading ideological purity for viability.
"Part of why Forbes is doing so poorly is the Bush juggernaut and the other part is the McCain phenomenon," Mr. Sabato of University of Virginia said. "He's neither, while the juggernaut and the phenomenon are filling the television screens. And social conservatives are badly divided this time. They need a winner this time because they are tired of losing. So they have signed onto Bush out of desperation."
In addition, Mr. Forbes's conservative economic message -- a call for a flat tax, less government and the ouster of the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan -- is proving to be a tough sell in one of the most robust economic cycles in this century. With the federal budget balanced, interest rates falling, the stock market hitting record highs and federal taxes having been lowered, it is hard for Mr. Forbes to make much headway with his call for drastic economic reform.
"We are in peace, prosperity and 4.2 percent unemployment," said Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist and chief executive of Policy Impact Communications, a Washington lobbying firm. "The worst harbinger for Forbes right now is not the polling data, but the strength of the retail sales figures this Christmas."
Then, there is Mr. Forbes himself, a man who has never held public office, who remains awkward in debates and whose campaigning skills, while much improved, are still stiff.
Despite this, Mr. Forbes is on the road, almost nonstop. Not only is he campaigning in New Hampshire and Iowa, but also in Alaska, Arizona, California, Delaware, Florida and South Carolina, almost any state with a primary. And his television advertisements and two-bus caravan of blaring music and campaign workers in Forbes uniforms have become fixtures in the early primary states.
In virtually all his presentations, Mr. Forbes remains wedded to his stump speech, rarely straying from his script, even down to the highly practiced laugh lines. He limits his contact with reporters to tightly controlled 15-minute sessions, and seems to hold his supporters at a distance.
In New Hampshire, for instance, while campaigning one chilly morning at the Belmont Restaurant in Manchester, a place where nearly every presidential candidate has gone to shake hands, Mr. Forbes awkwardly went around the room to introduce himself while diners munched on their toast and eggs.
And, when he was finished, rather than sit down at one of the large communal tables filled with diners and engage them in a discussion, something nearly every politician has done, he quietly sat down at a table to eat with his wife, Sabina, and two local supporters, seemingly oblivious to everyone else in the restaurant.
While Mr. McCain enjoys spending large amounts of time on the campaign trail talking to reporters or while Mr. Bush hardly passes supporters without touching them and giving them a squeeze, Mr. Forbes keeps himself closeted off on the campaign trail, riding on a separate bus from the press and his supporters, except for the occasional brief interview or formal news conference.
"Presidential politics is almost as much about personality as policy," said Mr. Gillespie, the Republican strategist. "I think it is difficult for voters to relate to Steve Forbes, partly because of his moneyed background and also because of his style. His style is not consistent with the American public's perception of the U.S. presidency."
Even in debates, Mr. Forbes, who was the first candidate to come out swinging against Mr. Bush, has since seen his role shrink as more air time is given to Mr. McCain and Mr. Bush -- so much so that the Forbes campaign has been complaining that moderators asked him fewer questions by half than these two candidates in the last debate, which was moderated by Mr. Brokaw in New Hampshire.
And, perhaps one of the cleverest, and biggest, laugh-getters of the current series of debates was a line about Mr. Forbes, not by him. In a Des Moines debate two weeks ago, Mr. Forbes said of Democratic proposals, "That usually means hold your wallet." A rival Republican candidate, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, turned to Mr. Forbes and interjected, "Steve, I couldn't even lift your wallet is all I can say."
 
State of the Campaign
This is the last in a series of status reports on the campaigns of the top contenders for the Democratic and Republican nominations as they enter the primary season.
 
AT A GLANCE/The Forbes Campaign
 
HEADQUARTERS -- Alexandria, Va.
 
STAFF SIZE -- 110
 
CASH ON HAND -- The campaign cash balance as of Sept. 30, 1999, was $1.8 million. But since Mr. Forbes, with a net worth of over $400 million, is financing his own campaign, his cash resources are pretty much what he wants them to be. Since 1996, he has spent more than $53 million running for president.
 
TOP CAMPAIGN STAFF -- The political director is James Tobin, the former Northeast political director for the Republican National Committee. The campaign manager is William DalCol, who ran the Forbes presidential campaign in 1996 and was chief of staff for Jack F. Kemp's vice-presidential bid that year. The deputy campaign manager is Ruth Kistler, former deputy executive director of the National Republican Congressional Committee. The senior communications director is Greg Mueller, communications director for Patrick J. Buchanan's presidential campaigns in 1992 and 1996.
 
PROMINENT ADVISERS -- Caspar W. Weinberger, secretary of defense for President Ronald Reagan, on foreign policy, and Paul M. Weyrich, head of the Free Congress Foundation, on social policy. His economic advisers include Alvin Rabushka, a flat-tax theoretician at the Hoover Institution at Stanford University; Gary and Aldonna Robbins, former economists in the Reagan Treasury Department; Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at CNBC.com; John Harrington, energy secretary in the Reagan administration, and Ken Blackwell, secretary of state in Ohio.
 
BIGGEST COUP -- Endorsement by The Manchester Union Leader, New Hampshire's largest newspaper, which calls him "God-fearing, respectful of innocent life, and determined to restore a sense of decency to the White House." At the same time, however, the editoral says Mr. Forbes "looks like a geek."
 
BIGGEST MISTAKE -- Still haunted by a 1996 decision to run scorched-earth television advertisements against Bob Dole, which hurt Mr. Dole among voters in general and tarred Mr. Forbes with the reputation as a spoiler in his own party.
 
CHALLENGE AHEAD -- Turning all that money into votes.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
What Women Wanted

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
The first female overachiever of this millennium would have been Freydis, the sister of Leif Ericson. Leif was quite the millennial man himself, having stumbled on North America around the year 1000. And when the first Norse settlement there was attacked, Freydis led the defense, despite her advanced pregnancy. "She took her breasts out and whetted the sword upon them. At that, the enemy became afraid and ran away," reported a Viking chronicler. Why, in the era of Xena and Buffy the Vampire Slayer, does this woman not have a TV series of her own?
I don't know if Freydis qualifies for one of the really great women of the last thousand years -- the thing with the sword was really her best moment. The inevitable nominees from the distant past would include Queen Elizabeth I, Joan of Arc and Shikibu Murasaki, whose "Tales of Genji" was the first realistic novel. My own favorite is Hildegard of Bingen, a 12th-century abbess, mystic and composer who went into a trance and levitated whenever a male authority figure tried to cross her. 
 What you notice about these women, and most of the other super-achieving females of the millennium, is how solitary they seem. The great things they did may have startled the world, or improved the lot of humanity, but they didn't open the way for other women to follow in their path. Wang Zhenui discovered the law of lunar eclipses in the 18th century, but that didn't create opportunities for future generations of Chinese women to become astronomers.
Closer to our own time, the great women no longer look quite so isolated. But many of them seem like disappointed figures, waiting for something that never arrived. Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton, the 19th-century suffragists, understood that they'd probably die before women in America got the right to vote. But they did believe that when the day came, it would change everything for their sex from that time on. It didn't. "She would have been astounded we had to go through another women's movement," said Lynn Sherr, the author of "Failure Is Impossible," an Anthony biography.
We don't know the name of the first woman who looked down at her sleeping daughter and imagined her having the same chances as any boy. But we do know that she didn't get her wish. Women who fought for social change often believed they were on the brink of an era when they could make an impact on society without being the most spectacular strivers of their era. It didn't happen. During the French Revolution, women petitioned the National Assembly to remember to "abolish also the privileges of the male sex." The Assembly forgot.
It took the post-industrial revolution to create an economy in which the sexes might be able to compete equally, and it took a biological revolution to give us control of our bodies. A millennium ago women had the will to practice birth control, but the means were more than a little shaky. In Eastern Europe, protected sex in A.D. 1000 involved drinking a potion made of ground wolf penis, spitting into the mouth of a frog or eating bees. In Muslim Spain, where things were more sophisticated, women who wanted to avoid pregnancy were advised to leap up and down after the sexual act, then jump backwards nine times.
But once birth control became relatively simple and physical strength dwindled as a requirement for the world of work, society shifted so quickly you'd have thought the pressure of all those generations of isolated eccentrics and disappointed strivers was propelling things forward. When I was in high school, teachers were still warning us that girls couldn't be scientists. Now 40 percent of all graduate degrees go to women. Progress seems slow when you happen to be living it, but put in a millennial context, the speed takes your breath away.
Those of us who are professional complainers can tell you all the areas where we're still falling short. We fret that what was won might be taken away, and feel guilty about the gulf between our lives and those of women in places like Afghanistan. But the peculiar celebration of the turn of the calendar we're having this New Year's Eve gives us a chance to think about the obvious but incredible fact of how far we've come, and what we've seen in our own lifetimes. The liberation that women throughout history have fought for, or sometimes been unable to even imagine, occurred in the last blink of the millennium, for us.

HEADLINE: Radical Islamic Network May Have Come to U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS and CRAIG PYES 

 BODY:
Nearly four years later, all that remains of the shootout in Roubaix, France, is a facade of burned-out row houses in dull red brick, charred roof beams with leafy seedlings etched against the sky, and screens of cinder blocks sealing every doorway. Passers-by hastening through the rain to Friday prayers at a nearby mosque pay little heed to 59 Rue Henri Carette.
The inferno that erupted amid gunfire before dawn on March 29, 1996, killed four young men of Algerian origin wanted by the French police after a series of armed holdups and the killing of a motorist who resisted an effort to hijack his car. In a three-month helter-skelter of attacks on supermarkets and other targets, the Roubaix gang, operating like common hoodlums, netted barely $10,000. 
 But French investigations revealed something more menacing: that the Roubaix victims were part of a radical Islamic underground linked to the Armed Islamic Group, a guerrilla organization fighting an Islamic holy war against the military-dominated government in Algeria. The G.I.A., as the group is known by its French initials, is considered brutal, and is thought to be responsible for many of the 100,000 people, mostly civilians, who have died in the Algerian conflict.
The G.I.A. network, law-enforcement sources in France and elsewhere say, has long tentacles. While deeply rooted in Western Europe, especially in Belgium, Britain, France and Italy, it also has connections in Afghanistan and Turkey and, perhaps most important, in Bosnia, where a lawless environment during and after the war in the first half of the 1990's provided Islamic radicals with secure hideouts and access to Bosnian passports and weapons.
Now, the authorities say, there are signs that the Algerian connection may have reached the United States.
For years, associates of the young men who died in Roubaix were known to have extended their activities to Quebec, where relaxed immigration rules and the Algerians' familiarity with French made Canada's French-speaking province an inviting haven. Canadian and French law-enforcement agencies say they were aware of the Quebec operations and kept them under at least sporadic surveillance.
The G.I.A. is not known to have directed any of its operations at the United States over the last several years. But two weeks ago, the arrest of Ahmed Ressam, a 32-year-old Algerian who had been living in Montreal, by United States customs officials seemed to indicate that the Algerian underground had widened its field of operations.
According to a federal indictment, Mr. Ressam arrived in Port Angeles, Wash., on Dec. 14 off a ferry from Victoria, British Columbia, with bomb-making equipment in the trunk of his car.
Yesterday, a 31-year-old Algerian man was arrested in Brooklyn and charged with being an accomplice of Mr. Ressam in what federal officials contend was an elaborate terrorist plot.
Also yesterday, federal prosecutors asserted that Lucia Garofalo, a 35-year-old Canadian woman who was arrested on Dec. 19 on the Vermont border, belonged to the same G.I.A. cell as Mr. Ressam. It remains unclear whether Mr. Ressam and Ms. Garofalo were collaborating when they were arrested; the prosecutors provided no specific information.
Mr. Ressam, the man arrested in Washington State, has pleaded not guilty to many federal charges, including making false statements to United States customs officials, using a Canadian passport with a false name, smuggling explosives and carrying unregistered firearms. United States officials say he has disclosed little, leaving them to puzzle out what his target might have been, whether it was linked to the millennium celebrations, and whether he had associates who may still be at large in the United States.
For the moment, American officials are trying to figure out why the G.I.A. would plan a strike in the United States when its units in Algeria are reeling from offensives by the Algerian military, which appears to have the upper hand in the conflict. One theory is that Mr. Ressam and his associates may be part of a loose group of free-floating mujahadeen, or holy warriors, some Algerian, some not, who share a hatred of the United States and bomb-making skills that they honed as volunteers in the fighting in Afghanistan, Bosnia or Algeria.
Much about Mr. Ressam remains murky, but officials in Europe say that they have known about him for several years and that he is part of an international network of Islamic militants willing to use terror to promote their vision of an Islamic world order. Interviews with officials in Europe and the United States, along with scholars who specialize in Islamic radicalism, have also offered a broader picture of the ideology, tactics and targets of the Algerian underground, and of the G.I.A. in particular.
From these sources, scattered pieces of the jigsaw puzzle of Mr. Ressam's life can be assembled. Canadian investigators, for example, say that in 1998 he shared an apartment in Ville Anjou, a Montreal suburb, with Fateh Kamel, a 39-year-old Algerian with G.I.A. links who was jailed in France this year on charges of terrorist conspiracy.
Law-enforcement agencies on both sides of the Atlantic are focusing on Mr. Kamel. A French official said his Montreal telephone number was found in the address book of Christophe Caze, a 28-year-old medical school dropout from Lille, an industrial city next to Roubaix. Mr. Caze converted to Islam, fought with an international brigade of Muslim fighters in Bosnia in the early 1990's and then became leader of the Roubaix gang. After the 1996 shootout, Mr. Caze, fleeing into Belgium, was shot dead at a police roadblock.
French prosecutors say that Mr. Kamel was active in the G.I.A. support networks, and that he had links to the militants in Roubaix, although what these were remains unclear. One French official described him as the group's "spiritual leader." Another French official said the truth about his ties died with Mr. Caze.
"We can't say exactly what the role of Fateh Kamel was because Christophe Caze is dead, and he's the only one who knew," the official said.
French investigators, especially, have been galvanized by a G.I.A.-led campaign of violence in France, which included a plane hijacking in Algiers in 1994 that envisaged crashing the Air France jet into the Eiffel Tower, a disaster averted when French commandos stormed the plane in a stopover in Marseilles. In addition, there was a bombing of the Paris subway in 1995 that caused eight deaths, part of a four-month terror campaign that included other bombings.
The most audacious of the Roubaix group's ventures, a car bomb that was to have exploded in front of the police commissariat in Lille on March 28, 1996, spread alarm that the Algerian militants' activities might have broader targets that Algeria and France.
The bomb was set to go off the day before leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations, including President Clinton and President Jacques Chirac of France, gathered for a meeting in Lille.
After the Peugeot car packed with explosives was disarmed, it was traced to the militants living in Roubaix, setting up the shootout in which the four Algerians died.
According to French antiterrorism experts, a major problem in penetrating the G.I.A. networks has been their diffuse nature. These officials say that, unlike some other terror groups, the G.I.A. is split into separate cells, each composed of shifting groups of people who use Islamic code names, has no central leadership, and has little coherent policy.
A French official cited the Roubaix group as an example.
While the French investigation had shown that the Islamic radicals in the Roubaix group had "close relations with the G.I.A.," he said, it was not clear that they were under G.I.A. control.
"The G.I.A. is not an organization like Action Directe or the Red Brigades," he said, referring to terrorist groups active in France and Germany in the 1980's. "It's not an organization that's very structured, it's a collection of disparate units that act relatively autonomously."
Despite this, law-enforcement agencies across Europe say that raids on G.I.A. cells revealed a common operational pattern that has echoes in the Ressam case. Among these is Mr. Ressam's suspected use of false documents. Canadian authorities say he used a false French passport to enter Canada in 1994, and American authorities say he used a false Canadian passport to enter the United States. Investigators believe he might have used other false documents to make trips among Canada, Europe and the Middle East while he was petitioning unsuccessfully for refugee status in Canada.
Investigators in France, Belgium and Italy say that G.I.A.-linked cells have drawn on a network of passport factories and dozens of clandestine couriers. According to French court documents, one characteristic of G.I.A. recruiting procedures in Europe has been to confiscate the passports of young militants and recycle them for use by others in the network. American prosecutors asserted in court today that one document forger the G.I.A. relied on was Said Atmani, an Algerian who, with Mr. Kamel, was Mr. Ressam's roommate in Montreal for several months before being deported to Bosnia in November 1998.
According to the French charges against Mr. Kamel, involvement in this passport-forging ring was a major part of his underground work. The French indictment, which was used to extradite Mr. Kamel from Jordan in the spring, accuses him of "trafficking in false administrative documents," meaning passports and other identity papers, including some from Australia, Belgium, Canada, Italy, Turkey and Britain, "to facilitate the movement of terrorists."
Another point European experts have noted in the Ressam case is the bomb-making equipment found in the car. In recent years, investigators in Belgium and Britain, in roundups of suspected G.I.A. terrorists, have seized do-it-yourself terrorist manuals that have included details on how to produce toxins, how to handle high-powered weapons -- and how to make bombs from nitoglycerin, the explosive RDX, the chemical fertilizer urea, and wristwatch timers, materials United States prosecutors say Mr. Ressam was transporting when he was arrested. RDX, one of the manuals notes, turns brown when properly mixed.
In an 8,000-page manual contained on a computer diskette that the Belgian police seized from a G.I.A. member in March 1995 there is a similarly detailed description of how to make explosives and how to blow up buildings, bridges and public monuments. The manual opens with a dedication to Osama bin Laden, the wealthy Saudi Arabian hiding in Afghanistan whom American officials consider the world's most dangerous terrorist leader and groups like the G.I.A. consider a charismatic figure.
According to European investigators, another aspect of the Ressam case -- the deportation to Bosnia in 1998 of Mr. Atmani, who is suspected of sharing the Montreal apartment with Mr. Ressam and Mr. Kamel -- highlights still another feature of the Algerian underground: its links to Bosnia.
During the war there, and after, the investigators say, Bosnia was a G.I.A. sanctuary and a source of local passports and weapons. In addition, for many young Algerians, it served the same radicalizing purpose as the war in Afghanistan had for a previous generation of young Muslims in the 1980's.
After Mr. Ressam's arrest, American antiterrorist experts suggested there might be links in the case to Mr. bin Laden, who has been out of view since the United States accused him of masterminding the bombings of the American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania that killed 220 people in August 1998, and posted a $5-million reward for his capture. American officials said they first became aware of Mr. Ressam when he was spotted meeting in Montreal with known associates of Mr. bin Laden, who issued a religious decree, or fatwa, in February 1998 calling on followers to attack Americans anywhere.
These links may yet prove significant. But the picture offered by law-enforcement officials investigating Mr. Ressam's connections in Canada, France and elsewhere suggests that the men to whom Mr. Ressam was closest in Montreal, men like Mr. Kamel, had their own geographical and political frame of reference that would have needed no prompting from Mr. bin Laden to mount attacks against Western targets.
Islamic militants have had little problem recruiting in cities like Roubaix, where many of France's four million Muslims have faced racial discrimination, high unemployment, and the powerful influence of some local mosques, which have served as indoctrination schools for radical forms of Islamic belief.
As visitors to the Sunna mosque around the corner from the scene of the Roubaix shootout soon discover, the influence of Islamic radicals is strong enough to discourage open conversation on the subject.
"If you talk about those things, death will find you," said a 17-year-old self-professed drug dealer who gave only his street name, Rabbit.
Events in Algeria, too, have had a radicalizing effect. In 1992, after the military-led government canceled parliamentary elections, which a radical Islamic party was on the verge of winning, civil war erupted.
Initially, the guerrilla struggle was led by the armed wing of the Islamic Salvation Front, the group denied victory in the election. But by the mid-1990's the insurgents had split, with the G.I.A. emerging at the cutting edge of the violence. From the outset, the G.I.A. turned to Algerians in France as one of its main sources of money and recruits.
Gilles Kepel, a French scholar specializing in radical Islam, said that 1989, the year the Berlin wall came down, was a watershed year for many young Muslims in the poorer districts of France, a moment when many chose Islam as the third way between American-style capitalism and socialism.
"These kids were drinking, taking drugs, dropping out," Mr. Kepel said in an interview. "They found Islam in the mosque, or in prison. Embracing Islam was an assertion of the self. It was the French version of the story of Malcolm X."

HEADLINE: The Journey to 2000

 BODY:
The concluding day of the 20th century and therefore of the second millennium -- that event so freighted with various meanings by historians, politicians, fictionists and doomsaying preachers -- is upon us. With allowances for the dateline, it will fall everywhere with equal finality, evoking all around the world the same feelings of solemnity for humanity's catalogue of travails and triumphs, and stirring in every corner of our common planet the desire to celebrate our hope for a peaceful and healing future. Those aspirations will stir with an equal inexorability in quiet villages on far continents and in the digital glitter of Times Square.
At this newspaper, we cannot ignore the fact that the world's most famous New Year's Eve party takes place on our doorstep. The history of that party spans almost the entire century and is intimately connected to that of The Times. The intersection was known as Long Acre Square until 1904, when The Times moved to the area. In 1907 Adolph Ochs, who had purchased the newspaper 11 years earlier, came up with the idea of lowering an illuminated globe down a flagpole to mark the New Year. Ever since, Times Square has been the center of New York's celebration, and with the coming of the age of television, the teeming crowd that gathers to watch the ball drop has become an international symbol of the passage from the old year into the new. 

As Millions Cheer
Tonight an expected two million people will jam themselves into Times Square. Over a billion television viewers will be watching them count down the last seconds of 1999. At the dawn of the millennium, Times Square will become, in effect, the virtual town square for a nation and indeed for a world reshaped by revolutions in communications, transportation, medicine, commerce and perhaps most forcefully by America's century-long act of self-invention. It is that chronicle of change that presses most insistently forward as 2000 comes into view.
Henry Luce of Time magazine put America at the center of the story with a memorable term: the American Century. Those three words convey unmistakable self-congratulation, but there should be no artificial modesty about an overarching fact of the era. This is a nation that within the memory of our oldest citizens used the blood of its soldiers and the power of its founding idea to guide the world away from totalitarian rule and economic ruin.
 
One Hundred Years Ago
To be sure, the America that awaited the dawn of 1900 was by no means ready for its eventual role as guardian of what we now call the free world. But the years around the turn from the 19th to the 20th century became the hinge of a new age. After the great labor of filling up the continent, an inward-looking United States expanded its vision and ambitions, grasping for leadership in a world it had once ignored. In 1901 the only American president born in New York City, Theodore Roosevelt, moved into the White House. By 1908 he would enshrine progress and economic justice as national ideals. By reclaiming powers Congress had been accreting since the Civil War, he also created the powerful modern presidency as an institution capable of shaping both this nation's goals and world events. In the same period the country began to move rapidly toward the urbanized, mass-consumer society as its dominant mode of living. Products, style and money swirled together in a hurricane of social exploration. In 1920, for the first time, a majority of Americans lived in cities.
But beneath these flurries of imperial ambition and middle-class materialism, more spiritual aspirations were quickening as well -- a yearning for a society that was as enlightened as it was productive. That definitively American desire was captured in a letter written in 1912 by one apostle of the machine age, Thomas Edison, to another, Henry Ford. After surveying other societies, Edison concluded that "in a lot of respects we Americans are the rawest and crudest of all. Our production, our factory laws, our charities, our relations between capital and labor, our distribution -- all wrong, out of gear. We've stumbled along for a while, trying to run a new civilization in old ways, but we've got to start to make this world over."
 
The Fight for Freedom
 The idealistic desire to make the world over is the deepest mystery of the American character and our signature national trait. It was also the guiding influence in the century's thematic political conflict -- the series of armed and unarmed struggles to thwart tyranny. American idealism is mysterious because it has always existed in a paradoxical linkage with greed, an alarming tolerance for social injustice, and the racial blindness that allowed the same mind that shaped the Declaration of Independence to condone slavery.
Despite these flaws, the American vision of remaking the world was built around a stainless philosophical core -- the twin ideals of democratic self-government and individual liberty. These values would prove decisive in World War I, then World War II and finally the 50-year contest to block the Soviet Union's military aspirations and its doctrine of monolithic state oppression. A hundred years before the start of the watershed conflict of World War II, Alexis de Tocqueville observed that citizens in a democracy would be slow to enter wars and dangerously ineffective in the early fighting. But, he predicted, they would "easily turn into good soldiers when once they have been torn from their business and their pleasures." And he sensed that once engaged, they would not quit.
Less easy to foresee was that America and the West would have the benefit in World War II of the century's most important leader, President Franklin D. Roosevelt. He rallied, in his words, "the American people, in their righteous might" and led the alliance that defeated Adolf Hitler. On the humanitarian level, Roosevelt and his planners failed greatly in ignoring the apex of Nazi evil, the extermination of six million Jews. Nothing can erase the primal nature of that lapse. But the victors' peace imposed by the next president, Harry S. Truman, did provide a contrasting pinnacle of wisdom unlike anything in the history of warfare. The Marshall Plan to lift a wrecked Continent from the rubble was both a monument to American idealism and a coup for strategic self-interest.
 
Struggle in the Nuclear Age
For with Hitler's death, another, better-organized threat to liberty arose in the Soviet Union. Unless America had revitalized Europe, the Russian Bear would have ambled hungrily toward the Atlantic. Instead it was blocked through containment, a new doctrine that would prevent another global war but burden humanity with a prolonged anxiety about nuclear annihilation.
The bomb, however, was not the weapon that produced the concluding triumph of a century of expanding freedom. It was the American economy and the worldwide influence of the popular culture made possible by that economy. Robber-baron abuses and the Great Depression had, through painful steps, produced a consensus on how to manage capitalism. By regulation and taxation the government would curb the cruelties of laissez-faire capitalism, but never so sternly as to destroy the freedom of markets and the zeal of mold-breaking entrepreneurs. Unlike Europeans and the Japanese, Americans were get-rich-quick romantics willing to tolerate the huge, enduring income gaps between the most affluent and the poorest that remain the chief defect of the social contract governing their market economy.
 
The Power of Prosperity
 The compensating factor was the creation of a huge middle class and the attendant expansion of workers' ability to enjoy products and pleasures once reserved for the elite. Through mass communications, the images of America's generalized prosperity had an impact that rattled totalitarian capitals. The Soviet Union disintegrated when its economy could not sustain a decent standard of living while also matching the United States in the renewed arms race announced by President Ronald Reagan in 1981. Americans are still arguing whether his declaration of economic war on the "Evil Empire" was the act of a simpleton or a visionary strategist. But the shining fact is that the interplay between Mr. Reagan and the Soviet reformer Mikhail Gorbachev sped the destruction of a Soviet empire dedicated to the denial of civil liberties and national self-determination. For America, the century ended with a triumphant maturing of the concepts of freedom that a restless and innovative people had carried from Europe and nursed into vibrancy in the rough cradle of a frontier continent.
 
A Toast of Farewell
The original American frontiers had to do with covering geographic distance -- from coast to coast, from farm to factory, from hamlet to city or suburb. But the nation finishes the century with many of its social frontiers uncrossed. Racial justice and decent medical care are not yet a guaranteed part of every citizen's birthright grant to "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness." Our people need arms controls that limit both nuclear weapons and the handguns on America's streets.
Indeed, on this New Year's Eve we still do not know if the invention of the silicon chip will surpass that of nuclear weapons as the signal technological event of the century. With visionary leadership, we may dare to hope that the ultimate engine of war will take second place in mankind's memory to a worldwide explosion of knowledge. Yet what can be known in these last hours of the year 1999 should be saluted by the glowing orb in Times Square and with toasts in living rooms across the land. It was a century in which freedom triumphed and generosity became a global ideal because of the most distinctive of all American inventions, a society based on the values of political freedom, economic opportunity, individual worth and equal justice. It is that invention that must be preserved and celebrated above all others, for it is our national treasure and the world's.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Meets Clergy to Explain Homeless Policy and Is Asked to Add Housing

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met at City Hall yesterday with 20 of the city's ranking clergymen for more than an hour to try to placate critics of his welfare and homeless policies, and said he had agreed to additional meetings with the group to discuss increasing the amount of city money for low-income housing.
At a news conference after the meeting, Mr. Giuliani said, "We agreed to work together to see if we could create more affordable housing." Mr. Giuliani said he had offered to arrange meetings between the ministers' group and some of his senior advisers for housing and economic development. 
 The mayor's meeting yesterday was with the Commission of Religious Leaders of New York City, a group formed earlier in the year that includes leaders of Catholic, Protestant, Jewish and Islamic congregations. Several of the city's most influential religious leaders, including Cardinal John O'Connor and the Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, are among its founding members.
Mr. Giuliani said the City Hall meeting had given him a "chance to dispel some of the false information about our programs regarding workfare, work and homelessness." He said he particularly focused on explaining the city's policy of arresting homeless people who refuse to go to shelters or hospitals and of separating children from their parents in cases of severe neglect. The mayor has also imposed a new policy, which is being challenged in court, that would place homeless children in foster care if their able-bodied parents did not find work.
In interviews yesterday, several of the clergymen who attended the meeting said they were encouraged by the mayor's interest in affordable housing. But some said they remained unconvinced about the merits of his current homeless policies.
"He laid out his reasons, but I still don't think we all agree with his sanctions," said Archdeacon Michael S. Kendall of the Episcopal Church's New York Diocese. "I certainly don't."
Whether the City Hall meeting had been sought by the mayor or the clergymen's group remained unclear yesterday. While Mr. Guiliani told reporters that "it was a meeting I organized," several members of the group said they had first proposed the idea of a meeting in a letter to the mayor in mid-December.
The clergymen said they ended the session convinced that the mayor would seriously consider their proposals for a greater commitment by the city to housing, which they said was a long-awaited benefit of a booming private sector and budget surpluses at City Hall.
"The critical thing is the need to follow up," said Msgr. Kevin Sullivan, chief operating officer of Catholic Charities of New York, who represented the Archdiocese of New York at the meeting. He said the mayor had suggested the group meet with two deputy mayors, Joseph Lhota and Rudy Washington, and with the commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Richard T. Roberts.
"People at the meeting were very pleased that he indicated a willingness to continue a dialogue," Monsignor Sullivan said of the mayor. "I think the robustness of the economy means that there should be a way to figure out how to find permanent housing, decent jobs to support families and supportive services."
Rabbi Robert Levine, chairman of the Interfaith Committee of New York Rabbis, said he had proposed that Mr. Giuliani use whatever savings the city has derived from the sharp decline in the number of its residents who are on welfare as a fresh financial injection in housing for the poor. "He seemed to find it a thoughtful suggestion," Mr. Levine said.
